Email_Body: NikeInc. yesterday named Georgetown University basketball coach John Thompson to its board of directors.Thompson, aNikespokesman since 1980, becomes the first minority-race board member atNike, which expects $ 3 billion sales in sports and fitness shoes, clothing and accessories for its fiscal year ending May 31. The naming of Thompson follows criticism last July by Operation PUSH and its leader, Jesse Jackson, thatNikewas exploiting blacks and had none in upper management. In August, Operation PUSH urged a boycott ofNikeproducts, andNikepublicly said it would name a black to its board within a year. The next month, Thompson arranged a meeting in his office between Operation PUSH andNikeofficials."I've had an opportunity to know [Nikechairman] Phil Knight," Thompson said on a tape provided by Georgetown. "I have a lot of interest and a lot of curiosity, particularly as it applies to the business world. And this will afford me an opportunity to expand my knowledge and at least give some more input of my feelings about the business world."Thompson will make $ 10,000 a year to sit on the board, plus $ 2,000 for each of six annual board meetings. His first board meeting is next month.
email_title: Thompson Put OnNike'sBoard

Email_Body: Nikehas an unusual rival in the Barcelona Olympics: Juan Amigo Freixas, a Spanish lawyer who says he owns theNiketrademark in Spain.In 1981, Freixas bought this 1932 trademark from a knitwear manufacturer: a photo negative of the headless Winged Victory of Samothrace, a statue in Paris' Louvre Museum that has ''Nike''on its pedestal. That, he says, gives him theNiketrademark for apparel in Spain.Nikeprotested, but a Spanish civil court ruled otherwise, enjoiningNikefrom selling apparel there.Nikehas lobbied various U.S. government agencies and trade groups in a two-year legal battle and has appealed to the Spanish Constitutional Court - which might rule soon.Until then,Nikehopes for a reversal, or at least a ruling that doesn't broaden Freixas' claim beyond apparel. And, saysNikecounsel Lindsay Stewart, the company has made contingency plans: ''The obvious gift of a T- shirt wouldn't be included in our giveaways.''
email_title: Nikebattles over trademark in Spain

Email_Body: NikeInc. filed a lawsuit today against L.A. Gear Inc., charging its rival with incorporating aNike-patented design in its new Catapult basketball shoe.The suit, filed in Federal District Court here, says some elements of L.A. Gear's Catapult cushioning system infringes twoNikepatents. The patents, covering whatNikecalls a "spring moderator device," are not now used in the company's shoes. Instead,Nikehas an air-cushioning system that uses pressurized gas. LikeNike'sspring moderator, L.A. Gear's Catapult shoe has a cushioning system designed to improve the jumping performance of wearers.WhileNike,based in Beaverton, Ore., does not use its system on any shoe, Lindsay Stewart,Nike'sgeneral counsel, said it was important for the company to protect its designs. "We spend a lot of money on research and development and we don't want to see it abused."An L.A. Gear spokesman did not immediately return a telephone call seeking comment.
email_title: L.A. Gear Shoe SpursNikeSuit

Email_Body: Next week, newspaper ads paid for by a Washington D.C.-area foundation will ask you to send your ''dirty, smelly, worn-out''Nikeshoes toNikechairman Philip Knight and to not buy a pair untilNikebuilds ''a manufacturing plant'' in the USA.ButNikespokesman Dusty Kidd says that might leave you barefoot: ''You can't make shoes profitably in this country. People wouldn't buy them. They'd be too expensive.''The ads will come from Made in the USA, a Chevy Chase, Md., foundation whose backers include labor unions and manufacturers. The group wants to call attention to its claim that 65,000 U.S. footwear jobs were lost in the 1980s. It plans to spend about $ 1 million on ads targetingNike,says chairman Joel Joseph.Nikeshoes are assembled in Asia. ButNike'sKidd says that shoe components are made in the USA, creating 1,162 full-time jobs inNike'sU.S. work force.Made in the USA saysNike'sAsian subcontractors pay Indonesian workers 14 cents an hour.Nike'scounter: That's four times the average local wage.
email_title: Group to nailNikefor loss of U.S. jobs

Email_Body: He's in the World Series, but you haven't seen Deion Sanders'sNikecommercials during CBS broadcasts of the games - and you probably won't.That doesn't meanNikeInc. is fed up with Mr. Sanders, as many fans were after the seventh game of the National League Championship Series celebration, when he poured buckets of water on CBS sportscaster Tim McCarver, apparently in retaliation for some on-the-air criticism. Nikestill stands behind Mr. Sanders, a Braves outfielder and a Falcons cornerback whomNikepays $ 1 million a year to endorse its cross- training sneakers. His commercial just ran out its two-month cycle,Nikesaid."He had a rough week," said company spokesman Dusty Kidd of the McCarver controversy and of some fans' criticism that Mr. Sanders is more concerned about hisNikedeal - which pays him an extra $ 900,000 a year to shuttle between the Braves and Falcons - than he is about the Braves winning the World Series."But he's still a .300 hitter, he still had the most triples in the [National] league, and he's still an All-Pro cornerback," said Mr. Kidd. "In some people's minds, maybe [the controversy] does tarnish him. But we stand behind him."GRAPHIC:Photo: Brave/Falcon Deion Sanders appears as himself - "out of control" - in aNikesneakers ad. /Nike
email_title: Ad over, butNikebacks Sanders

Email_Body: Despite stumbling in the fourth quarter,NikeInc. Wednesdayreported record earnings and revenue for its fiscal year ended May 31.The nation's largest maker of athletic shoes said annual revenue rose36% to $ 3 billion from $ 2.2 billion last year. Net income rose 18% to$ 287 million, or $ 3.77 a share, vs. $ 243 million, or $ 3.21 a share, in1990. Piper Jaffray repeated its strong buy recommendation afterNikespoke optimistically about the current quarter. InNike'sfourthquarter, net income fell 13% to $ 58.6 million, or 76 cents a share, vs.$ 67.2 million, or 89 cents a share, last year. Revenue rose 18% to$ 719 million, vs. $ 609 million.NikeChairman Philip Knight said half ofNike'sfiscal 1991 growthcame from abroad, where revenue jumped 80% to $ 862 million.Nikesharesrose 1 1/4 to $ 42 1/2.Other earnings Wednesday:2nd qtr. - Abbott Laboratories, net income of $ 268.3 million vs.$ 240.2 million (+12%), per share 63 cents vs. 55 cents (+15%); CBS,operating income of $ 50.7 million vs. $ 138 million (-63%), per share$ 3.31 vs. $ 5.36 (-38%); Federal National Mortgage Association, netincome of $ 331.5 million vs. $ 320 million (+4%), per share $ 1.21 vs.$ 1.10 (+10%); Motorola, net income of $ 119 million vs. $ 161 million(-26%), per share 90 cents vs. $ 1.22 (-26%); Student Loan MarketingAssociation, net income of $ 64.7 million vs. $ 74 million (-13%), pershare 87 cents vs. 72 cents (+21%); Vons, operating income of $ 15.8million vs. $ 10.4 million (+52%), per share 40 cents vs. 27 cents(+48%).3rd qtr. - King World Productions, net income of $ 16 million vs.$ 14.2 million (+13%), per share 40 cents vs. 36 cents (+11%).4th qtr. - ConAgra, net income of $ 99.4 million vs. $ 73.5 million(+35%), per share 65 cents vs. 59 cents (+10%).KNIGHT: Optimistic outlook.
email_title: Earnings reports:Nikeruns up a record year

Email_Body: Nikesays it can turn your worn-out sneakers into sleek new ones.Basically,Nike'sprocess grinds and pulverizes whole shoes to make material that can be used for the outer soles of new shoes. Nikesays it can completely recycle every shoe it makes except the ones with cleats. So far, it doesn't have machinery to separate metal from rubber and fiber.The firstNikesto contain recycled material will be in stores next spring. The shoe will be a version of one ofNike'sbest sellers: the Air Escape Low, a mid priced outdoor cross trainer.Nikesays a sole with up to 20% recycled material performed as well and sometimes better than regular soles in laboratory tests.Nikesays once it gets its patent, it will let other companies use its recycling method.''Maybe at some point - way in the future - we'll have a system where shoes can be 100% recycled, where you never throw a pair away. You always take them back like bottles or other common recyclables,'' saysNike'sDusty Kidd.CORRECTION:Nike'snew technology for recycling shoes into new athletic shoes is featured in Omni magazine's August issue, out today. Clarification ran 7/28/92.
email_title: Nikeset to recycle old shoes

Email_Body: NikeInc. of the U.S. expects to report relatively flat earnings in its second fiscal quarter ended Nov. 30, says chairman Philip H. Knight.A year earlier, the sports shoe and apparel maker earned US$58.1 million (C$66.4 million), or US77 cents a share. Knight indicated thatNike'sper-share earnings for the recently completed second quarter ranged from US75 cents to US80 cents.In recent years,Nikehas commonly reported big quarterly earnings jumps, but a flat second quarter would be something of a victory in these recessionary times.Knight declined to give specific estimates and didn't discuss revenues for the period. A year ago,Nikehad revenues of US$648.8 million. Knight's comments indicate thatNikewill earn roughly between US$57 million and US$61 million for the fiscal second quarter.In the fiscal first quarter,Nikeearned US$114.4 million (US$1.50 a share) on revenue of US$947.2 million. Fiscal first quarter earnings were 15% above profits in the year-earlier first quarter.
email_title: Nikesees flat earnings

Email_Body: NikeInc., which paid millions to put its name on the U.S. track and field team's uniforms at the Barcelona Olympics, is appealing a stunning high court decision that bars the advertising or sale ofNikeapparel in Spain, a company attorney said yesterday.Spain's Constitutional Court last week refused to lift a lower court order prohibiting the Beaverton, Ore. -based company from using theNikename on clothing because a Barcelona firm registered the trademark first in 1932. Nike, whose shoes are not affected by the ruling, planned to use the Olympics promotional campaign to launch a new line of sports clothes.If further legal actions fail - and if the courts rule the injunction bars U.S. athletes from wearingNikeuniforms - the firm stands to lose US$20 million in sales in Spain alone and many times that sum worldwide.''We do not believe we've lost the battle by any means, much less the war,'' said John Faylor,Nike'sEuropean lawyer.But the decision clearly leftNikeat a disadvantage in its long-running dispute with Juan Amigo Freixas, the Barcelona lawyer who bought theNikename from the original registrant, who briefly made socks during the 1930s.Amigo has reportedly askedNikefor US$30 million for rights to the brand, according to Faylor, who has called the Spaniard a ''pirate.'' Nike, however, claims the decision won't keep athletes from wearing its name when the Games open on July 25 because the International Olympic Committee does not consider the uniforms to be a form of advertising or promotion.
email_title: Nikefights Olympic court ban

Email_Body: NikeInc. has countersued Avia Group International Inc., contending that the shoemaker is making shoes that useNike'ssole-cushioning technology. Bill Dragon, Avia's president, denied the contentions, accusingNikeof "typical arrogance." Avia, based in Portland, had suedNikelast month for infringing patents for its Cantilever sole, a system in the concave sole that directs the shock of impact away from ankles and knees. Avia seeks to block sales ofNikeAir 180 running shoes, which it says copy the Cantilever technology. Avia is also asking for unspecified damages.In its counterclaim,Nike,No. 1 in the athletic footwear industry, contends that Avia abandoned its original Cantilever outsole, rendering the patent invalid. The company, based in Beaverton, outside Portland, further contends that Avia products infringe twoNikepatents. Avia is owned by Reebok International Ltd.
email_title: COMPANY NEWS;NikeCountersues Avia Over Patent

Email_Body: NikeInc expected summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, to be marketing bonanza for its athletic apparel; instead, they have led to angry charges byNikethat the company is being extorted by an alleged Spanish 'pirate';Nikesays it stands to lose as much as $20 million because of Spanish lawyer named Juan Amigo Freixas and his business partner,Nike'sformer distributor in Spain; Amigo owns right to useNikename in Spain (M)
email_title: NIKE'SOLYMPIC PLANS FACE HURDLE ERECTED BY SPANISH 'PIRATE'

Email_Body: Nike,which has paid millions to become an Olympic sponsor and to put its name on the uniforms of the United States track and field athletes at the Barcelona Games, is appealing a court decision that would bar the advertising or sale ofNikeclothing in Spain, a lawyer forNikesaid today.Spain's Constitutional Court refused last week to lift a lower court order prohibiting the sports apparel company, based in Beaverton, Ore., from using theNikename on clothing because a Barcelona firm, which manufactured socks, registered the trademark first in 1932.  Nike,whose shoes are not affected by the ruling, has planned to use the Olympics promotional campaign to launch a new line of sports clothes. If further legal actions fail, the firm stands to lose $20 million in sales in Spain alone and many times that sum worldwide, according to company documents.
email_title: Niketo Appeal Apparel Ban

Email_Body: A new book about the inner working of athletics shoe and apparel giantNikealleges steroid use byNike-sponsored athletes and widespread under-the-table payments to amateur competitors. "Swoosh, The Story ofNikeand the Men Who Played There" was written by sisters Julie Strasser and Laurie Becklund. Strasser wasNike'sfirst advertising director and her husband, Rob, was the marketing whiz during the company's meteoric rise to national prominence in the 1980s. Becklund is a reporter for the Los Angeles Times.Nikesays the authors took a slanted approach because Rob Strasser, who leftNikein 1988, now heads a consulting company whose clients include Adidas, one ofNike'smajor competitors. Julie Strasser says Adidas didn't hire her husband's company until after publishing rights to the book were sold.JUST A COINCIDENCE: Sophomore guard Bret Just of 12-0 Tulane is the son of Mark Just, the agent for pro basketball players named in the points-shaving scandal that rocked the New Orleans school in 1985 and led to the discontinuation of the program. WHATEVER HAPPEN TO: Former Georgia Tech and Tulane player Michael Christian? He's living with former Tech and now Detroit Pistons forward John Salley in Detroit and is managing a nightclub partially owned by Salley.PICTURE THIS: Tulane coach Perry Clark never saw his junior guard, G.J. Hunter, play high school ball in person, but was so impressed with the film of one of Hunter's games, he sent assistant Ron Everhart to Garland, Texas, to sign him. Not to imply that it was a mistake, for Hunter is a starter for the Green Wave but the film was not of one game, as Clark thought. It was a highlight film of an entire year's worth of games compiled by Hunter's father.WHERE'D THEY GO: Kansas City baseball reporters will hold their awards dinner Saturday. Harold Reynolds of the Seattle Mariners was to have been the only non-Royal player honored. Now? The Royals' player-of- the-year award will go to Danny Tartabull, recently signed by the New York Yankees as a free agent; the pitcher-of-the-year award will go to Bret Saberhagen, recently traded to the New York Mets, and the special achiever award will go to infielder Bill Pecota, also traded to the Mets.NAME THAT SPORT: They're moaning again about foreign-born athletes working harder and threatening to overtake their native competition. U.S. golf? Italian basketball? Nope. Japanese sumo wrestling, where Hawaii's Salevaa Atisanoe, better known as Konishiki, could become the first foreign "yokozuna" or grand champion, in the history of the sport.A GIANT THREAT: How concerned are folks in San Francisco about those reports of the Giants possibly moving to San Jose? "What is really important now is football," said San Francisco State University broadcast professor and sometime baseball fan Arthur Berger. "When the 49ers go, then you know it's the end of the world."CLASS ACT: Only a week ago, Detroit Lions Barry Sanders and Willie Green were playing in the NFC championship game. Now they're back in school, taking the college classes they missed while playing football and need to earn their degrees. Sanders left Oklahoma State University after his third year while Green left the University of Mississippi about a year away from his degree. Both say they'll earn their degrees from Oakland University in the Detroit suburb of Rochester, Mich.MIAMI-MANIA: Among the fans in attendance Tuesday night for the University of Miami's 45-42 basketball upset of 17th-ranked St.John's was UM wide receiver Lamar Thomas, the showboatingest of the showboating Hurricane football players. He says the basketball team, playing its first season in the Big East, could duplicate the turnaround the football team made form doormat to power after its 1983 national championship. "They're starting on the bottom like we did," Thomas said. "But if they win a couple of big games like we did, all of a sudden they can be on top."
email_title: NORMAN AREY'S SPORTSCENCENikeunder fire in new book

So far, it doesn't have machinery to separate metalfrom rubber and fiber.The firstNikesto contain recycled material will be in stores nextspring. The shoe will be a version of one ofNike'sbest sellers: theAir Escape Low, a mid priced outdoor cross trainer.Nikesays a sole with up to 20% recycled material performed as welland sometimes better than regular soles in laboratory tests.Nikesays once it gets its patent, it will let other companies useits recycling method."Maybe at some point - way in the future - we'll have a systemwhere shoes can be 100% recycled, where you never throw a pair away.You always take them back like bottles or other common recyclables,"saysNike'sDusty Kidd.

Email_Body: NikeInc. officials warned that second-quarter earnings may not match the record performance in the first quarter. Earlier yesterday, Oregon-basedNikereported first-quarter net income of US$114 million (C$130 million), or US$1.50 a share, on revenues of US$947 million, compared to 1990 first-quarter income of US$99.7 million, or US$2.62 a share, on revenues of US$833.6 million. Nikesaid first-quarter results benefited from a big increase in ''at-once'' sales. Those sales - not booked as future orders - rose 45% in the quarter ended Aug. 31. In a telephone conference call with analysts,Nikeofficials said it is unlikely ''at-once'' sales will reach that level in the second quarter.Nikesaid the first quarter's record revenues and earnings reflect growth in all its brand divisions and other brands. Domestic footwear revenues increased 5% to US$558.3 million, while domestic athletic apparel grew 24% to US$98.6 million over last year. International sales rose 37% to US$248.3 million over last year, while revenues from other brands, such as Cole Haan and Tetra Plastics, rose 8% to US$42 million.
email_title: Nike'srecord quarter

Email_Body: To the Editor:After reading the rhapsodic article about the newNikeTown building in Chicago (Styles of The Times, July 19), I believe it is time to disclose the secret ofNike'ssuccess. According to the August issue of Harper's magazine, the workers (mostly women, poor and malnourished) in theNikefactory in Indonesia are paid $1.03 a day, not enough for food and shelter. A pair of shoes that retails for $80 in the United States costs 12 cents to make.Nike'sprofits (the company had sales of $3 billion last year) are earned on the back of the third-world poor.Let no one justify this exploitation by arguing it provides work for people who would not otherwise be employed. This would be the equivalent of justifying slavery on the ground it gave work to idle black Africans.NikeTown in Chicago cost $34 million, according to your article. Banners hanging from the ceiling of this temple of high-tech read: "Performance, Technology, Innovation." How innovative is it to gain enormous wealth by exploiting the poor and the helpless? CATHERINE DE VINCKAllendale, N.J., Aug. 1, 1992
email_title: The Third World Secret ofNike'sSuccess

Email_Body: Being the world's leading sports gear marketer makesNikean obvious target for critics. The latest call for aNikeconsumer boycott - a U.S. manufacturing group - is running ads faultingNike'suse of labor in developing countries. Nikechairman and founder Phil Knight says the company has little choice about using such labor in order for compete with its rivals here and abroad.After losing $ 20 million on a factory in Saco, Maine, that closed in 1985, Knight concluded ''Americans don't want to make shoes'' - at least at going global rates. At aNikesubcontractor in Gwangzhou, China, workers make about $ 85 a month, nearly double the salary of professors at Beijing University.Then there's the idea, as Sports Illustrated put it, thatNikehas helped ''a fantasy-fueled market for luxury items ... (that) led to a frightening outbreak of crimes.''Knight doesn't seeNike'ssought-after sneakers as having a causal effect on crime: ''Nobody jumps on Toyota if its cars are used in drive-by shootings.''
email_title: Nikechairman answers critics

Email_Body: The latest sneaker attacks by Reebok, British Knights and L.A. Gear againstNikehave rankled executives at the top athletic shoe company, but don't expectNiketo kick back."We're not going into the mud-wrestling pit with them," says Andy Mooney,Nike'svice president of marketing, who called the attacks "par for the course when you're No. 1."Reebok and L.A. Gear launched their air assaults during the Super Bowl broadcast. Reebok's ads featured jock endorsers tellingNike endorsers to "Pump Up, and Air Out." In L.A. Gear's ads for its new catapult shoes, National Basketball Association star Karl Malone says: "Everything else is just hot air." Nikeexecutives were enraged, calling the Reebok ads a cheap shot. And CBS actually pulled the L.A. Gear ad, saying the depiction of the catapult device in ads was misleading.Now British Knights is set to step onNike'stoes with a $ 15 million campaign, breaking Thursday, that features rapper M.C. Hammer hammering home the themeline "Your mother wearsNikes!"Nikeis not amused."That statement couldn't be further from the truth," Mr. Mooney says. "But, to tell you the truth, we'd love it if everybody's mothers woreNikes."; Whims of warOn the marketing war front:Atlanta television station WSB has begun running twice-hourly local news inserts on Prime Cable broadcasts of CNN Headline News in the metro area. The local inserts, which a WSB spokeswoman said "add an element of localism" to Headline News's coverage, follow the boom in Cable News Network ratings since the war began.The National Guard this week is filming a commercial at Fort Benning, Ga., urging U.S. companies to back their employees who have been called up to fight."Without the men and women in the National Guard, 44 percent of our nation's defense just wouldn't be there," says the commercial, being filmed by Detroit advertising agency Ross Roy. "Be a hero. Give your employees the freedom to protect ours."Greeting card companies have begun selling cards with Persian Gulf war themes.Day Spring Greeting Cards, a Siloam Springs, Ark., manufacturer of religious greeting cards, is selling a line of "With Love From Home" cards at Christian bookstores and Wal-Mart.Hallmark is selling a line of "Just How I Feel" cards to send to soldiers, offering "missing you" and "thinking of you" sentiments.American Greetings is offering a "Greetings From The Gulf" line of 12 cards for soldiers to send home. The cards sport Desert Shield logos and pictures of camels and sand. They are sold in military stores overseas. Next week, the company will begin selling "America Misses You" cards.Normally methodical marketers continue to be perplexed by the double whammy of war and recession. General Motors Corp. and Chrysler Corp. have chopped $ 240 million from their ad budgets. Meantime, others - including Audi, Coors, Sony and Warner Brothers - have shifted their ads from the cheaper media of cable and spot television onto the networks. Network advertising sales are so soft these days, it's sometimes cheaper than spot and cable TV.; Quickly ...Now that the dust has settled from the C&S/Sovran Corp. merger, the banking company plans to choose a single advertising agency. Company officials said Monday they are holding a review for the $ 10 million to $ 20 million account. The incumbents - Ogilvy & Mather, Atlanta (C&S's agency for more than a decade) and Sovran's agency, Lawler Ballard of Norfolk, Va., have been invited to pitch, of course. . . . The Los Angeles office of Delta Air Lines' advertising agency, BBDO, followed through on a report that its Moscow office was pitching the KGB account. The agency's creative team came up with this tongue-in-cheek ad - "We Love to Spy, and It Shows." Others: "We're not your father's KGB"; and "Gee! No. KGB."Compiled from staff, wire and published reports.
email_title: BUSINESS REPORT: ON ADVERTISING; Shoemakers jump onNike

Email_Body: NikeInc., the nation's largest marketer of athletic shoes, reported today that its third-quarter earnings jumped 12 percent, but the performance disappointed Wall Street andNike'sstock price tumbled.The company earned $70.7 million, or 93 cents a share, in the quarter ended Feb. 28, up from $63.1 million, or 83 cents a share, a year earlier.Nikesaid revenues shot up nearly 39 percent in the third quarter to $802.2 million from $577.9 million a year earlier. On the New York Stock Exchange, the company's class B stock tumbled $2.50, to $47.50 a share.Nike'sshare earnings were at the low end of Wall Street forecasts, which ranged from 90 cents to $1.05 a share, according to analysts at Lynch, Jones & Ryan Inc.Nikesaid higher costs had cut revenues, reflecting advertising expense for the introduction of several new products.Nikesaid it planned to continue its heavy advertising.Selling and administrative costs as a proportion of sales rose to 22.7 percent, from 19.9 percent last year. Interest costs in the quarter jumped to $9.7 million, from $2.5 million, partly reflecting higher borrowings to accommodate a planned rise in inventories.
email_title: Nike'sNet Is Up by 12%

Email_Body: Madrid, Spain -NikeInc. is in the midst of an ugly legal battle with a Spanish attorney who owns theNikename in Spain - registered 60 years ago by a Barcelona sock maker. Pressure is building on both sides:Nike,a sports shoe and apparel company based in Beaverton, Ore., wants to clear the matter up before the July 25 opening ceremony, while Juan Amigo Freixas - who says the athletes can't use theNikename without his permission - knows his payoff will shrink after the Games fade into history. At stake are the profitsNikehoped to reap when it paid a handsome sum - the company won't say how much - to hitch its name to the U.S. athletes.Nikedocuments put potential sales losses at $ 20 million in Spain alone and many times that worldwide.The Associated Press contributed to this report.
email_title: LICENSINGNikein Spanish trademark dispute

Email_Body: Spain has been put on the U.S. government's "watch list" of nations thatdeny protection to U.S. trademarks afterNikeInc. was blocked fromselling its apparel in Spain.Spanish courts have sided withNike'sformer distributor in Spain,allowing Cidesport SA to continue selling knockoffs ofNikesports andfitness wear under aNiketrademark, aNikespokesman said.Niketerminated an eight-year relationship with Cidesport after a 1989audit. The Beaverton, Ore.-based company planned to market its ownproducts, but was prevented by a court injunction.
email_title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS   Spain on watch list

Email_Body: Responding to a lawsuit filed on Wednesday byNikeInc., L.A. Gear Inc. denied today that its new Catapult shoe infringed twoNikepatents.L.A. Gear said technology used in the Catapult did not infringe a cushioning system patent held byNike.The company said the United States Patent Office had previously not objected to L.A. Gear's use of technology that might appear similar toNike's. L.A. Gear also said its shoe's lacing system did not infringe another patent held byNike.The company said it would defend itself againstNike.L.A. Gear said separately that it had filed for a deadline extension to March 15 from March 1 on the recording of some financial information with the Securities and Exchange Commission.Because the company has posted losses, L.A. Gear said it was out of compliance with covenants on a $360 million bank line of credit and needed to evaluate the results of continuing negotiations. The company said it expected to conclude talks with lenders and might announce a new agreement by March 15.
email_title: L.A. Gear Responds to Suit

Email_Body: NIKEtoday reported record quarterly earnings and became the first company in the sports and fitness industry to generate more than $US1 billion ($A1.38 billion) in revenues during a single quarter. Nike'snet income for the three-month period, which ended August 31, 1992, was $US122,593,000, ($A168,651,190) or $US1.60 per share, an increase of 7 per cent from the $US114,437,000 ($A157,430,980) or $US1.50 per share earned during the same period last year. Consolidated revenues for the quarter increased to a record $US1,099,862,000 ($A1,513,080,153) up 16 per cent from $US947,161,000 ($A1,303,009,387) in the prior year with every division recording growth.In Europe,Nikebecame the first US-based company in the industry to record revenues in excess of $US1 billion in a 12-month period. European revenues for the 12-months ended August 31 totalled $US1.009 billion ($A1.39 billion). Nikehas been investing in European marketing and building an organisational infrastructure. NikeChairman Philip Knight said: "Nike'srecord first quarter and 27-per cent increase in future orders reflects the growing strength ofNikeas a global brand franchise."Our US business was robust during the critical back-to-school season just completed, and worldwide future orders for spring delivery are at record levels."PAEND OF STORYGRAPHIC:Nike. . . first past the billion-dollar post.
email_title: Nikesprints to $1.3bil record

Email_Body: NikeInc. today reported a 14.5 percent increase in earnings for its first fiscal quarter, driven by 14 percent revenue growth fueled by its expansion in Europe.Nikeearned a record $114 million, or $1.50 a share, in the three months ended Aug. 31, up from $99.6 million, or $1.31 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year ago. Revenue rose to a record $947.2 million, from $833.6 million a year earlier.Nikesaid it was the first time any company in its industry -- athletic shoes and apparel -- made more than $100 million in a quarter.
email_title: NikeProfits Rise 14.5%

Email_Body: On July 14, "Prime Time" will hit prime time whenNikeairs Deion Sanders's first national commercial during the All-Star Game.The 30-second spot, which will promote a new type of cross-training shoe, features Deion the football player, the baseball player, the dancer, the father, etc. The commercial is the first in what is expected to be a series of Deion/Cross Trainer ads forNike. Sanders signed a multiyear deal withNikein mid-May.Nikewill premier a new Bo Jackson commercial on the same night. Both ads are narrated by fast-talking MTV comic Denis Leary. Sanders has a three-word script; Jackson does not speak.In Sanders's spot, Leary talks about how "Deion is so busy he needs two nicknames, Prime Time and Neon Deion."Sanders is shown with the Falcons, with the Braves and in various off-field activities including walking his daughter Deiondra, washing his car and hanging with his "posse."But according to Sanders, the toughest part of the commercial was attempting to dance like rap star Hammer. In one part, Sanders is shown dancing to "2 Legit To Quit.""I've got a lot of respect for Hammer," Sanders said. "It's so tiring. I thought I could move, but dancing is something else."Jackson's commercial focuses on his rehabilitation from hip socket replacement."You think it's over," Leary says in the commercial. "It ain't over till the hip socket sings. OK?"GRAPHIC:color photo: Denis Leary color photo: Deion Sanders showing off his PRIME TIME clothes in his newNikecommercial color photo: Deion Sanders in a swimming pool in his newNikecommercial.
email_title: Deion high-stepping in ad's debut

Email_Body: Quit gasping about player contracts such as Bobby Bonilla's $ 29 million deal with the New York Mets. A new book, Swoosh: The Story ofNikeand the Men Who Played There, explains that sports business successes sometimes come with a lot more zeros on the bottom line. Nikefounder Philip Knight, a former University of Oregon runner who began with little more than an idea from one of his papers in business school, was instantly worth $ 178 million when the Beaverton, Ore., company went public in 1980.During Super Bowl XXVI,Nikesays it will debut a TV ad that pairs Michael Jordan with ''one of the most powerful icons of the 20th century.''But the company's less-cosmic early days, as shown by co-authors J.B. Strasser and her sister, Laurie Becklund, sound a lot more fun:- The company's name came to one of the founding workers in a dream. (Knight wanted ''Dimension Six.'')-Nikegot its air-cushioned shoes only because it listened to an unemployed aerospace researcher ignored by others.- An art student designed the Swoosh logo for $ 35.But in detailingNike'sups and downs, the authors are instructive. Women, not to mention minorities, were never in the management loop - even asNikewas dismissing the fledgling aerobics craze as ''fat ladies dancing to music.''AndNikeonly survived, arguably, because of early backing from a Japanese creditor - U.S. banks were too timid - and becauseNikeovercame regulatory interference from the U.S. government. Litigation becameNike'sstandard operating procedure.The authors conclude that ''the individualism that madeNikedifferent is gone, but so is the spirit that made employees care.'' Then again, today'sNikeworkers can't just do it - it already has been done.GRAPHIC:PHOTO; b/w CUTLINE: ON THE MONEY: Philip Knight has ledNikeInc. from no more than an idea in one of his business school papers to a multimillion-dollar athletic shoe enterprise.
email_title: New book followsNike'scorporate footsteps

Email_Body: NikeInc., which has been under fire from some blacks, named John Thompson, Georgetown University's head basketball coach, who is black, to its board of directors yesterday.Nikeis one of the world's largest sellers of athletic shoes. Among its most enthusiastic customers are urban teen-agers, many of whom are black. Last year, Operation PUSH, a civil rights group founded by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, charged thatNikedid not hire enough blacks. In August,Nikepledged to name a someone from a minority to its 11-member board within a year. Liz Dolan, aNikespokeswoman, said that adding a minority member had been planned for some time.OfNike's4,500 employees, about 8.5 percent are black, Ms. Dolan said.Nike,based in Beaverton, Ore., markets shoes that are manufactured by independent contractors elsewhere, typically in the Far East, and does not, therefore, have a large factory work force.Mr. Thompson's teams have been in every N.C.A.A. tournament since 1979 and the 1984 team won the N.C.A.A. national championship. He has been a consultant toNikesince 1980 and has spoken atNikesales meetings and coaches' clinics and made appearances to promoteNikeproducts in Europe and Asia, where they are less well known than in the United States.He was also head coach of the United States 1988 Olympic basketball team, and is the second Olympic coach to joinNike'sboard. The first was Bill Bowerman, co-founder ofNikeand an Olympic track and field coach in 1972.Mr. Thompson was not in his office at Georgetown yesterday; a spokesman for the university said he was traveling.Mr. Thompson, 49, is a member of no other corporate board. He will be paid the customary $10,000 annual director's fee and $2,000 for every bimonthly director's meeting he attends.While sales of many expensive athletic shoes have languished, those ofNikehave continued to thrive, although at a slower pace than in earlier years. In the year ended May 31, 1990,Nikeearned $243 million on annual revenue of $2.2 billion. Analysts said that in the year ending next week,Nike'srobust foreign sales would help lift revenue past $3 billion and earnings close to $300 million.GRAPHIC:Photo: John Thompson:NikeInc. (Associated Press)
email_title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Coach at Georgetown Will JoinNikeBoard

Email_Body: Despite stumbling in the fourth quarter,NikeInc. Wednesday reported record earnings and revenue for its fiscal year ended May 31. The nation's largest maker of athletic shoes said annual revenue rose $ 287 million, or $ 3.77 a share, vs. $ 243 million, or $ 3.21 a share, in 1990.Piper Jaffray repeated its strong buy recommendation afterNikespoke optimistically about the current quarter. InNike'sfourth quarter, net income fell 13% to $ 58.6 million, or 76 cents a share, vs.$ 719 million, vs. $ 609 million.NikeChairman Philip Knight said half ofNike'sfiscal 1991 growth came from abroad, where revenue jumped 80% to $ 862 million.Nikeshares rose 1 1/4 to $ 42 1/2.Other earnings Wednesday:2nd qtr. - Abbott Laboratories, net income of $ 268.3 million vs. $ 240.2 million (+12%), per share 63 cents vs. 55 cents (+15%); CBS, operating income of $ 50.7 million vs. $ 138 million (-63%), per share $ 3.31 vs. $ 5.36 (-38%); Federal National Mortgage Association, net income of $ 331.5 million vs. $ 320 million (+4%), per share $ 1.21 vs. $ 1.10 (+10%); Motorola, net income of $ 119 million vs. $ 161 million (-26%), per share 90 cents vs. $ 1.22 (-26%); Student Loan Marketing Association, net income of $ 64.7 million vs. $ 74 million (-13%), per share 87 cents vs. 72 cents (+21%); Vons, operating income of $ 15.8 million vs. $ 10.4 million (+52%), per share 40 cents vs. 27 cents (+48%).3rd qtr. - King World Productions, net income of $ 16 million vs. $ 14.2 million (+13%), per share 40 cents vs. 36 cents (+11%).4th qtr. - ConAgra, net income of $ 99.4 million vs. $ 73.5 million (+35%), per share 65 cents vs. 59 cents (+10%).KNIGHT: Optimistic outlook.
email_title: Earnings reports:Nikeruns up a record year

Email_Body: RUNNING 14.5km may seem a masochistic way of developing camaraderie in the workplace, but the staff at sports footwear companyNikeswear by it. Nikewill be one of many companies combining an office barbeque with the 14.5km Herald-Sun Bananarun from Williamstown to Gosch's paddock near Richmond station on April 12.  Nikepromotions manager and former AFL umpire George Lawler says as many 20Nikeemployees will run the 14.5km before relaxing with a 8earned barbie on the banks of the Yarra."The Herald-Sun Bananarun is a great way for us all to enjoy the benefits ofNikesportswear while we take on the challenge of running 14.5km," Lawlor said.Entry forms for the run are available from BP service stations and Foodplus stores.Competitors can park near the finish and catch a train from Richmond station to Newport station, just near the start at The Strand in Williamstown.END OF STORYGRAPHIC:Bananas . . .Niketeam members Bindi Klemke, Cartha McKerrow, FionaRogers and George Lawler.
email_title: Bananarun a real feet forNike

Email_Body: Another "revolutionary" shoe. Another John Lennon song.NikeInc.'s new Air Huarache ads strike a familiar chord with fans of sneaker ads and Mr. Lennon's music. The new TV ads feature the song "Instant Karma" from Mr. Lennon's days with the Plastic Ono Band, after he left the Beatles.In 1988, after a legal hassle,Nikeagreed to stop using an original recording of the Lennon-Paul McCartney song "Revolution" in its commercials.There is no legal dispute this time, according toNike. "Instant Karma" is licensed by Lenono Music and authorized by Yoko Ono,Nikespokesman Dusty Kidd said.Nikesaid the new campaign is a "celebration of some of the self- empowering tools of life: preparation, commitment, teamwork and fitness."
email_title: Nike's'Karma'

Email_Body: LOS ANGELESRivalsNikeInc. and L.A. Gear Inc. say they have settled their legalbattles over patents for their high-tech basketball shoes.The settlement, which came yesterday, provides no monetary compensationto either company. Other terms were not released.Nikeagreed to dismiss its claims that L.A. Gear's Catapult shoetechnology infringes onNike'spatent rights and to take no further legalaction.Beaverton, Ore.-basedNikeagreed to dismiss its counterclaims that sixmodels of L.A. Gear's basketball shoes infringed on patents ofNike'sAirJordan shoes and take no further legal action.
email_title: NEWS BULLETINS   Settlement reached

Email_Body: This city has two examples of the purest form of megastore - a store devoted to just one brand.NikeTown Chicago showcases the range ofNikeproducts, representing 20 sports. But where megastores end with vast size and selection, stores such asNikeTown add theatrics. Peter Alles of Columbia, Mo., was admiring goods in one of three basketball departments. ''This is different from a mall sports store, where they've already decided what to show you,'' he says. ''My son is downstairs, enthralled by the Aquasocks display.''The Aquasocks display includes a 22-foot tank of tropical fish. The floor is made of video screens running water images. It's called a video pond. Sean Alles, 11, was so impressed by the pond, he ignored full-sized athlete mannequins suspended from the three-story ceiling, a regulation-height basketball hoop with a massive photo backdrop of Michael Jordan, even a display of Batman's boot, designed byNike.NikeTown and many other one-brand stores charge full price to avoid angering their regular retailers. But few visitors leave without bags.NikeTown T-shirts are one of the top sellers. Two moreNikeTowns are planned this spring in Atlanta and Orange County, Calif.Next door is Sony Gallery of Consumer Electronics. The store displays Sony's full line and its newest technologies, such as an XBR(2) Trinitron TV. ''This is a showcase, for our customers, even for our retailers, to see Sony products at their best,'' says Sony's Rick Clancy. Other features: a home entertainment center, complete with wall-size movie screen; an auto-like room for sampling car stereo products; Walkman stereos set up with batteries and tapes fill half the second floor.Another designer store with big dreams is the Barbie Boutique in F.A.O. Schwarz 's flagship in New York. Like the others, Barbie Boutique is a chance to showcase the vast array of products. A 3-foot-tall My Size Barbie skates on tracks near the ceiling. Barbie clothes for doll and child and specialty dolls from Madis on Avenue Barbie to Empress Bride Barbie fill the store. -''We're looking to expand this idea; we think it will have great appeal in many sites,'' says Mattel's Donna Gibbs. ''It could be as popular as The Disney Store.''GRAPHIC:PHOTO, b/w CUTLINE:NIKETOWN: Provides theatrics as well as products.
email_title: DOWN THE AISLES OF A MEGASTORE // A showcase forNike,Sony

Email_Body: Bobby Cremins was paid more byNike($ 130,000) than he earned in salary as Georgia Tech's basketball coach ($ 105,000) in 1990.The greatest portion of Cremins's income - $ 162,878 - came from his television show.Cremins's agreement withNikeconsists of two parts - consulting and appearances on behalf of the shoe company. And because the Georgia Supreme Court ruled Cremins's personal appearances on behalf ofNikeare not subject to the Open Records Act, the $ 130,000 does not include any income he might receive for those appearances. Despite the ruling by Fulton County Superior Court Judge Frank Hull, which was upheld by the Georgia Supreme Court, Cremins maintained, "I consider this disclosure of documents pertaining to his athletically related outside income an invasion of my privacy."Cremins's income does not include the value of perquisites such as the use of a luxury automobile, membership in the Indian Hills Country Club and health/life insurance, all provided by the athletics association.Here are some stipulations in the five-yearNikecontract Cremins signed on June 16, 1987:- If Tech is put on probation by the NCAA which results in a prohibition of TV appearances,Nikecan reduce the $ 130,000 annual payment to $ 65,000 during the probation period.- Cremins receives up to $ 4,000 (wholesale value) inNike merchandise for use at his summer camps and clinics and up to $ 2,500 (retail value) ofNikemerchandise for his personal use, plus "such quantities ofNikebasketball shoes as he may reasonably request for his own personal use." Three assistants each get $ 500 in merchandise.- Tech receives 135 pairs of shoes for the men's basketball team and one set of practice apparel for each team member.- Cremins agrees to "makeNikeshoes available to members of the Georgia Tech men's basketball team, to be worn during practices, games, clinics and other occasions in which team members wear basketball shoes. . . . shall describe to members of the team the advantage ofNike basketball shoes and suggest they wearNikebasketball shoes."-Nikeagrees not to advertise the fact Tech's team endorsesNike products or "in any other way advertise or indicate thatNikeathletic shoes are the official shoe' " of the team.- Cremins agrees to advise Tech president Patrick Crecine and/or athletics director Homer Rice of the income he receives fromNike, and to secure the administration's approval of the stipulations and approval that permission for the team to wearNikeshoes.-Nikehas the right to terminate the contract if Cremins is convicted of a felony or "publicly admits the use of cocaine or other illegal hard drugs specifically excluding marijuana ," if Cremins ceases to be head coach at Tech or another "major" Division I team or if the program receives a "death penalty" sentence from the NCAA.Cremins's income does not include the value of perquisites such as the use of a luxury automobile, membership in the Indian Hills Country Club and health/life insurance, all provided by the athletics association.
email_title: BOBBY CREMINS'S INCOME;Nikeprovides $ 130,000 a year, other benefits

Email_Body: Avia Group International Inc., a sports apparel company, broadened its patent infringement suit againstNikeInc., saying the rival company used a basketball-shoe sole on which Avia holds a patent. Avia, based in Portland, filed the initial suit in Federal District Court here last year, contending thatNike'sAir 180 running shoes infringed three Avia patents. In the amended claim, Avia saidNikehad also infringed its patents with its Air 180 and Airforce 180 basketball models. The suit seeks unspecified damages and a permanent injunction.Nike,based in Beaverton, Ore., had no immediate comment.
email_title: COMPANY NEWS;Avia Widens Suit AgainstNike

Email_Body: American athletes expect to wear theirNikeapparel at the Olympics, even though a Spanish court rejectedNike'sfinal appeal in a multimillion-dollar trademark feud, the U.S. Olympic Committee said yesterday. ''We would hope this court would not attempt to dictate to any athlete from any nation what competitive gear they would wear in these Games,'' the USOC said. ''We would view that as extremely hostile and beyond their jurisdiction.''But a lawyer for the Spanish firm that owns theNiketrademark in Spain says the court decision definitively prohibits athletes from wearing theNikename.GRAPHIC:Photo: Barcelona apartment dwellers peer at a giantNikeposter of Ukrainian pole vaulter Sergei Bubka. Despite a court ruling rejecting the company's appeal,Nikeclothing will be worn at least by U.S. athletes.
email_title: Nikeloses battle, may win war

Email_Body: Sneaker fads may be fleeting, but athletic shoes may last for decades. That's whyNikeInc. is introducing sneakers made of recycled materials.Nike,the country's largest athletic shoe manufacturer, said that starting in the spring it would sell a new version of its Air Escape Low shoes with soles made of about 20 percent recycled materials. The shoes, to be priced at $75, will be sold in boxes made of recycled paper.  Nike,whose sales in the fiscal year 1992 totaled $3.41 billion, wants to prevent old sneakers from building up in landfills and other waste-disposal sites. Last year, 388 million pairs of athletic shoes were sold, according to an article in the current issue of Omni magazine.At first,Nikeplans to recycle its defective footwear, but it is applying for a patent for its technology to re-use old sneakers. The process involves a giant Cuisinart that grinds whole shoes into small bits that will later be used in material for new soles."Once our patent application is accepted, we'll make that technology available to any other shoe company in the world that wants it," aNikespokesman, Dusty Kidd, said.By the fall of 1993,Nikeintends the seven styles it makes for outdoor sports to have soles made of recycled material, a company spokeswoman said. The next step would be to use recycled materials in its basketball shoes, aerobic shoes and running shoes."Maybe at some point -- way in the future -- we'll have a system where shoes can be 100 percent recycled, where you never throw a pair away," Mr. Kidd said. "You'd always take them back like bottles or other common recyclables."
email_title: COMPANY NEWS: Saving Battered Soles;Sneakers Find an Afterlife AsNikeStarts Recycling

Email_Body: L.A. Gear Inc. filed a $3 billion lawsuit today againstNikeInc., chargingNikewith trying to monopolize the market for high-tech sneakers and drive L.A. Gear out of business. The countersuit was filed afterNikesued L.A. Gear last month for patent infringement. L.A. Gear, based in Los Angeles, accusesNikeof trying to monopolize the high-technology basketball shoe market. L.A. Gear denied that its new Catapult shoe technology infringed any patents.In its suit, filed in Federal court on Feb. 15,Nikecontended that six models of basketball shoes sold by L.A. Gear infringed patents forNike'sAir Jordan shoes, which are endorsed by the basketball star Michael Jordan. Officials fromNike,based in Beaverton, Ore., were not available for comment on L.A. Gear's suit.
email_title: COMPANY NEWS;L.A. Gear FilesNikeCountersuit

Email_Body: NikeInc., the U.S. sports shoe and fashion giant, is facing a painful Olympics in Barcelona later this month after a ruling by Spain's highest court that it cannot advertise its products in Spain and that its sponsored athletes at the Games may not wear its flashy logo.Choosing their moment with deadly precision, two Catalonians have gone to the courts claiming that they have had theNikename, and an emblem very similar to that of the U.S.Nikecompany, registered in Spain since 1932. The court bought their story. The two are said to be asking US$30 million for ''their'' trademark. Nikewas not available for comment late Friday, but its Spanish representatives have appealed against the June 30 ruling by the Constitutional Court (Barcelona branch). Their problem is that the wheels of Spanish justice grind slowly and the Games are just three weeks away.Expansion, the Spanish newspaper that unearthed the ruling, is quoting local representatives of the U.S.Nikecompany as saying the damage to the company would be ''irreversible and irreparable'' if its athletes are not able to sport the company logo during the games.While the ruling does not mean that Michael Jordan will have to compete without his shoes on, it could mean that TV closeups of their victorious heaving chests will be free of advertising. It also meansNikewould have to take down its hoardings in Barcelona and the rest of Spain. Nikewas planning to use the Games to help launch a multimillion-dollar new range of sports clothes in the autumn.It proved impossible Friday to locate the two legal owners of theNikemark in Spain, Juan Amigo Freixas and Flora Bertrand Mata.
email_title: Niketripped up as Olympics near

Email_Body: Sneaker makerNikeInc.'s revenue for fiscal 1991 exceeded US$3 billion (C$3.4 billion). Of the US$768 million in revenue growth during the year,Nikesaid nearly half was generated by international operations. Total international revenue was US$862 million, up 80% from last year's US$480 million. Nikealso said worldwide orders for athletic footwear and apparel scheduled for delivery between June and November of this year total US$1.4 billion, up 9% from the same period a year earlier.The Beaverton, Ore. company said its fourth-quarter results include a 6% decline in domestic footwear revenue.
email_title: Nike'srevenue jumps

Email_Body: NikeInc., the athletic shoe and apparel marketer, said today that its earnings rose 16.7 percent in its third quarter, helped by strong international sales.Nike'snet income for the three-month period that ended Feb. 29 was $82.5 million, or $1.08 a share, up from $70.7 million, or 93 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year. Sales increased 8 percent, to $867 million from $802.2 million.Earnings were helped, the company said, by strong overseas sales, which increased 27 percent, to $254 million. Sales were up 59 percent in Germany, 38 percent in Italy, 30 percent in France and 76 percent in Asia, the company said.Nikesaid its domestic footwear sales rose 2 percent, to $478 million, while sales of athletic apparel in the United States fell 3 percent, to $97.2 million."In the U.S., where we have maintained our 31 percent market share, future orders indicate renewed domestic growth will occur in our next quarter," Philip Knight,Nike'schairman, said.Nike'sshare price fell $3.625 today, to close at $70.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
email_title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;NikeProfit Rises 16.7%

Email_Body: NikeDoes It AgainWieden & Kennedy Inc., the Portland, Ore., agency that coined the anthemic phrase "just do it" forNikeInc., has taken its own advice. It has produced one of the year's most admired campaigns -- again. "Nikeis the high-water mark in American advertising," said Andy Berlin, a principal at Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein in San Francisco.Saluting theNikecampaign's "style and 'cool' factor," Nat Whitten, co-creative director of Weiss, Whitten, Carroll, Stagliano in New York, added that Wieden's advertising "isn't just to shock or get attention; it sells the product."Among this year's lauded ads forNike:a nostalgic, low-key television commercial shown during Super Bowl XXV; print ads that talked to, not at, women, in a sensitive, respectful manner, and a series of humorous "Bo Show" spots, which defied predictions that Bo Jackson's football injury would end his effectiveness as aNikeendorser. Pepsi Gets a Prize SloganDoes Diet Pepsi have the right one, baby? Indubitably. (You were expecting "Uh-huh"?)The slickly produced campaign for the Pepsi-Cola soft drink, by BBDO Worldwide in New York, has spawned an upbeat national catch phrase during a less-than-upbeat year. The campaign's slogan -- "You got the right one baby, uh-huh," half-sung, half-growled by Ray Charles -- has been added to the vernacular, and has been placed on Diet Pepsi containers. The advertising was "a step ahead," said James Patterson, chairman of J. Walter Thompson North America in New York.The campaign marked another victory in its psychological warfare with Coca-Cola. Coke outsells Pepsi. But Pepsi often out-advertises and out-markets Coke."For Coca-Cola, I haven't noticed any spots all year," said Nat Whitten, co-creative director of Weiss, Whitten, Carroll, Stagliano in New York. "Yet I've noticed all the Pepsi spots." Nuprin's Luck With EndorserFinding an outstanding campaign in the pill-and-pain category is like fishing a diamond ring out of a box of Cracker Jack. Yet J. Walter Thompson USA in New York managed that feat with advertising for Bristol-Myers Squibb's Nuprin brand of ibuprofen."Nupe it with Nuprin," the campaign urged, and consumers heeded that call to self-medicate, as sales of the brand, previously sluggish, began to rise.The campaign won praise for another rarity, signing a spokesman from the sports world who was actually well suited for the product. Of course, it was sweet serendipity that the endorser, the aging tennis star Jimmy Connors, unexpectedly stormed his way into the U.S. Open semifinals just as the campaign started.One complaint: the unfortunate play on words between "Nupe" and "Nuke." Some say the campaign works despite that; others say that is exactly what makes the ads work. Auto Themes: Safe and FrugalTwo unorthodox automotive campaigns drew raves, though the plaudits were far from unanimous.For Volvo Cars of North America, Messner Vetere Berger Carey Schmetterer in New York played single-mindedly on motorists' anxieties about safety, using the theme "Drive Safely." It is "the best tagline," said Jeff Atlas, chairman of Atlas Citron Haligman & Bedecarre in San Francisco. "Very simple and very appropriate."Some executives were put off by the suggestion that parents who love their children drive only Volvos. Some also saw the campaign's attack on mini-vans as an unfair swipe at Chrysler.The other campaign was for Subaru of America's 1992 models, by Wieden & Kennedy. A refreshing dose of reality infused the campaign, which debunked traditional auto-advertising obsessions with status, power and glamour. One spot, startling in its candor, depicted people who pay a lot for trophy cars as shallow, vain and deep in debt.But the campaign theme, "what to drive," came under fire. "It takes itself so seriously in trying to be different," said Marty Weiss, co-creative director of Weiss, Whitten, Carroll, Stagliano in New York. Challenge of the 90's: Credit CardsThe red-hot debate raging over the new American Express green card campaign has ad folks arguing until they are blue in the face. For now, color the prevailing judgments dark.Donny Deutsch, executive vice president and creative director of Deutsch Inc. in New York, belittled the advertising's "spend, spend, spend, isn't-life-fun, yuppie attitude." He and others cited ads by Chiat/Day/Mojo Inc. in New York that celebrate frivolities like flying the Concorde."The creative strikes me as sophomoric," said Jay Schulberg, executive vice president and executive creative head of Bozell Inc. in New York.Samuel J. Chisholm, president of the Mingo Group Inc. in New York, is "not sure this approach is direct enough -- and I carry two American Express cards."Others, less negative, argue that the campaign will evolve. They say it would do better to focus on a theme found in some of the ads, which present the card as a powerful financial tool with flexible spending limits and no revolving-interest charges. Not Much Memorable From DetroitThis was not a good year for Detroit. Nor was it a good year for Detroit's advertising."It's no wonder G.M. is closing 21 plants, with the kind of advertising they do," said Nat Whitten, co-creative director of Weiss, Whitten, Carroll, Stagliano in New York.Among the most castigated campaigns: the muddled, meaningless theme for Oldsmobile, "the power of intelligent engineering," by the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago, and the nearly invisible advertising for Chrysler's struggling Plymouth division, by Bozell Inc. in Birmingham, Mich.A notable exception was the advertising by Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco for General Motors' Saturn division, which was warmly applauded for its intelligent appeals to car buyers. 'News' Approach Raises QuestionsA series of television commercials by McCann-Erickson in New York for the Vaseline line of skin-care lotions was cited by some as a dubious achievement in deceit.The spots featured Joan Lunden, the co-host of ABC's "Good Morning America," in what seemed to be news reports on skin care. The spots used elements of news shows, like an anchor desk and on-screen logos, which cloaked their commercial nature."If you're trying to build credibility for a product, you don't do it by creating a fake news show," said Jeff Atlas, chairman of Atlas Citron Haligman & Bedecarre in San Francisco. "You're trying to trick me, and I don't like being tricked."The pitfalls of such spots were underscored on Dec. 19, when one turned up during ABC's news magazine "Prime Time Live." The network, which had barred the spots from running during news programs, apologized for the error. Testing the Limits on Bare FleshThe notorious, nude-filled advertising supplement for Calvin Klein jeans drew lots of gawkers. Most agreed that the emperor, too, wore no clothes.The supplement, created by Mr. Klein's in-house advertising department, was included in a plastic bag wrapped around selected copies of the October issue of Vanity Fair magazine -- a "polybagged outsert" in the industry's picturesque jargon. Inside, 116 pages of black-and-white photographs depicted pouty young men, pretending to be members of a rock band, preening in various states of undress.It symbolized advertising's never-ending efforts to test the limits in using sex, and skin, to sell products.  But people on both sides of that issue thought the campaign was artless."It stood for everything that missed the mark," said Donny Deutsch, creative director of Deutsch Inc. in New York. He decried the advertising's supplement's "decadent sexuality" as "so 80's."Nat Whitten, co-creative director of Weiss, Whitten, Carroll, Stagliano in New York, termed it "out of touch." His special peeve: "They didn't show the models how to hold the guitars right."
email_title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;In the Year of the Soft Sell: The Subtle and The Dubious

Email_Body: The Spanish government has vowed to helpNikeInc. in the trademark dispute threatening to make a shambles of the company's multi-million dollar Olympic ad campaign, officials said.In a letter sent this week to the European Commission, Spanish officials promised to ask a Barcelona judge to allowNiketo post bond in the case, an official at the Ministry of Industry, Commerce and Tourism said.That arrangement would allow the Beaverton, Ore., company to sell and advertise its sports apparel in Spain while awaiting a final court decision in the trademark conflict. The letter, however, warns that "the judiciary in Spain is independent of the executive and is not obliged to comply with the request," the official said.There was no immediate response from the courts.The Commission had asked the Spanish government to helpNikefight the Barcelona judge's standing order prohibiting it from selling clothing in Spain - an injunction that also might prevent the U.S. track and field team from wearingNikeuniforms at the Barcelona Games, which open July 25.Nikepaid a multi-million dollar figure to put its name on the U.S. and Algerian track teams at the Olympics.But just who owns that name is being fiercely disputed in Spain by lawyer Juan Amigo Freixas, who holds aNiketrademark registered in 1932 by a Barcelona sock maker, and Cidesport, a formerNikedistributor that has indirectly acquired marketing rights to Amigo's trademark.Two courts have upheld the Barcelona judge's injunction despite the factNikewas awarded its own trademark in Spain in July 1990.Nikehas estimated it stands to lose $ 20 million in sales in Spain alone - and many times that worldwide - if it cannot advertise its new line of clothing at the Games.OFFICIALS BANNEDAuthorities have banned Ivan Slavkov, head of Bulgaria's Olympic committee and son-in-law of former Communist strongman Todor Zhivkov, from travelling to the Barcelona Olympics.Yordanka Vandova, Slavkov's lawyer, said Wednesday the Sofia prosecutor had issued a letter saying Slavkov's passport was withdrawn July 8, and he could not fly to Barcelona as planned Wednesday.Slavkov, an International Olympic Committee member since 1987, was scheduled to attend an IOC finance meeting in Barcelona today before accompanying Bulgarian athletes at the games, Vandova said.Slavkov was charged with embezzling $ 304 from the Bulgarian Olympic Committee in January, 1990, shortly after his father-in-law was ousted by reform Communists.ATHLETE PUMPEDStella Umeh, the diminutive gymnast bound for Barcelona, looked out over a sea of young faces and let it be known how she felt about a sendoff for Olympic athletes Wednesday afternoon."This is cool, really cool."Umeh, all of five feet, 100 pounds, takes off for the Olympic Games today knowing she's no longer a stranger to a bunch of fans in the country's largest city."This should really be a confidence boost for us," she said of a barbecue, fashion-show pep rally put on by various Olympic sponsors outside a downtown shopping centre in Toronto. "It's nice to know this many people care about us."Umeh and her gymnastic teammates depart this morning for Spain. Other members of Canada's team are already in Europe, while others pass through Toronto in the next few days before travelling to Barcelona.
email_title: NikeInc. has a lot on line

Email_Body: NikeInc.'s second-quarter earnings were up 58% from the same period last year, chairman Philip Knight said.The strong earnings report comes despite a nationwide boycott ofNikeproducts called by Operation PUSH last August. Nike'snet income for the three months ended Nov. 30 was $ 58 million, or 77 cents a share.  During the same quarter last year, the company earned $ 37 million, or 49 cents per share.Revenues for the second quarter increased 46% to $ 649 million from $ 446 million in the previous year."I think our numbers speak for themselves," saidNikespokeswoman Liz Dolan.  Retailers were showing confidence inNikedespite the boycott and general fears of a recession, she said.Nikesaid minorities compose 16% of its work force, up from 11% in January 1989.  The company said it recruits at black colleges and has made many other efforts to help minorities.Nikeplans to add a minority member to its board by July.
email_title: Nike'squarterly earnings up 58%

Email_Body: There are famous new voices in the ongoing jibes between Reebok andNike.In a new $ 20 million ad campaign for its Pump sneakers, Reebok airs six TV spots using athletes as spokesmen.Both companies say it's the first time athlete endorsers have taken shots at the competition. It has also promptedNiketo consider legal action, saysNikead manager Scott Bedbury, because ''after a callous attack, you can't sit on the sidelines.'' The Reebok ads implicitly tweakNikeendorsers. Consumers are meant to think ofNike'sMichael Jordan when Reebok's Dominique Wilkins says, ''Michael, my man, if you want to fly first class,'' switch to Pumps. Reebok decathlete Dave Johnson says, ''I'm the man who knows cross-training,'' notNike'sBo Jackson. Reebok's Boomer Esiason is more direct: ''Boomer knows something that Bo don't know.''Nike'sBedbury says, ''It saddens us to see (endorsers) misused or abused. ... This doesn't bode well for the ad industry.''Reebok marketing vice president David Ropes says the ads just reflect reality. ''Athletes' egos are so huge they needle each other. This banter is their professional jargon.Nikeis just blowing smoke.''Where there's smoke, there's publicity - and that helps both companies. ''In the world of competitive noise, both of us benefit,'' says Reebok's Ropes. ''We're battling for a share of consumers' minds.'' PUNCH PITCH: The World Boxing Council is considering selling licensed merchandise and might even try to improve its image through a consumer ad campaign. The WBC, a leading boxing sanctioning group, has hired the New York ad agency Taylor-Gordon, Aarons & Co. to publicize its pension programs and support of medical research. ... Arnold Schwarzenegger appears in free-market economist Milton Friedman's five-part TV series Free to Choose, starting Sunday on CNBC. ''I came from a socialistic country, Austria, (where) you can hear 18-year-old kids already talking about their pension. But me, I wanted more.'' ... ... Junior college quarterback John Kaleo, who signed Wednesday with University of Maryland, shows how sponsors can leave an impression. ''The Weed Eater Bowl,'' Kaleo told The (Baltimore) Sun, ''solidified my decision.'' Maryland tied Louisiana Tech 34-34 in the Poulan/Weed Eater Independence Bowl last December.
email_title: SPORTS BUSINESS;Reebok ads haveNikeconsidering suit

Email_Body: NikeInc., which paid millions to put its name on the U.S. track and field team's uniforms at the Barcelona Olympics, is appealing a stunning high court decision that bars the advertising or sale ofNikeapparel in Spain, a company attorney said yesterday.Spain's Constitutional Court last week refused to lift a lower court order prohibiting the Beaverton, Oregon-based sports apparel company from using theNikename on clothing because a Barcelona firm registered the trademark first in 1932.NikeInc., whose shoes are not affected by the ruling, has planned to use the Olympics promotional campaign to launch a new line of sports clothes. If further legal actions fail -- and if the courts rule the injunction bars U.S. athletes from wearingNikeuniforms -- the firm stands to lose $20 million in sales in Spain alone and many times that sum worldwide, according to company documents."We do not believe we've lost the battle by any means, much less the war," said John Faylor,Nike'sEuropean lawyer.But the decision clearly leftNikeat a disadvantage in its long-running dispute with Juan Amigo Freixas, the Barcelona lawyer who bought theNikename from the original registrant, who briefly made socks during the 1930s.Amigo has reportedly askedNikefor $30 million for rights to the brand, according to Faylor, who has called the Spaniard a "pirate."Amigo refused to divulge his demands in a recent interview. He said the injunction would preventNikefrom carrying out its Olympics promotion.Nike, however, claims the decision won't keep athletes from wearing its name when the Games open July 25.The International Olympic Committee does not consider the uniforms to be a form of advertising or promotion, Faylor said in a telephone interview from Frankfurt.The arguments againstNikecould be strong, however.In documents filed with the Constitutional Court and the U.S. Trade Representative,Nikeitself raised the Olympics sponsorship issue to argue that retaining the injunction would cause irreparable damage to the company.And sinceNikepaid millions to The Athletics Congress -- the governing body of U.S. track -- for the right to dress the athletes inNikegear, the Spanish courts may not look kindly on the company's claim that its sponsorship was mere altruism."Nike'ssponsorship of the U.S. track and field team during the 1992 Olympic Games is a central component ofNike'slong-term international marketing strategy,"Nikeattorneys wrote the Washington-based U.S. Trade Representative in April.The prospect of missing out on the Games is particularly painful since Reebok, a fierce competitor in shoes and apparel, is providing the uniforms that all U.S. athletes -- includingNikespokesman Michael Jordan -- will wear on the awards podium if they win medals.In the meantime,Nikeis hoping the Constitutional Court reverses itself -- quickly, with the Olympics less than three weeks away.The Constitutional Court -- having spoken only onNike'smotion to lift the injunction -- has yet to rule on the validity of Amigo's 60-year-old trademark.
email_title: NikeInc. appeals court ruling

Email_Body: Legal rebuff toNike'sGames plans MadridNIKEIncorporated has suffered a major setback in its trademark battle with a Spanish lawyer who has vowed to prevent the US track and field team from wearingNike'sname at the Barcelona Games.With the Olympics set to open on Saturday andNikecounting on US athletes to show off its new clothing line, a Barcelona court refused to lift its order barringNikefrom selling or advertising its sports apparel in Spain.The decision left the US company with few short-term options in its court wrangle with a lawyer, Mr Juan Amigo, who bought theNiketrademark in 1981 from a Barcelona sock company that registered it as a trademark 60 years ago. Nikehas repeatedly insisted it would not negotiate with Amigo and his ally, the Barcelona clothing company Cidesport, which has asked around $US25 million ($A33.60 million) for rights to the trademark.But the two sides are scheduled to meet in Madrid, with the encouragement of American diplomats, according to a US embassy spokesman, Mr Paul Saxton.Nikepaid a multi-million dollar sum to put its name on the US and Algerian teams in Barcelona.Its case has been bolstered by the European Commission, which asked the Spanish government last month to convince the court to allowNiketo post a bond allowing the company to sell its apparel while awaiting a final decision.The United States has also weighed in onNike'sbehalf, placing Spain on a special trade "watch list" for what US officials consider slack trademark laws and enforcement.The negotiations may beNike'sonly chance of following through on its plan to put its name on the Olympic athletes.Company lawyers say the uniforms are not "advertising", and therefore do not fall under the court order.But Amigo and Cidesport insist the order bars the Olympic athletes from wearing the uniforms.The injunction was upheld earlier this month by the Constitutional Tribunal, Spain's highest appeals court.AP

Steroid use byNike-sponsored athletes and widespreadunder-the-table payments to amateur competitors are among the allegations in a new book about the athletic shoe and apparel giant. A statement fromNikeInc. corporate vice-president Liz Dolan admitted there was truth in some of the stories in the 660-page book - Swoosh, The Story ofNikeand the Men Who Played There by Julie Strasser and Laurie Becklund - but added it's all ''ancient history.''
email_title: Nikeathletes used steroids: book

Email_Body: NikeInc. and Phipps haven't yet signed a lease. But several Phipps tenants said they anticipate a deal soon and that theNikeTown store could open next year. Officials of Phipps andNike,the sporting goods giant based in Beaverton, Ore., declined comment Thursday.Tenants, some of whom have talked toNikeofficials, said the company likes Atlanta because it is a major sports center. The city is home of the Braves, Hawks and Falcons, and it will host the Super Bowl in 1994 and the Summer Olympics two years later.NabbingNikeTown would give bragging rights to Phipps over other Atlanta malls, including nearby rival Lenox Square. Phipps is in the midst of a $ 140 million renovation and expansion.Tom Ross, Tiffany's vice president, saidNikeTown would be a major draw and w ould boost traffic in Phipps, which has suffered poor traffic in recent years.
email_title: No lease yet
