Email_Body: NikeInc., which paid millions to put its name on the U.S. track and field team's uniforms at the Barcelona Olympics, is appealing a stunning high court decision that bars the advertising or sale ofNikeapparel in Spain, a company attorney said.Spain's Constitutional Court last week refused to lift a lower court order prohibiting the Beaverton, Ore. -based sports apparel company from using theNikename on clothing because a Barcelona firm registered the trademark first in 1932.If further legal actions fail -- and if the courts rule the injunction bars U.S. athletes from wearingNikeuniforms, the firm stands to lose $ 20 million in sales in Spain alone and many times that sum worldwide, according to company documents. ...Daley Thompson will make a final attempt to qualify for a fifth Olympic Games decathlon Thursday and Friday at an arranged meet in London.Thompson, the world record-holder and Olympic gold medalist in 1980 and 1988, must achieve the qualifying standard of 7,850 points at the Crystal Palace meet for a place on the British Olympic team.
email_title: OLYMPICS

Email_Body: NikeInc. said today that it would begin showing next week a television commercial to promote racial harmony that features Spike Lee, the film maker.Set in an outdoor basketball court called Spike's Urban Jungle Gym, the advertisement, directed by Mr. Lee, shows black and white basketball players giving reasons for not playing with one another. Mr. Lee steps in to say: "If we're going to live together, we've got to play together." The commercial, which also features Tim Hardaway, a Golden State Warriors player, was filmed at an outdoor basketball court in Los Angeles about two weeks before the riots that followed the verdict in the Rodney King case.The filming was done in an area that later saw some of the worst disturbances. Mr. Lee said the commercial is a reworking of a scene from his 1989 film "Do The Right Thing." Nikewas criticized last summer by a Chicago-based civil rights group founded by the Rev. Jesse Jackson. The group urged the sneaker maker to increase its hiring of blacks and called for a boycott by the black community.Nikesaid at the time that 8.5 percent of the 4,500 employees in its headquarters here were black.Eventually, however, the campaign petered out becauseNikesneakers had become a virtual uniform for inner-city youths.The company said in 1990 that 14 percent of its sales were to blacks. Nikesaid it plans to put on sale in August a line of sports apparel inspired by Mr. Lee's Urban Jungle Gym, including jackets, shirts and shorts with slogans like "The Mo' Colors, The Mo's Better" and "Live Together/Play Together."
email_title: COMPANY NEWS: Promoting Racial Harmony;NikePlans Commercial That Features Spike Lee

Email_Body: Spike Lee and Michael Jordan are back withNike.This time, the two are starring in the company's $5 million "Stay in School" campaign.One spot, which will begin nationally during the National Basketball Association's All-Star Game on Feb. 10, features Mr. Lee as his "Mars Blackmon" character, joking around with Mr. Jordan, the Chicago Bulls star. After a slightly intense discussion about the principles of gravity, they tell other kids in the classroom, "Don't be stupid; stay in school." "These spots are important to me because education is the key," Mr. Lee said in an interview. "Spike and Michael saying 'stay in school' is not the only answer, but it helps."Also, we tried to put humor in," the Brooklyn film maker said. "We're not trying to be too preachy."NikeInc. has been criticized in the past for using black athletes in its ads but having few of them in as corporate executives. Mr. Lee said some of the criticisms were valid.But he said: "We have tried to work some of these things out. I wish a lot of other companies were as open minded asNike.They want to do the right thing. No pun intended."Nike'sagency, Wieden & Kennedy, first matched Mr. Lee and Mr. Jordan in 1989.
email_title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Nike's2 Stars Appear In a New Campaign

Email_Body: Phipps Plaza has the high fashion of Saks Fifth Avenue and the glitter of Tiffany's. Now it's going for a slam dunk withNikeTown.The Buckhead mall is being eyed byNikeTown, one of America's funkiest retail concepts. It blends fantasy for wannabe jocks, high-tech glitz for the entertainment-minded and, yes, shoes and other merchandise.A newNikeTown store in Chicago has a maple basketball court, where people can test sneakers. The firstNikeTown opened in Portland, Ore., in 1990.
email_title: Phipps shooting forNikesport store

Email_Body: American manufacturers sold some 388 million pairs of athletic shoes last year. Retailers saw $ 12.1 billion in estimated sales. Environmentalists see 776 million shoes made largely of plastic and other synthetic material heading straight for landfills. NowNikeInc. of Beaverton, Ore., may forever change the footwear industry by being the first to offer, partially at least, recyclable and recycled neakers."Maybe at some point we'll have a system where shoes can be 100 percent recycled, where you never throw a pair away. You always take them back like bottles or other common recyclables," says Dusty Kidd ofNike.The key to turning today's shoes into tomorrow's lies in a newNiketechnology. The process grinds and pulverizes whole shoes into material for the outsoles of new shoes.Nike'sprocess can completely recycle every shoe the company makes except for cleated models. The machinery to draw metal out of rubber and fiber isn't here yet, but the technology is.The firstNikesto contain recycled material will arrive in stores next spring. The shoe will be a new version of one of the company's best sellers, the Air Escape Low, a mid-priced outdoor cross trainer for men and women.
email_title: NIKEOFF AND RUNNING WITH RECYCLABLE SHOES

Email_Body: NikeInc.'s earnings rose 6 percent in the second quarter of the fiscal year, setting record levels for profits and sales, the athletic shoe manufacturer said today.Earnings for the three months ended Nov. 30 totaled $61.5 million, or 80 cents a share. In the comparable period last year,Nikeearned $58 million, or 77 cents a share. Revenues increased 15 percent, to $743.4 million.European sales led the increase, with Germany up 73 percent, France up 63 percent, Italy up 138 percent and Spain up 83 percent.United States athletic footwear revenues declined 2 percent, but domestic athletic apparel revenues were up 2 percent. Revenues from other brands owned byNikerose 18 percent.Nikesaid the domestic athletic footwear revenues were lower because retailers had been cautious in placing orders six months ago.Although the increases were strong, they paled in comparison with those announced for the first quarter, when the Beaverton-based company reported earnings of $114 million.
email_title: NikeProfit Rises by 6%

Email_Body: Memo toNike:Potentially terrific - and cheap - new sneaker endorsers are just down the road from your Beaverton, Ore., headquarters.Thousands ofNikeshoes have begun washing up on Oregon beaches - the result of a May 1990 shipping accident that left 80,000 sneakers floating in the Pacific. Some beachcombers are stockpiling hundreds of shoes, claiming the shoes are fine - after clams and seaweed are removed. Swap meets let collectors find their sizes - and create matching pairs.''The advertising possibilities are obvious,'' says Shirley Tarnasky, owner of 50 seagoing sneakers. ''Shoes that can float in the ocean for a year and not come apart at the seams just have to be good.''So how about, say, a pickup basketball game between beachcombers to proveNikescan take a lickin' and keep on tickin'? LaughsNike'sLiz Dolan: ''It's an (ad) idea we haven't really considered.''ButNike'sTV ads for the NBA playoffs are old standbys: replays of six resurrected Michael Jordan-Spike Lee spots. A STEP UP: Walking passed swimming as the USA's No. 1 recreational sport in 1990, says a National Sporting Goods Association study. Total walkers: 71.4 million, up 72% since 1985. ... The World League of American Football's New York/New Jersey Knights average 15 kids a game at their free home-game child care. ... Inspired by Disney World, Sen. Malcolm Wallop, R-Wyo., urged a $ 300,000 federal study of using monorails to ease traffic congestion in national parks.
email_title: Even washed-upNikeshave plenty of value

Email_Body: Like other companies,NikeInc. has had some problems during the recession. But the nation's leading maker of athletic shoes appears to be landing on its feet.Nike,which makes Air Jordan and other high-priced sports shoes, is expected to report results today for its fiscal year ended May 31. Tuesday, the company said it was comfortable with Wall Street estimates of $ 3.65 to $ 3.85 a share, vs. $ 3.21 last year. The stock jumped 2 3/8 to $ 41 1/4. ''I don't think there'll be any surprises,'' says Kidder Peabody analyst Gary Jacobson . ''It's been able to hold its own in a difficult environment while others fade away.''Nikesaid earlier that 1991 revenue had topped $ 3 billion - 36% higher than its $ 2.2 billion in 1990.Nikefaces challenges in 1992 because of increased competition and a growing trend away from expensive athletic shoes. Some analysts predict revenue growth will slow to 17%. Jacobson says he's looking for only 9% earnings growth to $ 4.15 a share - not the big double-digit growth investors saw in previous years.Still, Jacobson and First Albany analyst Todd Berko say the company has bright prospects ahead internationally, where trends lag three years behind the USA. ''It's an incredibly well-managed company that's had an incredible string of successes the past few years,'' Berko says. ''The product development is still the strongest in the industry and they're still committing money to advertising.'' Valuable assets? Shares of Craig Corp. have been roaring higher since BusinessWeek reported Monday that some investors believe Craig is greatly undervalued. But at least one analyst takes exception to the article and recommends selling the Los Angeles-based real-estate and supermarket company. Craig shares, up 2 3/8 Monday, rose another 2 1/8 to $ 20 5/8 Tuesday - a 28% gain in two days.BusinessWeek, citing unnamed money managers, said Craig's 50% stake in Stater Bros., a private California supermarket chain, and stakes in financial services company Citadel Holding and real-estate manager Reading Co. make Craig's assets worth about $ 30 a share. But H.D. Brous & Co. analyst Howard Rosencrans, one of the few analysts to follow the company, says the stock is fully valued at $ 15. He urges his clients to sell. He says 1991 sales slowed at Stater Bros. He says defense cuts and the poor real-estate market is hurting Craig's other interests.
email_title: GoodNikeearnings look like a shoo-in

Email_Body: MICHAEL DELL RATTACompany:NikeJapan Corp.Title: General manager, corporate planning officeNationality: AmericanHobbies: Mountain biking, photographyIronically, Michael Della Ratta's pursuit of stress relief eventually brought him to Tokyo.  While working at a consulting firm in Washington D.C. 11 years ago, he enrolled at a local Japanese martial arts school, to help work off every day stress. Hooked by aikido, he came to Japan to study the martial art for a year in Wakayama Prefecture, near Osaka.  Dela Ratta said he was particularly impressed by aikido's great attention to form, or kata.The characteristics of aikido may apply to Japanese business in general, he said.  "The Japanese don't spent a lot of time analyzing.  Instead, they concentrate more on forming internal modes of operation, so they can react to many different situations."Since joiningNikein 1982, he has spent most of the last decade in Asia, including stints of China and Taiwan.As general manager ofNikeJapan Corp.'s corporate planning office since September, Della Ratta calls himself a "cultural bridge" betweenNikeInc. of the U.S. andNikeJapan, a wholly owned subsidiary of Nissho Iwai Corp."What I try to do is getNikeJapan on the same timetable as the rest ofNike, which is very tough," he explained.Della Ratta sees the changing lifestyles of Japan as beneficial toNike.  "Now Japanese people want to get outdoors more.  They want to be running, mountain biking or surfing.  So that's encouraging for our industry."

Nikehas employed an all- star roster of male athletes, including Bo Jackson and Michael Jordan, to lure men to its lines of athletic footwear. But what about women, who accounted for roughly 42 percent of all athletic shoes purchased in 1990?"We feel our advertising has to be different for women," said Lisa DeNeffe, aNikespokeswoman. "Women look up to other women, but they don't really have specific role models as much as men do. So we took a different approach." That approach is illustrated in an eight-page insert thatNikeand its advertising agency, Wieden & Kennedy, began placing in women's magazines earlier this month. Instead of sports stars, the ad relies on simple sentences in large black type that chronicle the stages in a woman's life from childhood to adulthood."You wanted to be a veterinarian," the ad states in a section devoted to childhood. "You wanted to be president. You wanted to be the president's veterinarian."
email_title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;NikeApproach To Women

Email_Body: THENikesportswear company said today it would stand behind double world sprint champion Katrin Krabbe, suspended from athletics for four years for manipulating a dope test.The German Athletic Federation (DLV) banned Krabbe, world 400m silver medallist Grit Breuer and 1987 double world sprint champion Silke Moeller on Saturday for four years after they returned identical urine samples at a random test at their training camp in South Africa. On Tuesday the sport nutrition firm Isostar, which sponsored Krabbe and Breuer, said it would scrap a two-year promotional deal worth hundreds of thousands of dollars.But aNikespokesman said the company would stand behind Krabbe and Breuer until it knew the full story."Both runners have been strong supporters ofNikeand we've been strong supporters of them,"Nikespokesman Dusty Kidd said. "We think they deserve continued support at least until this thing gets some resolution."Kidd saidNikeexecutives had reviewed all the information so far available and were not satisfied that any conclusive evidence had been presented regarding the drug tests."This particular situation suggests manipulation, but the question is, who did the manipulating?" Kidd said."Certainly we have reviewed the information we've got from Germany and we still feel that resolution is yet to be final. Until it is, it's not fair for the athletes not to get the support they need."The Oregon-based athletic footwear and sportswear company has had a contract with Krabbe, Breuer and their Neu Brandenberg running club since March 1990 and supplies equipment to the club.Krabbe, who has argued that the tests were doctored by an outside party, has pledged to fight the suspension in the law courts and her manager has threatened a $7.95 million lawsuit against the DLV.- REUTEREND OF STORY
email_title: Nikegets behind Krabbe

Email_Body: Nikesaid it had signed a four-year agreement with NBC under which it would become the only athletic footwear and apparel maker to advertise during the network's coverage of the French Open and Wimbledon tennis championships.Nikewould not disclose how much it spent on the agreement.On May 26, during NBC's coverage of the French Open,Nikewill introduce a new spot featuring the tennis player Andre Agassi.
email_title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Nikein Pact With NBC For Tennis Exclusives

Email_Body: David Robinson of the San Antonio Spurs will resume his starring role next week in a series of spots forNikeparodying the television program "Mr. Rogers's Neighborhood."In past spots, whichNikesaid had generated an unusual amount of fan mail, Mr. Robinson invited a diverse collection of guests, including his coach, Larry Brown, and the classical pianist Rudolf Firkusny, into his "neighborhood," which is a basketball court.The new spots, which will supportNike'snew Air Force 180 basketball shoes, feature, among others, Charles Barkley of the Philadelphia 76ers, an oft-disciplined player who will teach viewers his word for the day: "fined."
email_title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Basketball Star InNikeSpots

Email_Body: NikeInc. announced plans Tuesday to bring its hotNikeTown retailing concept to Buckhead's Phipps Plaza next spring.It is a "store" that has wowed shoppers in Chicago and Portland, Ore., where the onlyNikeTowns currently exist. There had been rumors among Phipps tenants for months thatNikeTown was coming.The 25,000-square-foot Atlanta store will have 60 full-time employees and be located on the first floor of the new Phipps Plaza wing that houses a Parisian department store."Our design concept forNikeTown incorporates sports, fitness, entertainment, history and product innovation, all in one," said Melinda Gable, a spokeswoman for the Beaverton, Ore., footwear maker.Mixing Disneyland and MTVNikeTown is like a mixture of Disneyland and MTV, with customers as the audience participating in a production.Shoppers walk through doors to the center of a Hollywood-like town square that has videos and life-size sculptures of sports stars, such as Deion Sanders and Michael Jordan.Sports sounds - the squeak of basketball shoes or the smacking of a tennis ball - accompany customers as they walk through each area of the store. Once customers make a selection, a high-tech delivery system speeds merchandise through clear plastic tubes from the stockroom to the customer."The AtlantaNikeTown will have the same town-square concept as the other stores, but will be more modular in design to accommodate future product lines and to serve as a focal point for community events," Ms. Gable said.
email_title: Nikeplanning a splashy store for Phipps Plaza Shop expected to open near Parisian in spring '93

Email_Body: BEAVERTON, Ore. -NikeInc., the largest athletic apparel maker in the world, has built its business by speaking to men.  If women were eavesdropping and understood the message - fine.Nikewas happy to sell them smaller, pretty-color versions of its men's offerings.  In the industry, these are known as ''take-down'' products.  With that approach, it is little wonder thatNike'swomen's business has been only a trickle in the company's revenue stream. For the fiscal year ended May 31, it accounted for about 16 percent, or $480 million, of total revenues of $3 billion.  By comparison, Reebok International Ltd., the other industry titan, does about half its $2.16 billion annual sales in women's products.  But with the domestic men's market at its saturation point, Beaverton-basedNikehas acquired a fascination with women rivaling that of an adolescent boy.  ''Nikeis a male brand,'' says Kate Bednarski, marketing manager of women's fitness shoes forNike.''But we're now committed to growing our business on the other side of the channel.'' The commitment comes in the form of new head-to-toe women's collections - designed by women for women - and a critically acclaimed advertising campaign that says ''Just do it'' in a distinctly feminine voice heretofore unheard fromNike.Analysts and industry obser vers are generally enthusiastic aboutNike'spotential in the domestic women's market.  Overall, shoes alone in that market amount to about $3 billion annually if you figure in the whole spectrum from sneakers to highly engineered performance shoes. It's $2 billion if you toss out the shoesNiketypes caustically refer to as ''foot coverings.'' Fitness apparel (other than footwear), a loosely defined category that includes about everything women don't wear to the office, is estimated at $16 billion a year; the sports-performance part of it that most interestsNiketakes up about $2 billion.
email_title: NIKE'SNEXT MOVE IS TO WIN WOMEN

Email_Body: The New Mexico basketball program, unable to locate quality opponents overseas, has cancelled a planned August trip to Europe. The Lobos had scheduled games in Austria, France and Switzerland Aug. 10-24. However, a Cincinnati-based travel agency arranging the trip could not confirm enough games. STRAW RETURNS: Darryl Strawberry, who missed 48 games with a herniated disk, was activated by the Los Angeles Dodgers between games of a doubleheader with the Montreal Expos. Pitcher Kip Gross, who was called up from the minors and won the opener 8-3, was optioned to Class AAA Albuquerque.  NIKENEWS:Nike,which has paid millions of dollars to put its name on the U.S. track and field team's uniforms at the Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, says it is appealing a Spanish court ruling that bars the advertising or sale ofNikeapparel in Spain. Spain's Constitutional Court last week upheld a lower court's order barring the sports company from using theNikename on clothing bcecause a Spanish firm registered the trademark in 1932.Nike,whose shoes are not affected by the ruling, planned to use the Olympics to launch a line of sports clothes.Nikesays it could lose $ 20 million in sales in Spain and much more worldwide if the ruling stands. TYSON APPEAL: Mike Tyson's lawyers have requested copies of any contracts between the boxer's rape victim and her former civil lawyer for use in the appeals process. Alan M. Dershowitz, who is heading Tyson's appeal, said he is exploring ''appropriate legal grounds'' for his legal actions and needs the contracts from Marion Superior Court Judge Patricia Gifford. Tyson was convicted Feb. 10 of raping Desiree Washington last July.
email_title: STAYING HOME

Email_Body: Apparel bearing Michael Jordan's likeness won't be on sale in NBA arenas for long. You'll have to go to a store that sellsNikeproducts. Jordan has asked the National Basketball Association to stop using his likeness on its licensed apparel. The Chicago Bulls star has that right, say NBA senior vice president Gary Bettman and NBA Players Association executive director Charles Grantham.A player and the league can share revenues from NBA merchandise deals using a player's likeness - or a player can decline to involve the NBA in a product category in which he has an exclusive deal.And Jordan decided to go solo withNikein his apparel arrangement.Nike,which does not sell its products in NBA arenas, says its annual sales of Jordan gear top $ 200 million.But with the NBA no longer a partner in Jordan's apparel deal - the financial impact on the NBA and Jordan remains to be seen - fans won't be able to buy clothing items bearing both Jordan's image and the Bulls' logo.Nikedoesn't use NBA logos on Jordan apparel.Nikeisn't gloating. ''It's between the NBA and Michael,'' saysNike'sLiz Dolan. ''It has nothing to do withNike.''A recent survey by Sporting Goods Business said Jordan has more influence over consumer purchases than any other athlete. Proceeds from retail sales of NBA merchandise, which topped $ 1.1 billion last year and was led by Bulls gear, trickle down to all NBA teams.
email_title: Jordan cuts NBA out of apparel deal

Email_Body: NikeInc. said yesterday that its first-quarter profits rose 7.1 percent, but heavy spending on advertising during the Olympics caused profits to fall below investors' expectations.Nike'sstock price dropped $2 immediately after the earnings were released, but as the day progressed, it rebounded as investors focused onNike'shigh level of orders for the spring. The shares closed on the New York Stock Exchange at $76.375, a gain of 75 cents.Nikeexecutives defended the heavy Olympic advertising spending, saying the results are already evident. "Our U.S. business was robust during the critical back-to-school season just completed, and worldwide futures orders for spring delivery were at record levels," said, Philip H. Knight, the chairman ofNike.The company sold one million pairs of $65 basketball shoes during the back-to-school season, making it the nation's best-selling shoe for the season. For the quarter ended Aug. 31,Nike,which is based in Beaverton, Ore., earned $122.5 million, or $1.60 a share, compared with $114.4 million, or $1.50 a share, in the period last year.Nikewas expected to earn $1.72 a share, according to a survey of analysts by Zacks Investment Research. Sales Advanced by a Sharp 16% Nike'ssales grew a robust 16 percent, to $1.09 billion, compared with $947 million last year.Nike,which plans to spend $140 million on advertisements this year, said that one-third of those expenditures will take place in the first quarter.Advertising and other administrative expenses "went through the roof," said Gary M. Jacobson, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody.Still, Mr. Jacobson called the heavy promotional outlay a prudent investment. "The Olympics only come around once every four years," he said.Nikeexecutives also say there is a direct correlation between the heavy global advertising levels and the strong spring orders.For September through January, 1993,Nikehas orders for $1.36 billion of shoes, 27 percent higher than the orders for the corresponding period last year. The company said its January orders were the largest single-month total in the company's history."The most important number to look at is the futures number," said Josie Esquivel, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers. "It's really pretty astronomical in this type of environment," she said, referring to the sluggish demand for most consumer goods.In a conference call with analysts,Nikesaid that it continued to gain market share in Germany at the expense of Adidas.Mr. Knight ofNikesaid that despite the higher expensesNike'searnings should grow by 15 percent for the fiscal year.Niketold analysts that its business grew by 5 percent in the United States and by 49 percent in foreign markets.In addition to sports shoes,Nikemakes athletic clothes and Cole Haan dress shoes.
email_title: COMPANY NEWS;Earnings ofNikeIncreased By 7.1% in the First Quarter

Email_Body: Sneaker giantNikesays earnings jumped 17% its latest quarter, butNikestock stumbled 3 5/8 to $ 70 1/2 Monday. Though net income climbed to a record high, results were slightly below analysts' expectations of $ 1.12 to $ 1.15 a share. Net income for the quarter ended Feb. 29 rose to $ 82.5 million, or $ 1.08 a share, from $ 70.7 million, or 93 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue also hit a record $ 867 million from $ 802 million. Though analysts trimmed earnings estimates for the year, they recommendedNikefor the long term.  Chairman Philip Knight says investment abroad, where revenue rose 27% from a year earlier, is starting to pay off.  CIRCLE K PLAN: A group of international investors that includes the owner of Saks Fifth Avenue has offered $ 425 million to buy Circle K, the USA's second-largest convenience-store chain.  Circle K says its sale to CK Acquisitions could help it emerge from bankruptcy-court protection by the end of the year. Circle K filed for Chapter 11 in May 1990 and has lost more than $ 1 billion the past two years. In December, it said it will close 1,500 of its 3,700 stores, situated mostly in the South. Circle K's reorganization plan and any sale must be approved by the bankruptcy court. The parent of Circle K's chief rival 7-Eleven - Southland - was bought by Japanese investors in 1990 . FedEx DEAL: Federal Express says it is ending its domestic European and intra-European services May 4. The company says it agreed to sell its domestic French operations to TNT Express Worldwide's TNT Chrono Service S.A. and is selling domestic U.K. operations to Securicor Omega Express Ltd. Terms of the deals weren't disclosed. Also, FedEx said it lost $ 193 million, or $ 3.58 a share, in its third quarter, which ended Feb. 29. The loss includes a $ 254 million charge to pay for the European restructuring. The company lost $ 106 million, or $ 1.98 a share, in the year-earlier quarter. ANDERSEN SETTLEMENT: Arthur Andersen & Co., accused of helping
email_title: NIKEEARNINGS

Email_Body: You can't escape the long arm ofNike.It seems that every time you turn on the tube, flip a magazine page or gaze at a billboard, theNikeInc. ''swoosh'' and a well-paid athlete are staring back at you.Nike'sadvertising firepower has taken it to the top of the athletic shoe market, but those creative and often outlandish ads don't come cheap. In the first nine months of 1990,Nikespent $ 61.8 million for TV and radio air time, cable TV spots, newspaper and magazine pages and billboard space - up 79% from the same period in 1989. The numbers come from LNA/Arbitron Multi-Media Service and Advertising Age and don't include the cost of creating the ads and payments to celebrity endorsers.No other sports company came close toNike.No. 2 sports shoe-maker Reebok International spent $ 30.6 million in the first nine months of 1990, up 13%; Sports Illustrated spent $ 23.5 million (undoubtedly most on endless repetitions of its cable TV subscription ads featuring football phones, Michael Jordan videos, etc.), up 73% from 1989; and L.A. Gear spent $ 23.2 million, up a whopping 162%. No other sports companies cracked the top 200.To put those numbers in perspective, look at how much the really big spenders put out in only nine months: AT&T spent $ 371.5 million and McDonald's $ 334.6 million. LINKAGE: New LPGA Commissioner Charles Mechem isn't pulling many punches in his analysis of the tour. In a recent interview in Golfweek, Mecham said the LPGA suffers from a ''massive inferiority complex. I don't mean that critically of anybody, but I think the organizatiom is a lot stronger that it realizes it is.'' ... Golf icon and Senior PGA Tour member Don January is getting into the golf architectural business. His partners include son Tom and Craig Curry, formerly of Jack Nicklaus and Associates. CHAIN GANG: Hybrid bikes aren't two-wheelers for biologists, but they are quickly moving up the evolutionary ladder. A cross between fat-tired mountain bikes and featherweight road racing bikes, hybrids are catching on with fitness fanatics and born-again cyclists. Some purists scoff, but the market loves them. According to Bicycling magazine, more than 100 of the 941 new bicycle models can be classified as hybrids, an increase of 30 products from last year's selection. The good news: The average price of a hybrid has decreased from $ 612 to $ 478. Last year's hot model was Schwinn's $ 300 Crisscross, rated a Best Buy by both Consumer Reports and Bicycle Guide. Road bike prices are up an average of 30%, while mountain bikes increased only 11%. COLLECT CALLS: Some people think baseball memorabilia came of age when they stopped putting gum in baseball card packages. Another milestone: Sotheby's auction salon in New York is selling the collection of James C. Copeland, a California sporting goods retailer, March 22. Among the goodies: a rare Honus Wagner tobacco card that could bring $ 150,000, and a collection of 160 World Series press pins that could fetch $ 300,000. ... Score Inc. has created a ''hobby advisory board'' to learn how it can best serve dealers. SHELL GAME: Next trip to the ballpark, tip your hat to the MVP - the Master Vendor of Peanuts, that is. Peanuts have been a big part of baseball for more than 100 years, according to the National Peanut Month Committee. More than $ 10 million is shelled out for peanuts at ballparks every year. The MVPs will be named in March and the lucky vendors will get a trophy, a button and a free trip to spring training in Florida.
email_title: SPORTS BUSINESS;Nikepays price for big presence

Email_Body: NEW YORKShoemakerNikeInc. nosed out fragrance maker Calvin Klein as sponsor ofthe most popular print advertising campaign of 1990, a consumer surveyshows. Nikemoved up from fourth place in the 1989 survey, while Calvin Kleinfell from the top spot for the first time in four years, according toresults in the survey from the research firm Video Storyboard Tests Inc.Video Storyboard Tests interviewed 24,000 people over the course of1990 for its latest survey, asking them to recall the newspaper andmagazine ads that they found to be the most outstanding they had seenrecently.Other top ads: Camel cigarettes, Revlon cosmetics, Absolut vodka,Infiniti cars, Marlboro cigarettes, Guess apparel, Ford vehicles, andMaybelline cosmetics.
email_title: NEWS BULLETINSNikeoutpaces Klein

Email_Body: Spanish trademark laws are threatening to turnNike'ssponsorship of the U.S. Olympic track-and-field team into a multi-million-dollar fiasco. NikeInc. is in the midst of a court battle with a Spanish attorney who owns theNikename in Spain - first registered here 60 years ago by a Barcelona sock maker.With the Olympics less than six weeks away andNikeplanning to plaster its disputed name on U.S. athletes' uniforms, the company and the attorney, Juan Amigo Freixas, are playing a game of courtroom chicken. Whoever swerves first is likely to lose tens of millions of dollars. Pressure is building on both sides:Nike, an American sports shoe and apparel giant based in Beaverton, Ore., wants to clear up the matter before the July 25 opening ceremony. Amigo, who says the athletes can't use theNikename without his permission, knows his payoff will shrink after the games end.Amigo ''should be aware that it would result in a very unpleasant embarrassment for the Kingdom of Spain,'' said John Faylor,Nike'sEuropean counsel. ''Juan Amigo is a pirate, as we see him, who's using the . . . trademark to blackmailNikeinto a negotiating position andNikerefuses to submit to those kinds of tactics.''At stake are the profitsNikehoped to reap when it paid a handsome sum - the company won't say how much - to hitch its name to the U.S. athletes. Nikedocuments put potential sales losses at US$20 million in Spain alone and many times that amount worldwide.To make matters worse forNike, competitor Reebok's logo will be on the sweatsuit of every American who steps to the winner's podium in Barcelona, includingNikespokesman Michael Jordan, should the U.S. basketball team take a medal.At the heart of the dispute are Spain's idiosyncratic commercial laws, which have generated an array of cases involving foreign firms that entered the Spanish market only to find someone else already owned their brands.Trademark laws here long permitted anyone to register and renew a name simply by paying a fee, even if they never produced anything.The statutes were changed in 1988 to permit easier challenges to inactive trademarks, but registrants still aren't required to prove they have an ongoing business or product when filing an application.''Trademark piracy is practically the national sport in Spain,'' Faylor said by telephone from Frankfurt.''Nikehas been one of the many trademark companies that have experienced harassment.''Is it piracy? Or just smart business?''They can think what they want,'' Amigo said from Barcelona. ''If the Olympics hadn't come to Spain,Nikewould never have landed here because they wouldn't know where Spain was.''Amigo bought theNikename from the original owner, who produced knitted wear during the 1936-39 Spanish Civil War and kept the trademark - a photographic negative of the headless Winged Victory of Samothrace statue in the Louvre Museum - long after production ceased.The registration applies only to sports apparel, not shoes - but it's the U.S. track team's shirts and shorts that will be most visible to television cameras.In July 1990,Nikewas issued a registration for its name and ''swoosh'' symbol, but two Spanish courts upheld Amigo's earlier trademark. The Constitutional Court is now consideringNike'sappeal.At one point, Amigo askedNikefor US$30 million for rights to the brand, Fraylor said. Amigo refused to divulge any figures.''He's trying to basically take advantage of what he has,'' said the U.S. official.GRAPHIC:Photo: Michael Jordan teamed up with Bugs Bunny forNikeSuper Bowl ads in January, but there's a chance he won't be able to wearNikelogos at the Barcelona Olympics.
email_title: Nikefacing Olympian battle

Email_Body: Two makers of athletic shoes and sports wear reported widely divergent financial results today.NikeInc. of Beaverton, Ore., reported its fifth consecutive year of record revenues and earnings, while L.A. Gear Inc. of Los Angeles reported a loss for its second quarter.Both companies' stock moved sharply on the news.Nikeshares jumped more than 10 percent, closing at $66.375, up $6.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. And L.A. Gear slid more than 13 percent, closing at $10.625, off $1.625. Philip H. Knight,Nike'schairman and chief executive, said in a statement that the company was well positioned to continue its growth."A 17 percent increase in future orders for the next six months sets the stage for another record year in 1993," Mr. Knight said. "This increase reflects U.S. retailers' continued success withNikeproducts in an otherwise difficult retail environment." He added thatNikewas also strong in Europe.L.A. Gear said its loss stemmed partly from the cost of settling three separate consolidated shareholder suits, as well as a loss from continuing operations."The company's new management is continuing its efforts during this transition year to redirect the company, both operationally and financially," said Stanley P. Gold, L.A. Gear's chairman and chief executive.Following are details of the companies' results: NikeFor the fourth quarter, which ended May 31,Nikesaid it earned $70.7 million, or 92 cents a share, up 20.6 percent from $58.6 million, or 76 cents a share, in the period a year ago. Revenues rose 17.9 percent, to $847.6 million, from $719.0 million in the fourth quarter of the 1991 fiscal year.For the year,Nikehad earnings of $329.2 million, or $4.30 a share, up 14.7 percent from $287.0 million, or $3.77 a share, in the 1991 fiscal year. Revenues rose 13.7 percent, to $3.41 billion, from $3 billion in the previous year."The Olympic Games will further showcaseNike'sproducts and athletes to a truly global audience," Mr. Knight said. "Seven of the 12 U.S.A. Basketball Team players and 66 of the 129 track and field qualifiers areNikeathletes." L.A. GearFor its second quarter, which ended May 31, L.A. Gear had a deficit of $24.4 million, up substantially from a loss of $4 million in the period a year ago. Sales fell 36.9 percent, to $104.7 million, from $166 million in the second quarter of the 1991 fiscal year.The loss for the quarter reflects a $13.87 million after-tax charge for the settlement of the shareholder suits. The company attributed the decline in earnings to a drop in the number of shoes sold worldwide. The company said that pricing pressure on its old product line will reduce gross margins for the balance of the year.
email_title: COMPANY NEWS;NikeEarnings at Record; L.A. Gear Posts Deficit

Email_Body: NIKEAND THE BARE ESSENTIALSTHE sportswear firm,Nike(Greek for victory), has not enjoyed the best of times at the Olympics. Michael Johnson, subject of a large advertising campaign byNike,flopped in the 200 metres, while anotherNikestar, Sergei Bubka, failed to reach the qualifying heights in the pole vault. At leastNikewill not be upstaged by rivals Reebok tonight. Reebok has a deal with the United States Olympic Committee to provide tracksuits for all US medal-winners to be worn on the podium. This agreement has caused problems for six of the ''dream team'', including Michael Jordan and Charles Barkley, who are contracted toNikefor seven-figure sums. Eventually a compromise was reached. So if - or rather when - Jordan, Barkley and Co win gold tonight, the medal ceremony should be fun. Apart from the sight of the chosen dignitary straining to place medals around the necks of near 7ft-tall athletes, some of the basketballers will be revealing some chest. The reason for the unzipped tracksuit tops? So the collars can fold down and conceal the Reebok logo.NAME the one football video that is available in the club boardroom, but not in the club shop? ''Dion Dublin - the goals''. This tape was sent to every leading club by John Beck, Cambridge United's manager. It worked. Manchester United forked out pounds 1m for Dublin's services. What next? ''Vinnie Jones - the tackles''? CLEAR OBJECTIVEA daunting task for batsmen - clearing the Lord's pavilion - has been turned into a competition. A cheque for pounds 1,000 is the reward for any cricketer who carries the beautiful old building, a feat achieved once, by Albert Trott (via a chimney pot) for the MCC against the Australians in 1899. The Cricket Lore Challenge, organised by the cricket magazine, is open until 1999, the centenary of Trott's achievement. Many have tried to emulate Trott's feat, players like Keith Miller, Kim Hughes, Wasim Akram and Mike Llewellyn. Llewellyn came closest, in the 1977 Gillette Cup final for Glamorgan against Middlesex, when he hoisted a delivery from John Emburey - it rose high enough but caught the top of the north tower.WE ALL know Olympic medals bring their rewards. Fame for all, fortune for a few. And some new friends for Shannon Miller. The 15-year-old gymnast who is returning home to Edmond, Oklahoma, with three medals has aroused a lot of interest. ''Young men are calling from all over the country trying to get her phone number,'' an Edmond civic official said. ''One little guy from Denver has probably called seven or eight times today. He says it's a real emergency.''RACING'S RICHESThe glamour of the turf . . . prizes at Ngong Racecourse, Nairobi, are a bit different from those at Kentucky and Epsom. A bucket pump was the top reward in the first race; race three offered a backpack sprayer; race four, a maize hand shredder; race five, a wheel barrow; and the concluding feature race of the evening promised a milk churn.WHETHER FORECASTSTo commemorate what they call the ''dawning of a new age'', those wags at the football fanzine, When Saturday Comes, have produced a souvenir poster of the ''all-singing, all-dancing Premier League''. It features a predictions' chart, a vital excercise for any fan. The questions are not your normal ''pick the cup winners'' routine. Far from it. Take Arsenal . . . ''Name the number of central defenders bought between August and December'' followed by a box for your guess. Blackburn's is on a similar theme: ''Number of forwards bought during season''. The conundrum for Chelsea supporters: ''First month in which David Mellor is spotted at Stamford Bridge''. Southampton's involves ''final position in Fair Play League''.A HEALTHY dose of pre-season delirium has also infected Shoot! To promote their Charity Shield competition, Shoot! ran a picture from last season of a Liverpool-Leeds United match. The scene? David Batty upending Steve McManaman. Cruel.IMPORT QUANDARYA quick look at the new Celtic line- up makes worrying news for their UEFA campaign, given the tight restrictions on imported talent. At No 1 they have a South African, while the 12 others in the squad comprise seven from France, two from Australia, plus three from Italy. The line-up from Paradise is, of course, the new Celtic wine- list, the top bottle being the ''Celtic Champagne'' attractively priced at pounds 15.95. Other footballing essentials in the Parkhead catalogue include a hamper (''with red and white Celtic house wine''), tartan dungarees, an exclusive mountain bike (which would last three seconds outside Ibrox, covered as it is with Celtic emblems), cameras, telephones, binoculars, decanters. Oh, and football kit.DIVIDED LOYALTIESSachin Tendulkar, Yorkshire's Indian tyro, has come up with a variation on the dilemma of county v country - he may be playing for his county against his country next week in a pyjama series in Sheffield. The Tykes have insisted that Tendulkar, who made his first Championship century this week, represent them if both they and India reach the final of the Flamingo Land Floodlit Trophy at Don Valley Stadium on Thursday. Tendulkar turns out for his county against Durham in the first semi-final on Tuesday and then for his country against Lancashire the following night. ''No one can recall a similar situation in a tournament,'' Don Robinson, the promoter, said, ''so Sachin might qualify for a mention in the Guinness Book of Records.''TAKING THE BISCUITTHE Olympics have become so commercial, with everyone from fizzy-drink manufacturers to Wolverhampton butchers involved, that when the men's 100 metres was referred to as the Blue Riband event, some confusion was understandable. Overheard in a crowded room was a vexed voice . . . ''is this race sponsored by the biscuit-makers?''.SPOKEN WORDThe Chris Boardman limerick competition provoked some patriotic responses after the British cyclist's gold medal-winning ride. Joanna Rimmer, of Newcastle-upon-Tyne, wins a bottle of Aberlour Malt Whisky for the following . . .Who was our first gold award man?A chap with the name of Chris Boardman.With a hat like Darth VaderThis great Lotus raiderDid as well as a Briton abroad can.What rhymes with Sally Gunnell? Entries to Sports Diary Limerick, The Independent, 40 City Road, London EC1Y 2DB.PSNo let-up in the rivalry between broadcasters. After Sky had been beaten by LWT in the Tennents five-a-side tournament at Earls Court, an extra-terrestrial spokesman muttered: ''First time we've lost out to them at football.''
email_title: The Diary

Email_Body: Apparently sacrificing personal financial reward, Georgia Tech football coach Bobby Ross outfitted his 1990 national championship squad with theNikeshoes his players preferred, taking a $ 37,000 cut from his previous contract with Pony.The strained relationship between Ross and Pony was evident in a letter to him from the company's national marketing manager for football, Randy Beverly, dated Nov. 6, 1989. It noted that a number of Tech players were wearing shoes made by other companies, saying that "could be perceived as a material breach of contract." It also stated: "I would like to assume that this is a temporary slip on your part and that you will ensure that in future games the players will wear the appropriate footwear." On March 26, 1990, Ross signed a contract withNike."I don't even know what it says," Ross said of his contract with Nike, which paid him only $ 6,000 last season. "I used to get some money from Pony, but the kids wantedNikeshoes, so we changed."Ross's remuneration fromNikeis paid strictly on an incentive basis:- $ 1,000 for winning a conference championship.- $ 5,000 for winning a national championship.Ross also receives $ 2,000 (retail value) inNikemerchandise.Nikeprovides 50 pairs of shoes for Tech players, and others must be purchased at a rate of three pairs for the price of two.Nikeprovides 100 free pairs if Tech goes to a bowl game.Under Ross's contract with Pony, Tech received 400 pairs of shoes in 1987 and 300 pairs in both 1988 and 1989.Also, each of 12 assistants and six other persons designated by Ross receives $ 500 inNikemerchandise, and Ross receives 400 T-shirts to distribute to youngsters at his summer camp.Ross was paid a $ 25,000 base stipend by Pony for the 1989 season, which included the following incentives:- $ 1,000 for each national network television game, $ 500 for each regional game.- $ 2,000 for a Jan. 1 bowl appearance, or $ 1,000 for a non-New Year's Day bowl.- $ 500 for a Top 20 finish, $ 1,000 for a Top 10 finish, $ 5,000 for a national championship.- $ 1,000 for an ACC title.- $ 5,000 for being named national coach of the year.Ross would have gotten $ 4,000 from Pony for Tech's televised games this season. There is no TV incentive in hisNikecontract.

Email_Body: Separate company reports pumped upNikestock Wednesday while cramping comeback efforts of L.A. Gear.Nikesays it has increased its share of the U.S. athletic-shoe and clothing market to 31%. The stock market approved:Nikeclass B shares jumped 6 3/8 to $ 66 1/8. L.A. Gear's ongoing losses - $ 24.4 million in the second quarter, ended May 31 - caused it to postpone an Aug. 28 dividend payment on its preferred stock. Shares of the athletic-clothing and shoe manufacturer dropped 1 5/8 to $ 10 5/8.''L.A. Gear shouldn't be a big surprise,'' says Gary M. Jacobson, Kidder Peabody shoe analyst. ''Nineteen ninety-two is a transitional year for L.A. Gear.''But a transitional year is better than the alternative.  If it weren't for the restructuring and new management, L.A. Gear would be in bankruptcy proceedings now, Jacobson notes. Instead, L.A. Gear has settled shareholder lawsuits and government problems, is discounting old inventory and is repositioning as a casual clothier and shoemaker.''Just Do It''Nikeis continuing its cross-training by gaining market share both domestically and internationally.''Nikehas built a very firm foundation,'' says Kevin Silverman , analyst at Kemper Securities. Its strong association with pro athletes and its investment in research and development are paying off. But he sees L.A. Gear as a company playing off fashion and suffering from fading fads.Both analysts likeNike,saying it is a bargain even after Wednesday's run- up. They are divided on L.A. Gear. ''I think the market is overlooking the turnaround value of L.A. Gear,'' Jacobson says. ''I think the stock is a steal.'' CBS's earnings rise: Thanks mostly to a greater demand for television network advertising, CBS reported a 37% rise in net income per share for the second quarter. Net income was $ 70.1 million, or $ 4.53 per share, vs. $ 50.6 million , or $ 3.31 per share, a year earlier . The network's quarterly revenue rose 10% to $ 781 million from $ 710 million . The stock edged down 7/8 to $ 195 1/2.Also helping the earnings, says CBS Chairman Laurence Tisch: CBS's rise from third to first place in prime-time network ratings. Plus, it aired the two semifinal games of the NCAA men's basketball tournament during the quarter. Last year, the games aired in the first quarter.
