Email_Body: Nikeis making advertising lemonade out of Bo Jackson's lemon of an injury, by emphasizing his rehabilitation work.The shoemaker's new TV ad opens with Bo at the center of the ''Bo Show,'' a Busby Berkeley-style musical with frenetic dancers (in sequined Raiders and White Sox uniforms). As a big band lays down a funky beat, tuxedoed Bo singsNike'snew catchphrase, ''Bo knows it's got that Air thing.''But Bo stops the show to proclaim that he's ''an athlete, not an actor.'' He literally crawls out of the TV and gets to work on his rehab program: swimming, spinning on a stationary bike and weight training.The show goes on, however, with George Foreman as the star. He leads the dancers in a new verse, ''George knows it's got that Air thing.''The ad is directed by Joe Pytka, who is responsible for the original ''Bo Knows'' ads. The first installment is due July 9 during baseball's All-Star Game. Other versions of the ''Bo Show'' will run later this summer and feature a new lineup of guest hosts: Wayne Gretzky, Jerry Rice, Darryl Strawberry, Randall Cunningham and Eric Davis.GRAPHIC:PHOTO; b/w CUTLINE: MAY I CUT IN?: Boxer George Foreman offers to take Bo Jackson's place duringNike'snew cross-training commercial.
email_title: Nikeready to squeeze more ad time out of Bo

Email_Body: JIMMY CONNORS is up to his ankles in a shoe controversy.Connors, who at age 39 defied the odds by winning reaching the semifinals at the United States Open, has endorsed Converse shoes for so long that the company named a line of tennis shoes for him. Yet at the Open he has played inNikes.What's the story here? Well, LIZ DOLAN, aNikespokeswoman, said Connors approached aNikerepresentative a few months ago at the Wimbledon championships and said he was having problems with his feet in longer matches and thought that shoes were a factor."He told us he would wear our shoes for free if he could get a pair that were really comfortable," Dolan said by telephone fromNikeheadquarters in Beaverton, Ore.A Converse spokeswoman, HELENE FLETCHER, said she was authorized only to read a statement that noted Connors was playing "possibly the best tennis of his career.""Converse has enjoyed a longstanding relationship with Jimmy and plans to continue working with him in the years to come," the statement said. (AP)
email_title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Connors: The Shoes

Email_Body: TIME is running out forNikein its trademark battle with a Spanish lawyer who has vowed to prevent the United States track and field team from wearing the company's kit in the Barcelona Games.With the Olympics opening on Saturday, a Barcelona court refused to lift its order barringNikefrom selling or advertising its sports apparel in Spain. The decision left the company with few short-term options in its wrangle with the attorney Juan Amigo, who bought theNiketrademark in 1981 from a Barcelona sock company that registered it as a trademark in the 1930s. Nikehad insisted it would not negotiate with Amigo and his ally, the Barcelona clothing company Cidesport - a formerNikedistributor - who have asked $ 20-30 million ( pounds 11-16 million) for rights to the trademark. Now, in increasing desperation and exhorted by American diplomats, the two sides are scheduled to meet in Madrid today.The Oregon-based company paid a multi-million-dollar figure to put its name on the US and Algerian teams in Barcelona. It expected the promotional campaign to generate $ 20 million in sales in Spain alone. Nikewas awarded its own trademark in Spain in 1990 and company officials say they are still confident the Spanish courts will eventually rule the trademark valid.But, although the European Commission asked the Spanish government last month to persuade the court to allowNiketo post a bond allowing the company to sell its apparel while awaiting a final decision, the injunction was upheld this month by the Constitutional Tribunal, Spain's highest appeals court. Nikesays the uniforms are not "advertising", so do not fall under the court order. The trademark dispute does not affectNike'ssports shoes or its "swoosh" symbol.
email_title: OLYMPIC GAMES:NIKEIN FRANTIC BATTLE TO SAVE ITS NAME

Email_Body: NikeInc. signed a letter of intent to acquire the Sports Specialties Corporation, a distributor of licensed headwear based in Irvine, Calif., from the Oppenheimer-Palmieri Fund L.P. Terms of the acquisition, which the companies expect to close within 60 days, were not disclosed. Sports Specialties, which pioneered the sale of licensed sports merchandise and distributes caps decorated with logos of professional and college sports teams, is expected to have sales of $70 million this year.Nike,based in Beaverton, Ore., said Sports Specialties would be operated as a subsidiary. Robert Warsaw, chief executive officer of Sports Specialties, and James Warsaw, president, will remain with the company.
email_title: COMPANY NEWS;NIKEAGREES TO ACQUIRE MAKER OF SPORTS CAPS

Email_Body: Whether it's corporate philosophy or advertising,NikeInc. takes the same approach: Just Do It.New research shows that black role models such as Magic Johnson and Jesse Jackson may be no more persuasive than President Bush in reaching young urban blacks. ButNikestill thinks its latest Spike Lee ads are worth it.In the $ 800,000 campaign that broke last week, the black filmmaker pitches racial harmony along with sneakers."If we're gonna live together, we've gotta play together," Mr. Lee said in the ad.Nikespokesman Dusty Kidd said the effectiveness of a campaign "is always difficult to measure." But that's not a concern of the company."It's important to at least make an attempt to get your point of view across," he said.
email_title: Nikedefends ads

Email_Body: WhileNikeand Reebok continue stomping each other for supremacy in the athletic shoe market, Converse has snuck in with a refreshing new back-to-the-basics marketing campaign.Once the king of canvas, Converse Inc. had been reduced to also-ran status in the sneaker market after the meteoric leap of No. 1NikeInc. and No. 2 Reebok International Ltd. Reebok, with its current "Pump Up, and Air Out" campaign, and British Knights's new spots featuring rapper M.C. Hammer jeering, "Your mother wearsNikes!" both bash market leaderNike.In a decidedly contrarian approach to the fray, no-nonsense Converse has come up with an "It's what's inside that counts" promotion that features more shoes than celebrity endorsers.The campaign's sports pros - Larry Bird, Jimmy Connors and Bernard King - play off the brand's 83-year history with folksy conversations, such as Mr. Connors's that starts like this: "My mother learned to play tennis from her mother . . . " The $ 22 million campaign, launched this month, is Converse's biggest ever."We didn't want to join the finger-pointing match againstNike," said Gordon Tucker, Converse senior vice president of marketing.GRAPHIC:Photo: NoNike-stomping: Converse touts its history. / Converse
email_title: Converse sidesteps shoe wars, goes back to basics in new ads

Email_Body: Reuters News AgencyBEAVERTON, Ore. NikeInc., the largest U.S. marketer of athletic shoes, reported third-quarter earnings jumped 12 per cent but the performance has disappointedWall Street this week andNike'sstock price tumbled. The Beaverton-based sneaker maker - whose earnings were restrained byadvertising and interest costs - earned $70.7-million (U.S.) in thequarter ended Feb. 28, or 93 cents a share, up from $63.1-million or 83cents a year earlier.On the New York Stock Exchange on Monday, its stock tumbled $2.50 tofinish at $47.50 in active trading after the earnings report. The sharesfell another $1.75 on Tuesday and 50 cents yesterday, to close at $45.25.Nike'sshare earnings were at the low end of Wall Street forecasts,which ranged from 90 cents to $1.05, according to a survey of 13 analystsby Lynch Jones & Ryan Inc. The average forecast was 97 cents a share.In its earnings report,Nikesaid revenue shot up 39 per cent in thethird quarter to $802.2-million from $577.9-million a year earlier.Separately, the once high-flying sneaker maker L.A. Gear Inc. said ithad reached agreement with its banks to restructure loan agreements.Last month the No. 3 maker of athletic shoes reported a $7.1-millionloss for the fourth quarter, technically throwing L.A. Gear into defaultwith the banks.Los Angeles-based L.A. Gear said its agreement with bank lenders, ledby BankAmerica Corp. of San Francisco, waives the sneaker maker from atechnical default it had anticipated. The company has said it expects afirst-quarter loss.The company said total bank credit will be cut, at its request, to$300-million from $360-million, with a limit of $250-million forborrowings and $70-million for letters of credit. The sublimit for lettersof credit would fall to $50-million later in the year. The agreement issubject to final documentation, expected to be completed by the end ofMarch.
email_title: Nikestock tumbles for the third day   Higher profit still disappoints investors

Email_Body: Barry Bonds is arguably the best player in baseball, but before Wednesday's game the Pittsburgh outfielder seemed a little envious of Deion Sanders's new multi-year deal withNike.He told his good friend and two-sport star, "I'll just take $ 100 and some shoes." Sanders will get much more than that after signing on earlier in the day with the shoe giant that has helped make mega-stars of Michael Jordan and Bo Jackson.NeitherNikenor Sanders's agent, Eugene Parker, would discuss financial terms of the multi-year deal. But Sanders said several weeks ago that the contract was worth more than his contract with the Falcons, which is $ 750,000 a season."It's going to be a lot of fun," Sanders, who did not have any major endorsements before theNikedeal, said Wednesday. "We're going to do some commercials and I'm just going to be myself."Nikespokeswoman Lisa Deneffe said Sanders will be used to endorse the cross-trainer shoe and other fitness products."Deion will definitely be very visible," she said. "We feel he can bring a lot to us."His first commercial will air sometime around the baseball All-Star Game in July, and part of it will be shot in New York on May 28, a Braves off-day.What will it be about?"We won't give that away," said Deneffe. Said Sanders, "I can't say anything. It's going to be a surprise. Maybe I'll do some dancing."Meanwhile, Parker said there has been little discussion with the Braves about a contract extension which would take Sanders through the baseball season. His client's current contract ends July 31, when he is supposed to report to the Falcons.
email_title: Niketo let Sanders be like Mike

Email_Body: THE threat of war hangs over the 25th Olympic Games in Barcelona. A trade war, in fact.Nike, the US sports shoe manufacturer, has found to its chagrin that becoming an official patron of the Games buys no favours in Spain.A Barcelona judge has ruled the multinational company may not advertise or distribute its products in Spain. The case was brought by the Catalan firm of Cidesport, a family company which has held rights of theNiketrademark in Spain since 1932.Now President George Bush's office has intervened, through international trade spokeswoman Carla Hill, to register its anger with Spain's Ministry of Trade and Industry.The US has now put Spain firmly on the list of countries which could suffer reprisals if it continues to impose protective measures against the company which is based in Portland, Oregon (which Bush hopes to carry in November's Presidential election.) Sergei Bubka, and Michael Jordan are among the American firms' best-known sponsored athletes. Undeterred,Nikesays its leading athletes will wear its products because they are not for sale in Spain.Lawyers for SpanishNikesay the police are entitled to enforce compliance with the law - thereby raising the spectacle of the US men's relay team running barefoot |With commercial sponsorship of athletes reaching grotesque levels at these Games, it's unlikely eitherNikewill back down.TERRORIST FEARTHE Games have occasioned the biggest police exercise in Spain since the rule of fascist dictator Franco. More than 30,000 policemen are keeping watch from helicopters, tanks, motorbikes, patrol cars and unmarked vehicles.Some security men are even in the harbour and off the coast in navy submarines.Operations are being directed from a $1 million purpose-built bunker, centre of a closed-circuit video network filming the stadium and tracks, the Olympic village and the city's main streets.The main fear is a headline-grabbing military operation by members of ETA, the ultra-nationalist group seeking independence for the Basque country in northern Spain.With many ETA activists in jail in both France and Spain, Barcelonans are praying for a trouble-free Olympics.In the hot seat is Interior Minister Jose Luis Corcuera who boasted in Parliament that recent arrests probably left only one active ETA commando unit in Spain. That's fine, Jose, but where is it?After two years of efforts to reach a truce, the Spanish Government evidently felt strong enough to maintain an official silence in the face of a recent truce offer from ETA leaders.Last week two Basque political parties, Herri Batasuna and Eusko Alkartasuna, signed a joint pact and wrote to Spanish Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez and French President Francois Mitterrand demanding recognition of the Basques' right to self-determination.If ETA and the Basques behave during the Games, the Spanish Government has let it be known, ever so unofficially, that it will make some "tactical, conciliatory gestures" to the Basque nation.TOUCHY SUBJECTIT is not Basque terrorists but the regional government of Catalonia(capital Barcelona) which is causing most embarrassment to Spanish authorities.Jordi Pujol, head of Catalonia's Council, has outraged Madrid by campaigning in the European press for recognition of Catalonia. One full-page advertisement declared Catalonia was "a country within Spain which has been able to bring the Olympics to its capital, Barcelona".Pujol's campaign has led to an outcry from the Madrid Government which points out that the central government has borne more than 50 per cent of the cost.In his visit last week to the Olympic village where his son, Felipe, is a member of Spain's yachting team, King Juan Carlos made no direct reference to the controversy. But he did remark that the Games were "of transcendental importance in the history of Spain".Pujol, unrepentant, accused Spain's ruling Socialist Party of"criminalising Catalan nationalism". The lofty ideals of the Olympics are unlikely to heal the breach.A hardy contingent of sports fans from Australia have fallen at the first Olympic hurdle - the language barrier."Jeez, mate," complained one Aussie, "it's hard to get around over here. No-one speaks Australian."It reminded me of the old bloke from Coogee who went on a world tour soon after retiring. Back at the bowling club eight weeks' later someone asked him how it had gone."It was OK," he said grudgingly, "except there were too many New Australians."HUMAN FAILUREWHILE the Games are in the stadiums, Barcelona's Science Museum is not to be outdone. It is staging an exhibition of sports simulation which enables visitors to experience the thrill of the grand slalom or the pole vault, for example, without actually moving.As well, the exhibition features comparisons between human athletic records and the achievements of the animal kingdom. This shows that no animal has jumped as high as the kangaroo (3.3 metres); that only Sergei Bubka, with his 6.13m pole vault, has jumped higher than a dolphin, and that Arnold Schwarzenegger swinging on a rope exerts a force of 100kg, less than one-third of that achieved by your average chimpanzee.I wonder if our Science Museum could mount a similar exercise comparing the intelligence of animals and, say, politicians. Just a thought.HOTSHOTSTHE hidden factor of these Games may well prove to be the heat. It is sweltering. Temperatures over the past week have swung between 30 to 38 degrees.Spain's own Olympic football team has been suffering. Being blow-wave Iberians, a sports psychologist, Dr Jesus Garcia Barrero, was called in to help cool them down. My tip is that the sun-parched Moroccans, Algerians, Ethiopians and Kenyans will star in the track events. Give the Icelanders and Finns a miss this year.DAYLIGHT ROBBERYIT comes as no surprise to learn that the Spaniards gave us the word pirata which we translate as pirate. I visited an official money-changing office which carried a table in the window offering 178 pesetas for each Pound 1 sterling. I changed Pound 50 and discovered to my horror I had received only 161 pesetas per Pound .When I protested I was insolently told the higher rate was only for transactions worth 500,000 pesetas or more. I got my money back but only after a furious row involving a threat to call the police.Barcelona's restaurateurs have also gone mad. As of last week their eateries became - officially - the highest priced in all of Spain. Their bonanza may be shortlived. One hotel chain owner predicted in El Mundo last week that half of the city's restaurants will fold after the three-week GamesHARD YAKKA |IN Seville, the Australian Consul ate is housed in the British Institute. Yes, folks, the British are the landlords and we are the humble tenants.And the office keeps strict British colonial hours - open Monday to Friday, 10am to noon.CASTRO'S VISIT EMBARRASSES THE HOSTBARCELONA is plastered with posters greeting Cuba's President, Fidel Castro.He arrives today with 20 other Latin American heads of state for the Iberio-American summit opening in Madrid on Thursday. "Cuba, with you more than ever," say the street posters.Spain's Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez, a fawning friend of Uncle Sam, is doing his best to play down Castro's historic visit.While left-wing mayors and regional leaders are queueing for a photo opportunity with the honcho from Havana, USA-style socialist Gonzalez will beat Ben Johnson sprinting in the other direction.Perhaps wind-assisted.GRAPHIC:Four Ports: VISITOR: Fidel Castro BUSH, JORDAN, ARNOLD Illus: TRUE BLUE: Sergei Bubka will defy Spanish authorities on theNikeaffair.
email_title: BUSH'S THREAT IN GAMES SQUABBLE;BARCELONA NOTEBOOK

Email_Body: TWO of the world's biggest suppliers of sports equipment -Nikeand Adidas - have warned the US Government that trade retaliation against China would seriously hurt their Hong Kong operations. Nike, the world's largest producer of sports shoes, said if punitive tariffs were imposedNikewould have to sharply raise prices or shut down its entire operation in China. Such action would undermine its regional headquarters in Hong Kong, where there would be thousands of job losses, the company said. Nikehas urged the US Trade Representative to target China's state-run shoe factories instead of those operated by private enterprises.Adidas, another industry giant, said all of its financing, purchases and shipping for Adidas merchandise manufactured in China was done through businesses in Hong Kong, which would be hard hit by US trade retaliation.For example, a company such as Yue Yuen Industrial Ltd, the large sports shoe maker which listed on the Hong Kong stock exchange in June, could see its business seriously wounded.But the powerful American Textile Manufacturers Institute (ATMI) has demanded that the US impose punitive tariffs on key Chinese exports to match dollar-for-dollar the losses suffered by the US from China's trade barriers.Sth CHINA MORNING POSTEND OF STORY
email_title: Nikesays trade boot is on the other foot

Email_Body: OLYMPICSNikesays OKNikeInc. said Monday its trademark problem in Spain won't affect the ability of national teams to wearNike-produced uniforms in the Olympic Games. "Despite repeated press reports that link our trademark case to Olympic uniforms, there is no connection legally," said Lindsay Stewart,Nikevice-president and corporate counsel. He said the uniforms bearing theNikelogo comply with International Olympic Committee regulations that restrict advertising. "The courts in Spainhave ruled we may not sell apparel or advertise our apparel until our trademark case is settled," Stewart said. The company will provide the national uniforms to the track and field teams of the United States, Nigeria, Algeria, Paraguay and the Bahamas. SWIMMINGLocal medal haulPaced by Hannah Buchanan, Shelly Price and Shannon Marklew, Nepean-Kanata Barracudas rose from 22nd place a year earlier to seventh in provincial swim team age-group rankings as they turned in a solid effort at the Ontario Long Course Age-Group championships in Etobicoke. Buchan, 10, who had earned under-10 high point honors at the recent Eastern Ontario championships at the Nepean Sportsplex, earned silver medals in the 200 and 400 freestyle; Price, 12, took silver in the 200 breaststroke and Marklew, 13, bronze in the 200 metre butterfly. Gloucester-Ottawa Swim Club's J.M. Mills, 12, broke the existing Ontario record of 1 minute, 7.92 seconds in the 100 backstroke with a 1:07.74 clocking but finished behind Windsor's Greg Meisner who swam the distance in 1:06.03, provincial and Canadian records. Mills also missed a Canadian record in the 50 freestyle as he swam 26.30. The national mark is 26.20. Mills added a second silver in the 100 freestyle and a bronze in the 100 butterfly. GO teammate Stephanie Zarins took gold in the 200 breaststroke and Gord Veldman of Ernestown earned gold in the 200 backstroke. Julie Gravelle, 12, of GO won three silver and two bronze; Jean Ooi, 14, of Ernestown a silver; Perth's Kelly Crampton a bronze and the Cornwall 4x50 freestyle relay squad of Erin Berard, Corina MacRae, Harveen Soodan and Andrea Bedard the 11-12 girls relay bronze.(Citizen staff and news services.)
email_title: DIGEST

Email_Body: NikeInc. posted a 23% increase in profits for its latest quarter Friday and said worldwide orders continue to be strong. The leader in athletic footwear said it earned a record US$76 million (US98 cents a share) in the quarter that ended Nov. 30, compared with US$61.5 million (US80 cents) a year earlier. Revenues rose to US$875.8 million from US$743.4 million. For the first half of its fiscal year,Nikeearnings have jumped to US$198.6 million (US$2.58) from US$176 million (US$2.30) in last year's first half. Revenues have risen to US$1.98 billion from US$1.69 billion.
email_title: Nikeprofits jump

Email_Body: A yearlong dispute regarding the use of Michael Jordan's likeness on NBA sportswear has been resolved in principle - without litigation or arbitration - to the satisfaction of His Airness,Nikeand the league.But, according to Doug Stamms,Nike'smarketing attorney, ''The ink is not dry yet.''Deputy commissioner Russell Granik is comfortable, though. He saysNike,Jordan and the NBA are ''finding a way to live together and prosper.'' The three parties worked out their differences as they applied to the Olympics and have now dealt with broader issues pertaining to league merchandising.For whatever it's worth (David Stern is on call to caddy for Michael), the league has retained the right to market Jordan's likeness.Had it not, the NBA probably would've substituted Mirage hotel and casino owner Steve Wynn. MAGIC FORMULA: Nobody says it better than columnist Dan Shaughnessy. For example, in Tuesday's Boston Globe, he noted, ''Magic Johnson has said the same things so many times that even Arsenio will have a hard time pretending he's hearing the stuff for the first time.''Then again, Magic has said so many things so many different ways, the truth is often ignored in the process.Out of one side of his mouth, Magic fingered the Cavaliers for allegedly backing off him because of a bandaged scratch on his arm, a premise Craig Ehlo and Cleveland teammates labeled absurd.Out of the other side, Magic tried to lay guilt trips on Suns owner Jerry Colangelo and Karl Malone for voicing concerns regarding the risk of playing against Johnson, who's infected with the AIDS virus. According to Magic's warped logic, their ulterior motive was to ice the competition.To be perfectly blunt, Magic's assertion that Malone's comments influenced his decision is sheer twisted wreckage.Immediately following his final retirement, he was quoted extensively as saying he didn't even know what Malone said until 36 hours after his decision. Shortly thereafter, he created a more convenient story line.In the last couple weeks, I figure Magic has been fawned over by the national media roughly a dozen times in his effort to sell his book to people who'll buy anything and to document his world-class athleticism for womanizing.Not once has an interviewer refuted Magic on the Malone discrepancy or other bogus contentions. Not once has one challenged his preposterous Cavaliers theory. Not once has anyone questioned his supposed concern for others as a factor in his retirement, when, in reality, the only person he ever really has been concerned about is himself. CLIFF NOTES: As far as I know, Cliff Robinson is the only player in the league who plays three frontcourt positions every night and defends them all with honor. Occasionally, he must even clamp down on a particularly hot off guard.Each season, the 6-9 Trail Blazers' minutes, blocks, steals, rebounds, scoring, (turnovers), field goal and free throw percentages improve. Yet his lack of recognition is constant.Each season, Robinson plays in every exhibition, every regular-season game (251 and counting) and every playoff game (58) and doesn't fool around in any of 'em. Yet his durability, versatility and competitive spirit are largely ignored.Each season, the Blazers have advanced well into the playoffs, and Robinson's role has increased. Yet each time ballots are cast for best sixth man, most improved or best defensive player, he's one step removed from an afterthought.How can that be? It must be because Cliff has such a hard last name to remember compared to vote getters such as Sarunas Marciulionis, Detlef Schrempf and Dan Majerle. WONDERLAND: That's not all I'm wondering about today:- I mean, is Larry Bird working in Boston's front or back office?- Shouldn't the Nets be thinking of getting Vernon ''Can't we all just get along?'' Maxwell to enhance their chemistry?- Think Clifford Ray gets visibly excited about a comeback each time he reads a Warriors box score? How about Martha Raye?- Does the Hornets' Allan Bristow entertain any plans of getting into coaching this season?- Will the Hornets' Johnny Newman's field goal attempts dip to fewer than 15 a game now that he has broken his shooting hand?- Have the Hornets really replaced Newman with David Wingate? Who's his agent, Marion Barry?- Since the Celtics obviously have to do something (signing first- rounder Jon Barry to a fair contract is too easy), I wonder who'll be the lucky unrestricted free agent VP Dave Gavitt falls in love with but won't pursue? Who will Gavitt trade for, then ignore because he expects to get paid? Who will Gavitt claim off waivers, then release before his first per diem check is due?Charles Barkley wanted to take his little girl to see Malcolm X but felt it was too violent, reports column castigator Frank Drucker. ''So he's waiting for Spike Lee to make the sequel, Malcolm PG.''
email_title: Jordan, league fashion a compromise

Email_Body: Deion Sanders finds that it pays to play two sports.Sander's three-year endorsement contract withNikecalls for him to earn $ 1 million a year as long as he plays both baseball and football. If Sanders, an outfielder for the Atlanta Braves and cornerback for the Falcons, decides to play only one sport, the contract's value drops to $ 100,000.Nikealso has an option to drop the contract completely if Sanders chooses one sport, according to The (Atlanta) Journal-Constitution.
email_title: Nikevalues versatility

Email_Body: If his contract to endorseNikeathletic shoes and apparel has any bearing on Deion Sanders's future, the dual sports star is likely to continue juggling his football and baseball careers for the next few years.The three-year deal signed this summer calls for Sanders to receive about $ 1 million annually from the athletic shoe manufacturer, provided the Falcons cornerback/Braves outfielder plays at least a half-season in each of the two sports, according to an attorney who reviewed the contract forNike.Sanders also receives a bonus based on the sales volume of the model of shoe he wears in each sport. The penalty if Sanders were to give up either sport is a stiff one, dropping the contract's value to about $ 100,000.Nikealso maintains an option to terminate the contract should Sanders decide to play one sport.Sanders's deal withNikewill likely push his sports-related earnings for 1992 close to the $ 4 million mark.His contract with the Braves, extended through the regular season, will pay him $ 972,000 and offers Sanders the opportunity to add another $ 100,000 or more in postseason bonuses.Sanders's new one-year "supplemental contract" with the Falcons calls for about $ 2 million. However, he figures to forfeit between $ 400,000 and $ 500,000 in penalties for missing the club's first regular- season game and one or two midseason games while he joins the Braves for baseball's postseason.Sanders's attorney, Eugene Parker, could not be reached for comment. Lisa DeNeffe, public relations manager forNike, declined to comment on the contract.DeNeffe did say the company was "tremendously excited" by the early results of Sanders's endorsement deal."It's definitely a good fit forNike," said DeNeffe. "We've done the one [commercial] spot so far and, based on our consumer hotline, it's had great response. We're definitely looking forward to furthering our relationship with Deion."DeNeffe said a second commercial featuring Sanders would debut around the Christmas holidays but declined to offer details.Reports have indicated Sanders and comic Dennis Leary, who appears in the first commercial, will discuss why Santa Claus is not generally portrayed as a black man.Staff writer I.J. Rosenberg also contributed to this report.GRAPHIC:color photo RAN ON D-1: $ 4 million man Deion Sanders has a $ 1 million endorsement deal withNike.Deion Sanders's deal withNikelikely will push his sports-related earnings for 1992 close to the $ 4 million mark. But there are considerable losses if he doesn't play both football and baseball.
email_title: BASEBALL: THE BRAVESNikedeal worth $ 1 million a year, making Sanders a $ 4 million man

Email_Body: For advertisers, 1990 was a strange year. Early on, the outlook was rosy. Ads glowed with glasnost to celebrate historic changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. But by fall, ads addressed more somber topics - a souring economy and the Persian Gulf crisis. USA TODAY's Stuart Elliott looks back in this review of best and worst ads of 1990:  Nikehits again:Nikejust might be the most creative advertiser of 1990. The best of the best was ''Bo's family reunion.'' Few thoughtNikecould top its ''Bo knows'' spots, among the best ads of 1989. But this wildly imaginative TV ad presented 15 versions of superstar Bo Jackson, excelling in every sport from football and baseball to horse racing and golf. Other highlights:- ''Announcers,'' a TV ad that parodies football, sportscasters andNike'sown ads.- Two more TV ads in the Mars Blackmon series directed by Spike Lee and co-starring Lee and basketball titan Michael Jordan. They drew more praise than Lee got for his movie Mo' Better Blues.- A new campaign called ''Rock 'n' roll tennis.'' One TV ad paired Andre Agassi and the year's most unlikely pitchstars - the Red Hot Chili Peppers, a cult punk-rock band.Not every ad clicked. Someday, Mr. Rogers is going to spankNikefor the ''Mr. Robinson's Neighborhood'' ads with David Robinson. Can you say, ''Cease and desist''? Agency: Wieden & Kennedy Inc. In the pink: Year 2 of Energizer's series of E.B. ads surpassed the fun of Year 1, when Energizer also made the Best Ads list. Just when viewers least expected it, along came the pink rabbit to march through ads that mock other ads. Targets in '90: ads for air fresheners, long-distance telephone service, soft drinks and hemorrhoid remedies.Most hilarious: an ad that simultaneously made fun of foreign films and coming attractions. It took the form of a preview for a make-believe movie called Dance with Your Feet. To complete the illusion, the ad ran in movie theaters as well as on TV. Agency: Chiat/Day/Mojo Inc. Politically speaking: For everyone who despairs over mud-slinging political ads, hope surfaced in Minnesota's U.S. Senate race. Deftly humorous TV ads for long-shot challenger Paul Wellstone were a big reason that he upset the two-term Republican incumbent, Sen. Rudy Boschwitz.One ad, ''Looking for Rudy,'' was based on the comic documentary Roger & Me. The ad followed Wellstone as he searched in vain for Boschwitz so they could debate.Another ad, ''Fast-paced Paul,'' presented Wellstone cramming all his positions into a single 30-second spot. The rapid spiel was necessary, the ad explained, because Wellstone couldn't match Boschwitz's ad budget. Agency: North Woods Advertising, adman Bill Hillsman's free-lance shop. Doggone clever: A TV ad for Milk-Bone dog treats put smiles on the faces of viewers by putting a smile on the face of a dog. The ad likened new Milk- Bone tartar-control products to toothpaste. The inspired video image that closed the sale: a bull mastiff sporting an enormous ear-to-ear grin. The silly sight was made possible by special effects that superimposed a human mouth onto the dog's mouth. Agency: FCB/Leber Katz Partners. These ads fly: The growing glut of car ads in '90 made it hard for any pitch to stand out. Kudos to Chrysler's Eagle line for ads that manage to stand out and be outstanding.The ads all are in the same style: As an announcer asks a car buyer why he or she purchased a 1991 Eagle model, there's a wry twist to a familiar joke.Sample: A man says Eagle Talon ''rated higher in overall quality of workmanship than cars like Ford Probe and Honda CRX.'' Says the announcer, actor Orson Bean: ''I'd like to see a breakdown of all the competition.'' The man replies, ''Now, let's not get spiteful.'' Agency: Campbell-Mithun-Esty Advertising. Comebacks: A hot trend that began in '88 - revival ads - reached fever pitch. To get the attention of baby-boom consumers, advertisers brought back familiar characters, slogans and jingles of the '50s, '60s and '70s.A warm Welcome Back to: Punchy, Hawaiian Punch's punch-drinking cartoon kid; Coca-Cola Classic's reunited hilltop choir; Nipper the RCA dog, joined by a junior puppy partner; a cartoon baby named Horton whose first words are ''Ruffles have r-r-r-r-idges''; and Joe DiMaggio back at bat for Mr. Coffee.Agencies: N W Ayer, McCann-Ericson, Ammirati & Puris, DDB Needham Worldwide, Meldrum & Fewsmith Advertising.GRAPHIC:EAR PHOTO; color, Rob Brown, USA TODAY; PHOTO; color (2) CUTLINE: BO JACKSON: Star ofNike'simaginative ad. Email_Body: Inside a suite in New York City's Grand Hyatt hotel, three of America's most celebrated black sports and entertainment figures were trying to make peace with Operation PUSH, the Chicago-based civil rights organization. Georgetown basketball coach John Thompson was there. So was actor/filmmaker Spike Lee. And Chicago Bulls all-star guard Michael Jordan. The three celebrities gathered on a Sunday evening last September as paid representatives ofNikeInc., the world's largest athletic shoe and apparel company. Their mission: End the boycott PUSH had called againstNiketo protest its minority hiring and business practices.The meeting was scheduled afterNikeChairman Phil Knight failed to satisfy PUSH during a widely publicized session in August on the Georgetown campus. "It was John Thompson's idea," Knight said of the New York meeting. "I was complaining to John that we weren't getting anywhere in negotiations. John's line to me was, 'You think too much like a white man. Let me go negotiate with them.' "But the negotiations failed -- and the two sides haven't met since. Now, as the largely unsuccessful boycott continues, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who founded PUSH, refers toNike'sblack endorsers as "shoe salesmen" who seem more interested in making money than "fighting for equal opportunity."PUSH officials complain thatNike-- though its annual retail sales to black consumers total hundreds of millions of dollars -- has no high-ranking black executives and does no business with black-owned banks and advertising agencies. According toNike, 320 (7.5 percent) of its 4,243 U.S.-based employees are black. Blacks account for about 4 percent of the population of metropolitan Portland, Ore., whereNikeis based.Nikehas announced it will hire a minority vice president this year and name a minority to its board of directors by 1992. Knight said the appointments probably will be black. "If we were perfect, we would've gotten that taken care of sooner," he said, adding thatNikewas formed in 1972 as a small, "too male and too white" company.Thompson, a $ 200,000-plus-a-yearNikeconsultant, said no organization has a right to tell another how to do business. Jackson responded in a recent interview: "That detachment from ethical responsibility, that detachment from racial justice, as opposed to personal aggrandizement, is not in the best tradition of fighting for equal opportunity."The boycott has had little apparent effect onNike, whose earnings soared 58 percent last September, October and November over the corresponding period in 1989. Jackson said the PUSH boycott will continue untilNikenegotiates "a joint plan for economic justice." The boycott may be difficult to sustain: PUSH, citing economic troubles, recently laid off its entire 12-person national staff.Thompson gently poked fun at Jackson last fall, giving him a pair ofNikesneakers for his 49th birthday. "When Jesse opened the box, he broke out laughing," Thompson recalled. But now Jackson isn't smiling. "Those sneakers," he said, "they're still in the box."GRAPHIC:PHOTO, AFTER AN AUGUST 1990 NEWS CONFERENCE, THOMPSON, RIGHT, AND JACKSON CONFERRED ABOUT OPERATION PUSH'S BOYCOTT OFNIKETO PROTEST ITS MINORITY HIRING AND BUSINESS PRACTICES. CAROL GUZY; PHOTO
email_title: Boycott or Not,NikeSales Push Upward;Jackson's Troubled Operation No Match for Thompson, Lee and Jordan

Email_Body: In the end, what's good for the sole is what counts. While athletic-wear giantsNikeand Reebok account for about half of the running shoes sold in this country, the May issue of Consumer Reports plugs lesser-known and less-costly Saucony Jazz 3000.The Saucony shoes rated higher thanNikeand Reebok models in recent tests conducted by the magazine's athletic equipment experts.However, the magazine did recommendNikeAir 180 and Avia ARC 2040MZ for men. For women, New Balance W997 and the Reebok Running Pump also impressed the in-house testers.

Email_Body: Liz Dolan,Nike'svice president of corporate communications, says five minutes on the medal stand won't make anyone think Michael Jordan or any otherNikeclients represent Reebok."You'd have to have been living in a cave to think that," Dolan said. "In Michael's case, he'd wear [the official uniform] for five minutes; he'll wear our shoes his entire career. There's no risk that anyone will think he's affiliated with anyone butNike."That's why, Dolan said,Nikeis encouraging all of its Olympic medal- winners to wear the official medal-ceremony uniform, which is a Reebok product. Reebok's contract is believed to be worth about $ 4 million.Jordan has said "there is no way in the world I am wearing a suit that's made by Reebok," but he also has hedged slightly, saying he'll decide "when the time comes." USA press chief Mike Moran has said that any medal winner who does not comply will not be permitted on the awards stand, and that no athlete ever has refused to wear the official uniform. In the previous two Olympics, Levi Strauss held the contract.The Dream Team'sNikeclients also include David Robinson, Charles Barkley, Scottie Pippen, Chris Mullin, John Stockton and assistant coach P.J. Carlesimo.Bureaucracy winsSprinting star Bruno Marie-Rose has been excluded from the 100-meter race at the Olympics because French organizers forgot to register him. Marie-Rose, a member of the team that set a world record in the 400-meter relay in 1990, was told Thursday he was excluded from the 100 because of the error by French track officials. "It's so stupid, so idiotic," he said. Serge Bord, who already plans to step down as head of France's track team after the Games, assumed responsibility for the mistake.
email_title: BARCELONA OLYMPICS OLYMPIC GAMES Olympic sidelines News and notes from around the GamesNike:Wearing Reebok OK

Email_Body: It's enough to make a TV sports fan choke on his beer. There he is innocently watching his basketball or baseball game expecting it to be interrupted by commercials, sure, but jock-style commercials aimed at jock-style guys.Suddenly he's bombarded by incredible images that flash by his eyes.Images of a sci-fi creature emerging from a pod as humanoid, a cartoon daredevil bouncing inside a giant running shoe, or an animated runner, escaping from his own burning scrapbook image. Fifteen-second and 30-second mini art films created and directed by some of the world's most talented filmmakers (including Canada's David Cronenburg) and commissioned byNike,to advertise its new 180 air-cushioned running shoe.Are these commercials art? Or commercial art? Or just commercial? And what are they doing on jock TV?The campaign was born last year whenNikeasked its ad agency, Wieden & Kennedy, to come up with a campaign for the 180 that could run internationally. (The 180 was the firstNikeathletic shoe to be introduced everywhere in the world at once.)The problem was how to communicate to people who speak different languages and idolize different sports heroes, sports heroes beingNike'straditional creative approach.The creative folk at the agency solved the problem by suggestingNikecommission filmmakers from different parts of the world to express what the 180 meant to them.The new 50 per cent larger air cushion was to be the main focus, with no spoken words, just music and sound effects.The resulting commercials were surprising, even toNike.Originally scheduled to launch in North America on the Superbowl, the spots were held back.Another commercial was hurriedly put together, usingNike'straditional sports hero approach, and featuring triathalon champ Mark Allen. The jocks were safe from art for a time.But when the artsy ads got good reaction in Europe,Nike'spresident, Phil Knight, decided to try them out at home. And according toNike,they've worked.Could it be that people who are ready to shell out $ 150 for a running shoe ($ 169.99 in Canada, $ 192 with tax) are also ready for art in their running shoe commercials?The artistic approach has some opponents, however. It prompted one columnist to criticizeNike'sprint version of this campaign as a self-motivated form of corporate sponsorship of the arts.But, in fact, the campaign is nothing of the sort. It was motivated by the need to find a practical solution to a problem, that of creating international advertising. And in the process, filmmakers were given the kind of artistic freedom seldom granted to commercial illustrators or directors.They were also given exposure to a world-wide audience that would likely never have heard of them otherwise. Not a bad trade.If you haven't seen theNike180 commercials, you still have a chance until June. David Cronenburg's sci-fi thriller, and Dutch animator Evert de Beijer's giant running shoe are still airing on CTV during Blue Jays games.*Mooooove Over, Cancows: That singing cow is back in the news again. It seems the bronze Bessie award-winning crooner for HP Sauce is one more example of an American performer appearing in a Canadian commercial.Yes, that lounge-cow is from Arizona, born and bred.According to writer Bill Martin, creator of the HP commercial, ad agency Bozell Palmer Bonner would have cast a Canadian cow, but the weather in November was too cold for the shoot. They cast this particular cow because she looked like a Canadian cow, and had no ear-notches or curly horns.As one of 26,000 cows in the herd, how did she get the part?Says Martin: "She probably didn't move away as fast as the other cows when they came to take Polaroids."She didn't have to know how to sing either. In close-up, the singing cow was actually a puppet, and the voice was Canadian musician Tim Tickner.By the way, fans of this commercial can look forward to a follow-up in September, starring a chicken and a pig named Wilbur, pitching four new sauces from HP. They're Americans too.The duo won't be singing, but you can bet the commercial will be fun and sophisticated.Meanwhile, rumor has it the cow has signed up an agent and will be appearing in Vegas next month.
email_title: Nikefinds sports fans like artsy commercials
