Email_Body: Shares ofNikeInc. ran into trouble Monday, when the Beaverton, Ore.- based athletic-shoe maker reported weaker-than-expected earnings.Nikestock sank 2 1/2 to $ 47 1/2The nation's largest maker of athletic shoes reported earnings of 93 cents per share for the quarter ending Feb. 28 - a 12% jump from 83 cents. Analysts had been expecting the company to earn about 97 cents. ''The results were a little disappointing,'' says Gary Jacobson, analyst at Kidder Peabody & Co. ''It appears thatNikeis losing momentum.'' The company cited higher expenses related to the introduction of new products such as the Air 180 running shoe. Expenses rose to 22.7% of revenue from 19.9%. Revenue in the period rose 39% to $ 802 million.Nikesaid it plans to continue its ''aggressive'' marketing campaigns.Nikeinventories rose 121% in the period, suggesting sales are slowing dramatically, notes Mike Shea, analyst at Black & Co. Overall orders rose 12%, led by apparel (up 17%) and overseas footwear (up 43%). But domestic shoe orders, which account for more than 60% of sales, were flat. ''That's a red flag,'' Shea says, adding that he recommends selling the stock if you own it.Meanwhile, the nation's No. 3 athletic-shoe maker, L.A. Gear, had better news. It restructured loan agreements with major lenders. L.A. Gear shares rose 1 to $ 13 1/2. Last month, the Los Angeles-based athletic-shoe maker reported a fourth-quarter loss of 35 cents a share, vs. net income of 58 cents the year before. Thumbs down: Warner-Lambert Inc. shares dipped 1 7/8 to $ 72 1/2 after its Alzheimer's drug, Cognex, failed to win approval from a Food and Drug Administration advisory committee. The FDA said the drug was no more effective than a sugar pill. Alex. Brown & Co. lowered its rating to a sell from neutral. Shearson Lehman Bros. lowered its rating to underperform from outperform.''The drug was highly touted and an important and major factor in many people's thinking about the fundamental outlook for Warner-Lambert,'' says Alex. Brown analyst Richard Stover. Analysts project that Cognex, if approved, would eventually generate more than $ 500 million in yearly revenue.Company officials and some analysts insist the drug will get FDA approval by 1993.- James Kim and Rhonda Richards
email_title: Weaker earnings tripNikeshares

Email_Body: NikeInc.'s newest director already has a job assignment.Monday, Georgetown University basketball coach John Thompson was named toNike'sboard of directors. Tuesday, he joined the personnel committee, which oversees actions involvingNikeemployees. Directors are required to serve on a committee.Last year, Operation PUSH, a Chicago-based civil rights group, alleged that the athletic shoe and apparel company denied blacks adequate employment and business opportunities and called for a boycott ofNikeproducts.The Rev. Willie Barrow, vice chairman of PUSH's board of directors, says Thompson's appointment is a victory.''Since we sat down with them, they're now doing many of the things we had on the drawing board,'' he says. ''We've awakened their responsibility to the black community. I congratulate them.''Not so fast, saysNikespokeswoman Liz Dolan.''The boycott has not affected us at all by objective measures,'' she says. ''Sales are up dramatically and we have the same level of support from suppliers and retailers.''(The boycott) has sensitized us to some issues, so now we are much more open about making announcements about what we are doing instead of just quietly doing them.''Nikedirectors are paid a fee of $ 10,000 a year and $ 2,000 for every board meeting they attend. Board meetings are held bimonthly.
email_title: Operation PUSH hails Thompson appointment

Email_Body: Liz McColgan, who has had more colds than impressive races recently, got well Sunday at theNikeWomen's Race. The great Scot broke the world best for 8 kilometers (4.97 miles) by 14 seconds. Her time of 24 minutes, 48 seconds was worth a $ 25,000 bonus from Clairol, plus the $ 5,000 first prize.Lynn Jennings, who set a world-best 25: 02 here last year, was second (25: 08) and Judi St. Hilaire third (25: 09).''When I'm on song, it's going to take a very, very special person to beat me,'' said McColgan, who last year won the World Championships 10,000 meters and the New York City Marathon. ''I'm very confident of my ability.''But McColgan, 28, who has an 18-month-old daughter, was apprehensive on Mother's Day. She was 41st in her last U.S. race, the World Cross Country Championships in March, which Jennings won for the third consecutive time.McColgan blamed overtraining, which led to a cold and two subsequent illnesses. ''I had something to prove to myself and everyone else,'' she said.After passing 2 miles in 9: 47 Sunday, she began pulling away from Jennings and eased up at the finish. ''I reckon I could have run 24: 32 if I had run through,'' she said. ''I really wanted a good race to say, 'Hey, I'm back to my old self.' ''McColgan, who owns a home in Gainesville, Fla., is the favorite for the 10,000 meters at the Olympics. She will run the Cleveland Revco 10K next Sunday and the Advil Mini-Marathon May 30 in New York.''She's incredible,'' Jennings said. ''She's the best in the worldGRAPHIC:EAR PHOTO; color, Porter Binks, USA TODAY; PHOTO; b/w, Porter Binks, USA TODAY CUTLINE: LIZ MCCOLGAN: Offers Barcelona preview. CUTLINE: LOOK OF A CHAMPION: Liz McColgan's world record inNikerace was worth a $ 25,000 bonus.
email_title: McColgan sets world best inNike

Email_Body: Children's Television Workshop, the educational production company responsible for bringing Sesame Street to public television, has announced that it would begin work on an ambitious new series intended to improve children's reading and writing skills.     The series, called The Ghostwriter, is scheduled to begin on PBS stations in the fall of 1992. The target audience will be children 7 to 10 years old.      Children's Television Workshop announced the beginning of production after receiving a commitment for a $ 5-million grant fromNikeInc., the maker of athletic shoes. Nana Griller, the assistant director of information at Children's Television Workshop, said theNikegrant was the largest single corporate donation ever made to a children's television show.     The show's overall budget will be $ 20-million for 48 episodes, with about $ 8.8-million coming from PBS and Children's Television Workshop, and the rest from other foundation and government sources.     Richard K. Donahue, president ofNike,said the company would also help promote the project. He said that could mean guest appearances by some of the athletes, including Michael Jordan, Bo Jackson and David Robinson, who have endorsedNikeproducts.     Nikedecided to be the sole corporate backer of the series as part of a larger program aimed at advocating education for inner-city children, Donahue said.     He said the company's commitment in this area had been longstanding and was not related to recent criticism for urging children to buy expensive athletic shoes, a charge he called a "canard."     The executive producer of The Ghostwriter is Elizabeth Nealon, formerly vice president of MTV International.     The show's stylistic approach will incorporate visual and musical techniques borrowed from MTV, Ms. Griller said.     The format will use graphics to make reading the print on screen more entertaining.     The stories will center on six children, three girls and three boys, and their interaction with an unseen ghost who can communicate with them only through writing.     Children's Television Workshop will also publish an accompanying magazine and teachers' materials, as well as computer games using the series' characters."China Beach' returning in June for seven weeksAssociated Press    LOS ANGELES The Vietnam War series China Beach will return to temporary active duty next month, network officials announced last week.     The Emmy-winning series was suspended in December, but ABC had promised to air the seven remaining episodes made for the 1990-91 season.     The episodes will air for seven weeks, beginning June 4, in the coveted prime time slot of thirtysomething.     The network move follows a lobbying campaign by executive producer John Sacret Young, who urged thousands of supporters to write protest letters to ABC executives.     The series has been placed on hiatus twice and pushed to new time slots three times during a four-year run on ABC.     The future of China Beach is not yet known. ABC will announce its fall schedule this week.
email_title: New PBS show will promote reading

Email_Body: Sonny Vaccaro has leftNikeInc., where he worked as a roving basketball consultant, to become chairman of DIC Sports Marketing, a division of DIC Enterprises. The Burbank, Calif. -based company specializes in producing animated TV shows, such as The Real Ghostbusters and Super Mario 3.During Vaccaro's association withNike,he helped sign college coaches John Thompson (Georgetown), Jerry Tarkanian (Nevada-Las Vegas), Bobby Cremins (Georgia Tech) and Jim Valvano (N.C. State) to lucrative shoe contracts. Vaccaro produced the Dapper Dan High School All-Star basketball games and helped runNike'ssummer basketball/tutoring camps.There have been allegations of conflict of interest and suggestions that the coaches' association with Vaccaro helped them enroll the best young basketball talent.Vaccaro told USA TODAY that his new job should put to rest such allegations.Vaccaro will work on sports- and TV-related projects for DIC, the first of which is the Sept. 17 NBC broadcast of the Comic Relief celebrity special presented in Chicago by Michael Jordan last month. Proceeds from the show are earmarked for charities to aid children and the homeless.DIC also has been preparing a Saturday morning cartoon featuringJordan, Wayne Gretzky and Bo Jackson that is expected to premiere this fall.
email_title: Nikeconsultant joins sports marketing firm

Email_Body: Athlete Bo Jackson and his fellowNikeendorser, Chicago Bulls basketball player Michael Jordan, are taunted by name in new series of TV commercials for rival Reebok's Pump sneaker; but no one asked their permission or paid them for privilege; CBS has so far resisted running commercials, andNikeis threatening legal action (M)
email_title: NEW REEBOK ADS ENRAGE RIVAL BY TAUNTINGNIKE'SSTAR ENDORSERS

Email_Body: Nikebroke off its sponsorship deal with KATRIN KRABBE, the world sprint champion from Germany who is expected to receive a four-year ban after failing a drug test.The sportswear company also abandoned a similar deal with GRIT BREUER, Krabbe's teammate, who also tested positive for a banned substance. Krabbe, the 100- and 200-meter world champion, and Breuer, the 400-meter European champion and world silver medalist, tested positive for Clenbuterol, a muscle-building substance.Krabbe, in an interview published yesterday by the German magazine, Super Illu, said the athletes did not know that Clenbuterol was on the list of banned drugs.THOMAS SPRINGSTEIN, coach of the two athletes, has admitted giving the drug to the two sprinters. His contract withNikehas also been canceled.
email_title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;NikeEnds Deal with Krabbe

Email_Body: Deion Sanders's "Prime Time" line of clothes is being sidelined - for now.Public relations agent Jerry Davis said Mr. Sanders's multiyear contract withNikemeans that the fleet-footed star has to wearNikeapparel and shoes."We have to wait and see whatNikedecides to do," says Mr. Davis. Could it be thatNikewants to introduce a Deion-inspired line of athletic wear of its own?Mr. Davis won't say, but industry watchers say that they wouldn't be surprised if a Prime Time shoe or warm-up suit is in the works.Until then, however, people who have Prime Time clothes may consider themselves lucky because no more orders are being taken, said Mr. Davis."So whoever has it may have a collector's item," he said.Even without promoting Prime Time, Mr. Sanders is pretty busy.His other irons in the fire include:A recently aired national commercial forNike.Possibly franchising the hair salon business he owns with Falcons teammate Jamie Dukes.A potential deal with NFL Properties for trading cards.The Falcons offering him an extra $ 1 million to report to training camp early.And the Braves attempting to sign him for the rest of the season.L.A. linkIt began as computer talk - messages flashed back and forth across an electronic bulletin board during the Los Angeles riots.Some who participated were content to assign blame for the violence. But Beverly Thomas, a resident of the Crenshaw neighborhood, wasn't. She wanted to dispel some of the stereotypes and help rebuild the affected areas."We're going to make change," she typed. "Either come in with us or get out of the way."Ms. Thomas was surprised by the offers of aid she received.Today, the 40-year-old computer consultant is helping develop a computerized bulletin board that matches people in the riot-torn area who need help with those willing to give it.Via her keyboard, Ms. Thomas, whose handle is Kaiju, has lined up about 30 accountants, bankers and entrepreneurs. They've helped about 20 merchants fill out loan applications.Her work doesn't end there.Ms. Thomas, who has a master's degree in business from California State University, is also considering formation of an investment pool to capitalize business start-ups."I want to see our community stand on its own economically," she said.Black ChamberThinking of starting a new business? A group of Atlanta professionals and entrepreneurs wants to help.Plans are under way for the Sweet Auburn Black Chamber of Commerce, which would help develop and market black businesses, said Lea O'Neal, a member of the chamber planning committee. She is also president of Black Atlanta Transplants.One planned chamber component is a six-week program for child entrepreneurs.The chamber will accept members in the fall.People . . .Larry K. Barnhill has been named director of operations for the Gwinnett Civic and Cultural Center, scheduled to open in November. Previously, Mr. Barnhill was director of operations for Pyramid Arena in Memphis, Tenn.Compiled from staff, news service and published reports.
email_title: BUSINESS REPORT: ON MINORITIES Deion's apparel benched for now

Email_Body: Is Deion Sanders the next Bo Jackson?Nikemay think so. With Jackson, the baseball/football star the shoe company currently has under contract, facing an uncertain future because of hip-replacement surgery,Nikeis trying to negotiate a multiyear deal with Sanders, the Braves outfielder and Falcons cornerback. Both Sanders and his agent, Eugene Parker, acknowledge a deal may be close, but neither will discuss specifics.Dusty Kidd, the public relations director forNikeInc., would comment only in general. "It would be dangerous to compare Bo Jackson to any other athlete," he said. "It's sort of like Michael Jordan and Scottie Pippen. One is vastly more recognized than the other. Every athlete has their own identity."Deion's market has never been tested," he said. "For a while last year I don't think people really thought of him as a two-sport player because he had spent most of his time in the minors in baseball. But the way he has started has changed people's mind s,and people have this romance with players who participate in two sports."Sanders, asked the range of money aNikedeal might reach, said, "It's more than my football contract." Sanders is coming up on the last year of his four-year deal with the Falcons, which will pay him $ 750,000.Sanders does not have any major endorsements, but Parker said equipment maker Mizuno, among others, has talked to his client.Parker also saidNikeapproached Sanders before the baseball season started, and Sanders's fast start would appear to give him some negotiating leverage with the shoe giant.GRAPHIC:Photo: Deion Sanders Asked how much aNikedeal might pay, he replied, "More than my football contract."
email_title: BASEBALL: THE BRAVESNikeknows Deion: Shoe deal in works

Email_Body: During the NBA All-Star Game telecast last month,Nikeintroduced the seventh edition of its best-selling Air Jordan basketball shoe.Nikeexecutives described the evolution of the 1991 Air Jordan during recent interviews at their nine-building, 570,000-square-foot headquarters in Beaverton, Ore.:" FEBRUARY 1989:Nikedesigner Tinker Hatfield flew to Chicago for a meeting with Chicago Bulls guard Michael Jordan. They agreed that the '91 shoe would be lighter with a snugger fit. " FEBRUARY 1990: Jordan examined drawings of the shoe withNikeexecutives in Santa Monica, Calif. The shoe was too heavy; Jordan suggested removing some leather from its tip." MARCH 1990: A rough prototype Air Jordan was shipped with technical specifications to the Fong Chuan Rubber Enterprise factory in Taiwan.Nikesneakers are manufactured in the Far East because U.S. labor costs are "no longer competitive," company chairman Phil Knight said." AUGUST 1990: Production began with materials imported from Germany, Australia, Japan, Argentina and the United States. As many as 150 assembly-line workers were involved in stitching the shoe's perforated leather upper. Each pair took about two days to make." NOVEMBER 1990: About 170,000 pairs of sneakers were ready to be shipped. Cost to manufacture, box, crate and deliver one pair of Air Jordans to a port in Taiwan: $ 29.65." JANUARY 1991: The shoes arrived inNikedistribution centers in Memphis, Portland, Ore. and Greenland, N.H." FEB. 4, 1991: Retail stores received their first shipments. Dealers' cost for each pair: $ 68.75." FEB. 10, 1991:Nikeintroduced its lightest-ever Air Jordan -- a size nine weighs 15 1/2 ounces. A 30-second commercial featured singer Little Richard in the role of a "genie in the lamp" who granted Mars Blackmon (the Spike Lee character) one wish. Did Blackmon want $ 1 million? No. A new car? No. He only wanted a pair of . . . what else?Nike'ssuggested retail price for the Air Jordan: $ 125.
email_title: The Evolution of a Shoe

Email_Body: PORTLAND, Ore. (AP) - Basketball superstar Michael Jordan, in an unprecedented move, has cost the NBA millions of dollars by forbidding it from selling apparel bearing his image, givingNikeInc. those rights exclusively. Jordan, 28, who led the Chicago Bulls to their first NBA championship last year, is among the most charismatic - and profitable - personalities in the league.While the NBA no longer may sell Michael Jordan T-shirts, you'll find all the Jordan wear you want atNike,which already rakes in about $200 million a year on Jordan's image.The company's Air Jordan basketball shoes, named for Jordan's gravity-defying on-court performance, are among its best sellers.Jordan has been on theNikepayroll since 1984. He will earn $21.2 million this year for hawking products ranging fromNikeshoes to Wheaties cereal to Gatorade sports drink, according to published reports.Industry sources saidNike,the world's largest marketer of athletic shoes and clothing, persuaded Jordan to end his apparel licensing involvement with the NBA."Nike,with Jordan under its wing, is strong-arming the NBA," Jeff Atkinson, editor of Sports Trend magazine in Atlanta, said.ButNikespokesman Dusty Kidd denied the company had any part in the decision. "It's strictly between Michael and the league," Kidd said.Seth Sylvan, who manages licensing for the NBA, said the league made $1.1 billion last year from the sale of licensed products. But he downplayed the effect of Jordan's decision."We're still in the business of licensing our logos and players," he said.Souvenirs other than apparel are not affected.
email_title: Jordan tells NBA it can't sell clothes bearing his image

Email_Body: At least he gets top billing. Godzilla, the Tokyo titan, takes on Charles Barkley, the bull of Barcelona, on tonight's MTV Music Awards. But since the battle is an ad forNikeand the monster is bare-clawed, guess who wins.''Have you ever thought about wearing shoes?'' Barkley asks after sending the prehistoric predator crashing through skyscrapers.Though Barkley bests the beast,Nikesees the pair as evenly matched in personality. They're both ''sort of a bad guy but also sort of a sympathetic hero,'' says spokesman Dusty Kidd. While Godzilla lurches around the city, ''Charles has some cartoonlike characteristics, being very outspoken and playing in an exaggerated way.''Agency Wieden & Kennedy made the ad to run in Japan, butNikeliked it enough to import it. Teaser ads have been running since baseball's All-Star Game in July.Barkley (6-foot-5, 252 pounds) was animated in an earlierNikead, and Godzilla (328 feet, 60,000 tons) has pitched Dr Pepper and Konica, says his agent, Hank Saperstein of UPA Productions. His 19th film, Godzilla vs. Mothra, will open in the USA next spring.
email_title: Godzilla meets Barkley on MTV

Email_Body: Ever sinceNikemiffed some parents this fall with its commercial of "Mr. Rogers' Neighborhood" - which featured NBA star David Robinson saying "Can you say kick some butt'?" - the nation's No. 1 athletic shoe company has been making amends. It has been casting Mr. Robinson in less ambiguous, heroic roles.A month ago, he appeared in a commercial playing piano with a 78- year-old concert pianist. Now Mr. Robinson is being plastered all over America (except Atlanta) on 1,200 public service billboards in 20 markets. He's urging kids to stay in school. The billboard shows Mr. Robinson hoisting a stack of books. A basketball sits on top of them. Beside the photo is a huge headline that reads: "Don't Be Stoopid. Stay In School.Nike."The ads are the lastest in the series ofNike"Stay In School" promotions that the company says are intended to "reach the youth of America in a positive way about achievement and excellence as it relates to both education and athletics." Another ad, featuring another NBA star, Michael Jordan, and actor/director Spike Lee aired over the weekend.Nike, and other expensive athletic shoe makers, such as Reebok, have stepped up their public service activities in the last year as they've come under pressure by minority and public interest groups concerned about the popularity of the shoes among inner-city youths and resulting crimes.; Hold the adsThe 1960's are considered the Golden Age of Advertising. That's when Americans delighted in watching commercials such as Alka-Seltzer's hall- of-fame "No matter what shape your stomach's in" ads, which featured bouncy music and shots of every shape of human stomach imaginable - from a belly dancer, to a fat guy working a jackhammer, to a woman arguing with a chubby man on the street while poking him in the stomach with a pointed finger.In those golden days, less than half of America (43 percent) wanted television without commercials, according to a Columbia University study. Thirty years later, the university reports, almost two-thirds of America (67 percent) wants its TV, hold the ads."The novelty value of commercials a quarter-century ago kept this percentage (of people who want commercial-free TV) down," reports Video Storyboard Tests Commercial Break newsletter. "But the novelty has all since evaporated and viewer complaints about commercial clutter have progressively grown. Older age groups, in particular, have a higher preference for television without commercials."Even more disturbing to advertisers, reports the newsletter, more than half of America (54 percent) is willing to pay "a small amount yearly" for TV without commercials, whereas in 1960 less than one in four (24 percent) said they'd pay for commercial-free TV.The goods news for advertisers: The percentage of people who say they frequently welcome a commercial break (36 percent) has not changed in 30 years; and, while more people want fewer, or no commercials, today more viewers (57 percent, up from 43 percent) believe "some commercials are so good that they are more entertaining than the programs."; Back againTrue to the title of his book, "Against Gravity," adman Ed McCabe has quit Miami advertisng agency Beber Silverstein & Partners, and returned to New York, after only eight months on a quest to build the Miami agency into a powerhouse like his first shop, New York agency, Scali, McCabe, Sloves. Mr. McCabe - variously described during his 30- year career as brilliant, cryptic and abusive - said he'd been toying with the idea of leaving Beber for a few months."I found myself facing the opportunity to do things my own way, and I had to take it," he told Adweek magazine.The magazine reports most of Miami's advertising community won't miss him, because it wasn't terribly bowled over by McCabe in the first place. Though he's the youngest copywriter ever to be installed in the Advertising Hall of Fame (at age 35), he wasn't the rain maker he was expected to be. "The copywriter produced only a few scattered showers," the magazine reports.Mr. McCabe, who could not be reached for comment, is opening his own New York shop, McCabe & Co., and reportedly is pursuing the $ 40-million Volvo account which his first agency, Scali, McCabe, Sloves, was forced to resign last month over a faked commercial scandal that rocked the industry.; QuicklyJim Osterman has been named the new editor of Adweek magazine's Southeastern edition, replacing Martha Nolan, who left to pursue freelance writing. Mr. Osterman joined the magazine in 1984 as a reporter and rose to managing editor in 1988.
email_title: BUSINESS REPORT: ON ADVERTISING; Mr. Robinson makes amends

Email_Body: Liz Dolan,Nike'svice president of corporate communications, says five minutes on the medal stand won't make anyone think Michael Jordan or any otherNikeclients represent Reebok."You'd have to have been living in a cave to think that," said Ms. Dolan. "In Michael's case, he'd wear [the official uniform] for five minutes; he'll wear our shoes his entire career. There's no risk that anyone will think he's affiliated with anyone butNike." That's why, Ms. Dolan said,Nikeis encouraging all of its Olympic medal-winners to wear the official medal-ceremony uniform, which is a Reebok product. Reebok's contract is believed to be worth about $ 4 million.Jordan has said "there is no way in the world I am wearing a suit that's made by Reebok," but he also has hedged slightly, saying he'll decide "when the time comes." USA press chief Mike Moran has said that any medal winner who does not comply will not be permitted on the awards stand, and that no athlete ever has refused to wear the official uniform. In the previous two Olympics, Levi Strauss held the contract.The Dream Team'sNikeclients also include David Robinson, Charles Barkley, Scottie Pippen, Chris Mullin, John Stockton and assistant coach P.J. Carlesimo.Albania's swim 'team' Frank Lescas was thrilled about his far-fetched journey from Pennsylvania to Albania as that country's entire Olympic swimming team. Until he saw the practice pool. There was no water in it. "People sometimes don't have running water in the house," he said. "How can I expect them to put gallons and gallons of water in a 50-meter pool?" Lescas, a sprinter from suburban Philadelphia who never had been in Albania, will be a 21-year- old senior at La Salle in September. He wasn't good enough to make the U.S. team. Lescas continued his swim training at home, then arrived in Albania on July 10 in preparation for his trip to Barcelona.
email_title: BARCELONA OLYMPICS Olympic sidelines News and notes from around the GamesNike:Wearing Reebok OK

Email_Body: Sneakers caught in the ripples NEW YORK: Beachcombers along Oregon's north coast are finding new treasures from the sea _ hundreds ofNikesport shoes washing ashore a year after a cargo ship mishap. Since April 2, Burke and Lisa Pond have found more than 140Nikeshoes on beaches between the mouth of the Columbia River and Gearhart. Steve McLoed, who until recently had never owned aNikeshoe, now boasts about 70. Shirley Tarnasky has found 50Nikesnear her oceanfront home in Rockaway Beach. But the shoes are not coming ashore in pairs, prompting Tarnasky to form the Sneaker Society to promote sneaker swaps at which people can trade to create matching pairs.Niketransportation manager Rich Hastings said yesterday that the shoes were from five boxcar-size containers that fell from a Seattle-bound cargo ship in the Pacific Ocean in May last year. About 40,000 pairs ofNikeswere lost. Associated Press
email_title: SNEAKERS CAUGHT IN THE RIPPLES

Email_Body: Foundation launching nasty ad drive to shame major companies into bringing manufacturing back to USTHE Made in the USA foundation is launching a nasty ad campaign against major US companies that manufacture products overseas -andNikeis the first target.The foundation has scrapped its original plan for more than US$ 50 million (S$ 81 million) "Buy American" campaign and instead will try to shame major marketers, such asNike, into bringing some of their manufacturing back home.According to the trade magazine Advertising Age, the non-profit lobbying group has US$ 1 million set aside for theNikeeffort and plans to break the ads in 20 major market daily newspapers soon, as well as in union publications.Several papers have been approached, but the media buy has not been made. Made in USA had been encountering "some resistance" from newspapers in running the ad, said chairman Joel D Joseph. However, he declined to name the newspapers."We presume they are refusing becauseNikeis a big advertiser," he said.The ads urge consumers to send their "old dirty, smelly, worn-outNikes" to chairman Philip Knight to "sendNikea message" to "come back home to the United States and start making shoes here once again".Oregon-basedNikeboth sources and manufactures components of its shoes in the US but final assembly is generally done in the Far East.The ad, which was created in-house, urges consumers to tell Mr Knight they will not buy another pair ofNikesuntil the company commits itself to building a US manufacturing plant.The anti-Nikead follows an Oct 1 letter to Mr Knight from Mr Joseph, who askedNiketo manufacture its top-of-the-line shoes in the US, since Mr Joseph contends they can be made here profitably.Nikesaid it had no apologies for its manufacturing practices."We are the No. 1 company in the business so we're willing to take the shot," said Dusty Kidd, public relations manager atNike. "We would hope that those who criticise us would be better informed."Mr Kidd said 1,200 ofNike'sUS workforce of 6,500 people were involved in manufacturing.  "We have more manufacturing workers in the US than any other athletic footwear company," he said.Nikesaid it did not directly employ any workers in the Far East but employed contractors there that undertook the manufacturing."Any factory we use is required to meet their government's standards for minimum wage," Mr Kidd said. He added that it was unlikely thatNikewould start any counter-advertising.Explaining why Made in the USA was going for this "take your gloves off" approach instead of a general "Buy American" effort, Mr Joseph said: "I think we can get more results and more (news) coverage."We're going for impact."He refused to name other marketers which the group plans to target. "We are promoting buy American, but we also are taking our gloves off and going after companies that we think are responsible for the trade deficit," he said.In a news release, Made in the USA also noted that in the 1980s, more than 65,000 US footwear workers lost their jobs whenNikeand other shoe manufacturers moved manufacturing to Indonesia where the workers are paid 14 US cents an hour.It cited a press report which said it costsNikeUS$ 5.95 to make a pair ofNikeCrosstrainers in Indonesia while these shoes retail from US$ 44.95 to US$ 124.99 in the US."We go where we can make the best product at the best price. If we made Air Jordans in the US they would (sell for) US$ 300,"Nike'sMr Kidd said.
email_title: Made in the USA lobby running afterNike

Email_Body: Basketball magnate Michael Jordan andNikeInc. recently, stepped to the rescue of Chicago Public Schools with checks totaling $ 200,000.Emblazoned on the sides of giant tennis shoes, the checks were presented to Chicago Public Schools Superintendent Ted D. Kimbrough at a press conference given by Jordan andNikeInc. Chicago school officials had announced in August that the budget wouldn't allow for the extracurricular activities, and entire programs, including athletics, would be wiped out.The basketball hero andNikePresident Richard Donahue revealed at the press conference that each would contributes $ 100,000, helping to save not only athletics, but other activities, including the chess and debate teams.  "We feel very dedicated to the school system here in Chicago, and to the kids so that they have something to hold on to, and hopefully, some motivation in their lives," Jordan said.Other contributors also came to the rescue when Kimbrough sent out a call to corporations and athletes.  "We have collected, including the two $ 100,000 shoes, $ 915,000," Kimbrough announced at the press conference.  "We still have a goal of $ 1.2 million."Jordan indicated that his benevolence isn't shortsighted.  "If next year is not what it's supposed to be, we're going to be there to try to support it," Jordan said.GRAPHIC:Picture, Jordan greets fan 4-year-old Jawaan Walker after announcing his andNike'scontribution to Chicago Public Schools, as Superintendent Ted D. Kimbrough holds shoes bearing the $ 100,000 checks.
email_title: Chicago Schools Troubled, Jordan AndNikeTo Rescue

Email_Body: When it comes to marketing, adidas is the David of the athletic-shoe industry. But it's challenging GoliathNikeon equal footing in the NCAA basketball Final Four. Adidas will spend just $ 23 million on U.S. marketing this year. It isn't even buying any TV ad time for Saturday's semifinal games or Monday's championship. While the West German firm supplied just three of 64 Division I NCAA playoff teams, two - Duke and Indiana - still remain.''This is absolutely perfect,'' says adidas USA president Peter Pirner. ''We only have a slingshot, but it's aimed well.''Nikewill spend $ 150 million on marketing this year - including tourney TV ads. It also supplied shoes to 29 playoff teams. Michigan and Cincinnati remain.No matter what happens Saturday, aNikeand adidas-backed team will face off in the championship - with an expected viewership of nearly 70 million. So while ads can cost up to $ 300,000, adidas is getting off cheap.''This is great exposure value,'' says Joyce Julius Cotman of sports- marketing consultant Joyce Julius and Associates.
email_title: Adidas shoe-to-shoe withNikeat NCAA

Email_Body: Bobby Crawford of Houston Dwight D. Eisenhower High and Marcus Thomas of Houston MacArthur face four-game suspensions this season for attending the summerNike/All-American Academic Camp.Marcus Mitchell of Houston Langham Creek is eligible to play the entire season, though he participated in the camp last month in Indianapolis.All three are among 11 Texas players who competed for the Houston STAND (Students Taking Action Not Drugs) basketball team organized by former Houston Rocket John Lucas and partner Jay Parker for a series of summer tournaments, including theNikeevent. ''I don't understand how you have a right to keep a kid from going outside the state to showcase his skills,'' said Lucas.The University Interscholastic League, which governs Texas public high school athletics, has a rule making it illegal for a student-athlete to attend invitation-only camps.''It's not really a camp. Only two hours a day are spent on basketball,'' said Bob Gibbons,Nike'sselection committee chairman. ''This is really an academic program. It would be great to open it to 5,000 kids, but that's not feasible.''Only 125 student-athletes are admitted to the five-day event.UIL athletic director Bill Farney said such ''invitation- only'' camps exploit players and don't give borderline players a chance to go.''DoesNikeaccept anybody that wants to come to that camp, on a first- come, first-serve basis?'' said Farney. ''The answer to that question would be an indication as to whether it is an invitational camp.''We're not branding all invitational camps as bad. But when you have a regulation passed by the schools, unless it's changed by the same procedure, it has to be enforced.''Farney has left the executive committees in each district to determine the eligibility of the players in question. Harris County District Court Judge Sharolyn Wood ruled in June that participation would not be in violation of UIL rules as long as ''no financial aid, prize, gift, or thing with monetary value is given to and/or received.''Crawford and Thomas are considering legal action against the UIL.Seven other players are waiting for rulings from five district executive committees. The remaining player, Marvin Hill, attends Houston St. Pius, a member of the Texas Association of Private and Parochial Schools, and is not affected by the UIL decisions.''It's so unfair that these other kids are being penalized because they attend public schools,'' said Susan Gunnewig, Hill's guardian.
email_title: Summer camp costly for Texas players

Email_Body: Michael Jordan: Nerd. An unheard-of association - until this year's National Basketball Association All-Star Game on Sunday.That's when shoe makerNikebreaks its newest commercial, featuring the high-flying maestro of the NBA airwaves, Mr. Jordan, dressed as Mars Blackmon, the nerdy character played by Spike Lee in previous Jordan/Nike ad campaigns. In the commercial, a genie (played by '50s rocker Little Richard) grants Mars Blackmon (Mr. Lee) one wish. That wish, naturally, is to soar like Mr. Jordan and - every flatfoot's dream - slam-dunk a basketball."Look, Mom, I can fly," says Mr. Jordan, the Mars Blackmon look- alike as he sails through the air.The commercial launches the sixth generation of Air Jordan tennis shoes, whichNikepremieres on the air - and Mr. Jordan premieres on his feet - each year at the All-Star Game.GRAPHIC:Photo: Michael Jordan (left) helps make a wish come true for Spike Lee's character Mars Blackmon (right) inNike'snew ads.
email_title: Nikenerd takes to the air, Jordan-style

Email_Body: AS every red-blooded American knows, some of the most memorable design imagery over the past decade has been lavished not on buildings, but on athletic shoes.NowNike, the sports and fitness company that has brought forth Air Jordans and "Just Do It," has createdNikeTown, a 12,000-square-foot store in downtown Portland, Ore. The new store, which will soon be replicated elsewhere, may do for fitness merchandising what the Ralph Lauren stores did for home design.NikeTown is modeled after a town square surrounded by freestanding pavilions."Did you see the movie 'Back to the Future'?" asked Gordon Thompson,Nike'screative director. "We thought the town square would be a great idea forNikeTown." If it smacks of Disney's Main Street, that too, is part of the point."We've tried to combine the merchandising concepts of Ralph Lauren, the fun of Disneyland, the exhibitry of the Smithsonian and the atmosphere of F.A.O Schwarz," he said.The store, which opened in late November, uses video screens as major design elements. Like the Lauren stores, it is a total environment. In the Aqua Gear pavilion, where waterproof gear is sold, shoes and socks are mounted in front of an aquarium. Product colors are coordinated with those of the fish.Customers try on socks around a "video pond," above, composed of nine floor monitors, which substitutes video images of sharks and other creatures for water.Such achingly hip design, which includes an Air Jordan penthouse, signals a new approach to marketing byNike,which plans to open a similar store in New York next year."People want to be entertained while shopping," Mr. Thompson said. "This is like a movie for people to go and see."
email_title: CURRENTS;Just Like Going to The Movies

Email_Body: Nikeplans to tap the women's market in a big way. Sylvia Wong reportsFROM next year, women can look forward to a new range ofNikesports accessories fashioned just for them.Ironically, they have Reebok,Nike'sarch-rival, to thank for this.  Reebok's colourful and fashionable sports shoes, which took the world by storm in 1985, have madeNikesee that women want sports goods not just for sports but also as fashion accessories. So, the company -which exhorts couch potatoes and athletes alike to "Just Do It" -is launching a new range of shoes, tights, leotards, swimming costumes and other accessories. The range is aimed at women who are likely to buy totally coordinated outfits.John Chew, managing director ofNikeSingapore Pte Ltd, said the firm had to make its women's shoes less chunky and more colourful to match Reebok's appeal.Because women were less inclined to shop at sports outlets,Nikewould set up women's corners in department stores, Mr Chew said. The company would open 10 such corners in Orchard Road department stores next year.He said the women's market, which now accounts for only 12 per cent ofNike'sturnover in Singapore, was expected to double next year after the new range comes out.  But he declined to discloseNike'stotal turnover for Singapore.While women customers are getting more attention now,Nike'slargest customer base remains the men and "authentic athletes". Its best-selling shoes are those in its running range, followed by cross trainers, basketball and tennis shoes.Mr Chew said running shoes accounted for as much as 30 per cent of local turnover. AmongNike'smost popular models are the Huarache, Air Max and Pegasus models. The company will bring in an improved version of its Air Max model next year. The Air Max Plus will have an air cushion all around the sole of the shoe and will retail at slightly more than $ 200 a pair.Oregon-basedNikeInc reckons it has the largest share of the global sporting goods market.  For the year ended Nov 30, 1991, it said worldwide sales jumped 20 per cent from the previous year to US$ 3.2 billion (S$ 5.1 billion).Reebok International, its closest competitor, chalked up sales of US$ 2.7 billion for the same period while German brand Adidas was third with worldwide sales of about US$ 2.1 billion.Nike'slatest results show that for the quarter ended Aug 31, the company earned US$ 122.5 million, while sales grew 16 per cent to US$ 1.09 billion compared with US$ 947 million in the same period last year.In Singapore, turnover has doubled in the past two years sinceNikeset up its wholly-owned subsidiary,NikeSingapore, to handle its own marketing and distribution.  Before this,Nikewas distributed by Robertson Wilson.Mr Chew said the advantage ofNike'slocal agency was that it could focus its energies on selling onlyNikeproducts. Having a wholly-owned local agency also enabledNiketo carry out unique marketing strategies like its "Ekins" (Nikespelled backwards) programme.The local company employed three Ekins, whose job is to go round to sports clubs, corporations, schools and uniformed groups to advise people on how to buyNikeshoes."Consumers usually buy on the basis of colour but Ekins try to educate them that they should buy shoes suited to their feet. For example, people with flat feet, high arched feet or normal arched feet require different shoes," Mr Chew said.Nikealso took over the display of its products in the shops of its 100 dealers in Singapore. The local company provided display stands and signs to shops to control the image of its products.Mr Chew said that in Singapore it was a close fight betweenNikeand Reebok for the market leader position. Last year,Nikespent $ 1 million advertising its well known tag-lines like "There is no finish line" and "Just Do It" to match Reebok's "The Physics Behind the Physique".Nike'sad spending would rise by up to 20 per cent this year, Mr Chew said.The company has already lined up a series of new ads from the US, which will be screened soon.GRAPHIC:Who says women are the weaker sex?;NikeSingapore MD John Chew: the firm is launching a new range of sport accessories for women
email_title: Nikewants more women to "just do it'

Email_Body: When the National Sporting Goods Association's World Sports Expo opens a four-day run in Chicago July 15,Nikewill be conspicuous by its absence - and Atlanta's annual Super Show is the primary reason."We figured we were seeing 95 percent of the same people we'd already seen at the Super Show," said Mikal Peveto,Nike'smarketing manager/running apparel, in Atlanta this week for the Peachtree Road Race. "We looked at the cost - we were spending $ 4 million in Chicago - and decided to put that back into the retail segment."Instead, that money will be spent on flying representatives of Nike'stop 100 accounts to its home office in Portland for an annual sales message, new product displays and other programs aimed at the retail market. Nikewill get plenty of exposure from a recently completed agreement with The Athletics Congress (TAC) in which the company will provide uniforms for the U.S. teams participating in the Pan American Games in Cuba, the World Track and Field Championships in Tokyo and the 1992 Olympics in Barcelona.According to Peveto, the company will supply shoes and apparel to TAC, but not money."We will supply radical, bold uniforms, but uniforms that at the same time will be respectful of the games and the country," Peveto said. "Nike'sphilosophy is to push the envelope, so the public will see a bold interpretation of our nation's colors. It will be like pro tennis star) Andre Agassi, an attitude. The uniforms will make a statement. The attitude will be aggressive on race day. That fits the attitude of the United States. It's an aggressive, daring, prideful country and our uniforms will reflect that."FOOT PATROL: While running the Peachtree 10K course last Sunday, Peveto occupied his mind by conducting an informal shoe count. In one hour, he counted more than 1,200 runners wearingNikeshoes (53 percent of his total;Nike'smarket share is 51 percent). By Peveto's count, 18 percent of the runners wore Asics shoes, exactly that company's share. . . . Stan Clark,Nike'sSoutheast footwear specialist, says his company would like to increase its visibility during the Peachtree Road Race and will approach the Atlanta Track Club about increasing the size of its sponsorship. . . . According to Linda Hannon, this year's Peachtree Road Race Expo - moved from Colony Square to the Swissotel at Lenox Square along with race headquarters - was the biggest ever with more than 60 exhibitors. "This Expo is for Jane and John Runner,' and we hope they enjoy it," said Hannon, who coordinates the Expo. "We decided Buckhead was a more convenient location for the runners. Lenox Square definitely is the place to be on July 4 in Atlanta." . . . Athletics director Homer Rice has promoted and retitled several members of his staff at Georgia Tech, including Bernie McGregor (chief administrative officer), Kevin Bryant (assistant A.D./marketing) and Mike Finn (assistant A.D./communications). Jim Murphy will continue as chief financial officer. The changes will provide more authority for those working under Rice, who then will be able to devote more time to fund-raising and Tech's  role in the 1996 Olympics.ASTRO-NOMICAL PRICE: John McMullen, owner of the Houston Astros, is trying to sell his team for $ 95 million, although a recent report in Financial World magazine assessed the club's value at $ 92 million. Among a group negotiating to buy the team is Charles Duncan, former president of Coca-Cola. . . . South Carolina will host its third annual International Conference on Sports Business April 1-4 next year, according to Jerry Kissel, a professor in the university's school of athletics administration. . . . Atlanta World Cup officials will narrow a list of four sites - the World Congress Center, Inforum, the International Trade and Convention Center and the old Sears building - as prospective locations for the 1994 soccer games' media center and international broadcast center. "Hosting these centers would help solidify Atlanta as a communications and technology hub," said Atlanta World Cup chairman Lewis Holland. "It offers us a continuing business opportunity with long-lasting benefits." Chicago, Dallas, Denver and Phoenix are the other finalists for the centers.
email_title: SPORTS BUSINESS: DAVID DAVIDSON; Super Show savesNike$ 4 million Chicago trip

Email_Body: NikeInc., the world's largest footwear and sports apparel company, boldly stepped forward last week and bailed out the flagging Ben Hogan Tour when it signed a multiyear partnership with the PGA Tour.Nikethus assumes sponsorship of pro golf's premier satellite tour.  In doing so,Nikein effect allowed the financially struggling Ben Hogan Co.  off the hook.  Last year the Hogan Co. asked the PGA Tour to be released from its sponsorship, and it appeared for a time that pro golf might lose the closest thing it had to a feeder system.  TheNikeTour will commence in 1993 and will be structured almost identically to the Hogan Tour with a 30-tournament schedule of $100,000 to $200,000 tournaments.  The Hogan Co., based in Fort Worth, Texas, was part of the Minoru Isutani conglomerate (which also included the Pebble Beach Co.). The conglomerate crumbled earlier this year. Last spring the Hogan Co. became part of the AMF Cos.  Since 1990, the Hogan Co. had committed $3.5 million annually to the Hogan Tour but found it increasingly difficult to keep up the payments in light of its parent company's travails.  The PGA Tour courted potential sponsors. It had been rumored that Anheuser-Busch, Coca-Cola and Buick were interested, but nothing materialized.Nikestepped in at the last moment with what was reported to be a major financial commitment. TheNikeTour figures to prosper indefinitely in this new arrangement.  Whereas the Hogan Co. suffered losses last year reported to be $30 million,Nikeboasted revenue of $3.4 billion for its most recent fiscal year. Nikegot its first exposure to golf in 1983 in the form of golf shoes.  Since then, it has increased its exposure through affiliations with several PGA Tour players. Now it figures to reap enormous benefits on the advertising and marketing fronts.  The 1992 Hogan Tour will generate approximately $4.3 million in prize money, which represents a 41 percent increase over 1990.  Naturally, PGA Tour Commissioner Deane Beman is delighted with the new affiliation. ''Nike'scommitment ensures (this tour) will remain a vital part of the PGA Tour for years to come,'' he said.  Chip Shots: Entry deadline for the inaugural Missouri Handicap Championship is Sept.  16. The tournament is Sept. 24-27 at Highland Springs CC in Springfield.  The event is open to all golfers with a USGA handicap index of 40.4 or below.  The field is limited to the first 150 entries. The field will be split into four flights. Flight winners will be determined by the 36-hole cumulative net score.  Entry forms are available at all Missouri Golf Association courses. Entry fee is $85. For information, call the MGA at (314) 636-8994.  A practice round is Sept. 24 with the first round Sept. 25, second round Sept. 26 and final round Sept. 27. All play is stroke play.  KASP Sports 1380 AM offers a ''Fairways and Greens Winter Golf Getaway'' Dec. 9-13, which will feature rounds of golf at the Dunes, Citrus, PGA West Stadium and Mission Hills. The hosts will be Jay Randolph Jr., Jeff Smith and Jim Sheehan of KASP's ''Fairways and Greens'' show. Cost per person is $1, 500.  To register, send a $300 deposit (made out to KASP Golf Classic) with your name, address, phone number and handicap to: KASP Golf Classic, 2360 Hampton Avenue, St. Louis, Mo. 63139. Balance of payment is due by Nov. 1. The getaway also includes lodging, round-trip airfare to Palm Springs, Calif., cocktail party upon arrival, breakfast and cocktail party daily, awards dinner and prizes.  The PGA Grand Slam of Golf, featuring 1992's four major-tournament champions, will be held Nov. 10-11 at the Kauai Lagoons Resort in Hawaii.  Masters champion Fred Couples, U.S. Open champion Tom Kite, British Open champion Nick Faldo and PGA champion Nick Price will compete for a $1 million purse in the 36-hole event on Kauai's Kiele Course.  Ian Woosnam, the 1991 Masters champion, won last year's competition.  Richard Jarrett, Scott Edwards, Ed Schwent, who won the recent St. Louis District Championship, and Derre Ousley, who won the recent Metropolitan Championship, posted the top scores at Wednesday's USGA Mid-Amateur qualifying at Country Club at the Legends in Eureka and advance to the national Mid-Amateur Sept. 19-24 in Detroit. Jarrett took medalist honors with a par 72. Edwards, Schwent and Ousley posted 74s.  Jim Plummer of Lake Saint Louis won the Missouri Golf Association's Senior Tournament at Highland Springs CC in Springfield.  In the U.S. Amateur at Muirfield Village in Dublin, Ohio, Don Bliss was the only Missourian to make the cut. He was tied with six other players at 148 after two rounds of stroke play.  Justin Leonard, a junior at the University of Texas, won the championship 8 and 7 over Thomas Scherrer.  Coming Right Up: SUNDAY - District finals of the Chrysler National Long Driving Championships at Creve Coeur Recreation Complex, one of 15 district sites nationwide. Two players from the 26-person field will qualify for the finals in Boca Raton, Fla., Oct. 3-4. Each competitor will drive six balls that must land within a 40-yard-wide surveyed grid.  TUESDAY - The Blues March of Dimes Celebrity Classic at Norwood Hills Country Club. The noon scramble will be preceded by a putting contest and buffet lunch and followed by an auction and awards banquet with comedian George Lopez the emcee. For information, call 993-6670.  TUESDAY - USGA Senior Amateur qualifying at Greenbriar Hills CC.  FRIDAY - Florissant Valley Jaycees tournament at Paddock Country Club.  Pre-tournament festivities begin at 10:15 a.m. with golf at 11 a.m. Proceeds go to Marygrove (abused and neglected children). Entry fee is $75. For information, call 837-9999 or 837-2200.  FRIDAY - Columbia Golf Tournament, Columbia, Ill., with proceeds to the Missouri and Southern Illinois perinatal program at Cardinal Glennon Children's Hospital. Entry fee is $275. Format is threesome scramble.  Starts at 11:30 a.m. Call 577-5605.  Also on tap: Sept. 12-13 - Jim Jackson Memorial, Algonquin.  Sept. 24-27 - Missouri Handicap Championship, Highland Springs (Springfield).  Sept. 25 - Blue Choice Gateway PGA Pro-Am, Bogey Hills.  Sept. 27 - Blue Choice Gateway PGA Shootout, Bogey Hills. Email_Body: While the Chicago Bulls' Michael Jordan tries to blow the Los Angeles Lakers off the basketball court in the NBA finals, an Arlington inventor is putting on a full-court press against one of Jordan's biggest backers,NikeInc.Charles Petrosky, a 73-year-old inventor who works out of a cluttered shop in his basement, claims in a federal suit in Alexandria that the manufacturing giant swiped his invention when it marketed the Air Jordan sneaker, named after the Bulls' star guard."There's no doubtNikeknew about Mr. Petrosky and his idea for an air cushion sole before the introduction of the Air Max and the Air Jordan," said Joel M. Freed, Petrosky's attorney. Freed said his client patented an air cushion sole in 1978 and tried to sell the idea toNikelong before it first marketed the Air Jordan in the 1980s. The suit has been compared by attorneys on both sides to the case of a former Maryland man who accused several carmakers of stealing his idea for an intermittent windshield wiper now used on millions of vehicles. The Ford Motor Co. agreed to pay inventor Robert W. Kearns $ 10.2 million in that suit.Petrosky's suit, which is not expected to come to trial until the fall, seeks what could amount to hundreds of thousands of dollars in royalties and penalties.Nikesaid it has sold millions of pairs of Air Jordans at a retail price of more than $ 100 a pair.Nike'srepresentatives said its Air Jordan and Air Max shoes bear little resemblance to the air cushion sole patented by Petrosky."If you look at his proposed system and you look atNike's, no one would say they are the same," said Leslie A. Nicholson, one ofNike'sattorneys.  "More importantly, they work very differently."Nicholson also said that Petrosky's invention "is remarkably similar" to an air cushion sole patented in the early 1900s and that the suit may raise the question of whether Petrosky's shoe should have been awarded a patent.Petrosky's sole has several chambers that are connected by tiny holes. The chambers are filled using the kind of air pump and needle used to inflate basketballs.Nike'sair cushions are sealed plastic bladders that are inserted into the sole of the shoe.The theory behind each is that when the wearer walks heel to toe, the cushions redistribute the air so that the contours always provide support and a comfortable fit.Nikerepresentative Lindsay D. Stewart conceded that "the little guy-big guy phenomenon" is a factor in the Petrosky case and that a jury might hold more sympathy for the "basement shop-style" inventor.Petrosky, who was hospitalized recently for infections in his cardiovascular system, said he was eager to return to his beloved basement workshop on North Jefferson Street. Though he was given last rites recently, he has improved, and doctors have given him a favorable prognosis."When I get to feeling better, I'm going to get back at it," Petrosky said from his bed in Arlington Hospital. He said he continues to have new ideas and yearns for the days when he would "get up at 2 o'clock in the morning and go down to the basement and tinker around."Petrosky's tinkering dates to the late 1940s, when he was discharged from the Army after World War II and he and a friend opened a barbershop in the Ballston area.He dreamed up a razor strop that was mounted on a support beam so the barber could sharpen his straight razor without having to use two hands. Charles T. Petrosky, the inventor's 38-year-old son, said his father failed to patent the gadget and was angry when he later saw a mounted strop advertised in a trade journal."It was the fish that got away," the inventor's son said.From then on -- especially when the elder Petrosky retired from cutting hair in 1975 -- the inventor was far more mindful of patenting his ideas. He was awarded nine patents over the years, including one for a ring with a small blade attached that could be used in self-defense and another for a system designed to rid cities of rats.Petrosky's son said his father invented the ring because he was concerned about increasing urban violence and assaults against women. "If a woman slapped someone across the face with the ring on, it would scratch them -- mark them -- so that police could identify them easier," he said.The "classic better rat trap" sat on the bed of a truck and used bait to lure rats out of alleys, up a ramp and into a chamber where they could not escape. "All the man would have to do is drop by in the morning and pick up the truck," Petrosky's son said. While the truck was being driven away, the rats would be killed by fumes pumped into the chamber from the truck's exhaust, he said.Neither invention captured consumers' imaginations, and though a few rings were manufactured, none was ever sold, Petrosky's son said."I just never got off the ground in marketing," the elder Petrosky said.Freed refused to let the Petroskys discuss the inspiration for the air cushion sole because of the lawsuit. But a 1978 newspaper article said Petrosky had pinned his hopes for fame and fortune on what he described as a "walking-on-air" shoe."You take a common football needle and hand air pump, and just pump away," he told the now-defunct Washington Star. "A gunky substance inside seals it when you remove the needle. It's a million-dollar idea."

Email_Body: IN Swoosh: The Unauthorized Story ofNikeand the Men Who Played There, authors J.B. Strasser and Laurie Becklund say the Fortune 500 running-shoe company started by Philip Knight seemed destined to fail in the early days. Among the gaffes:*Nike'sJapanese manufacturer once proudly offered a discus-thrower's shoe called the Throw-Up.* When some prescient staffer signed Bo Jackson in 1986 tohustleNikeproducts, Jackson was playing minor-league baseball for the Memphis Chicks. Knight demanded to know who signed the guy so the idiot could be fired. * The authors describe executive retreats, known as "Buttfaces," enlivened by drinking marathons. And atNike'sfirst national sales conference, a rep from Texas did a brisk business selling marijuana pipes to colleagues.* WhenNikedecided to establish a new manufacturer in Korea, a company exec flew to Seoul and asked the desk clerk at his hotel, "Where can I find some shoefactories?"* And then there's the story about a Taiwanese business trip Knight and a colleague named Gorman made. At a toast-filled banquet, Knight, an old Asia hand, matched his hosts drink for drink. Gorman gave up and tossed his drinks under the table, where they splattered on Knight's pant leg. When the totally blotto Knight realized what Gorman had done, he knocked him down a flight of stairs. Then he vomited and lost a contact lens in the mess.GYPSY STYLINGSHankering for some old-fashioned gypsy string music? Try Gypsalero at the Glass Slipper, tonight at 9.The acoustic Vancouver quartet draws on influences ranging from Django Reinhardt to John McLaughlin and embraces the styles of samba, swing, classical, czardas and tangos.TRULY, MADLY, DEEPLY, AGAINJulia Roberts isn't the only one who found consolation in the arms of another after the big wedding that wasn't last summer.Her ex, Kiefer Sutherland has fallen for aspiring actress Lisa Stothard. Since their first dinner date last fall, the two have been inseparable - together nearly every day, including Thanksgiving at his home in Montana and Christmas with her folks in Wisconsin.For their two-week anniversary, he rented an ice rink, packed a picnic and took her skating. Not long after, she moved in.She's swooning. He's smiling. And word is they're looking at real estate in Los Angeles - together.HI HONEY,I'M HOMEI gave her little hints, and let her guess the rest.- a man on The Oprah Winfrey Show describing how he revealed to his wife that he had been a male prostitute.

Some have the word ''Independence'' scrawled on them. NIKEAPPAREL: U.S. athletes expect to wear theirNikeapparel at the Olympics, even though a Spanish court rejectedNike'sfinal appeal in a multimillion-dollar trademark feud, the U.S. Olympic Committee says.The entire U.S. track and field team has a contract to wearNikeapparel. Many other American athletes wearNikeshoes.''Based on what we have seen, we don't think the interpretation has anything to do with competitive gear or any other apparel or shoes worn by American or other athletes in the Games,'' USOC spokesman Mike Moran said.''We would hope this court would not attempt to dictate to any athlete from any nation what competitive gear they would wear in these Games.''Contributing: Karen Allen, Steve Wieberg

Email_Body: Shoe manufacturerNikeInc. is ''comfortable'' with analysts' estimates it will increase net income 14%-20% to between US$3.65 and US$3.85 a share for the fiscal year ended May 31. Chairman and chief executive Philip Knight declined to give specific estimates, although he did say total net income would increase about 15% for the year - a gain that would indicate total net income of about US$279.4 million (C$320.2 million) for the Beaverton, Ore.-based company. He said sales for the year topped US$3 billion, a 34% jump from year-earlier sales of US$2.2 billion. The company is scheduled to report fourth-quarter and fiscal year earnings today.

Email_Body: New-wave sneakers finally get their sea legs New York BEACHCOMBERS along Oregon's north coast are finding new treasures from the sea - hundreds ofNikesport shoes washing ashore a year after a cargo ship mishap.Since April 2, Burke and Lisa Pond have found more than 140Nikeshoes. Steve McLoed, who until recently had never owned aNikeshoe, now boasts about 70. Shirley Tarnasky has found 50Nikesnear her oceanfront home in Rockaway Beach.Some people are now carting sneakers and hiking boots home by the wheelbarrow load.But the storm-tossed shoes aren't coming ashore in pairs, prompting Shirley Tarnasky to form the Sneaker Society to promote sneaker swaps at which people can trade to create matching pairs.Niketransportation manager Rich Hastings said yesterday the shoes were from five boxcar-size containers that fell from a Seattle-bound cargo ship in the Pacific Ocean in May last year.About 40,000 pairs ofNikeswere lost but now were reaching Oregon after traveling thousands of miles on ocean currents, Mr Hastings said.Though coated with seaweed and filled with sand and long-neck clams, most of the shoes are as good as new after a cleaning, Ms Tarnasky said.She saidNikewas missing the boat by not taking more interest in the seagoing sneakers."The advertising possibilities are obvious," she said. "Shoes that can float around in the ocean for a year and not come apart at the seams just have to be good." AP

Bo Jackson has been unable to play a single inning of baseball in the '91 season, but he'll still make an appearance during the July 9 All-Star Game.Nikehas purchased four minutes of ad time during the prime-time telecast. And for the third year, the shoe company is using the game to premier a new Bo ad campaign.Past commercials - including the famous ''Bo knows'' - have been award- winners. The new series will kickoff with a 60-second spot that highlights this year's theme.Nikeis keeping details of the new campaign secret until next week. But this much has leaked: The new spots will have the world's most famous two- sport athlete singing and dancing and will involve several other guest athletes.Jackson injured his hip last January as an NFL running back for the Los Angeles Raiders. He was released by baseball's Kansas City Royals in spring training, then signed by the Chicago White Sox.Since the regular season began, Jackson has been working on an intensive rehabilitation program and vows to return to baseball.He is expected to remain on the disabled list, though, until August.GRAPHIC:EAR PHOTO; color, Nick Ut, AP CUTLINE: ALL-STAR SPOT: Injured hip or not, Bo Jackson will be showing off some new moves in a series ofNikecommercials that will debut during CBS' telecast of baseball's All-Star Game July 9.
email_title: Nikeknows hurting Bo to make All-Star show

Email_Body: OLYMPIC athletes could be running away from police in Barcelona . . . to stop them confiscating their track outfits.The possibility was raised last night after a Madrid court confirmed a ban on the U.S. firmNike, the world's largest sportswear seller, using the name on its clothing in Spain.Judges said the trademarkNikeon clothes there belongs to lawyer Juan Amigo, who bought the title 11 years ago from a sock firm which registered it in 1932. He wants up to £15million to allowNiketo use the name - taken from the Greek goddess of victory - during the Olympics.The American giant, which had planned a major showcase of new designs in Barcelona, says it now faces multi-million-pound losses.It has paid out huge sums for the right to outfit the American and Algerian track and field teams, including U.S. stars Carl Lewis and Mike Powell and Algerian Noureddine Morceli - favourite to win the 1,500 metres.The ban affects only clothing, notNikeshoes or the firm's familiar tick-shaped 'whoosh' logo. But if the court ruling is defied, athletes could face confrontations with police trying to enforce it.Last night, the American team was defiant. 'I'd like to see them try it,' said spokesman Mike Moran. 'The right to wear competitive gear of anyone's choice is an Olympic tradition.' Nikewas also refusing to back down. 'It is beyond the realm of possibility that these uniforms will be taken from the athletes,' said the firm's lawyer Lindsay Stuart. 'All these products were purchased or given to the athletes outside of Spain.'It would be the same as you going into Spain with aNikeT-shirt in your suitcase and having it taken away from you.' However, Senor Amigo's lawyer, Jose Antonio Hernandez, said: 'I trustNikewill comply with the law. If they don't comply, they'll have to pay the consequences.'After yesterday's ruling by Spain's highest appeals court, the American Embassy arranged a meeting betweenNikeand Senor Amigo - butNikecancelled the talks.The company's Madrid attorney, Enrique Jimenez Batalla, said it will not negotiate. 'We're of the opinion that the court order does not affect the Olympic Games,' he added. 'It affects the sale of clothing in Spain.'Mike Moran agreed. 'Spanish courts have no jurisdiction over our athletes and what they wear,' he said. 'I can't believe that anybody is going to take the uniforms off our athletes in the middle of the arena. It's too outlandish.'The International Olympic Committee has given governing bodies of sport around the world the right to make these marketing agreements.' Nike'ssetback came despite the support of the European Commission and the Spanish and American governments. They wanted the firm to be allowed to post a bond to let it advertise and sell clothes while the case was going on.One possibility is that it will get round the injunction by supplying athletes with outfits bearing its logo, but not the nameNike.ChoiceGRAPHIC:Displaying theNikename, Algeria's Noureddine Morceli - favourite to win the 1,500 metres in Barcelona - powers down the track. Now he could be forced to swop outfits . .. but they'll have to catch him first.
email_title: Make tracks, the police are after our vests!;OLYMPIC STARS RUN INTO TRADEMARK ROW

Email_Body: Imagine the following live broadcast during the Olympic Games this month: The Spanish police interrupt a basketball game and ask American athletes to strip. The officers then confiscate any shirts or shorts carryingNikeInc.'s logo.Although such a scene is a worst-case scenario, it could happen as a result of a dispute over trademark rights between the Beaverton, Ore., maker of athletic wear and Juan Amigo, a lawyer and associate ofNike'sformer distributor in Spain.  Nike,sponsor of American Olympic teams, had hoped for wide advertising exposure during the Games. But that hope has been dashed by a Spanish court ruling that bans the company from marketing its sports clothing during the Olympics. An appeal of the ruling, which does not forbidNiketo market its logo on shoes, is unlikely to be taken up in time for the July 25 start of the Games. 'Tremendous Economic Damage'"It's unfair that the court is supporting someone who is taking advantage of someone else's success and who is causing tremendous economic damage," complained Cesar Garcelan, marketing director of AmericanNike,the company's current distributor in Spain, who estimatesNike'sapparel sales in Spain at more than 2 billion pesetas, or $20 million, a year.The company must now sell its clothing line at souvenir stands in Barcelona without the logo. Lawyers forNikeestimate that at the Olympic stand, those lost apparel sales were expected to represent about 10 percent of total sales. Sports bags account for perhaps another 10 percent, with shoes, whichNikeis allowed to market, representing the bulk of the sales.Richard K. Donahue,Nike'spresident and chief operating officer, was quoted in the Spanish business paper Expansion as saying that the company's trademark rights have been "trampled" in Spain. No Negotiation 'With Pirates'A United States Embassy official said that while the Embassy was supporting the American company, trademark battles often occurred in Spain and companies usually agreed to settlements in which they paid to gain control of their names. Adidas A.G. had a similar case and wound up paying.But oneNikeexecutive said, "Our company's policy is not to negotiate with pirates."The formerNikedistributor and Mr. Amigo are now marketing their own identical range ofNikesportswear. Various people involved in the case contend that Mr. Amigo has asked for amounts varying from an early offer of $8 million to $10 million to settle the wrangle.Mr. Amigo and the lawyers who are handling his case were unavailable for comment.The nameNikewas first registered in Spain in 1932 by a Catalonian sock knitter and included a picture of a statue of an armless Greek goddess that stands at one of the stairway entrances to the Louvre in Paris titled, "The Victory of Samotrace." The word "NIKE" is written at the pedestal in this 1932 registration.Mr. Amigo bought the rights to this trademark, which had never been used, in 1982. TheNikecompany in Oregon was granted trademark registration for shoes in 1983 and for sports clothes several years later.Trouble started when the American company decided to change distributors in 1989 when its contract expired. Mr. Amigo, a friend and associate of the former distributor, according to SpanishNikesources, then sought to register as a trademark a practically identical version of the United States logo, as well as some 200 versions of names using the word "Nike."Spain's trademark registrar denied the application. Mr. Amigo then filed for an injunction banning the marketing ofNikeapparel in Spain on the ground that the two logos, the 1932 Greek goddessNikeand the American trademark, were "confusing for clients." A lower court ruled in favor of the injunction in March 1991.Nikeappealed to Spain's Constitutional Court, the highest court. In April 1991, the court accepted the proceeding, but a definitive ruling is not expected for two to three years, well after the summer games.Because the Constitutional Court normally rejects about 90 percent of all appeals,Nikeapplied to post bond as a precaution that would allow the company to market its logo until a final ruling was made. It lost this second proceeding July 3 and has appealed in a last-ditch effort that is unlikely to beat the Olympic deadline."It is absolutely incredible that this man, Mr. Juan Amigo, can affectNike'sexposure all over the world by preventingNikefrom dressing the U.S. team," Mr. Garcelan complained.GRAPHIC:Photo: A dispute over trademark rights is dashingNike'splans to market its sports clothing at the Barcelona Olympics. TheNikelogo was prominent atNike'ssuccessful retail store at the 1988 Games in Korea. (Nike)

Email_Body: IF, LIKENike, your range of sports apparel is named after the Greek goddess of victory, it may be embarrassing when it is worn by losers rather than winners.If, likeNike, you had plastered the images of these losers on billboards across the world in expectation of them being winners, it may be acutely, excruciatingly embarrassing. And if, likeNike, you had paid millions of dollars to these losers for the privilege, you might be wondering about the wisdom of your Olympic investment. BILLBOARD 1: "You have just passed Michael Johnson. More than most athletes will do this summer."Well, "most athletes" - the badminton players, for instance - were not competing against Johnson. But even within his chosen event, the 200m sprint, at least five runners proved they could pass theNike-emblazoned Johnson - he came sixth of eight in his semi-final, failing even to qualify for the final.BUBKA: brought to earthALLSPORTBILLBOARD 2: "Spanish air traffic control has been warned."They needn't have been. Sergey Bubka, the best pole vaulter in history, the long-serving,Nike-wearing world record holder (6.11m) and world champion, failed even to clear his opening height in the pole vault final. The Ukrainian made two attempts at 5.70m, then had a foolhardy, equally unsuccessful stab at 5.75m.BILLBOARD 3: "Ever heard the Algerian national anthem? You will."Oh no, you won't. At least, not as a result of the performance ofNike-toting Nourredine Morceli. He came a modest seventh in the 1500m final.OtherNike-brandishing flops:- Kenyan runner Richard Chelimo had his 10,000m gold medal taken away from him. He finished second in the race, but was awarded the gold after being judged to have been impeded by Moroccans. Unfortunately, the decision was later reversed.- Jim Courier, possessor of the most lucrative shoe contract outside American basketball - worth at least $ 4 million a year over five years - was beaten in the tennis quarter-finals by unknown Marc Rosset from Switzerland, 6-4, 6-2, 6-0.- Even the sixNike-soled members of the basketball Dream Team - notably Michael Jordan - made themselves unpopular by cynically draping American flags over their shoulders, in order to hide the Reebok logo on their tracksuits.Such footwear-associated cock-ups are uncannily reminiscent of goddessNike'smost famous image, depicted in a frieze on the Acropolis: on her way to deliver a message to the embattled city of Athens,Nikehas to stop to fix her sandal, making her late.
email_title: CURSE OFNIKE

Email_Body: German sprint star Katrin Krabbe is in danger of losing her sponsorship withNikeunless she is cleared of drug use next month by track and field's governing body, the German magazine Stern claims. Krabbe, Grit Breuer and Silke Moeller were suspended Feb. 15 by German track officials for manipulating urine samples at a training camp last year.
email_title: Nikemay drop Krabbe

Email_Body: Even if Bo Jackson's professional sports career is in limbo, Bo knows he can always hawk sneakers.A spokeswoman forNikeInc., provider of one of Jackson's many paychecks, says her company "has never cancelled a contract with any professional athlete due to injury or illness."Liz Dolan added that there is nothing in Jackson's contract with Nikestipulating he has to play two sports, or even one. Last spring, Jackson, whose football and baseball careers are jeopardized by a hip injury, signed an extension withNikethrough 1993."We're not going to cut him,'' said Dolan, commenting fromNike headquarters in Beaverton, Ore. "Our fitness center is named after Bo. So we'd like to invite Bo to come spend the next year rehabilitating himself at the Bo Jackson Sports and Fitness Center."Nikedidn't dump Michael Jordan when he had an injury that sidelined him in the second year of his contract. Dolan suggested Jackson's career may not be over."Bo is a surprising, explosive athlete. I wouldn't jump to any conclusions," Dolan said.Forbes magazine recently reported Jackson's annual endorsement income at $ 2.5 million. His agent, Richard Woods, calls the figure conservative.Jackson, the ultimate football/baseball hybrid, can be seen in ad campaigns forNike, AT&T, Cheerios and Pepsi. He also serves as spokesman for Bo-Med - medical supplies for weekend warriors, of which he is part of a joint venture - and he's pursuing the possibility of starting a restaurant franchise.But if Jackson is restricted to playing only one sport, or none at all, it certainly diminishes his superman aura."The two-sport thing has been the cornerstone of our campaign," Fred Schreyer,Nike'sdirector of sports marketing, said recently. "I have no doubt he would be a star if he played one sport, and he might be a celebrity as well, but I don't think we ever would have gone the way we have if it wasn't the two-sport thing."It's the guy who can do anything.
