Email_Body: For the second time in two years, Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., has won a Stephen E. Kelly Award for the best magazine advertising campaign. It won the $100,000 prize for work forNikeInc.The agency won the 1991 Kelly, announced last night by the Magazine Publishers of America at a dinner in Los Angeles, for three four-page print advertisements in aNikecampaign aimed at women. The campaign, which has been praised for appealing to women in an unstereotypical manner, was one of three Wieden & Kennedy campaigns forNikeamong the 25 nominees.The agency also won the Kelly in 1990 for aNikecampaign that appeared in magazines in 1989. The latest award is another in a recent series of honors for Wieden & Kennedy that included Agency of the Year from Advertising Age and Adweek.
email_title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;NikeCampaign Does It Again

Email_Body: Even athletes have to discover one day that life is full of those little compromises especially when sponsorship is involved. The ''Dream Team'' is one example. Reebok has sponsored the United States squad; several of the millionaire basketball players have individual deals withNike.Yesterday a compromise for the medal ceremony was reached all 12 players will wear the official US Olympic Committee uniform ''but in such a manner that does not reveal any commercial identification,'' according to the American basketball president, Dave Gavitt. Effectively the sixNikecontracted players, including Michael Jordan, Charles Barkley and John Stockton, will be able to cover up the Reebok identification marks but not displayNikesymbols. Nikemight at least find that preferable to Sergey Bubka, the world pole vault record holder, who adorns their advertisments. Bubka was photographed in training wearing his prescribedNiketop and Adidas shorts.  Whoops.
email_title: Compromise

Email_Body: John William Hart III is an insurance salesman in Los Angeles who alsowrites poetry about baseball. He has published two books, The Tao ofBaseball and Dugout Poems, both of which are in the Baseball Hall ofFame's library. Hart, 32, attends ball games (Dodgers) or listens to themon the radio (television stunts the imagination). After listening to thefirst game of the American League Championship Series, he offered this -an application of the Taoist philosophy - to the Toronto Blue Jays.Learning is the practice of remembering.The Tao is forgetting.Keep on forgetting until you reach the state of sitting.To win the World Series one must forget all.Have no private answer.And sit.New Bo Jackson videoNikeoffers Bo Jackson fans an advertising-entertainment hybrid for theChristmas market. It's a home video titled Bo Knows Bo: The Bo JacksonStory.Nikecollaborated with CBS"Fox Video to market a 45-minute programthat combinesNikeadvertising with a documentary-style look at the two-sport athlete's life. Advertising Age reports that Bo Knows Bo is the first product fromNike'snew sports-entertainment division.Nikeplans to market videos onother athletes.Steffi Graf, a pasta lover, is starring in a new German ad campaign forBarilla, the Italian pasta marketer. In addition to noodles, she's gettinglots of cash - $3-million (U.S.) over three years. Print ads and a 20-second television commercial show Graf wearing a variety of pasta asearrings, a brooch, pendant and ring.Hockey notesOn the Forbes listThere are several sports owners on the Forbes 400 list of the wealthiest  people in the United States. Email_Body: Move over Michael Jordan. There's some new Kids (& Kubs) on the advertising airwaves.     St. Petersburg's Three-Quarter Century Softball Club a.k.a. the Kids & Kubs is going to be featured in aNikecommercial during Major League Baseball's All-Star Game on July 14.      Editing of the commercial, which was filmed in late April at a Kids & Kubs game, hasn't been completed and aNikespokesman said the ad's plot is not being revealed before its airing.     "Given the setting and the types of players these gentlemen are, I think you can expect it to be a fun spot," said Dusty Kidd,Nike'sPR director. "They're an interesting group of guys down there."     Kids & Kubs president Paul Good saidNikehas supplied the club with sneakers for a number of years. For the commercial,Nikedonated $ 5,000 and 50 pairs of shoes to the softball club.     "They filmed a number of scenes and players, but I don't know what will finally end up on the screen," Good said. "This is super for us. This is the kind of thing you dream about, getting national exposure. You can't buy that."
email_title: Kids & Kubs reveal secret: It's the shoes

Email_Body: Kenny Anderson is the latestNikepitchman. The former Georgia Tech star has signed a multi-year deal, joining such marquee NBA players as Michael Jordan, David Robinson and Charles Barkley. Converse and Reebok were the other finalists for Anderson's endorsement.Nikeofficials plan to feature Anderson on a national television campaign this season. Anderson, a New York schoolboy legend, was selected No. 2 overall by the New Jersey Nets in last month's NBA draft.Richard Howell, who represents Anderson, said the contract forbids disclosure of financial terms or length. However, industry officials said after the draft that Anderson would probably receive a shoe contract for about $ 400,000 a year."We're obviously very pleased with it," Howell said. "You'll be seeing him on some ads."As for Anderson's playing contract, Howell said he has had one "philosophical" meeting with Nets officials and has another meeting scheduled within the next two weeks.
email_title: Anderson signs to representNike

Email_Body: The U.S.'S largest marketer of athletic shoes,NikeInc.,reported third-quarter earnings jumped 12%.The Oregon-based company, whose earnings were restrained by advertising and interest costs, earned US$70.7 million (C$81.7 million) in the quarter ended Feb. 28, or US93 cents a share, up from US$63.1 million, or US83 cents a share, a year earlier.However, the company said selling and administrative costs as a proportion of sales rose to 22.7% from 19.9% last year, reflecting advertising expense for the launch of several new products.
email_title: Third-qurarter earnings jump at sneaker-makerNike

Email_Body: With record sales and retail orders, dominant market share, and one of the top consumer awareness levels of any company anywhere, doesNikehave to worry about Operation PUSH?In a word, no.  "They've had no impact on our sales.  They've had no impact on our marketing," said Liz Dolan,Nike'scommunications director in Beaverton, Ore.  In this case, the "no-impact" action is the boycott of the athletic footwear firm's products that the Chicago-based black rights' group called for back in August. It was PUSH's way of protesting what it says isNike'spoor performance in reinvesting in the black community, when blacks are the source of so much of its revenue.Nikehas flatly refuted the charges on all fronts, and even counter-attacked by demanding that PUSH open its books.  Negotiations between the company and the civil rights group subsequently broke down."I have no idea what's going on there," said Dolan.  "They have not announced what they're going to do."What Operation PUSH didn't do is return phone calls, repeatedly, fromMarketing News.  However PUSH operators have stopped saying, "Say no toNike," when they answer calls."I don't think we understand completely what their motivation is," Dolan added, although she said that Reebok,Nike'sstrongest competitor, was in some sort of complicity with PUSH, as evidenced by a series of meetings between them and a Reebok ad in a PUSH publication.Reebok has denied this charge.At the heart of the dispute is PUSH's claim that some 30% ofNike'ssales come from the black community.  In line with that, PUSH saysNike'sreinvestment in the black community is woefully out of line.Nikeresponds that its sales are more in the neighborhood of 15% to blacks, that more than 15% of its hirings last year were minority group members, and some 7% of its employees are black.  The firm also boasts a line of famous athletic endorsers, including basketball's Michael Jordan."They know how hard we've worked" toward equal opportunity, Dolan said.  "We are the largest minority employer in Oregon.""Nikealready is an equal opportunity company," concurred securities analyst Alice Ruth of San Francisco-based Montgomery Securities, who follows the industry.  "[PUSH is] barking up the wrong tree."Ruth went so far as to say that, at the outset of the boycott call,Nikeactually may have received a sales boost."I heard about kids going into stores and deliberately asking forNikes," she said.  "Initially, [the boycott] may have had some pro-Nikereaction.  Their sales may be impacted by the economy, not by Operation PUSH."Ethnic experts thatMarketing Newstalked to lined up withNike."I don't necessarily like someone coming up to me and telling me how to invest my money," said Nathan Pope, principal of NPC & Associates in Landover, Md., the state's largest black-owned ad agency.  His only caution, though, was thatNikemanagement, "as sound and good businessmen, should know where their dollars are coming from.""In many instances, there's an over-reaction," said Jerome Williams, marketing professor at Penn State in University Park, Pa.  "I buy a lot ofNikeproducts.  I do a lot of running.  I think [Nikedoes] a good job.  But what are the responsibilities that go along with that transaction?"However, human resources consultant John Work, of the New York firm by the same name, said, "I don't like those kinds of marketing efforts . . . that black people are only worthy of athletic activity and not intellectual activity.  It says, Get these shoes and you can be like Michael Jordan.' It would seem to me that some of these basketball shoes are fast becoming ethnic products."Meanwhile,Nikekeeps rolling, recession and boycott notwithstanding."This idea we should negotiate something is questionable," said Dolan.  "Negotiate what?  We have never disagreed with Operation PUSH on basic goals of equal opportunity and affirmative action.  We disagree with them on how to go about making these changes.""[PUSH is] mandating equal opportunity," Montgomery's Ruth stated, pointing out what she sees as a fault in PUSH's stance and adding, "Nikehas integrity."
email_title: PUSH fails in boycott ofNikeshoes

Email_Body: After seven years, Michael Jordan led the Chicago Bulls to their first NBA championship - and no one is happier than Mars Blackmon, the basketball-crazy fan of Spike Lee'sNikecommercials.Nike'slatest humorous, celebrity-packed pitch, which debuts tonight during baseball's All-Star Game, has Mars at the NBA finals at Chicago Stadium, asking his perennial question, ''Is it the shoes?'' In the ad's kicker, A.C. Green of the defeated Los Angeles Lakers, grimly concedes, ''It had to be the shoes.'' Another version shows actress Dyan Cannon, one of the Lakers' famous fans, woefully agreeing. Nikebought four minutes of ad time during the All-Star game to kick off a $ 35 million ''Air'' campaign that features its biggest stars: basketball stars Jordan, David Robinson and Charles Barkley, tennis star Andre Agassi, and multi-sport star Bo Jackson.The athletes all have appeared in their own series of ads, but ''We wanted to have a link,'' says Tom Clark,Nike'smarketing director. ''It's not a real heavy-handed link. ... It says, these are the best shoes by the best athletes.''The series, by agency Wieden & Kennedy, includes the return of Bo Jackson in his firstNikead since the hip injury that put his athletic career on hold and, as a result, raised questions about his endorsement career.''Everybody knows what Bo's status is,'' Clark says. ''You could do an ad not addressing it, but by addressing it you connect more with the sports fan, who wants to know what's going on with Bo.''Other Air series ads, like the Jordan spots, provide a one-two celebrity punch. In an ad to run during the U.S. Open, a TV screen shows Agassi hitting the ball with such force that the TV rockets across the room. One vicious swat jars the TV's channel to a flash of Julia Child's cooking show, with the chef holding up an artichoke. Bo's ad ends with boxer George Forman jumping into the production number - andNikepromises more surprise endings to come.
email_title: Nikelaunches ads with kicker

Email_Body: Add rehabilitation to the long list of skills thatNikeInc. boasts Bo knows.In new television commercials that begin next Tuesday, during CBS's telecast of the baseball All-Star Game, the nation's leading athletic shoe marketer will present the third annual installment in its "Bo knows" advertising series that has become as popular with ad-award committees as it is with sneaker-buying consumers. The story line for the new spots, called the "Bo Show," centers on the football injury suffered by Mr. Jackson that forced his release by the Kansas City Royals baseball team. That is yet another unexpected move by Wieden & Kennedy,Nike'siconoclastic ad agency in Portland, Ore., since many in the ad community predicted that Mr. Jackson's injury would end hisNikepitchman chores."There's an opportunity in everything," Scott Bedbury,Nike'sadvertising director, said yesterday. "If anybody can make a comeback, it's Bo." The first "Bo knows" spot, in 1989, focused on Mr. Jackson's purported proficiency on guitar, while last year's boasted of his abilities in unexpected sports like auto racing.The first of the new spots shows Mr. Jackson attempting a new career as a song-and-dance man, only to quit in mid-warble. "This is ridiculous," he tells a bevy of chorines dressed in football and baseball costumes who seem to be spoofing Ray Charles's Diet Pepsi "Uh-huh" campaign.Mr. Jackson literally walks out of the commercial, by climbing out of a television set and into a family's living room, on his way to rehab. As he lifts weights and swims, attempting to get back in shape to join his new baseball team, the Chicago White Sox, he is interrupted by the chorines. When he refuses to rejoin them, the song-and-dance resumes with the boxer George Foreman -- another athlete on the comeback trail -- in Mr. Jackson's place.Nikeplans other "Bo show" spots later this summer, one featuring Wayne Gretzy of the Los Angeles Kings hockey team and another featuring baseball and football players: Jerry Rice (San Francisco 49ers), Darryl Strawberry (Los Angeles Dodgers), Randall Cunningham (Philadephia Eagles) and Eric Davis (Cincinnati Reds).Also during the All-Star Game,Nikeplans to show new spots with the tennis star Andre Agassi; David Robinson of the San Antonio Spurs of the National Basketball Association, and the film director Spike Lee as Mars Blackmon, the ultimate fan of Michael Jordan of the N.B.A.'s Chicago Bulls.GRAPHIC:Photo: The first in a series of new "Bo knows" television commercials created by Wieden & Kennedy forNikeathletic shoes has Bo Jackson trying out a new career as a song-and-dance man, surrounded by dancers wearing Chicago White Sox and L.A. Raiders uniforms. (Nike)
email_title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Next, 'Bo Knows' About Rehabilitation

Email_Body: NikeInc. named Georgetown basketball coach John Thompson to its board of directors. Operation PUSH launched a boycott ofNikelast year because of what it said wasNike'spoor record of minority employment and business dealings with black-run companies.  MSL FINALS: The San Diego Sockers defeated the Cleveland Crunch 6-1 Tuesday night for a 3-2 lead in the best-of-seven Major Soccer League finals. Game 6 will be Thursday night in San Diego. MAKING WAY FOR GEORGE?: Managing partner Robert Nederlander told the New York Times Tuesday that he wouldn't block an attempt by New York Yankees owner George Steinbrenner to regain control of the team. ''... If George made a deal with the commissioner to come back, I'd have no problem leaving,'' he said. Nederlander said the job is enormously time-consuming. TIME TO VOTE: Hall of Famers Hank Aaron and Rod Carew will be honorary captains for the All-Star Game July 9 at Toronto's SkyDome, Major League Baseball said Tuesday. The first position-by-position fan voting results will be announced June 3-4. (National League ballot, 5C) JOHNSON APPEALS: NASCAR race team owner Junior Johnson Tuesday appealed his 12-week suspension from Winston Cup competition for having an oversize engine Sunday at The Winston at Charlotte. Johnson said the infraction was accidental. A three-man committee is expected to rule on the appeal today.Compiled by Jack Carey
email_title: NEW DUTIES

Email_Body: BARCELONA, Thursday:Nikelost another missile from its profeeeional armoury last night when speed sensation Michael Johnson failed to reach the final of the 200m.Johnson, 25, shocked the athletics world when he finished equal sixth in his semi-final in a time of 20.78s. Nike, who invested millions in the Dan and Dave show, (decathletes Dan O'Brien and Dave Johnson, the former not competing and the latter runing 11th), will be severly blunted by Michael Johnson's failure.The semi-final was won by Namibia's Frank Fredericks in 20.14s. Fredericks was the furlong sprinter who brought Johnson's amazing 41-race winning streak to an end in June.The 200m final lost another class act when the 100m Olympic champion, Britain's Lindford Christie, came fifth in 20.38s.His semi-final was won by the US's Mike Marsh, who set a new Olympic record of 19.73s.Marsh's said: "I think it's posible to set a world record in the final."Australia's Melinda Gainsford said after her seventh place finish in a semi-final of the 200m: "Those glamour girls like (Gwen) Torrence and(Merlene) Ottey don't talk to little Aussies. But one day they will."Gainsford ran 23.02s in a semi won by Torrence in 21.72s. Ottey won the second semi.Gainsford's comments were refreshingly honest after the glamour girls paraded thmeselves on the brick red tarmac at Montjuic stadium suddenly finding tissues in bodysuits that seemingly only had room for bodies.After her semi, Gainford said: "I'm stuffed. The humidity was tough but I have no excuses."Going through to the semi finals gave me a professional outlook and will help in the years to come."Great Britain's Sally Gunnell backed up to win the major prize in the 400m hurdles last night. The US's Sandra Farmer-Patrick won the silver medal in 53.69.Gail Devers, the Olympic 100m champion easily won her heat of the 100m hurdles in 12.76, placing her on target for a double gold.
email_title: NO FREE PUBLICITY FORNIKEAS STARS BOW OUT;OLYMPIC EXTRA

Email_Body: Canada's 500-strong contingent to the Olympic Games in Barcelona that starts next week have been assured they won't be deliberate targets of the Basque separatist guerrillas.The ETA (Basque Homeland and Freedom) has killed about 750 people in a 23-year campaign for an independent Basque state, 20 of them in gun and bomb attacks this year.But RCMP Chief Superintendent Lowell Thomas told an athletes' briefing in Toronto on Monday: "The Spanish police have indicated to me that the Canadian contingent will not be subjected to any direct hits." Lowell, the RCMP liaison officer with the Olympic team, spent a week in Barcelona in April and worked with his Spanish counterparts."I am satisfied with the security arrangements that have been made to protect the athletes and they have now all been briefed on how to make their stay in Barcelona safe."He stressed to the team members to keep away from any suspicious-looking parcels as the terrorists have been notorious for their bomb attacks.Barcelona is normally patrolled by 2,000 policemen, but the security force will number 40,000 for the Games.NikeInc. said Monday its trademark problem in Spain won't affect the ability of national teams to wearNike-produced uniforms in the Olympic Games."Despite repeated press reports that link our trademark case to Olympic uniforms, there is no connection legally," said Lindsay Stewart,Nikevice-president and corporate counsel.He said the uniforms bearing theNikelogo comply with International Olympic Committee regulations that restrict advertising."The courts in Spain have ruled that we may not sell apparel or advertise apparel in their country until our trademark case is decided," Stewart said."We will do neither during the Olympics. The courts in Spain have made no ruling that bears on Olympic uniforms, which are the private property of the national team members who wear them."Spain's Constitutional Court last week refused to lift a lower court order prohibitingNikefrom promoting its clothes in Spain, arousing speculation that police would strip the offending symbol off the clothes of arriving athletes.The court held a Barcelona company first registered theNiketrademark in 1932.Juan Amigo, a Barcelona lawyer, bought theNikename from the original registrant, who briefly made socks during the 1930s.Amigo is said to have has askedNikefor $ 30 million for rights to the brand.
email_title: Canadians told they're not being targeted by Basques

Email_Body: Michael Jordan,Nikesports apparel company and the NBA have resolved - in principle - the issue of ownership of Jordan's likeness for merchandising purposes. The league has retained the right to market Jordan's likeness, but NBA deputy commissioner Russell Granik said the parties are ''finding a way to live together and prosper.''GRAPHIC:PHOTO, color, Robert Hanshiro, USA TODAY CUTLINE: MICHAEL JORDAN: Clears the air withNikeand NBA.
email_title: Owning a likeness

Email_Body: The athletic shoe and apparel marketerNikeInc. said Monday its earnings rose 17 percent in the third quarter, helped by strong international sales.Nike'snet income for the three-month period ended Feb. 29 was $ 82.5 million, or $ 1.08 a share, up from $ 70.7 million, or 93 cents a share, in the same period last year.Sales increased to $ 886 million from $ 802.2 million.
email_title: NATIONAL EARNINGSNike

Email_Body: NikeInc., the largest U.S. maker of athletic shoes, said it plans to manufacture a new line of ''outdoor fitness'' shoes whose soles are partly made from recycled shoes.Nikesaid it invented a process of grinding athletic shoes into a powder and mixing the material into rubber used for new shoes' outer soles. STEEL SETTLEMENT: A last-minute pay deal in the German steel sector averts a potentially damaging strike but economists said it could set a precedent for high-cost agreements in the current round of wage talks. The 6.4% package agreed by the IG Metall union was at the upper end of what will be acceptable for 1992.  HIGHER PROFITS: Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. said its profits for the 1991 final quarter and the full year rose. The pharmaceuticals giant said profits for the quarter ending Dec. 31 totaled $ 124.2 million, up 39% from a year earlier. For the year, net income totaled $ 326.1 million, more than double the $ 145 million made a year ago. JOINT VENTURE: Finland's national airline Finnair and Aeroflot St Petersburg, part of the former Soviet Union's national carrier, have agreed to set up a joint airline based in St Petersburg. Under the agreement, Finnair would lease McDonnell Douglas DC-9 aircraft and would train Aeroflot crews to operate them. It was not decided when the airline would begin operations. RUSSIAN DEBT: Russia's ability to service its share of the former Soviet Union's foreign debt will depend on the success of new foreign exchange regulations, Western bankers in Moscow said. Shortage of currency and the reluctance of other republics in the Commonwealth of Independent States to transfer funds to Russia mean the Commonwealth has struggled to repay $ 70 billion. AID FOR ADS: McDonald's got $ 465,000 from the U.S. Agriculture Department last year to promote Chicken McNuggets to customers around the world. The company is among dozens of corporate giants that have collected money under the USDA Market Promotion Program to find new overseas markets for U.S. products, The Associated Press said.Compiled by Darren Summers
email_title: RECYCLED SNEAKERS

Email_Body: Inside Track column notes Securities & Exchange Commission filings for insider trading showNikeInc president Richard K Donahue sold almost $2 million of his firm's stock last month, which is 8% of his holdings (S)
email_title: NIKEPRESIDENT SOLD $2 MILLION OF STOCK LAST MONTH, ABOUT 8% OF HIS HOLDINGS

Email_Body: Jimmy Connors' run in the U.S. Open had an unusual footnote: He must actually believe that if the shoe fits, wear it.Connors has a shoe endorsement deal with Converse that runs through 1993. The company plans to give him his own shoe in a new line due in the fall of 1992. But in reaching the Open semifinals, Connors wore all-whiteNikes.''It wasn't a business relationship,'' saysNike'sLiz Dolan, who says Connors was outfitted in July. ''He's just a guy who needed good shoes.''Converse, publicly, isn't concerned. ''We're just glad he played well,'' says spokeswoman Kathy Button. ''And he had our socks on.''Connors' agent Ray Benton doesn't see a problem. ''It was just a short- term thing,'' says Benton. ''He was just testing some other (shoes).''When it comes to consumers, however, the shoe might be on the other foot. According to a leading national survey by Video Storyboard Tests Inc., 54% of consumers say celebrity endorsers are ''just doing it for the money.'' The survey claims just 15% say celebrity plugs might make them more interested in a product.Connors' latest venture: Pepsi TV ads. GLOBALL: Nostalgic for the way things used to be? Consider the World Basketball League's ball, which teachers could use to explain pre-Industrial Revolution life.The Memphis-based league, which uses players under 6-5 and plays teams outside North America, wanted a trademark ball that looked good on TV and could be sold to fans.Given the WBL's international flavor, a leather ball that looked like a globe was an obvious aesthetic - if not practical - choice. But major manufacturers refused the job, citing production costs. Finally, entrepreneur Rich Ledenican of Windsor, Colo., agreed to handmake them in his garage.Prototypes suffered from continental drift - and some player reluctance. ''One player turned to a ref,'' says WBL Commissioner Steve Ehrhart, ''and said Africa came off.'' Another player tried to hide the globe ball before tip-off.The WBL now says the ball is OK - and on sale for $ 150. But don't hold your breath for your order: Each ball takes about eight hours to produce.
email_title: Converse's Connors made run inNikes

Email_Body: Bo Jackson's commercials created the impression that "Bo knows" the ins and outs of almost everything, especially sports. Now that the versatile athlete has been sidelined by a hip injury, one thing Bo does not know for sure is how much it will hurt his lucrative endorsement career.Jackson had parlayed his prowess in professional baseball and football into a high-profile job as a spokesman forNikeathletic shoes, earning him at least $2 million a year. The popular "Bo Knows" commercials played off Jackson's talents as both a star running back for the Los Angeles Raiders and an outfielder for the Kansas City Royals. In the commercials, he seemed the perfect pitchman for the company's cross-training shoes, which are cloth and leather sneakers designed for more than one sport. Jackson's ads, in large part, helpedNikeInc. to overtake Reebok International as the leader in the athletic shoe industry. Led to Other EndorsementsHis fame in theNikecommercials, created by Weiden & Kennedy, a Portland, Ore., agency, also helped win him jobs as a spokesman for A.T.& T. and Pepsico's Mountain Dew drink, which used a "Bo Knows" theme as well.But on Monday, the Royals released Jackson because of a slow-healing injury to his left hip that he suffered while playing football in January. Doctors say they do not yet know whether complications from the injury will keep him from playing for any team the rest of the year, or permanently.Sports marketing consultants said his attractiveness to some advertisers could be severely damaged, if not destroyed, if he is never able to play again. "It certainly does not make sense for sporting goods companies to use an injured sports celebrity," said David Burns, president of Burns Sports Celebrity Service in Chicago, a consulting service for ad agencies seeking sports celebrity endorsements. "The calls may simply stop coming in."For the moment,Nikeis standing by Jackson. Liz Dolan, a company spokeswoman, said his injury, though serious, would probably not have a long-term effect on his relationship withNike,should he recover. "This is unfortunate," she said, "but we'll wait for him to come back."WhileNike'sreluctance to abandon Jackson is not surprising, the company does not have to rely on him alone.Nikehas a stable of celebrities, including Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls in the National Basketball Association and John McEnroe, the tennis star. In addition, Ms. Dolan said,Nikeis always looking for young athletes on the verge of stardom.Nikestock fell as much as $3.75 yesterday before closing at $45.75, down $1.75, but the decline may have had little to do with the company's advertising prospects.Nikesaid analysts had lowered their estimates for its fourth-quarter earnings. The shares had fallen $2.50 each on Monday.Ms. Dolan saidNikehad just started work on its 1991 ad campaign, which will begin in July. She said that although no decision had been made, it was possible Jackson might be used in a humorous "Bo Knows Rehab" strategy for the cross-training shoes.Even if he had not been injured, Jackson would have been less prominent in the coming campaign,Nikesaid. Ms. Dolan saidNikeplanned to emphasize its basketball and outdoor cross-training shoes in the campaign and would use other sports celebrities. The company's previous campaign had concentrated on its sports cross-training shoes and had prominently featured Jackson.If Jackson does recover, but can play only one sport, probably baseball, consultants said he would still be able to do commercials. But his appeal would be limited, they said."Bo's advantage came from playing in two sports and appearing in sports stories most of the year," said Marty Blackman, a partner at Blackman & Raber, a sports marketing and promotions consulting firm. "With a lot of the glitter gone, his fees would certainly be reduced."Consultants said his endorsement fees, which by some estimates total about $5 million a year, could be cut by more than half if he is limited to just one sport.Some consultants said Jackson might have a hard time rounding up endorsements if he is never able to play any sport again. That would be because his career has been short; he has played professional football and baseball in the same year for four years."He didn't play long enough to become an established sports personality," Mr. Blackman said. "You have to become a champion like Joe Namath to have cachet once your sports career is over."But even as a retired athlete, Jackson might be attractive to some advertisers who want to reach children. Lloyd Kolmer, the president of Lloyd Kolmer Enterprises, another consulting firm that helps match celebrities with advertisers, said Jackson was likely to continue to appeal to young people."It's a hero's story," Mr. Kolmer said. "Children look up to him, not just because of sports, but because of his anti-drug and stay-in-school commercials."GRAPHIC:Photo: Bo Jackson's hip injury threatens his double career in athletics, but it is unclear how seriously it will affect his lucrative product endorsements. Jackson, right, appeared with the blues musician Bo Diddley in a commercial created by Weiden & Kennedy forNikeathletic shoes. (NikeInc.)
email_title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Does Bo, Hurt, Know as Much?

Email_Body: The Deion Sanders Double Duty Tour has apparently enlisted the aid of a corporate sponsor that will allow Atlanta's dual-sports star to avoid personally footing the $ 8,300 tab to participate in games for the Braves and Falcons on Sunday.A spokesman forNikewould not confirm Friday whether the athletic footwear and apparel manufacturer will underwrite the cost of a charter jet from Pittsburgh to Miami and back again. But it is believedNikehas become a major player in Sanders's excellent adventure. Sanders signed a three-year, $ 3 million endorsement deal withNikein June. His attorney, Eugene Parker, said Friday that "a third party," which he declined to identify, was aiding his client "with logistics and other considerations.""I've checked on our corporate jet, and it's being used that day, although not for Deion," saidNikepublic relations manager Dusty Kidd. "So if we're doing this for him, it's probably by charter."Falcons management and Braves manager Bobby Cox all but confirmed Friday that Sanders will be in Miami. The plan is for Sanders to leave Pittsburgh late Saturday night after Game 4 of the National League Championship Series, play for the Falcons in the 1 p.m. game Sunday at Miami and return for a possible Game 5 against the Pirates at 8:30 Sunday night.Falcons officials, who remain noncommittal about Sanders's status for Sunday's game against the Dolphins, said they were toldNikewas involved in securing transportation. The trip, which will originate from Pittsburgh's Allegheny County Airport rather than the more congested Greater Pittsburgh Airport, will also include at least two helicoptor rides.Parker said Friday that Sanders had not finalized his decision. "He's still considering all the factors," said Parker, who likely will accompany Sanders on his odyssey.Staff writer I.J. Rosenberg also contributed to his report.ROSTER REVISIONS: As anticipated, the Falcons have placed wide receiver Tony Jones (ankle) on the four-week injured reserve list. The club used its first of five allotted moves to activate wide receiver James Milling from injured reserve. A four-year veteran, Milling has been on IR since the beginning of the regular season with a severe ankle sprain. . . . The Dolphins signed free agent cornerback Stephen Braggs to replace the injured Chris Green (knee).THUMBS UP: Falcons offensive linemen have adopted the Mike Utley Foundation as their charity project this year and earlier this week posed for a picture wearing "Thumbs Up" T-shirts honoring the former Detroit guard, who was paralyzed last season. The T-shirts will be marketed later in the year, and the Falcons linemen will have an autograph session at a date and time to be announced.
email_title: Nikemay foot bill for Deion's odyssey

Email_Body: NikeInc is ordered to stop advertising its Side 1 women's apparel line after federal judge in Los Angeles grants preliminary injunction to Sideout Sport; Sideout is suingNike,seeking $10 million in damages for trademark infringement (S)
email_title: AD NOTES

Email_Body: NIKEshoes are having a good run at the Science Museum: on display are state-of-the-art trainers, pounds 89.99 on the high streets, the biggest draw for adolescent shoplifters and the kind of shoe kids get mugged for. The museum is not actually selling the shoes, but it has lent its name and given space to an exhibition devised byNikeas a tie-in to a pounds 1.7m television advertising campaign for its new Air 180 shoe.Strapped for cash, the museum is not trying to make a splash with the name of a commercial sponsor, however, even though it will have to drop plans for a new gallery of medicine if it fails to raise pounds 1m by the end of the year. Sports professionals may sign lucrative contracts to endorse one manufacturer's gear, but the museum is doing it for nothing. Caroline Kay, head of external affairs for the Association for Business Sponsorship of the Arts, described the arrangement as: ''Utterly astonishing.Nikemust be laughing all the way to the ringing cash tills. Museums can't live in the markets part of the time and in cloud-cuckoo-land the rest, imagining they are totally pure because they haven't accepted money.Nikeis getting a great deal of commercial benefit out of this association: the museum should be selling its own excellence rather than giving it away for free.''It is not the first time that the Science Museum has run into criticism for generous product displays. Its permanent ''Food for Thought'' gallery has been slated for its reconstructions of a Sainsbury supermarket and a McDonald's burger bar. Over the road, the Victoria and Albert Museum was criticised for its exhibitions of Sock Shop designer tights and Burberry raincoats.The Science Museum approachedNikewith the idea for the ''Running on Air'' exhibition. The argument is that it is interesting, scientifically valid and relevant to the visitor who doesn't make a habit of going to museums. This is true: 12-year-old boys, several wearingNikesof their own, were measuring their feet against their sports heros' shoes last week - Frank Bruno size 12, Ian Rush a dainty 71 2 - and guessing their high street prices. ''The public never pass comment on the level of branding. I think they would complain if it were unacceptable,'' said Caroline Nolan, the museum's public relations officer. This could be because the public thinks museum exhibitions are independent creations.The general visitor would be hard put to gather that ''Running on Air'' isNike'sshow rather than the Science Museum's, when hoardings express the museum's gratitude to the company for its support rather than vice-versa. ButNikeis quite clear that it sees the exhibition as scientific endorsement of its brand image as more than a fashion shoe. ''It positions us as a serious brand,'' saidNike'smarketing services manager, Simon Taylor. ''We tried to get the exhibition up and running the day the new shoe hit the stores and we manned the stand for the first few weeks''. He could have been talking about a stand at a trade fair.''When an art gallery shows an exhibition of a living artist, that is a kind of endorsement and it has an effect on market values of the work,'' said Helen Rees, director of the Design Museum. But relations with manufacturing industry pose particular problems for museums of applied arts and sciences - relying on manufacturers as they must for contributions to their collections and up-to-date information from the front line. ''Make it an exhibition of sports shoes and people hop up and down,'' said Neil Cossons, the Science Museum's director. ''But was the museum endorsing Rolls-Royce jet engines in a previous exhibition? That was a product-related exhibition by a single manufacturer and I find it curious that people draw a distinction.'' Perhaps the distinction is that children are not in the market for jet engines. If there are controls against product endorsement by children's television, why not by national museums?If museums bring in exhibitions designed by outside - and interested - parties, perhaps they should make a clearer distinction between ''museum space'' and ''private space''. It is an option the V & A will consider next year when new display areas become available at the end of their ''Japan in Perspective'' exhibition. ''If we have a major exhibition sponsor manufacturing products that are relevant to our collections, we could show additional material - perhaps from their archives - making it quite clear that it is not part of the exhibition itself,'' said Sally Mason, the V & A development director.Those who argue that sponsors may try to assert control over an exhibition are probably mistaken. Patrick Greene, director of the Greater Manchester Museum of Science and Industry, where British Nuclear Fuels gave pounds 73,000 to a new energy gallery, stressed that it was not until the last minute that BNFL asked for details of what would be on display. In the event, it disagreed with some of the contents - such as a picture of a bovine Chernobyl victim that came from a Soviet newsagency. The cow stayed: ''We stressed from the start that it was the museum's exhibition. BNFL would not have dreamt of interfering,'' said Dr Greene.The greater danger could be self-censorship with a museum inclined to tone down aspects of an exhibition that might upset a sponsor. ''Self-censorship is definitely a danger and any museum needs to be aware of it, but another danger is under-valuing what a museum has to offer,'' Dr Greene said.Surely one of a museum's most valuable assets is its reputation for academic integrity untainted by commerce - the reputation that makes business want to associate with museums in the first place. Perhaps the Science Museum should ask itself whether it is selling itself cheap to the shoe industry.'Running on Air' is on until 10 May.
email_title: HowNikegot a run for no money at the Science Museum; Does commerce taint academic integrity? Mary Greene looks at a display of training shoes that has led to controversy

Email_Body: WOULDN'T want to rain on the Olympic flame or anything, but here's some news about running shoes that doesn't exactly square withNike'ssensitive-new-age image.A story in the August issue of Harper's Magazine takes a look at the paycheque of an Indonesian woman named Sadisah. She works in an independent factory that makes shoes forNike.Sadisah works six days a week, ten and a half hours a day, for the equivalent of $ 37.46 US a month, or about 14 cents an hour. That's less than the Indonesian government's figure for "minimum physical need." Her wage lets her rent a shanty with no electricity or running water.A pair ofNikesworth 80 bucks US costs about 12 cents in labor.Michael Jordan reportedly gets $ 20 million to endorseNike, which is the sponsor of the U.S. track and field team. It would take Sadisah 44,492 years to earn that.Reebok, the official footwear sponsor of the Olympics, and No. 2 in the world marketplace toNike, makes its shoes in a lot of the same countries as the Just Do It giant.On Thursday, Reebok's Bernadette Mansur wouldn't say what the labor adds up to for every pair of her company's shoes."All the wages in our factories are above minimum wage," said Mansur, who is vice-president of communications at Reebok's head office near Boston.She said every factory fills out questionnaires about wages, working conditions and time off, and they're inspected constantly."We would never get into a manufacturing circumstance where the values or the working conditions in that factory did not meet with Reebok values."*Jackhammers. Lawnmowers. Boom boxes. Ah, the sounds of summer.No. 1 crazy-making noise for Vancouver people, hands down, is construction. The city's health department gets twice as many calls complaining about building noise than any other kind of noise.Brian Johnston keeps track of this, because he's the health department's noise abatement officer. "You gotta find out what's bothering the people."Next on the list is music, from houses, bars and cars.A big up-and-comer is lawn and garden equipment. Johnston gets a lot of calls about weedeaters, and even more about leafblowers.The health department just lowered the acceptable decibel levels of power equipment from 87 to 77. In January 1994, it'll drop to 74.Just so you know what the numbers mean, if you were 25 feet away from a gas lawnmower, you'd be getting about 87 decibels of noise. Between 70 and 80 decibels, you'd be hearing a fairly quiet vacuum cleaner or a hairdryer.Johnston says he's never had any really weird noise complaints - "nothing from a UFO" - but he does hear a lot about birds.He doesn't have any noise problems of his own."Noise hasn't bothered me really, but if you do sort of glom onto something, it can really become a problem," Johnston said. "We see people becoming hysterical, and they have to go under a doctor's care."His examples of the kind of noise that makes people lose it? Big air conditioners and hot tub filters. "It's continuous, and it can really drive a person batty."*And while we're talking noise . . . .We've finally nailed car alarms and boom cars. Hey, how about motorcycles?The high-pitched kind that sound like a chainsaw crossed with a killer mosquito. Or the low, growly ones whose sonic booms bounce back at us from every wall.Nothing ruins the peace of a summer day like some dork doing a James Dean shtik, burning rubber and busting eardrums as he (or she?) leaves the bike in low gear and revs up the motor."It's just one more frustration society heaps on us," says Bob Halabourda, acting inspector in the Vancouver police department's traffic section.Halabourda knows noise. Traffic cops get so much it, they get their hearing tested once a year.So, what can you do if you decide you've heard your last screaming engine?Not a whole lot. "You can certainly complain, but an officer actually has to catch them committing the offense," says Halabourda.The police can haul over any driver making too much noise. Only problem is, bikers get pretty quiet when they spot a cop in the rearview."When I'm out for a walk at lunchtime, I see it all the time," says Halabourda. "Funny, when I'm out riding, it doesn't seem to happen."
email_title: Shoe manufacturers race for profits

Email_Body: Lynn Jennings missed earning a $ 25,000 bonus by two seconds and breaking a time barrier by three at last year'sNikeWomen's Race in Washington, D.C. She had to settle for a world record for 8 kilometers (4.97 miles) of 25: 02.''I made a mistake,'' says Jennings, defending her title Sunday against a field with world 10,000-meter champ Liz McColgan of Scotland and 1990 winner Judi St. Hilaire. ''I saw the halfway split and thought we were way over pace. I forgot the 'last mile' isn't a full mile.  We floated in the middle.''Jennings doesn't anticipate any floating Sunday, especially with McColgan and another $ 25,000 bonus by Clairol.Jennings has won the last three world cross country titles. McColgan was third in 1991, four months after childbirth, and 41st last March in Boston, attributing the disappointing finish to overtraining.''It could be a real donnybrook,'' says Jennings, fifth in the World 10,000. ''I think the 25-minute barrier will go. I've raced Liz many times, but I've beaten her just twice. She's probably the greatest distance runner in the world right now.''I wouldn't read too much relevance into this. There's a big difference from the roads in May to the track in August.''
email_title: Jennings faces stiffNikecompetition

Email_Body: It is rather an amazing story, the explosion of theNikeshoe company as it tied itself to Michael Jordan's star during the 1980s. And sinceNike'sworldwide headquarters is in Beaverton, some 25 minutes away, this has been something of a triumphant trip for Jordan."Success isn't something you seek; it's something you stumble upon," Jordan said before tonight's NBA Finals Game 4 between his Chicago Bulls and the Portland Trail Blazers."It's something we stumbled upon. We didn't know it was going to happen. It's worked out unbelievably. The relationship has improved into probably one of the best relationships I've had with a corporate" sponsor.Some have chastised Jordan for his role with a product prominently marketed toward minority youth that often can't afford the price tag.Jordan says thatNikehas tried to keep costs down as much as possible, and that it's equally important to produce a shoe of high quality."You have a connection with that product," he said. "It's something that, if it wasn't for you, I don't know if it would be there. I don't abuse that in that I'll hold it over your head or somebody else's. I feel good about it inside, but I won't force it out where it looks like I'm an egotistical person. I'm proud of it, but I don't wear it on my shirt." Dancing With WolvesPortland's Cliff Robinson has been getting a lot of flak for his "Uncle Cliffy" video dance, which would have been of dubious quality if released in mid-January, much less during the finals.Add the fact that Robinson has shot 33 percent during the finals, including Sunday's two of 11, and you wonder if there was a typographical error on the video. Like, Uncle Stiffy."I need to try to get some easy baskets," Robinson said, "or try to make a nice defensive play to get myself going." . . .Some Bulls were trying a little psychology, claiming all the pressure was on the homestanding Trail Blazers and not the visitors."For some reason, we seem to be more focused on the road," Horace Grant said. "We live like a family. We go to movies together, we go to the mall, we eat together, we talk on the phone and go to each other's rooms. . . . It's like a sanctuary on the road."Portland's Clyde Drexler begged to differ. "When you're at home, it's a definite advantage," he said. "I don't buy that." Bulling AheadScott Williams has wrestled his way to the top of Chicago's bench chart, averaging better than 22 minutes per game as Bill Cartwright's center backup in the first three games.It's a welcome lift for Williams, the second-year center who was playing 11 minutes a game during the regular season. He had to listen to the continuing charge that Jordan, a fellow North Carolina Tar Heel, had used clout to get another UNCer on the team."I never thought it would be any tougher" because of the rumors, Williams said. "I thought about it a couple of times . . . but I wasn't guaranteed a roster spot. Everyone was fighting for a job, and I think I showed them I had the skills."Meanwhile Will Perdue has disappeared behind him, getting into only two of the three games, for nine minutes.
email_title: NOTEBOOK;Jordan: Shoe Success Was 'Stumbled Upon'

Email_Body: Sex sells. Why not death?As unlikely as it sounds, the Grim Reaper is becoming a pitchman, says Forbes (March 30). Market researchers say they detect a note of gloom in the land that may be induced by more than just the recession, a mood that makes consumers receptive to the carpe diem, or "seize the day," message.Cunard ran an ad for its Queen Elizabeth 2 cruise last year with the headline, "Life is short." It scored well.Nike,the maker of athletic shoes, did Cunard one better.Nike'sprint ad shows an attractive nude, accompanied by this message: "Yes, this is a goddess, but you are not a goddess, and you aren't ever going to be a goddess so maybe you should get used to it. You'll never be perfect (sorry) and you're not worshiped (usually) and does this matter? No."Obviously, the message is that you ought to jog inNikerunning shoes to preserve whatever looks you have left. According to Forbes,Nikegot 45,000 calls praising the ad - the most responses to any of its campaigns.
email_title: Fatal attraction?

Email_Body: As the men's team nears the gold, the flap over having to wear a Reebok uniform on the victory stand continues.Six of the 12 U.S. players are under contract toNikeand don't want to wear anything advertising Reebok. Michael Jordan is considering not taking part in the medal ceremony.''I'm not sure what I'm going to do,'' he said Wednesday.Reebok is an official supplier to the USOC and paid to have all U.S. Olympians wear Reebok suits on the award stand.Part of the code of conduct all athletes signed says they will wear USOC- designated attire. Jordan said he ''X'd'' out that clause before signing.''As long as we win the gold medal, that's all that matters to me,'' he said.''I've been on the stand before. I know what it means. Once they give me the gold medal I'm fine, no matter how. What they're doing is like saying you have to pick someone over your own father. I can't do that. I have too much loyalty. I've made my concerns known to the Olympic committee.''Mike Moran of the USOC said anyone not wearing the Reebok uniform ''won't get on the award stand.''
email_title: MightNikemen rebuff Reebok

Email_Body: The shoemakerNikeInc. nosed out fragrance maker Calvin Klein as the sponsor of the most popular print advertising campaign of 1990, according to a consumer survey of 24,000 people released Sunday by Video Storyboard Tests Inc.TheNikeprint ads last year included a campaign that featured basketball star Michael Jordan and filmmaker Spike Lee.The remaining Top 10, in order, were: Camel cigarettes, Revlon, Absolut vodka, Infiniti cars, Marlboro cigarettes, Guess apparel, Ford automobiles and trucks and Maybelline cosmetics. BAT DANGER: Lots of children get hurt batting in baseball each year, and a Roanoke, Va., woman is doing something about it.Lorine S. Caveness 14 years ago founded Home Safe Face Guards to make plastic shields to protect the batter's face from a pitched ball. She began developing the guard in 1968 for her son. The guard attaches to the sides of a standard batting helmet, covering the chin to the tip of the nose. The eyes are exposed, but a guard keeps the ball from them.The Consumer Product Safety Commission estimates that 5,500 baseball- related eye injuries were treated in hospital emergency rooms in 1989. Another study found 42,000 facial injuries each year in amateur baseball, with 18,000 for players age 5 to 18.Nationally, Little League and Dixie Youth Baseball require helmets but not masks. However, Little League officials in Marietta, Ga., do require face masks. One coach, Richard Hilton, described the face mask as "the best piece of safety equipment in Little League" since the helmet. The guards cost $ 13 each. A wire face guard made by Schutt Manufacturing of Litchfield, Ill., is available at sports stores.CAT DANGER: One in five sick cats has one of two deadly diseases, feline leukemia or a more recently identified virus similar to AIDS in humans, according to a new study. IDEXX Corp. of Portland, Ore., surveyed 1,500 veterinary clinics in the United States and covered 27,000 sick cats. The study showed that 7.4 percent of the cats suffered from feline immunodeficiency virus, or FIV, and 13.3 percent suffered from feline leukemia, a similar disease that also suppresses the ability of cats to fight off disease.Compiled from wire reports
email_title: LIFE;Nikeads are a shoo-in

Email_Body: MADRID: A trademark for a now defunct brand of socks could cost a top sports firm a fortune. Spanish courts have forbidden American athletes to wearNikeuniforms during the Olympics because its name belongs to a lawyer who bought it from the sockmakers. Lawyer Juan Amigo wants more than £20million for the 1932 trademark. Nike,which had hoped for sales worth at least £15million in Spain during the Games, will appeal.
email_title: £20m Olympics threat toNike

Email_Body: A stylish low-cut leather tennie with a hard plastic sole and metal spikes is the favored footwear of millionaires everywhere.     Really. In Florida. During spring training. On a baseball diamond near you.      And if you stare at the ground long enough, the colorful blurs on the feet of your favorite players will take on their own distinct personalities.     Notice the name brands.Nike,Mizuno, Adidas. Then there's the style (high top, low top) and the cleat type (metal, plastic, turf).     Color is uniform.     "Each team has its own color and the players have to wear that shoe," said Jeff Ross, who minds the footwear and other locker room fashionables as equipment manager of the Toronto Blue Jays.  "Everyone wears different brands, but it has to be the team color."     "Basically, most of the players use metal spikes, even on turf," says Ross, a 15-year veteran of major-league clubhouses. "Only a small percentage use the multi-purpose plastic cleat."     Like basketball, which succumbed in the late '80s to the black-clad feet of Michael "Air" Jordan, fashion has finally invaded America's national pastime.     "The high-tops started off as an ankle-support shoe but now its become a fashion thing," said Ross. "We're seeing more and more of them."      But beauty is only skin deep. The true value of a shoe lies in its comfort and purpose.     "The turf one is more of a shoe for shagging fly balls, jogging," said Ross. "It's more cushioning, especially on the knees. Some outfielders will use the turf shoe in the outfield on turf and switch to  the spikes when they bat."    Metal spikes are as much a part of baseball as tobacco stains on dugout floors and slow home-run trots. And while the molded plastic cleat is easier on the legs, the gripping and tracking abilities of spikes make them the most worn shoes in The Show.     "It's just something they (players) have been using throughout their careers. They're comfortable with them," Ross said of metal spikes. "Plus, if you slide into second or third, a guy is gonna think twice about blocking the bag if you're wearing metal spikes. It used to be a bigger deal in the old days, but there are certain players now who see you wearing plastic cleats and will block the base."     Ross says pitchers seem more particular about what they wear on their feet. While a position player might go through 20 pairs of shoes a season, about two pairs a year is tops for pitchers.     "Some guys will wear a pair of shoes until they're full of holes and ripping off their feet," Ross said, "while others will get rid of a pair of shoes if they have a bad outing."     Ahhhhh . . . the agony of da feet.JON WESTGRAPHIC:BLACK AND WHITE PHOTO, V. Jane Windsor; Meet the cleats: TheNikeAir Show, theNikeAir Slam and theNikeAir Slider
email_title: What the big-league feet are wearing

Email_Body: TheNikesummer camp for high school basketball players, with its lofty ideals stressing education, has moved after eight years from Princeton, N.J., to Indianapolis. It got a better deal.CINDY HORR of the Center for Visitors and Conference Seminars at Princeton said: "We liked having them. But they got a fantastic deal in Indianapolis, with business people getting behind them and underwriting the cost." Over the years the camp, which runs for a week in July, attracted the country's top basketball players who had at least a year of high school remaining. Such players as ALONZO MOURNING of Georgetown and KENNY ANDERSON of Georgia Tech and now the Nets were onceNikecampers.Most of the players attending were academically troubled. In 1989, more than half the 124 students tested were reading at or below the eighth-grade level. More than a third couldn't read above a fifth-grade level.That was a major reason why classes were held in the morning, and motivational speakers, like SPIKE LEE , MUHAMMAD ALI and GEORGE STEINBRENNER , addressed the athletes.The camp also attracted college scouts. They were there for the afternoon workouts.
email_title: SIDELINES: No Tents at This Summer Camp;Mornings Are For Motivation

Email_Body: A flotilla of up to 40,000Nikeshoes has been slowly bobbing around the Pacific Ocean since the spring of 1990.  News that these sartorial requisites have met a watery fate may dismay the youth of the West. But it has brought joy to Oregon's beachcombers, who have been making a fortune reselling the shoes which, surprisingly, have survived their immersion with surprising resilience.  In another benevolent spinoff, the data provided by plotting the progress of theNikeflotsam has allowed oceanographers to test several complex theories about the detailed mechanics of Pacific currents.  "It has been a real bonus to our work," said Dr. James Ingraham, of the National Marine Fisheries Service.  The story began on May 27, 1990, when a storm struck the freighter Hansa Carrier, which was en route to the United States from South Korea. The ship survived, but its shipment ofNikegym shoes was washed overboard. Not a sole was saved.  The incident was forgotten until November of that year, whenNikeshoes began appearing along the shores of Oregon. Large hiking boots, high-tops and other styles began to bob landward, at first in ones and twos, then in scores, eventually in the thousands. To the incredulity of locals, the beaches were swamped with multicolored shoes.  Within weeks, this well-heeled landing army had created a thriving new local economy. Beachcombers held swap-meets at which they exchanged right and left shoes, to be then resold in pairs. "I got my pair for $20," said Ingraham. "That's about a quarter of the price I would have paid in a store. Admittedly, they had spent a year sloshing about the Pacific, but after I'd worn them a couple of times, they loosened up and are quite comfortable now." The fact that their shoes were still wearable after many months' battering by storms and water would suggest thatNikeproducts have weather-proof qualities that could well be marketed. However, this has not been seized upon.  "We contactedNike,but they didn't want to know," said Ingraham. "Maybe a beachcomber's recommendation is not quite the testimony thatNikewas seeking." Maybe not, but the longevity of the shoes has been a real boon for Ingraham who, with colleague Curtis Ebbesmeyer, began studying the shoes' oceanographic meanderings. They used the data to produce a long paper for Transactions of the American Geophysical Union, a journal.  They report that many of the shoes appeared farther south than would normally have been expected for flotsam borne by the tropical Pacific currents that head north to Alaska.  Now, as the currents have swept back out to sea from Oregon, the shoes have been heading south and east, and already some have appeared on the shores of Hawaii.  "The next stop is Japan," added Ingraham. "After that, they will start on their second circle of the Pacific Ocean."
email_title: SAGA OF THE 40,000 UNSINKABLE SHOES

Email_Body: The U.S. home-ownership rate has stabilized after falling in the early 1980s, the Census Bureau says. After rising steadily from 1940 to 1980, the home-ownership rate dropped from 65.6% of households in 1980 to 63.9% in 1989.  But a Census study, ''Housing in America: 1989-90,'' found that the decline came before 1985 and the ownership rate since has been stable. The Census Bureau attributed the drop in the 1980s to a larger number of young adults staying single. That's still true, but more older people now are marrying and are more likely to buy a home, stabilizing the ownership rate. The study also found that not all people who wanted to buy a home could. In 1988, 57% of all households couldn't afford a median-price home in the area where they lived.  LTV BID WITHDRAWN: The French group Thomson-CSF withdrew its bid for the missile division of steelmaker LTV, Reuter reports, citing unnamed industry sources. The withdrawal followed U.S. opposition to the purchase on national security grounds. LTV had planned to sell the division to Thomson for $ 450 million as part of a plan to emerge from bankruptcy-court protection. FEDS SEIZE HOMEFED: Federal regulators seized San Diego-based HomeFed Bank, the nation's eighth-largest thrift. The Office of Thrift Supervision blamed Congress for not funding a program intended to save taxpayer money by finding buyers for insolvent thrifts without government seizures. HomeFed is the largest thrift ever transferred to the Resolution Trust Corp., which is in charge of selling assets of failed thrifts. HomeFed's 206 branch offices in California will be open as usual today. NIKENAME IN SPAIN:Nike,which has paid millions of dollars to put its name on the U.S. track and field team's uniforms at the Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, says it is appealing a Spanish court ruling that bars the advertising or sale ofNikeapparel in Spain. Spain's Constitutional Court last week upheld a lower court's order barring the sports company from using theNikename on clothing because a Spanish firm registered the trademark in 1932.Nike,whose shoes are not affected by the ruling, planned to use the Olympics to launch a line of sports clothes.Nikesays it could lose $ 20 million in sales in Spain and much more worldwide if the ruling stands. TREASURY AUCTION: Interest rates on six-month Treasury bills fell in Monday's auction to the lowest level in 29 years while the rate on three- month bills fell to a 20-year low. The Treasury Department sold $ 11.7 billion in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 3.32%, down from 3.66% at last week's auction and the lowest rate since July 8, 1963. Another $ 11.7 billion was sold in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 3.23%, down from 3.59% and the lowest rate since Feb. 18, 1972.
email_title: HOME OWNERSHIP

Email_Body: First of America Bank Corp. has bought about $150 million in assets of an Illinois thrift from the Resolution Trust Corp.  The bank holding company's subsidiary of Northeast Illinois closed the $8 million deal to acquire $135 million in insured deposits and certain assets of Waukegan-based Home Federal Savings Bank F.A.  Home Federal's six offices have been in government conservatorship since Dec.  14, 1990.  The RTC is the government agency responsible for selling the assets of failed savings and loans.  AP NATIONAL AIRLINES United, American Offer Coast Sale The nation's two largest airlines, American and United, said Monday that they had matched a half-price sale begun by Trans World Airlines on tickets for people flying from coast to coast this fall.  Fares from St. Louis to either coast will be unaffected by the promotion, TWA said.  Under the sale, passengers have until Thursday to buy tickets from several cities in the New York and Washington-Baltimore areas to several cities in the Los Angeles and San Francisco areas, for $198 round trip in most cases, the lowest price in years. Travel is good through Dec. 15, with five days around the Thanksgiving holiday unavailable, but the tickets are non-refundable.  AP ADVERTISING Mazda Reportedly In Time Warner Deal Mazda Motor of America Inc. has signed a three-year advertising deal with Time Warner Inc. that will involve magazines, books and television programs, a published report said Monday.  The trade journal Advertising Age said the deal could be worth as much as $96 million over the three years and will be built around the theme ''The meaning of life.'' Mazda and Time Warner officials declined comment.  Ad Age said Mazda will buy space in Time Warner's magazines, which include Time, People, Sports Illustrated, Money, Fortune and Entertainent.  AP ATHLETIC WEARNikeHas Record Profits In 1st QuarterNikeInc., the worldwide athlet ic footwear and apparel maker, said Monday earnings in its fiscal first quarter jumped 15 percent to a record high, but it warned that the second quarter may not have as much bounce.  Beaverton, Ore.,-basedNikesaid it made a profit of $114.4 million in the quarter that ended Aug. 31, up from $99.7 million a year ago.  The news sentNike'sshare up a brisk $2.75 to $50.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.Nikesaid it is the first company in the sports field to chalk up a profit of more than $100 million in a quarter.  Reuters ALLSTATE INSURANCE Auto Insurer Pulling Out Of New Jersey Allstate Insurance Co., one of the largest insurers in New Jersey, announced Monday it intends to withdraw all property and casualty business from the state.  Ed Young, the company's group vice president of auto insurance, attributed the decision to what he called the high cost of operating an auto insurance business in New Jersey.  Young said that in 1990 Allstate lost $72 million on auto insurance in New Jersey, resulting in a $24 million total loss to the company on property and casualty insurance state-wide.  AP INTERNATIONAL CAMPEAU Protection From Creditors Sought Campeau Corp. said Monday it will seek protection from its creditors in court, and will sell its flagship building in Toronto and settle all claims against it by Olympia & York Developments Ltd. as part of a final restructuring plan.  The company plans to seek a court order under the Companies' Creditors Arrangement Act - an Ontario law that protects companies from their creditors - before the end of October, said a Campeau spokesman.  Olympia & York, owned by Toronto's Reichmann family, is owed about $541 million in secured Campeau debt, debt tied to certain projects, and privately and publicly held debentures.  Reuters HANSON PLC Beazer Agrees To $600 Million Merger Construction company Beazer PLC, battered by recession and burdened by debt, has agreed to be acquired by the conglomerate Hanson PLC for $608 million, the companies said Monday.  Together, the companies will be better poised to develop their construction businesses when the economy recovers, their top executives said. Hanson already has considerable interests in the building industry.  Beazer will postpone plans to sell off its European operations. Just last week, the company had detailed plans to spin off those operations for what analysts expected would be at least $606 million.  Beazer said at the time it wanted to concentrate on its U.S. businesses in 30 states.  AP
email_title: ILLINOIS ACQUISITION FIRST OF AMERICA BUYS S&L FROM RTC
