Email_Body: The Spanish government has vowed to helpNikeInc. in the trademarkdispute threatening to make a shambles of the company's multimillion-dollar Olympic ad campaign, officials said yesterday. In a letter sentthis week to the European Commission, Spanish officials promised to ask aBarcelona judge to allowNiketo post bond in the case. That arrangementwould allow the Beaverton, Ore., company to sell and advertise its sportsapparel in Spain while awaiting a final court decision in the trademarkconflict.
email_title: SPORT IN BRIEFNikegets help

Email_Body: Chad Carithers scored 16 goals to lead the Gladiators to first place in theNikeunder-19 indoor tournament last week at The Soccer Academy in Lilburn. The Gladiators defeated Phoenix 9-0 in the championship game."This was our best tournament in the seven years of theNike," said Steve Keiss, tournament director. "We had no ejections, all games were played in the proper spirit, and fans, players and officials all had a tremendous time." The Most Valuable Player was Troy Wood of the Steamers '75, whose team was eliminated 4-2 in the semifinals by the Gladiators. Steve Brandt of Chelsea Villa, which lost 3-0 in the semifinals to Phoenix, was named Best Defender. John Brown of Chelsea Villa was voted Most Sportsmanlike. Michael Rachael of Phoenix and Mark Albertus of the Gladiators were voted Best Goalkeepers.The 17-team tournament was divided into three divisions. Each division played a round-robin format to decide who reached the playoff round. The top two teams in each division and the next two teams with the best record qualified.In the quarterfinals: Phoenix beat the Grasshoppers 4-3; Chelsea Villa beat the Homeless Millionaires 6-3; the Gladiators topped the Yellow Bellies 10-2; and the Steamers downed the Smart Wunz 6-2. . . .Two local women's teams lost in the Region III finals in Charleston, S.C., last week. In the over-30 division, Poco Loco of Texas defeated the Atlanta Breeze 6-5 on penalty kicks. In the open division, North Texas defeated Soccer Warehouse 5-1. . . .The under-12 Brookwood Steamers lost to the Gadsden, Ala., Hawks in a tournament played at Canterbury Park in Kennesaw. The game was tied 1-1 and the Steamers lost on the fifth penalty kick. . . .The Atlanta Express, the local team competing in the Sunbelt Independent Soccer League, is in third place in the Southeast Division after a 4-3 victory over the Atlanta Quicksilver. David Smith, an Atlanta Attack player, got the winning goal - his second of the game.Other Express goals came from Richard Taylor and Selby Neese. The Quicksilver got goals from Scott Smith, Tracy Crouch and Gilberto Ramirez.The Express (1-2) trails undefeated Memphis and Arkansas (3-0) in outdoors play. The Express has added Greg Sheen of the Attack and Mark Gailey, the starting goalkeeper for the University of North Carolina.The two teams meet three more times this season.
email_title: SOCCER NOTES; Carithers leads Gladiators to title inNiketourney

Email_Body: If, for whatever cockeyed reason, you wanted to cast a classical musician alongside a professional athlete in a sneaker commercial, you might find a likely candidate or two. But you would find a host of unlikely ones, and among the very least plausible would be the pianist Rudolf Firkusny.Reserved and patrician in his bearing and in his playing, Mr. Firkusny, who lives in New York but was born in Napajedla, Moravia (now part of Czechoslovakia), in 1912, is the epitome of old-world grace and gentility. "I am not very much in the sport world," Mr. Firkusny said recently. Yet there he is on television with David Robinson of the San Antonio Spurs, playing Chopin and, uh, basketball in a commercial forNike.The idea came from James Riswold, an admirer of Mr. Firkusny's piano-playing and a copywriter for the advertising agency Weiden & Kennedy, based in Portland, Ore. Mr. Riswold's work in otherNikecommercials has received wide acclaim.Though Mr. Firkusny took part only in the final day of shooting, he said the process of repeated takes was exhausting, much as in a recording session. "For the first time I realized that it's not such an easy life to be a movie actor," he added. But there were rewards. He reported gleefully that he made one basket -- a feat, alas, not shown in the commercial.And now Mr. Firkusny revels in a new-found fame. "Everybody saw it somehow," he said. "My mailman told me he saw me on television. The druggist and my daughter's doctor saw it. That's the magic of television. I think it was good that for once serious music was put together with sports. Music needs all kinds of encouragement."
email_title: MUSIC;Chopin Meets the Slam Dunk

Email_Body: TWO of the world's biggest suppliers of sports equipment -Nikeand Adidas - have warned the US Government that trade retaliation against China would seriously hurt their Hongkong operations. Nike, the world's largest producer of sports shoes, said if punitive tariffs were imposed the company would have to sharply raise prices or shut down its entire operation in China.Such action would undermine its regional headquarters in Hongkong, where there would be thousands of job losses, the company said. Nikehas urged the United States Trade Representative to target China's state- run shoe factories instead of those operated by private enterprises. Adidas, another industry giant, said all of its financing, purchases and shipping for Adidas merchandise manufactured in China was done through businesses in Hongkong, which would be hard hit by US trade retaliation.For example, a company such as Yue Yuen Industrial Ltd, the large sports shoe maker which listed on the Hongkong stock exchange in June, could see its business seriously wounded.As an original equipment manufacturer forNikeand Adidas, Yue Yuen employs 13,300 workers in its four mainland factories and nearly 200 supervisors, many from Hongkong, in operations that last year were 80 per cent devoted to the United States.But the powerful American Textile Manufacturers Institute (ATMI) has demanded that the US impose punitive tariffs on key Chinese exports to match dollar-for-dollar the losses suffered by the US from China's trade barriers.The groups were responding to a call by the US Government for public comment on which Chinese goods to single out for retaliation should Beijing fail to accept American demands to lift trade barriers against US products.Most of the 20 or so trade groups and companies that responded urged the Trade Representative's office to defuse the trade row by reaching a fair-trade agreement with Beijing instead of taking punitive action.They further urged that their products be left off the hit-list of Chinese goods should the talks fail and retaliation become necessary.US President George Bush has set an October 10 deadline for Beijing to sign a deal that would open up China's markets or face sharply higher tariffs against Chinese exports to the US.Deputy Trade Representative Michael Moskow increased the pressure last month with an ultimatum that unless Beijing accepted all US demands during market access talks beginning on August 19 in Beijing the US would publish a tentative hit-list of Chinese goods.In responding to the trade office's call for public comment, ATMI said the US should target Chinese goods that made up the key parts of China's export trade and those considered as high priority items by Beijing.The textile association added that the goods selected for punitive tariffs should be products China made exclusively for the US market - such as cotton towels, blankets and women's sweaters - so that China could not side-step punishment by exporting these products to other markets."Many of our member companies have long been victims of the unfair and illegal trade practices routinely carried out by China," the ATMI said.Crampton and Knowles, a top US dye company, accused China of widespread unfair trade by using trade barriers, employing prison labour and ignoring copyright.It urged the US to target goods that hurt China's economy most, including garments, footwear and toys.But the Hongkong General Chamber of Commerce warned that any damage to China's economy would affect Hongkong's economy."To make Hongkong an innocent victim is clearly a major injustice. There can be no winners in this," the chamber said.The Hongkong Toys Council warned the Trade Representative that retaliation against China would "critically threaten" the territory's toy manufacturers because 95 per cent of China's toy exports to the US were in fact produced by Hongkong firms on the mainland.The Federation of Hongkong Industries urged US officials to exclude from the hit-list "those items which in your opinion might damage Hongkong industry if retaliation is necessary".The Hongkong Watch Manufacturers Association and the Hongkong Electronics Association also pleaded against retaliation, warning that such action could result in hundreds of thousands of job losses.
email_title: Nike,Adidas fear tariffs' effect on HK;Top shoemakers warn US

Email_Body: TRADEMARK difficulties in Spain will not have any impact on the ability of national teams wearingNike-provided uniforms to compete in the Olympic Games, the sports clothing company said today."Despite repeated press reports that link our trademark case to Olympic uniforms, there is no connection legally," saidNikevice-president and corporate counsel Lindsay Stewart. "Uniforms that bear the logo of the company who made them comply with IOC regulations restricting advertising." "The courts in Spain have ruled that we may not sell apparel or advertise apparel in their country until our trademark case is decided.We will do neither during the Olympics."The courts in Spain have made no ruling that bears on Olympic uniforms, which are the private property of the national team members who wear them."Nikewill provide the official national uniforms to the track and field teams of the United States, Nigeria, Algeria, Paraguay and the Bahamas.The trademark case in Spain does not affectNikefootwear which will be worn by many leading athletes.- PAEND OF STORY
email_title: Nikeuniforms get Olympic approval

Email_Body: MADRID:Nike,which has paid millions to put its name on US track and field outfits at the Barcelona Olympics, is to fight a court decision that bars advertising or sale of its sportswear in Spain and which could cost the firm £10m in Spanish sales alone. A constitutional court has refused to lift a lower court order prohibiting the Oregon-based companyfrom using theNikename on clothing because a Barcelona firm registered the trademark first in 1932.
email_title: Nikein court battle

Email_Body: SPAIN'S quirky trademark law is threatening to turnNike'ssponsorship of the US Olympic track and field team into a multi-million dollar fiasco. NikeInc is in the midst of an ugly legal battle with a Spanish lawyer who owns theNikename in Spain - registered 60 years ago by a Barcelona sock maker.And with the Olympics less than six weeks away andNikeplanning to plaster its disputed name on US athletes' uniforms, the company and the lawyer, Juan Amigo Freixas, are playing a game of courtroom ollars.APEND OF STORY
email_title: What's in a brand name?

Email_Body: IN a sport dominated by money, John McEnroe and Andre Agassi will do an unusual thing at the National Tennis Centre today _ play an exhibition match for nothing. The reason is to promote their main sponsor,Nike, and announce its success in the Australian marketplace. Later this year,Nikeis expected to take over the mantle of market leader in the sports footwear industry from Reebok. The air sole is about to deflate the pump-action shoe.In an industry conservatively valued at $500million a year, that is a big deal, andNikeis not going to let us forget it.Today's exhibition tennis match is the first in a series ofNikepromotions. Next in line will be its basketball wares, which may entail an Australian visit next year by the biggest superstar in the game _ Michael Jordan.The company is among the top 10 television advertisers in the country, rivalling such traditional big spenders as Coca-Cola and McDonald's. Its formula has entailed using United States ads featuring Jordan, fellow basketballer Charles Barkley, Ukrainian pole vaulter Sergei Bubka and its "Just do it" jingle.A survey of viewers' ad recognition during the Barcelona Olympics putNike'sadvertisements near the top.The managing director ofNikeAustralia, Mr Tony Peddie, said the growth of theNikesports shoe in Australia followed the manufacturer's US success. "Our boom is product-created by theNikeformula, of being able globally to franchise athletes to products, like Michael Jordan," he said.One of his competitors, Mr Paul Moore, group director of sporting goods at Pacific Dunlop, which has the licence to sell Adidas sports shoes in Australia, agreed, saying thatNikeis flavor of the month."The sporting goods market in Australia is a fad market. You are very hot for a while, then something else comes up and knocks you off," he said."The business is driven from American trends and what youth demands.Kids aged 14 to 18 are controlling the market." Demand is also shaped by changes in technology. Reebok generated huge sales through the pump-action technology in the tongue of its runners.In 1979,Nikefirst developed its air sole. Now, through its AirJordan brand, it has matched it with Reebok in Australia. Adidas has tried to develop its own image through its torsion sole, also designed to reduce stress on the foot.Analysts putNike'sshare of the sports footwear market at 27 per cent, slightly below Reebok but rising. Next in line is Adidas (the dominant player of the early 1980s) with about 16 per cent of the market, followed by Puma (about 10 per cent) and the rest.Mr Peddie saidNikeaimed for the same success locally that it had in the US, where it has 33 per cent of the market. It had given itself 18 months to achieve that kind of dominance.Today's challenge between McEnroe and Agassi is one of several exhibitions every year for which the players are contracted. Mr Peddie said: "This promotion is all about showing the flag forNike. It is the first big shot in our sports marketing efforts and clearly this sort of thing is going to happen in the future. In the future we need to do something with basketball, which is such a growing sport."
email_title: Tennis greats with a spring in their instep

Email_Body: The St. Charles, Mo., City Council touched off a controversy when it agreed to designate part of the north end of the city as "Frog Town," the area's traditional nickname because it is, indeed, covered with frogs. But Lyndell Porterfield, the city attorney, pointed out that French people and their descendants consider the word "Frog" to be a derogatory reference to them. The neighborhood next to Frog Town is called Frenchtown.SOLE SURVIVORS: A flotilla of up to 40,000Nikegym shoes have been slowly bobbing around the Pacific Ocean since the spring of 1990. A storm struck a freighter and washed overboard its shipment ofNikeshoes. Months later, the shoes began washing up on the shores of Oregon. The shoes survived the immersion with surprising resilience. And scientists following theNikearmada's progress have learned more about Pacific currents. "It has been a real bonus to our work," said marine scientist James Ingraham.JAWS: A great white shark attacked a kayaker off California during the weekend. It was one of several encounters recorded in the past few days between human beings and sharks, prompting a warning to avoid the waters off Ano Nuevo State Reserve. Kayaker Ken Kelton was attacked by a large shark Saturday as he paddled his boat north of Santa Cruz. Although his boat was bitten, he was uninjured. Other shark sightings involved great whites biting a cod on a fisherman's line, attacking a seal and cruising near the surf line off Santa Cruz. Experts said the number of recent great white shark incidents is unusual.From our news services
email_title: BIZARRE BUZZ Tempers leaping at pairing of Frog and Frenchtownoddities

Email_Body: Stockholders and baseball card investors don't know about Bo - and the uncertainty took a toll yesterday.Shares ofNikeInc., the Beaverton, Ore. athletic footwear giant for which baseball and football star Bo Jackson did the popular ''Bo Knows'' ad campaign, plunged US$3 3/4 in early trading on the New York Stock Exchange before rallying late in the day. Nikestock closed down US$1 3/4 at US$45 3/4 after falling US$2 1/2 on Monday.Nikedropped US$1 5/8 on Friday, when reports that Jackson's injury could be career-threatening began to receive widespread circulation. The chance that the Los Angeles Raider running back and ex-Kansas City Royal outfielder may never play again has also prompted dumping of Jackson's baseball cards at big discounts, according to Jeff Kurowski, the baseball price guide co-ordinator for the respected Sports Collector's DigestA 1986 Topps Traded card which was selling Monday for US$10 dropped to US$5 with news of Jackson's release by the Royals, he said.''A lot of large quantities of his cards are being dumped,'' Kurowski said. ''We haven't seen a lot of activity in his football cards yet. But I imagine it will be the same result.''A lot of the value in Bo was built because he was in the national spotlight and the expectations in both sports were so high. Now it just might turn out to be unrealized potential.''A Wall Street analyst says not all the blame for the stock's drop should be attributed to Jackson's injury. Heidi Steinberg of Salomon Bros. in New York saidNike'searnings report, released Monday, showed ''expenses have increased, particularly selling expenses and interest costs.''But Liz Dolan,Nike'svice-president of corporate communications, said she's puzzled by the drop in share price.''Earnings were up and the price goes down. But the stock market is very emotional; Bo's injury could have something to do with it.''Since Jackson becameNike'smost famous spokesman in 1988, sales of cross-trainers have grown to US$350 million (C$400 million). Bo's contract withNikeruns through 1993.Jackson was on crutches yesterday as he visited his former teammates in the Royals' clubhouse.
email_title: Now investors know Bo's pain

Email_Body: NikeInc. is breaking into new territory by pledging $ 5 million to become the sole corporate sponsor of "Ghostwriter," a new children's show being produced by the Children's Television Workshop (CTW) for public TV.According to CTW, who also produces "Sesame Street" and "3-2-1 Contact,"Nike'scontribution is the largest promotional grant ever given to a children's public TV project and the first PBS show underwritten by a sporting goods company.The new "Ghostwriter" weekly prime-time series is aimed at children ages 7-10 with an emphasis on motivating kids to read and write.  "Ghostwriter" is scheduled to debut this fall on PBS and will be accompanied by an extensive multimedia outreach program. CTW describes the "Ghostwriter" show as "breakthrough children's programming" that tries to promote literacy by featuring hip, urban youngsters and a ghost who can only communicate through writing.  The show uses original music, funky animation, and celebrity guest stars to tell stories with cliff-hanger endings.Accompanying the TV series will be 20 million copies of a magazine based on the show, a nationally syndicated newspaper column, and a promotion and publicity campaign coordinated withNike.The 15-second on-air credit forNikethat will appear after every show was designed by advertising heavy hitter Wieden and Kennedy, with the theme "Exercise your head -- read."Nikewill have an advertorial page in each "Ghostwriter" magazine issue, sponsor recognition on other "Ghostwriter" material, and be able to use one of its very visible spokespeople to tout reading and the "Ghostwriter" project.  The company also plans to hold one or two national contests to encourage kids to read and write.Although "Ghostwriter" is contributing a page of its magazine toNike, "it's not like an advertising page; they're just giving us some credit for being a $ 5 million dollar underwriter," said Virginia Henson, director of public affairs for Beaverton, Ore.-basedNike.Last year, the company sponsored a $ 5 million commercial literacy campaign that included spots featuring Michael Jordan and Spike Lee sitting in a classroom with a blackboard that read "Don't be stoopid, stay in school."This year, after "lengthy internal discussions . . . we decided if we were going to put all our eggs in one basket, this program was certainly one that merited [funding]," she said.Of the show's $ 20 million startup fund, reportedly half will be used to produce 40 episodes for next year, and the other half will be used for promotion and community outreach.The "Ghostwriter" project funding is mainly a philanthropic effort byNikefor the community, Henson said, but she also expects to reap some marketing benefits."When you do these types of sponsorships you obviously engender goodwill, which, hopefully, transfers to consumer loyalty toward the product," she said."We're always positioning ourselves as having strong emotional ties with consumers," Henson said.  "For us.  this is exactly the type of emotional tie we like to have with the public."GRAPHIC:Photo, The new "Ghostwriter" series, produced by Children's Television Workshop, uses hip, urban kids to promote literacy.NikeInc. has already pledged $ 5 million to the show, making it the largest corporate sponsor of a children's public TV project., Photo by Frank Micelotta/CTW
email_title: Nikepledges $ 5 million for CTW show

Email_Body: American medal winners must wear Reebok outfits to the podium, the U.S. Olympic Committee says. But some members of the U.S. basketball team - notably Charles Barkley and Michael Jordan - say their contracts with other companies might force them to skip their expected gold medal ceremony. ''UsNikeguys are loyal toNikebecause they pay us a lot of money,'' Barkley said. ''If Reebok or the USOC is going to be upset about four or five guys not wearing a suit, it's a joke.Nikepays us a ton of money. I have two million reasons not to wear Reebok.''Scottie Pippen, Chris Mullin, John Stockton and David Robinson are other U.S. players under contract toNike.Reebok has a contract with the USOC that all medal winners will wear the specially designed Reebok warmup suit after winning an Olympic medal. Money received from Reebok goes to pay thousands of athletes in training, USOC spokesman Mike Moran said.
email_title: Dream Team may boycott medal ceremony

Email_Body: Plucking another treasure from the baby boomer song book,NikeInc. has launched a new ad campaign featuring "Instant Karma," the John Lennon classic. And yes, that's Lennon, crooning from beyond the grave to help move a few more units of something called Air Huaraches.Maybe turning John Lennon into a sneaker salesman is a tad craven, but by now it's old news.Nike, which licensed "Instant Karma" with Yoko Ono's permission, has been down this road before -- in 1987, when its use of the Beatles' "Revolution" in a commercial kicked up fan protests and a lawsuit from Paul McCartney. Advertisers have been grafting popular songs onto ad campaigns for so long that no one complains, even when Aretha Franklin transforms a song that wasn't hers, "Rescue Me," into "Deliver Me" for Pizza Hut.  So, as long as Madison Avenue insists on appropriating demographically correct tunes, we might as well be helpful. How about:For Domino's, Lennon again: "Give Pizza a Chance." For Crisco, George Harrison offers "My Sweet Lard."For Sealy mattresses, Bob Dylan sings "Lay Lady Lay" (alternates: Aerosmith's "Dream On," Lennon's "How Do You Sleep?").More Dylan: for Goodyear, "The Tires They Are a-Changin' "; for International House of Pancakes, "You Gotta Serve Somebody"; and for Kleenex, "Blowin' in the Wind."For the Jenny Craig weight loss centers: Peter Frampton's "Baby, I Love Your Weigh."For Trojan-brand condoms, the 5th Dimension's "Up, Up and Away (In My Beautiful Balloon)." And, of course, the Foreigner medley: "Feels Like the First Time," "Hot Blooded" and "Urgent."Foreigner again, for Mrs. Paul's fish sticks: "Hot Breaded."Dentu-Grip signs Paul Simon for "Slip Slidin' Away."For Right Guard and Secret: Lynyrd Skynyrd doing "That Smell" or J. Geils Band doing "Love Stinks."For Suzanne Somers's ThighMaster: Led Zeppelin's "Stairway to Heaven."Root Boy Slim's "Boogie Till You Puke" for Dupont Stainmaster Carpet.Linda Ronstadt for Isotoner: "When Will I Be Gloved?"The Who, licensing division: for Greyhound, "Magic Bus"; for Stanley tools, "Won't Get Tooled Again"; for Bausch & Lomb, "I Can See For Miles."Curtis Mayfield's "Superfly" for any airline.BCCI and the NRA can fight over Warren Zevon's "Lawyers, Guns and Money."Duraflame logs and Kingsford charcoal could bid for the rights to the Doors' "Light My Fire."Clearasil and Roberta Flack team up for "The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face."The Rolling Stones' "Tumbling Dice" for Harrah's casinos and resorts.The Eurythmics, for Marriott: "Suite Dreams Are Made of This."And Edwin Starr revives his career for Compound W: "Wart! Good God, ya'll, what is it good for? Absolutely nothin'!"Staff writers Vince Rinehart, Scott Patton and Richard Harrington contributed to this, uh, report.
email_title: Well, We All Shine...Shoes? Is There Any Song Madison Avenue Won't Steal?

Email_Body: For a company that says it's selling ''self- empowerment,''Niketakes a lot of flak.The harshest criticism:Nikeisn't just latching onto sports, it's meddling in them.Take CBS' broadcast of the National League playoffs, when announcer Sean McDonough suggestedNikeendorser Deion Sanders played for baseball's Atlanta Braves and football's Atlanta Falcons because he let a reported $ 1 millionNikebonus for doing so ''take precedence'' over team allegiance.Broadcast partner Tim McCarver's curt response: ''It shouldn't.'' Then there's the flap thatNikechairman and founder Phil Knight says prompted ''more negative calls and letters than anything else'' - whether sixNikeDream Teamers would wear Reebok-sponsored team outfits as they accepted their basketball gold medals at the Barcelona Olympics.In his Japanese-style office inNike'sJohn McEnroe Building, Knight, 53, has an answer for each charge. He says the company had ''no influence'' over Sanders' two-way play and that Sanders tookNike'sweekend shuttle ''because it had never been done before.''And whileNike'sMichael Jordan settled on draping a U.S. flag over the Reebok logo at Barcelona, Knight bristles that the media reduced the issue to ''a sound bite'' of an athlete picking ''his company over his country.''A company that last year spent $ 223 million on advertising, according to Advertising Age, doesn't welcome such publicity. Still, Knight says Jordan was upset, ''and I'd be, too.''Upset, that is, because none of the Dream Teamers ''did it for the money'' and because Jordan was presented with the Reebok sponsorship as a done deal. .And that's in violation of a basicNikepremise: The athlete is No. 1 - at least compared to everybody else in the sports world.That might be an unsettling concept to pro teams building fan loyalty meant to withstand lineup shuffles. Or to pro leagues, looking to move merchandise lines and TV rights as players come and go. Or to TV networks, trying to win ratings points with riveting replays, regardless of who's in focus.The friction causes brush fires, such as the dispute about Jordan's successful request that the National Basketball Association stop selling official league merchandise bearing his likeness - gear that arguably competes withNike'sJordan lines, which include $ 23 Air Jordan infant crib booties.''The NBA took those rights without actually having them,'' says Knight. ''Some of the players have said stop.''The primacy of the athlete - and the corollary thatNikehelps consumers find the athlete inside themselves - is as old as the company, whose marketing strategy began with putting shoes on serious runners' feet.Nike'sheadquarters, for instance, is a secular temple to athletes, complete with bust likenesses and encased relics of their exploits.Consider an area devoted to Steve Prefontaine, an Oregon runner killed in a 1975 car accident, displaying a menacing 1974 letter from track's governing body. Prefontaine, after competing in the 1972 Olympics, had the audacity to accept $ 5,000 from an embryonicNikefor basic expenses.The display case notes track officials' response to Prefontaine sporting aNikelogo: ''You can't do that. There are codes. There are subcodes.''Sometimes,Nikewelcomes publicity that pits it against the powers-that- be, such as when the NBA banned the original Air Jordan shoe for being too colorful.But asNikegrew, the criticism has a new edge: that nobody is rooting for Goliath.After slipping to archrival Reebok during the aerobics boom in the 1980s,Nike'srevenues rose from $ 877 million in 1987 to $ 3.4 billion in fiscal 1992.Nike'swomen's category is up from 12% of overall sales two years ago to 20% of today's overall revenues.Nikehopes expanding international sales, now $ 1.2 billion, will grow to 50% of total sales by 1996, when the company projects annual sales will reach $ 6 billion.AndNiketook care of its stockholders: Forbes magazine estimates Knight's personal wealth at $ 1.9 billion, about the same as Ted Turner, cable TV magnate and owner of sports teams.So it might have been only a matter of time untilNike'srole in sports was questioned, albeit not always convincingly. At the Barcelona Olympics, Mizuno endorser Carl Lewis suggested U.S. coach Mel Rosen might have let athletes' ties toNikefactor into his relay selections.The accusation wasn't given much credibility in the track world. And Steve Miller, a longtime track coach and Kansas State athletic director before becomingNike'ssports marketing director, dismisses the charge with more than a discourse on ethics: ''Could I - or anybody else here - keep our job if we did something like that? Absolutely not.''Miller also says the feesNikepays to shod major college basketball teams are guided by market forces. He says fees from about 25% of those deals go directly to colleges rather than to coaches, and that it's fine withNikeif that percentage increases, as long asNikegets the feet. Says Miller: ''How universities run their business is their call.''Nike'smove into providing a range of services for its athletes, the latest being the Charlotte Hornets' Alonzo Mourning, has prompted speculationNikewas ready to flex its muscle in athlete management or even buy out the market leader, International Management Group.Knight adamantly denies the IMG rumor, sayingNike''isn't anxious to get into being a full-blown athlete management company.'' He suggestsNike'sconcern with an athlete's overall business is a logical extension of concern for the credibilityNikewants an endorser to project.Bottom line: ''If sports lose their credibility,'' says Knight, ''so do we.''But don't expectNiketo back off when sports officials call the company an interloper. SaysNikead director Scott Bedbury: ''DoesNikehave a patent on the spirit of athletics? No. But neither does anybody else.''IsNiketoo powerful?Some critics sayNike'sbillion-dollar marketing muscle and flock of star endorsers are having an effect on what happens on the playing field.Some ofNike'sstar endorsersMichael JordanJim CourierAndre AgassiCharles BarkleyDavid RobinsonBo JacksonScottie PippenDeion SandersSergei Bubka NikeInc. revenues (in billions)'92 $ 3.4GRAPHIC:GRAPHIC, color, Sam Ward, USA TODAY, Source:NikeInc. (Diagram, line graph; PHOTO, color, H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY CUTLINE: SANDERS: Reported bonus for playing two sports.See sidebar;Nikechairman answers critics; See info box at end of text.
email_title: Criticism grows along with business

Email_Body: UNLESS you've been hovering round the dark side of the moon lately, you'll be aware that the Barcelona Olympics are now a matter only of weeks away. None are more conscious of this than the folks at Channel Seven, which will be screening 21 hours a day of games to recoup through advertising revenues some of the reported $46 million the network poured into the screening rightsThat money, of course, doesn't pay for the herculean operation that Seven has undertaken to ensure Australian viewers aren't tempted away from gymnastics and archery by Wendt and Hinch.Seven has, more or less, built a medium-sized TV station in Barcelona which, of course, will all have to be pulled down less than three weeks after the opening ceremony on July 25.Once hacks, camera crews, technicians and so on are all assembled in the city, Seven's Barcelona staff will number more than 150, which represents a pretty colossal expense account.THE media loves a controversy story when it comes to the Olympics, and Addison has turned up a couple of them.First, try to imagine the Spanish police interrupting a basketball game and asking the American athletes to strip their gear off, then confiscating shirts and shorts bearing theNikelogo. Ridiculous?Not according to The New York Times, which reports that a trademark row in Spain has resulted in a judgement in favour of a Spanish lawyer, Juan Amigo, an associate ofNike'sformer distributor in Spain who now sells a pirate line ofNikeclothing.As sponsors of the US Olympic teams, the realNike, of course, has counted on huge advertising exposure at the games, but Snr Amigo's court win means thatNikemay not market its sports clothes - except shoes for some unexplained reason - during the Olympics. With no appeal possible before July 25, the NYT saysNikewill have to sell its clothing line at souvenir stands in Barcelona without the logo.Amigo's price to drop the ban is a cool $US10 million, about half ofNike'sannual sales in Spain.SECOND: The European Broadcasting Union, EBU, is facing huge fines, according to Reuter, for refusing to allow a private channel, Screensport, access to any Olympic coverage.The EBU is a grouping of the main national broadcasters in Europe(including France's Antenne 2 and the BBC), but it has stubbornly refused Screensport any footage rights because it wants to pass on pooled coverage of the games to its own channel, called Eurosport.The European Commission appears to have grown annoyed at the EBU's stance, and has threatened it with emergency rulings this week, with fines that could make the Olympic TV rights look paltry, if it does not comply.SHE won't be covering the Olympics, but SBS will this week cover her.In one of those table-turning exercises that TV producers, if not always the viewing public, love indulging in, Jana Wendt has been allowed out of the Nine Network for an evening to appear as the victim of a Face the Press interview, to be screened on SBS at 8 o'clock tomorrow evening.The programme will mark only the second time Jana has appeared as an interviewee outside the Nine Network since January 1988, says the SBS publicity blurb.Gosh.
email_title: ADDISON

Email_Body: Probably by August 2000, at an Olympic Stadium constructed in someplace quiet, like Madison Avenue, a new Olympic era will be ushered in: no flags, no competing nations, only corporate sponsors. There will be teams fromNike, Reebok, Mizuno, from Umbro, Speedo, Converse, from adidas, Champion and Starter, from McDonald's, Wheaties and Pizza Hut. Michael Jordan and hisNikesagainst Shaquille O'Neal and his Reeboks in the gold medal basketball game. If the Games of Barcelona, which open Saturday, are any indication, we're closer to this insanity than you think. Just in case you haven't been obsessively following this summer's Sponsor Wars, let's recap: A Barcelona-based company named Cidesport, which claims it registered the nameNikein 1932, has won a decision in a Spanish court that upholds Cidesport's right to the trademark. Supposedly, this means all sponsored athletes are prohibited from wearing the nameNikeon their apparel here at the Summer Olympics. The Tribunal Constitutional didn't, however, tell us exactly how this ruling would be enforced. "What are they going to have,Nikepolice strip Gwen Torrence before she runs the 100?" a U.S. Olympic official asked Friday. "Are they going to rip off Carl Lewis's pants because they have the wordNikeon them? They're blustering and assuring the world that's what will happen. But if they want a brouhaha like the Olympics has never seen, let them try to tell our athletes what they can and cannot wear."Yes, indeed, you would be better off driving an athlete's Porsche into the drink before you mess with his or her clothing contract. This is more than just this little two-bit, publicity-hungry Cidesport vs.Nike.Nikealso is embroiled in a set-to with its primary rival, Reebok. Each sport of each country determines its apparel sponsor, which is why the U.S. basketball team is wearing uniforms made by Champion, sporting the Champion logo, and why the U.S. track and field team is wearingNikeuniforms. But each National Olympic Committee makes its own apparel deal; in this case the USOC has made it mandatory that all athletes wear an outfit made by Henry Grethel (via JCPenney) in the Opening Ceremonies, and sweats by Reebok during the medal and closing ceremonies. So what you've got, for example, is decathlete Dave Johnson, a Reebok guy, having to compete all week in aNiketrack suit.If you don't think the Logo Wars are impassioned, consider that Michael Jordan would rather stand nude on the medal stand than wear that unspeakable "other brand" in which he would be photographed and seen by more than 1 billion people. Wearing the mandatory clothing is part of the code of conduct that each athlete signs before the Games. Still, Jordan told Sports Illustrated, "There's no way in the world I'm wearing a suit made by Reebok."He reiterated that sentiment during a conversation in Monte Carlo last week. And a spokesman for the Dream Team said Friday, "Michael still says there's no way he's wearing it. Something will have to be resolved."It's unimaginable that theNikeathletes, including Jordan, Charles Barkley, Scottie Pippen, David Robinson and world record pole vaulter Sergei Bubka, would ever let Cidesport, or a Spanish court for that matter, intimidate them into putting tape over theNikelogo. But it's completely imaginable that they'd tape over the word Reebok during a medal ceremony, or wear aNikehat or some other attention-drawing piece of clothing that would pay homage to the company that pays each of them millions.Jordan, who isn't one to budge on such issues, may have to this time. It's not as if Reebok can go out and distribute posters with his likeness, wearing its apparel, after the Olympics. He (and the five other Dream Teamers signed withNike) already have been photographed ad nauseum wearing Champion, which is clearly a competitor. Jordan will spend much more time in a Champion uniform than he would in Reebok sweats.Nikegot the deal with The Athletics Congress and Reebok has to live, uneasily, with that. SoNikewill have to live with the fact that Reebok got the deal with the USOC.You'd hope that at some point the athletes would cherish the uniform to the point, that anything having USA and the Olympic rings would transcend the issue of who makes the garment. At some point, commercialism has to be put aside, even only for a few moments.Nikewon't void a deal with Jordan because he wears the USOC-issued warmups. Reebok won't revoke a deal with Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, Michael Chang, Zina Garrison or Coach Chuck Daly in the event each wears another sponsor's shirt for 10 minutes.That, of course, is probably the naive view, the opinion of a man who isn't paid millions to do anything exclusively. Even in the few cases in life when money isn't involved, extremist pride often is. When we see Fidel Castro wearing military fatigues with a swoosh on the chest and the words "Just Do It" underneath, we'll know the whole concept of sponsorship has gone completely over the edge.GRAPHIC:PHOTO, DREAM TEAM STAR MICHAEL JORDAN, ANIKECLIENT, VOWS HE'LL NOT BE SEEN IN A REEBOK OUTFIT FURING MEDAL CEREMONIES. STAY TUNED. REUTER
email_title: There's Nothing Cold About Logo Wars in Barcelona

Email_Body: PORTLAND, Ore. - The ad agency of Wieden and Kennedy, chief image crafter ofNikeshoes (''Just Do It'') and Subaru cars (''What to Drive''), is pushing the advertising envelope with its risky, intuitive campaigns and an unorthodox - to say the least - management style.  Two leading trade magazines, Advertising Age and Adweek, each have named Wieden and Kennedy agency of the year, citing the countercultural nature of the firm's work.  With current annual billings of $200 million, Wieden and Kennedy also has been in the running for two huge new accounts: MasterCard and Sega of America, which markets Genesis video games. Together, these represent about $115 million a year in new business.  To put the significance of this another way, an agency typically keeps 15 percent of its client's billings.  Yet Wieden and Kennedy staff members seem unfazed by all the attention.  They wear jackets inscribed with the reminder, ''Don't Act Big, No Sharp Stuff.'' Staff lists are alphabetized by first names.  Titles are left off business cards.  Nobody dresses up.  Beer flows from kegs on Friday afternoons.  And job applicants lucky enough to get interviews are asked such things as, ''Do you like to have fun?'' (Right answer: Yes). Or, ''Which kind of Milky Way is better - plain or dark chocolate?'' (Right answer: Let's go have a drink, then decide).  ''We don't have a personnel department,'' says Dan Wieden, one of the names on the door. ''What personnel manager in his right mind would hire these people?'' David Kennedy, the other founder, sometimes is mistaken for a janitor by the slew of new employees the agency has hired in the last year to cope with its startling growth. Little wonder - his work attire consists of denim pants, denim shirt, cowboy boots and a big ring of keys dangling from his belt.  Wieden, 47, says he didn't have much enthusiasm for advertising when he got into the business right out of the University of Oregon. He had wanted to be ''a playwright or a poet - something meaningful,'' he says.  Then, while working as a copywriter at a now-defunct Portland advertising office, he met Kennedy, who had moved his family of seven from Chicago to take a job as art director.  All of a sudden, Wieden says, advertising took on a whole new meaning. ''It was like realizing there was a higher form of the profession that could be very rewarding.'' The pair eventually worked up the nerve to start their own agency in 1982.  Their first account wasNike,whose billings at the time amounted to a measly $1 million a year.  There is a saying in adverti sing that great clients make great advertising.  There is no question, says Kennedy, 52, that the agency is the child ofNikeInc., the sports giant based in Beaverton, Ore.Niketook most of its advertising away from Wieden and Kennedy in 1983, then gave the whole thing back to the renegade ad shop in 1986.  ''Nikeallows us to be brave and has funded that bravery,'' Wieden says.  ''They ask us to jump off cliffs - and jump off with us.'' Indeed, asNikerevenues swelled to $3 billion a year - and its ad budget to more than $100 million - Wieden and Kennedy's work has grown in stature.  From the Bo (''Bo knows . . . '') Jackson self-parodies, to the teaming of Bugs Bunny and Michael Jordan, to the technically brilliant ''Instant Karma'' spot,Nikehas allowed Wieden and Kennedy to push the envelope.  ''A lot of agencies follow linear paths guided almost exclusively by research,'' says Scott Bedbury,Nike'sdirector of advertising. ''Wieden and Kennedy places a very high priority on the visceral side of communication.  It's a philosophy we share with them.'' In other words, it's a right brain kind of thing.  TheNikespots tend to be risky, but even Wieden and Kennedy's competitors say they get the job done.  ''At the end of the day when everybody goes home, it's what's in the magazines and what's on television that counts,'' says Bob Kuperman, president and chief executive officer of Chiat-Day-Mojo, a bigger agency in Venice, Calif., with a long reputation for producing creative ad campaigns. It currently handles advertising for Reebok,Nike'schief rival, and wasNike'sagency from 1983 to 1986. ''Wieden and Kennedy has consistently delivered, '' Kuperman says.  Despite Wieden and Kennedy's much-heralded work forNike,the agency didn't move into advertising's major leagues until it picked up the $70 million-a-year Subaru of America account last year.  To work with Subaru, the agency opened an office in Philadelphia, just across the Delaware River from Subaru headquarters in Cherry Hill, N.J.  Some staff members saw it as the breakup of the Wieden and Kennedy family.  Insiders and outsiders alike wondered whether the rapidly growing agency would lose its edge and become (gasp) predictable.  So far, it hasn't. Wieden and Kennedy's work for Subaru - which, unlikeNike,is far from a market leader and has suffered from an identity crisis - has turned car advertising on its ear with a revolutionary campaign that mocks the 1980s ethos of automobile as status symbol.  Meanwhile, back in Portland, co-creative directors Dan Wieden and David Kennedy try to figure out how to get big without getting bad.
email_title: NIKE'SAD SHOP JUST DOES IT

Email_Body: Foot in mouth disease NOW it can be told _ the true story of whyNikescrapped a television commercial for their trainer shoes. And a bizarre tale it is too. It seemsNikewent to a lot of trouble and dollars to make a commercial in Africa for American audiences.The idea was to have a group of Masai warriors running through the bush wearingNiketrainers and endorsing the firm's product in between spearing passing antelopes.A grumpy looking warrior fronts the screen, mutters something in his native dialect and a translation appears on the screen ""Just do it", which isNikeAmerica's slogan.Unfortunately that is not quite what the warrior actually said.Freely translated, the grumpy-looking warrior said: ""These are horrid shoes and they aren't big enough."As luck would have it, one of the few people outside Africa who spoke the warrior's language just happened to see the commercial at its first _ and only _ showing. End of commercial. Exit sullen natives.Exit red-faced ad makers.
email_title: RED FACES AS SHOE BLUE BLACKS OUT AD

Email_Body: Michael Jordan has told the NBA it no longer can sell apparel bearing hisimage, givingNikeInc. those rights exclusively.The Oregonian reported Jordan's decision, confirmed by the league,Wednesday. The move, unprecedented in the NBA, means millions of dollars.Jordan, 28, who led the Chicago Bulls to their first championship lastyear, is among the NBA's most charismatic personalities. Jordan, who has been on theNikepayroll since 1984, will earn $21.2 million in endorsements thisyear, according to reports.Nikeearns about $200 million a year on Jordan's image.
email_title: JORDAN-NIKEDEAL COSTS NBA MILLIONS

Email_Body: Unethical business practices hurt U.S. productivity, Gov. John D. Ashcroft said Friday in St. Louis.  ''Employees steal $160 billion worth of things from their employers in this country,'' Ashcroft said. ''Time spent stealing is time not spent producing.'' Ashcroft was addressing a conference sponsored by St. Louis University Emerson Electric Center for Business Ethics.  ''Rules have been relaxed in the legal profession,'' Ashcroft said. He said that advertising has permitted lawyers to solicit clients and increase the volume of litigation.  Ashcroft said the country ''needs new heroes.'' Today, he said, people regarded as heroes are those ''who ask the question, 'Is it legal?' - not, 'Is it right?' '' MONSANTO Mahoney Wins Management Award Richard J. Mahoney, chairman and chief executive officer of Monsanto Co., was awarded the first Corporate Cultural Diversity Management Award on Friday.  The award was presented by the Business Minority Council of Washington University's John M. Olin School of Business. The award is intended to honor efforts to increase the number of minorities and women within senior management.  ''Monsanto has been at the forefront of creating and implementing management training modules which encourage development of a culturally diverse work force,'' said Robert L. Virgil, dean of Olin School.  NATIONAL RJR NABISCO New Stock Offering Announced RJR Nabisco Inc. announced Friday in New York that it would issue 100 million new shares of common stock at a price of $11.25 apiece.  The food and tobacco conglomerate, which said last month it would sell 75 million shares, said it increased the size of the offering because of ''greater marketplace interest.'' An earlier 129-million-share stock issue, made as part of a debt exchange offer, has proved immensely popular on Wall Street. The shares began trading at $5.50 a share on Feb. 1 and have climbed past $11.  The already outstanding stock led the most-active list in afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange Friday, rising 25 cents to $11.75 a share.  APNIKEAvia Sues Rival Over Patent In a battle of athletic shoe rivals, Avia is suingNikeon claims of patent infringement.  The lawsuit, filed Thursday in U.S. District Court in Portland, Ore., accusesNikeof using a cushioning system similar to Avia's ''Cantilever'' technology inNike'snew Air 180 shoes, which sell for $125 a pair.  The lawsuit asks for unspecified damages as well as an injunction to stopNikefrom making and selling Air 180s, which were introduced in a nationwide advertising campaign during this year's Super Bowl.  AP R.H. MACY Aggressive Ad Campai gn Planned R.H. Macy & Co. Inc., shifting gears after a year of financial angst, said Friday it is expanding advertising in an aggressive drive for new business.  The retailer said it was spending $150 million on a television advertising campaign that is kicking off in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut area and will reach all of Macy's markets by the beginning of 1992.  The campaign is five times the retailer's $30 million annual budget for television advertising.  AP REVLON INC.  Second Big Asset Sale Held Revlon Inc. said Friday it would issue 40 million shares in its National Health Laboratories subsidiary, the second big asset sale announced by the cosmetics maker this week.  The privately-held Revlon sold an 18 percent stake in National Health Laboratories to the public last year. The new issue will leave Revlon with approximately 42 percent of the stock in the division.  Revlon said in a statement it would use the proceeds of the latest stock sale to reduce its debt load.  Earlier this week, Revlon agreed to sell its Max Factor product lines and Betrix subsidiary in Germany to Procter & Gamble Co.  AP USX CORP.  Two New Issues Begin Trading Two new issues of USX Corp. stock began trading Friday on the New York Stock Exchange - one for Marathon Oil Co. and one for the parent company's steel business.  The exchange allowed trading of the shares pending an approval of the split by USX shareholders at a meeting next month in Houston. The move allows the public to decide in which of the company's main businesses to invest.  The proposal calls for each share of USX stock to be converted into one share of Marathon stock and one-fifth of a share of steel stock.  The Marathon Oil stock fell 37 1/2 cents to $29.37 1/2 in NYSE trading Friday. The new steel issue climbed $2.75 to $22.75 on the exchange.  USX stock continues to trade normally, giving investors three ways to trade in the company. USX closed up 75 cents at $33.75.  AP INTERNATIONAL JAPAN GE, Toshiba Form Joint Venture Toshiba Corp. and General Electric Co. have agreed to form a joint venture to import and sell GE appliances in Japan, officials of the two companies said Friday in Tokyo.  GE Appliances Japan, Ltd., will be established in Tokyo next month to import and sell refrigerators, washer-dryers and other large appliances.  GE will contribute 51 percent of the 490 million yen ($3.6 million) in capital and Toshiba will contribute 41 percent. A holding company to be established in Singapore by the two firms will put up the remaining 8 percent.  Asahi News Service
email_title: ST. LOUIS BUSINESS PRACTICES ASHCROFT BLASTS U.S. ETHICS

Email_Body: Shares of United Telecommunications Inc., owner of long-distance company Sprint, sank 1 1/8 to $ 23 5/8 Monday as investors worried that Sprint may lose or have to adjust a contract with the government.The General Accounting Office claims the federal government is paying AT&T and Sprint $ 148 million more in the next two years than it should. It said Sprint charges too much. That could lead Congress to force Sprint to cut rates. AT&T and Sprint share a $ 25 billion contract to provide the government with long-distance phone service. But analysts say investor concerns about Sprint losing the contract are exaggerated. A lot of the fuss, they say, has been caused by MCI, which doesn't have a piece of the contract and keeps telling the government it could do the job more cheaply than either AT&T or Sprint.Joel Gross of Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette says Sprint already has cut long-distance rates several times to bring them in line with AT&T's rates. Gross says investors are worried that Sprint could lose a portion of its contract in 1993 after the contract is rebid. But that's unlikely. ''There is a rebid in the fourth year of the contract, but only between the two existing players,'' Gross says.Shoe-in:NikeInc.  gained 3 to $ 51 1/8 after the company reported a record quarter.Nikehad net income of $ 114.4 million, or $ 1.50 a share - vs. $ 99.7 million, or $ 1.31 a share, last year. It had record revenue of $ 947 million.NikePresident Richard Donahue told Reuter news service that he will expand his workforce by 500 to about 5,000 worldwide.The strong first-quarter results surprised Wall Street, which had worried that consumers would balk at buying high-priced athletic shoes during a recession. But ''price resistance hasn't hit yet,'' says Kidder Peabody analyst Gary Jacobson. ''People will continue to pay north of $ 100 for sneakers.'' Still, Jacobson is in no rush to buyNikeshares. ''Now's the time to stay on the sidelines,'' he advises. He thinksNikeis vulnerable until a recovery is evident.In fact,Nikewarned that next quarter could be weak. The company's worldwide orders for shoes and apparel scheduled for delivery between now and January are $ 1.1 billion - up 2% from last year. But Jacobson had been looking for a 7% gain.
email_title: Sprint owner's shares fall on GAO report

Email_Body: There's no trick to finding the Georgia Dome these days. It finds you. Nine months ago the $ 210 million project was merely a few concrete footings. Now much of the Dome's outside structure rises dramatically out of what last year was a vacant lot. On May 1, they start on the roof.By February, 1992, the exterior will be watertight. Hey, 25 years later, they can't even say that about Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium. . . . Georgia Dome officials even found two suites recently they didn't know existed. Architects had planned for four owner suites - two upper level and two lower level - but only two are needed. Dome marketing director Dennis Berkholtz leased the newly discovered ones for $ 80,000 each. . . . Go figure: The Georgia Dome still has a dirt floor and cannot be used. Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium puts tons of dirt over it's sodded grass to hold a motocross Saturday night.SUPER BUDGET: How big has "The Super Show" become? Exhibit A: The Nikepeople have a $ 6 million budget just for this week's events at the Georgia World Congress Center. Things are so secretive regardingNike's presentation Thursday that a security guard has been stationed next to the escalator leading to the ballroom level, under an elaborateNike archway. Workers in the area assembling booths must wear ID bracelets. . . . Exhibit B: No other trade show in the nation requires what this one does. All current exhibitors must pay for next year's space before they leave on Feb. 24, allowing show organizers to draw interest on the money.KISSING BANDIT: To the tune of "Brick House" by the Commodores, mascot Harry the Hawk came out during a timeout dressed as a buxom blonde and swaggered up to NBA official Dick Bavetta at last Saturday night's Hawks-Sonics game. Locking up with Harry in a sudden embrace, Bavetta laid one emphatically on the mascot's kisser. When razzed by players on the Hawks bench, Bavetta glanced over to them and said, "Hey, it's lonely on the road." . . . Hawks trainer Joe O'Toole has lost 40 pounds over a period of less than three months and is down to about 180 - no small feat considering the caloric nightmare of food on the road. It didn't come without a struggle. O'Toole's beloved afternoon ice-cream snacks are pretty much history, and he walks at least 40 minutes a day. On a recent trip to San Francisco O'Toole walked from Fisherman's Wharf across the Golden Gate Bridge and back, a distance of about nine miles, in 3 1/2 hours. . . . Somebody forgot to tell Kevin Loughery he isn't a head coach anymore. It's his voice, not Bob Weiss's, that carries from the Hawks bench. . . . Kelly Freeman, Miss Augusta, sang the national anthem Saturday night. So why were there are few catcalls when she was introduced to The Omni crowd? Mistakenly, she was referred to as Miss AuguIN THE TRENCHES: Atlanta Falcons offensive guard John Scully, who studies battles and war strategy in his spare time, has difficulty getting a feel for the Persian Gulf conflict. "It's kind of hard to develop a mental picture," said Scully, who has a model of the Battle of Murfreesboro set up in his house. "You don't even know the disposition of troops on the border. It's truly desert warfare. The only thing you could compare it with is the North African campaign during World War II, where logistics and supplies were really how campaigns were won or lost. It's difficult to defend in the desert because it's a featureless terrain. There's no place to hide. The attacker usually is rewarded." . . . Todd Marinovich, the banished Southern Cal quarterback, still has a lifestyle unbalanced from most folks. He's never tried a Big Mac, and they've never tried cocaine. . . . A nickname that should have stuck by now for a player who moves swiftly, sometimes under enemy defenses, and occasionally inflicts great damage from the perimeter: Scud Webb. . . . Hard to believe: Dunwoody tour golfer Tim Simpson, during a recent TV interview, claiming not to be bothered if people fail to recognize his talent. Sure, and at the Masters, Simpson would shrug off a ball shanked t
email_title: Glenn Sheeley's Sportscene; Georgia Dome keeps growing easier to find

Email_Body: Move over, Michael. Here comes Bo.Creating a natural marketing tie-in with basketball star and fellow Nikepitchman Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls, outfielder Bo Jackson signed with the Chicago White Sox on Wednesday. "It's not the fame, it's not the money, it's the chance to go out and get the world championship," said Jackson, who signed a one-year contract.However, Toronto Blue Jays general manager Pat Gillick said he thinks an association withNikeinfluenced Jackson's decision as much as the White Sox's status as contenders in the American League West."The wholeNikedeal was in Chicago. With him and Jordan owned by the same company, there is so much imagination that can come out of something like that," Gillick said.Gillick's Blue Jays and the Atlanta Braves were the other two clubs considered seriously by Jackson, a free agent after his release by the Kansas City Royals because of a hip injury sustained in last season's NFL playoffs."We weren't able to get into it at all," said Braves general manager John Schuerholz. "Richard Woods Jackson's agent called me Tuesday night to tell me things were moving pretty rapidly. He didn't tell me a signing was imminent. But there was nothing we could do about it."Jackson's salary will depend on how much he is able to play. The White Sox have options for 1992 and 1993. The first option will be automatic if Jackson is activated for at least 40 games this season. The White Sox must pick up the second option if Jackson plays at least 125 games in 1992.Jackson will earn $ 10,000 for each game played this season or a total of $ 700,000, whichever is greater. If he fulfills all performance bonuses over the next three seasons, he will make $ 8.1 million. Bonuses earned will automatically be included in the next season's base salary.The contract does not prohibit Jackson from fulfilling the final year of his $ 7.4 million contract with the NFL's Los Angeles Raiders if his health permits.
email_title: Bo finds home in Chicago; White Sox deal is pay-for-play

Email_Body: Georgia basketball coach Hugh Durham may make less than athletics director Vince Dooley, but when it comes to shoe contracts, Durham's the top Dog.According to documents obtained by The Journal-Constitution, Durham was paid a salary of $ 75,000 by Georgia in the 1986-87 basketball season.  For the '86 football season, Dooley, who was football coach and athletics director at the time, had a base salary of $ 95,000. Other income greatly increased the total packages of both men - Dooley's to $ 374,497.89, Durham's to $ 255,100.Both also had shoe contracts withNike. Dooley's called for a $ 30,000 endorsement fee, plus $ 2,000 in merchandise. Durham's called for a $ 35,000 endorsement fee, plus $ 1,500 in merchandise."That is a basic contract all coaches associated withNikehave," Durham said. "Nikehas about 60 or 70 coaches. It's a quite comprehensive document. It's not like they're dealing with one person; they're dealing with 60 or 70."Additional benefits include $ 5,000 worth (wholesale value) of merchandise for Durham to use at his camps and clinics, $ 1,500 worth (retail value) of goods for his personal use, $ 300 in merchandise for each of three assistants and 135 pairs of shoes for his team.In exchange, Durham wearsNikeshoes and sportswear exclusively.According to figures provided two years ago by Durham's attorney, Nick Chilivis, Durham also earned $ 3,000 from a basketball contract with MacGregor and $ 1,500 from a uniform manufacturer.Women's basketball coach Andy Landers made a base salary of $ 45,000 for the '86-87 season, but added only $ 9,500 in outside income, for a total package of $ 54,500.
email_title: Shoe deals fit just right for Durham

Email_Body: Turner Broadcasting System announced plans Wednesday to build the first independent television station in Moscow in cooperation with a Russian company. The joint venture must compete with other groups for a license to use Channel 6, the last VHF frequency available in Moscow. The plan is contingent on approval by the boards of TBS and its partner, the Moscow Independent Broadcasting Co.  CHAIRMAN FIRED: Hiroaki Shikanai was fired Wednesday as chairman of Sankei Shimbun, one of the most influential newspapers in Japan. ''Mr. Shikanai lacks the qualifications to represent such a company,'' said Shigeaki Hazama, president of the newspaper, part of giant media conglomerate Fuji Sankei. It's not clear why Shikanai was ousted. But Hazama confirmed reports that it was related to a scandal involving retirement benefits Shikanai alledgedly had the company pay the family of his predecessor, his father-in-law, Nobutaka Shikanai. NIKEDEFEAT: The Constitutional Court in Spain rejectedNike'slast-ditch appeal in its multimillion-dollar Spanish trademark feud, just days before U.S. athletes are slated to wear theNikename in the Barcelona Olympics. The decision by Spain's highest appeals court makes it a virtual certainty thatNikewill have to comply with an order barring the Beaverton, Ore., company from selling or advertising its sports apparel in Spain.Nikepaid millions to put its name on U.S. and Algerian track and field teams in Barcelona. BCCI PAYOUTS: The comprehensive plan to pay off the former depositors of the fraud-ridden Bank of Credit and Commerce International may now fall apart after a Luxembourg court delayed approval of the deal, Reuters reported Tuesday.  If a majority of creditors oppose the plan, which has the backing of Abu Dhabi, the main stockholder in the bank, the court may ask that changes be made. But radical alterations are unlikely as a result of the Luxembourg ruling. CHINESE TRADE: The House of Representatives passed two bills to clamp down on China's lucrative trade with the United States, hours after Beijing sentenced a reform-minded official to nine years in prison. Both bills face a veto threat from President Bush, who says continued contact is the best way of encouraging improvement in China's human rights record.  The first bill, passed 258-135, overturned Bush's one-year extension of preferential trade treatment for Beijing. The second, narrower measure would let the so-called 'most favored nation' trading status run through next July but then impose conditions on its renewal. It passed 339-62. FAA NETWORK: MCI Communications Corp. laid out the design Tuesday for its new telecommunications network for the Federal Aviation Administration, which uses a duplicate backup system to safeguard it from communications blackouts.  The 4.5 million mile network has software that detects and automatically reroutes calls to a duplicate backup system. BUSINESS HOLIDAYS: Banking and government offices may be affected by holidays Thursday in Egypt, Papua New Guinea and Syria; Friday in Ecuador and Venezuela; Saturday in Puerto Rico, Cuba, Maldives, Costa Rico and Equatorial Guinea.Compiled by Darren Summers
email_title: MOSCOW TV VENTURE

Email_Body: The state of Missouri currently has a model for the non-graded primary school.AtNikeElementary in Catawissa, students who have previously been bound to a traditional kindergarten-through-third-grade program are now offered a 3- , 4- or 5-year program. This non-graded approach allows teachers to move children through a continuous curriculum, allowing the developmental differences.  The overall goal is to ensure that all children reach their academic potential.  Although the non-graded program has been compared to the one-room schoolhouse, marked differences exist. Age groups and grades are clearly identified, and preset graded curriculums are taught year to year in a rigid format.  As large numbers of students began to attend, school rooms were added to existing buildings, and the different grades were split apart. This more closely aligns the one-room concept to our traditional graded schools of today. Certainly much cross-age learning occurred. Younger pupils learned from listening to older classes, and older students having problems could listen as presentations were made to younger classes. Much peer tutoring was employed, both as a help for the teacher and because the children enjoyed working together.  Today's non-graded program seeks to define sets of learner objectives that allow for developmental difference s of children. Learning strategies and materials to accommodate the flexible time provisions of non-graded classrooms can be varied and diverse. What they have in common is an understanding of how to determine when the child is academically ready to move from level to level. In a non-graded primary school, there is no repeating of a grade because of academic failure. Instead of retention, students are taught at a pace that ensures academic success and growth. A child may take five years to complete the traditional K-3 program, but it occurs by progressing through the primary levels at a slower pace. Teachers do not have to subvert the system to fit the child's needs but can use flexible time provisions to move a child at any time that child has met the academic criteria for each level. A three-year program is also offered atNikeallowing a student to accelerate through the program with academic successes. The curriculum is flexible, expanding to challenge all children.  The developers ofNike'snon-graded primary - myself, Barb Betz and Jean Wills - have broadened the curriculum to meet student needs. They have embraced a variety of teaching strategies including cooperative learning, cross-age tutoring, extensive use of volunteers, continuous assessment and mastery learning to help each child achieve academic successes. We have not addressed or cured all the problems that face our educational system, but we believe we have taken a step in the right direction.  Karen M. Smith is a teacher atNikeElementary School, Catawissa, Mo.
email_title: BACK TO THE ONE-ROOM SCHOOLHOUSE?

Email_Body: Beachcombers along the Pacific coast of the United States and Canada are scrambling to collectNikerunning shoes - the result of a lost cargo of footwear washed overboard from a ship a year ago."I am wearing a pair now, and I love them," said Steve McLeod, an artist in Cannon Beach, Ore., who has collected 70 shoes, including 10 pairs. Local residents of this Pacific coast town 64 kilometres (40 miles) west of Portland said the spring tides deposited hundreds ofNikeshoes along the coast.The footwear apparently washed overboard from a cargo ship more than a year ago, according to the Beaverton, Ore., athletics sportswear company.Niketransportation manager Rick Hastings said the shoes came from five large shipping containers that washed off a ship bound from South Korea to Seattle in May, 1990.The containers held 40,000 pairs ofNikerunning shoes, golf shoes and hiking boots.Hastings said the shoes have been found as far north as Vancouver Island in British Columbia."They have a little bit of seaweed on them and a few barnacles. But scrape that off and you have a standard pair of shoes," Hastings said."The only complaint I have received is that we didn't tie the pairs together, so they have to match them."McLeod said beachcombers have formed the Sneaker Society which meets to swap shoes to come up with pairs. He said anyone who finds shoes on the beach is welcome to join.
email_title: Beachcombers are pumped up!

Email_Body: THE ex-Socceroo tag doesn't sit kindly with Jeff Olver.The Heidelberg goalkeeper, the No.1 choice for Australia between 1986-89, is determined to regain the Socceroo crown from Robert Zabica and John Filan.Olver believes that at 30 he is still young in goalkeeping terms."If you look at the World Cup finals, you'll find the average age of the keepers is 35-36 with a few exceptions, like Zoff and Shilton, going well beyond that," Olver said. If form rather than age is the prerequisite for a spot in the national side, Olver has gone a long way towards staking a claim with his displays for Heidelberg."At the start of the season all the raves were about (St George keeper) Filan but I've looked for consistency rather than spectacular saves and I'm very pleased with my own form and the team's overall," he said.Olver was singled out for praise by coach Len McKendry after his keeping ensured a 1-0 win over Wollongong Mac and the two points made certain Heidelberg finishes clear of the relegation zone."That match was our cup final," he said. "It was worth four points as a defeat would have dragged us back near the bottom two." Olver's performance against Wollongong Mac earns him the player-of-the-week title in the Herald-SunNikeAir Golden Boot award.He receives a pair ofNikeAir runners worth $280. Email_Body: THE legendary Carl Lewis has boosted his £5 million-a-year earnings with a £1 million payment to advertise Japanese shoe producers Mizuno at next week's Barcelona Olympics.His US colleague, decathlete Dan O'Brien, picked up another cool million from rival sport shoe manufacturers Reebok in a spectacular £12 million television advertising campaign.German golden girl Katrin Krabbe was also paid a small fortune by market leadersNiketo sport their famous flash in Spain.At the other end of the scale, Britain's Linford Christie, the fastest man in Europe, has a £60,000-a-year contract with Puma to show off their latest footwear at the Games. And gritty Scottish long-distance star, Liz McColgan, perhaps the best British gold medal prospect, has recently signed a £20,000-a-year shoe deal with Asics.The payments are part of a £1 billion bonanza on offer at Barcelona as the world's running shoe firms and corporate giants search for stars to help them out of recession.There is, however, an ironic difference between Christie and McColgan and their American rivals, not merely a financial one.The British stars will be on their blocks and raring to go in the events that made their names. The mega-stars on whom the shoe people pinned most of their hopes and their dollar bills will not.Lewis failed dismally in the US sprint trials and will not be defending his Olympic title in the race to find the fastest man on earth.Fellow trials' flop O'Brien and Krabbe - 'emotionally exhausted' after finally winning a long, bitter fight to clear herself of drug test fiddling charges - will be going to Barcelona only as spectators.In fact, the endorsement campaigns devised by the leading sport shoe companies, competing in a cut-throat battle for a world market valued at a staggering £10 billion, are in utter disarray.To add to the general air of despondency, the final run-up to Barcelona has been littered with other big-name casualties, leaving embarrassed ad campaign directors in the industry in danger of entering the Marketing Hall of Shame.Other major household names in athletics who have fallen at the final hurdle, through injury, personal problems and enforced early retirement include Daley Thompson, Steve Cram, Peter Elliott, Roger Kingdom and Mary Decker-Slaney.As a result, a new air of caution has gripped major sports sponsors in Britain, marked by a flat refusal to invest in expensive network television marketing campaigns with any of our elite track and field athletes.The distinct lack of real big money interest is further highlighted by the fact that not one of the members of the Chafford 100 club, set up by former world javelin champion Fatima Whitbread to look after elite athletes' commercial aspirations, features among the top 10 earners in British sport.With personal sponsorship deals totalling just £1.5 million over the past 18 months for 17 of Britain's current crop of 24 elite athletes, they have emerged as the poor relations.Even with handsome appearance fees, grand prix prize money, newspaper interviews, fashion fees and television appearances on programmes like A Question of Sport, none of our top Olympians is understood to have earned more than £250,000 over the past year.In 1991 Peter Elliott was Britain's top athletics earner, making £160,000 (including a £20,000-per-year contract with Asics).Linford Christie's total earnings over the same period were reported to be over £100,000, although since his world championships success he is believed to have more than doubled his money to take over top spot.Other leading British earners include: javelin star Steve Backley, £150,000 (£55,000 from Adidas); Liz McColgan, £100,000; 400-metres Olympic medal hopeful Roger Black, £90,000-plus (£55,000 from Adidas); and Tom McKean, £80,000-plus (£20,000-per-year from New Ballance).According to Fatima Whitbread, most of these shoe deals have at least doubled in the cases of medallists from the world championships, with £25,000 bonus clauses built in for major Olympic success.The insulting fact that Britain's current crop of Olympic hopefuls appear to have been labelled also-rans in the major advertising stakes will, no doubt, spur them on to greater heights in their quest for Barcelona gold.If further incentive is needed for them to fill the apparent mega-star void, they need only look back at the riches garnered by Britain's most famous athletic rivals, Coe and Ovett.Sebastian Coe, the only man ever to win Olympic gold twice at the blue-riband 1,500 metres distance, bought a £1 million house in Twickenham with his earnings.Steve Ovett went on to enjoy his semi-retirement from a 16-bedroom mansion near Annan in Scotland.Had either been around today who knows what further fortunes would have lain in store? They might even have been up among the Faldos, Eubanks, Carsons and Gazzas in the earnings stakes.GRAPHIC:TOP ROW, FROM LEFT: MICHAEL JOHNSON, WITHNIKE,A HOT FAVOURITE FOR BARCELON LD; KATRIN KRABBE (EX-NIKE)AND DAN O'BRIEN (EX-REEBOK) BOTH SPECTATORS ONLY AT BARCELONA. BOTTOM ROW, FROM LEFT: LIZ MCCOLGAN, WITH ASICS, A GOLD MEDAL PROSPEC T, AND LINFORD CHRISTIE, WITH PUMA, BRITAIN'S MAIN SPRINT HOPE
email_title: THE OLYMPIC ALSO-RANS;EVEN BEFORE THE FIRST RACE, SHOE SPONSORS ARE COUNTING THE COST OF PICKI THE WRONG TEAM

Email_Body: Indianapolis, home of the world's most famous auto race, has a new claim to fame: theNikeA.B.C.D. (Academic Betterment and Career Development) basketball camp, the USA's preeminent proving ground for high school stars.Gentlemen, start your sneakers. The camp opens Friday and runs until the checkered flag drops Wednesday. Nikemoved the camp when it became apparent it had outgrown Princeton University, its home since 1983. With its basketball pedigree, Indianapolis was an easy choice.The Indiana University-Purdue University at Indianapolis campus is adjacent to the National Institute for Fitness and Sport.About 120 players are invited, at a cost toNikeof nearly $ 100,000. The roster reads like a who's who in high school basketball. Here's who Hoop Scoop magazine is listing as some of the top players to watch:- Best player: California player of the year Jason Kidd, a 6-4 guard who averaged 25 points and 10 rebounds last season for Alameda St. Joseph Notre Dame.- Best big man: Mississippi player of the year Othello Harrington, a 6-9 center who averaged 29 points and 19 rebounds for Jackson Murrah.- Best junior: A toss-up between 7-foot Rashard Griffith of Chicago King and 6-10 Rasheed Wallace of Philadelphia Simon Gratz.Nearly every major-college coach will be watching.Camp academic director Frank DuBois says players spend only 40 minutes a day on basketball and about five hours on academics. After all, this is theNikeAcademic Betterment and Career Development camp. ''We want these kids to know that there's more to life than basketball,'' DuBois says. REINSTATED: Dennis Holthaus, the Cincinnati Aiken football coach fired last year for making a racial remark to black members of his team, must be reinstated and given back pay. Hamilton County (Ohio) Common Pleas Judge Norman Murdock said the Cincinnati Board of Education acted illegally in firing Holthaus, currently an assistant at Aiken. REMATCH: Jasper (Texas) sprinter Bryan Bronson, Gatorade Circle of Champions Athlete of the Year, renews his rivalry with Wendell Gaskin of Kansas City (Kan.) Washington this weekend at Spokane, Wash. Gaskin beat Bronson in the 100 and 200 meters two weeks ago at the U.S. Junior Championships.
email_title: Niketakes scholarly approach to new Indianapolis camp
