Email_Body: Jim Courier, the biggest bread-winner on the pro tennis tour this year, could  be on his way to owning the whole bakery.Dade City's Courier, now ranked No. 2 after spending most of 1992 atop the  pyramid, has signed a reported six-year, $ 27-million endorsement contract with  NikeInc. that takes effect Oct. 1, when his current five-year endorsement  deal with Diadora expires.Nikeofficials won't confirm the figures, but Diadora advertising manager  Anne McIntosh said they are consistent with what has been floating around the  industry. If correct, the contract dwarfs the $ 4.14-million in prize money Courier  has earned during his five years on the pro tour (he's made a tour-leading  $ 1.55-million so far this year). He would be elevated into the same Madison  Avenue fraternity as Michael Jordan, Andre Agassi and Bo Jackson."We're delighted," said Dusty Kidd, public-relations manager forNike's  tennis division. "He has a certain style unlike any other player, and he's a  supremely athletic guy and that fits in with what we like."Courier is in Minneapolis with the U.S. Davis Cup team, which faces Sweden  in a semifinal match this weekend. He didn't return phone calls to his hotel  room.It's a fat deal for an athlete who doesn't appear to have as marketable an  image as Jordan, Jackson, Agassi and Deion Sanders, allNikeclients. But Kidd  said the company was attracted to Courier by his on-court performance and his  clean-cut, wholesome personality."He likes traditional American things: red cars, red guitars and he wears  a cap. He's a real all-American guy," said Kidd, adding that athletes such as  Jordan can bring in $ 200-million in sales each year.And you can expect to see him on your TV and in sports magazines in the  months to come, Kidd said.Nike, based in Beaverton, Ore., is putting together  a sizable advertising campaign for Courier, Kidd said.Courier will beNike'slead promoter of a new line of apparel called  Supreme Court, Kidd said. The line actually debuted last winter, butNike  already has gotten some design input from Courier and plans to relaunch the  new line designed around Courier's image.The tennis clothing and shoes will be dominated by the colors red, white  and khaki and feature pinstripes. The shoe, available now in stores, is called  Air Supreme Court, and comes in a low-top (suggested retail price $ 90) and  three-quarters-top model ($ 95), which is what Courier will play in.
email_title: Courier signs big pact withNike

Email_Body: NikeInc. says it is standing by the approach it took in a magazine advertisement alluding to an athlete's inner voice despite complaints from an advocacy group that says it trivializes mental illness.The Alliance for the Mentally Ill of New York State, based in Albany, N.Y., has taken issue with theNikead that features football player Jerry Rice. The group said hearing voices is a symptom of schizophrenia, a serious and extremely common mental illness. More than 2 million young people will be struck by the disease this year, spokesperson Norma Weinerth said.But that's not the kind of inner voice to which the ad referred,Nikespokesperson Dusty Kidd said. Rather, he said, it was meant to be inspirational.The ad begins: "Mother and father told you repeatedly. Crazy people talk to themselves. Still you heard the voice. Loud and clear. Just Do It."Learn how to hit a fastball. Work on your left hand shot. Study harder. Study longer. Get a raise."It concludes: "Crazy people talk to themselves. And finally, you realize, only a madman doesn't listen."Alliance members complained the ad is a flippant reference to mental illness to sell shoes.ASSOCIATED PRESS
email_title: Nikestands by magazine ad despite mental group's complaint

Email_Body: This strange story began on May 27, 1990, when a storm struck the freighter  Hansa Carrier as it crossed the Pacific from Korea to the United States. The  freighter survived, but its shipment ofNikeshoes was washed overboard. Not a  sole was saved. The incident was forgotten until that November, whenNikeshoes began  appearing along the shores of Oregon.Large hiking boots, high-top athletic shoes and other styles began to bob  landwards, at first in ones and twos, then in scores, eventually in the  thousands. To the incredulity of locals, the beaches were swamped with shoes  of many colors.Over the past two years, up to 40,000 shoes have washed ashore.Within weeks after the shoes started to wash up, a thriving new local  economy was created. Beachcombers held swap-meets to exchange right and left  shoes, then resold them in pairs.They've made a fortune selling the shoes, and buyers have been pleased with  their bargains."I got my pair for $ 20," said James Ingraham. "That's about a quarter of  the price I would have paid in a store."Admittedly, they had spent a year sloshing about the Pacific, but after  I'd worn them a couple of times they loosened up and are quite comfortable  now."The fact that the shoes were still wearable after many months' battering by  storms and water would suggestNikeproducts have a certain weather-proofing  prowess, a quality that could well be marketed. It hasn't been."We contactedNike, but they didn't want to know," said Ingraham. "Maybe  a beachcomber's recommendation is not quite the testimony thatNikewas  seeking."The longevity of the sports shoes has been useful in another way to  Ingraham, who is an oceanographer with the National Marine Fisheries Service.Ingraham and colleague Curtis Ebbesmeyer began studying the shoes'  oceanographic peregrinations. The data provided by plotting theNikearmada's  progress has allowed them to test several complex theories about the detailed  mechanics of Pacific currents."It has been a real bonus to our work," Ingraham said.With the data, Ingraham and Ebbesmeyer produced a lengthy paper for the  journal Transactions of the American Geophysical Union. They report that many  of the shoes appeared farther south than normally would have been expected for  flotsam borne by the tropical Pacific currents that head north to Alaska.Now, as the currents have swept back out to sea from Oregon, the shoes have  been heading south and east. Already some have appeared on the shores of  Hawaii."The next stop is Japan," said Ingraham. "After that, they will start on  their second circle of the Pacific Ocean."
email_title: Up to 40,000Nikeswash ashore in Ore.

Email_Body: Julie Lewis of Portland, Ore., has a masters degree in bio-nutritionand taught at a New England private college, which in no way explains howshe came up with the idea of manufacturing walking shoes from recycledgarbage. "I just liked the idea of creating something practical fromrecycled material," said Lewis, whose creativity has resulted in other,less successful, inventions. Lewis's walking shoes are made from recycled polypropylene, paper bags,coffee filters, reclaimed tires, foam rubber and scrap metal. The idea forthe shoe came from conversations with tire recyclers andNikefounder BillBowerman. The invention of a machine that weaves recycled polypropylenemade it possible. The first 5,000 pairs (they're called DejaShoes andretail for $59 in the United States) are scheduled to reach the marketsoon, she says. The company plans other styles, including a chukka bootand a sandal.Personal golf coursesBo in newNikeadBo Jackson, who is attempting to recover from a hip injury, will be at  Major League Baseball's All-Star Game, at least on television.Nikewill  be introducing a new Jackson commercial, but won't say if it will be a  continuation of the Bo Knows series.Nikehas bought four minutes of ad  times in CBS TV's July 9 broadcast and will use six spots during the game,  including a 60-second commercial starring Jackson.Jackson was released from his baseball contract with the Kansas CityRoyals before the beginning of the season because of hip injuries sufferedduring the National Football League season, when he plays for the LosAngeles Raiders. He signed with the Chicago White Sox and may startplaying after the all-star break. For the past three yearsNikehasstarted its back-to-school summer campaign with the July all-star game.Ruth, Joe or Ruff?Bob Fredette of the Rutland (Vt.) Daily Herald offers a baseball shaggydog story: A skid-row bum walks into a bar with his dog. "I don't have acent," the bum says to the bartender, but if my talking dog entertainsyour customers awhile, will you give me a drink on the house?"The bartender is curious, so he agrees."Dog," says the bum, "how did I feel when I got up this morning?""Ruff," the dog replies."Dog," says the bum, "what's on top of this bar?""Roof," says the dog."Dog," continues the bum, "who was the greatest baseball player of alltime?""Ruth," the dog barks.The bartender has seen enough and throws the bum into the street.The dog looks up at the bum and says, "Do you think I should have saidJoe DiMaggio?"The last word"To add injury to insult they show up wearing ties, their Rolexes and  some even bring their cellular phones. They discuss the Dow Jones averages  instead of batting averages." - Jerry Pritikin, 54, a Chicago Cubs  Bleacher Bum, who warns that the outfield seats have been invaded by  yuppies who care nothing about baseball but are there only to show off.
email_title: TRUTH & RUMOURS   WILLIAM HOUSTON'S WORLD OF SPORTS   Walking re-treads

Email_Body: IVAN KELIC is the strongest forward in the National Soccer League thi season and that's one of the reasons why he has become such a dangerous striker.That is the claim of Alan Davidson, who has seen Kelic's development in his three seasons at Melbourne Croatia."We've got rugged defenders like Andrew Marth and George Hannah but in 50-50 clashes at training Marth has bounced off while Kelic has held his ground," Davidson said. "He's all brute strength now and that's made it hard for defenders to knock him off the ball.Kelic equalled an NSL record on Sunday becoming only the second player to score six goals in one game.His feat easily earned him the player of the week title in the Herald-SunNikeAir Golden Boot award.As the weekly winner he collects a pair ofNikeAir runners worth $280.Kelic, however, believes his teammates deserve most of the credit."It was the easiest game I've ever played in - I just stood up front and put the ball in the net," he said."After I scored the third from a penalty, there was a real chance of becoming the league's top scorer and my teammates started playing to me." Kelic has been working on weights in the gym three times a week."I've felt much stronger and that too has helped in the confidence." he said.His goals this season have raised suggestions of a place in the Socceroo squad but Kelic is not getting carried away."The main priority is to help Melbourne Croatia make the grand final and win it. If I was to get a call-up from Eddie Thomson, it would be a bonus," he said.Kelic is the fourth player to win the award twice this season. With one round left, anyone from eight can win.Apart from the weekly award ofNikeAir runners, the overall winner receives $2000 fromNike.Herald-SunNikeAir Golden Boot Award. Email_Body: While doctors from Tijuana to Bangor, Maine, continue their game of prognosis roulette, it might interest those speculating about Bo Jackson's financial future that the wallet is getting fatter. Still."No,Nikehasn't dropped him, and, yes, he's still alive and well," Suzanne McKee, Jackson's business manager, said Tuesday before the question was asked. "He's going to Los Angeles Sunday to shoot a newNikecommercial. It's going to be with a comedian, but I can't discuss it beyond that." The script may be a secret but Jackson's endorsement status isn't.Nike, his major source of income, is designing another new campaign around him, despite the fact his future as an athlete is in doubt. (McKee did offer the obvious: that the commercial will deal with his rehabilitation from a hip injury.) There also are ongoing deals with Pepsi, "BoMed" sports medicine products (which is expanding distribution to Japan), Tiger Electronics games and Franklin Sports equipment.Jackson generally commands multi-year deals and least a half-million dollars annually per endorsement, according to Nova Langtree, president of Burns Sports Celebrity Service in Chicago, though theNikedeal is well into seven figures.Langtree, who assesses the marketability of sports stars, said Jackson's status could dip a year from now if he can't make a comeback with the Chicago White Sox. But she added, "As a spokesperson, he's gone so far beyond what is normal. And because ofNikeand how cutting-edge [its campaigns] are, there's going to be a second round of drama after the surgery. We might see a bionic man thing."McKee, who heads the newly formed "Bo Jackson Enterprises" in Mobile, said 1991 was Jackson's biggest year in terms of endorsement dollars despite his playing in only 23 games for the White Sox and that 1992 will match that."It ain't over - there's no fat lady singing," said McKee. "Look,Nike'snamed buildings after Bo. They're not going to just drop him."
email_title: BASEBALL Despite woes, Bo's dough still grows

Email_Body: RUGGED defender Andrew Marth yesterday admitted he has not yet hit his best form despite the recent media clamor for his inclusion in the Socceroos.The switch by Marth to a double centre-back role has helped Melbourne Croatia challenge for the NSL championship and earned praise from national coach Eddie Thomson who said the defender was on the verge of a call-up.Thomson took note of how Marth and George Hannah blotted out Warren Spink last Sunday. Only days earlier Spink had troubled Czechoslovakia with his sharpness and confidence to take defenders on. Marth also took the free kick which led to the winning goal against Preston Makedonia.While Marth concedes that his form is improving, he believes he has played better in the NSL."My second season at Sunshine George Cross (in 1988) was my best season and I ended up being the club's player of the year," Marth said yesterday."I still think I haven't played as well since although this season is now shaping up to go close."Marth is now part of Melbourne Croatia's ambitious charge for the title."The change of coach (at Melbourne Croatia) has made a big difference. Ken Worden has a playing style similar to John Gardiner (Marth's coach at Sunshine) and I'm enjoying the freedom to play the ball out of the back (rather than kicking long balls)," he said.The defender's performance earns him the player-of-the-week title in the Herald-SunNikeAir Golden Boot award.As the weekly winner, Marth collects a pair ofNikeAir runners.The overall winner receives $2000 in cash fromNike.Herald-SunNikeAir Golden Boot Award.Round 18. Email_Body: Moog Automotive Inc. has appointed John C. Corey president of the newly formedMoog Steering and Suspension Division, which will handle the company's chassis business.  Executives with Moog, a St. Louis-based maker of auto parts, said the new division will concentrate on steering and suspension products for vehicles.  Another division handles the company's temperature control business.  Corey was formerly senior vice president for finance and administration.  Corey will report to Larry W. McCurdy, president and chief executive officer of the company.  U.S. NATIONAL BANK Geoghegan Named President, CEO Dennis J. Geoghegan has been named president and chief executive of U.S.  National Bank of Clayton, the company said Thursday.  U.S. National opened in 1988 and has $26 million in assets.  Geoghegan was vice chairman of Mark Twain Bancshares' Ellisville bank in charge of generating new business.  MISSOURI FOOD BARN Official Says Business Returning Business dropped by about 18 percent during the first couple weeks of a strike that began March 3 but has since started to come back, a Food Barn official said in Kansas City.  P.A. Rawalt, Food Barn's vice president of human resources, said the company's business had increased by about 9.5 percent two weeks ago and another 3 percent last week.  The union, United Food and Commercial Workers Local 576, has claimed business is down by 75 percent.  Rawalt also said 1,048 employees have crossed the union picket lines, which couldn't be immediately confirmed by union officials. The local represents about 2,500 Food Barn employees, about 2,100 of them union members, at 47 stores in Missouri and Kansas, most in the Kansas City area. The union members went on strike after soundly rejecting a new contract that would have required about $18 million in concessions over three years.  Rawalt said Food Barn is the only remaining unionized grocery in the Kansas City area and can't continue to compete.  AP ILLINOIS CATERPILLAR INC.  195 Employees To Be Laid Off Caterpillar Inc. said Thursday that 195 hourly employees will be laid off indefinitely from the company's Peoria-area plants, effective April 1.  The layoffs are necessary to bring production of diesel engines in line with demand, according to a statement from the company. Caterpillar is the world's largest manufacturer of tractors and other earth-moving equipment.  It employed about 60,000 people overall as of mid-1990.  AP NATIONAL L.A. GEAR RivalNikeSued In 'Sneaker War' L.A. Gear Inc. Thursday launched a counter-offensive in the ''sneaker war,'' firing a $3 billion lawsuit at rivalNikeInc. that charged it with trying to monopolize the market for high-tech sneakers and drive L.A.  Gear out of the business.  The countersuit was filed afterNike,the nation's largest marketer of athletic footwear, last month sued L.A. Gear for alleged patent infringement.  In its countersuit, L.A. Gear said it believesNikeis trying to monopolize the high-technology basketball shoe market and eliminate L.A. Gear as a major competitor.  Los Angeles-based L.A. Gear also said its countersuit denies that its new CATAPULT shoe technology infringes anyNikepatents.  In its suit, filed in federal court in California on Feb. 15,Nikehad alleged that six models of basketball shoes sold by L.A. Gear infringe on patents forNike'sAir Jordan shoes.  Reuters FDIC Bank Insurance Fund Shrank 37 The nation's bank insurance fund shrank 37 percent last year and will probably need to borrow $10 billion this year to keep bailing out depositors of failed banks, a top banking regulator said Thursday.  L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., said the FDIC's fund suffered an operating loss of $4.85 billion in 1990.  ''To be conservative and to ensure that we have the funds we need on time, we will need, we believe, at least $10 billion this year and that could be higher if we experience conditions worse than we currently are forecasting,'' Seidman said.  He also warned that the fund may have to borrow $35 billion by the end of 1993 - part of a new Treasury proposal that would let it borrow up to $70 billion to protect depositors.  Reuters INTERNATIONAL AVIATION EC Asks For New Trade Agreement The European Community, locked in a dispute with Washington on whether its subsidies on Airbus aircraft violate free trade rules, asked Thursday for a new trade agreement to make clear what government support was allowed.  It asked the Civil Aircraft Committee of the 101-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to renegotiate GATT's Civil Aircraft Code to clarify the matter and avoid such disputes, a trade source said.  The United States charges that European subsidies to the four-nation Airbus Industrie consortium unfairly cut into the market of Boeing Co. and McDonnell Douglas Corp. The EC, in turn, says military contracts give American aircraft companies an unfair advantage.  Reuters
email_title: ST. LOUIS MOOG AUTOMOTIVE COREY IS NAMED DIVISION PRESIDENT

Email_Body: THE souvenir T-shirt, always one of the most popular items during American basketball's All-star weekend, became significant this year for what was not printed on it.T-shirts traditionally carry caricatures of the game's 10 starters. The late inclusion of Earvin ""Magic" Johnson to the Western Conference team seemingly would have meant an extra face. But not so.Missing was the likeness of Eastern Conference star Michael ""Air" Jordan, who has an exclusive apparel contract withNike.After months of wrangling,Niketold the National Basketball Association it can no longer sell any clothes bearing the image or name of the Chicago Bulls star.Jordan is only the beginning.Nikeintends notifying the NBA of 88 other players under contract who cannot be used in any way to generate merchandising funds.While the NBA expects to drop at least $1 million as a result ofNike'sstance, it is not overly concerned.The association's marketing arm is a $2 billion-a-year business of which only a small portion is generated from clothing.
email_title: THE SOUVENIR T-SHIRT

Email_Body: Reebok International Ltd. wants advertising that's as hot as its shoes.Its new ad campaign goes toe-to-toe with rivalNikeInc. in the pithy advice department. The first ad, airing during Monday Night Football, shows a ''sky surfer'' - a white-clad sky diver riding a snow board - somersaulting above the French Alps in his Pump cross-training shoes. The theme: ''Life is short. Play hard.''Reebok, which will spend $ 25 million on the campaign, scored with the Pump - 4 million pairs sold in 18 months - and its Blacktop outdoor basketball shoes. Second-quarter revenue rose 30% over 1990. The company commands 24% of $ 6 billion-a-year athletic -shoe market toNike's30%.But when it comes to great ads,Nikehas gotten all the airtime. Their star-filled ads are virtual news events and their slogans - from ''Just do it'' to ''Bo knows'' - quickly become buzzwords. Meanwhile, Reebok has suffered a depressing series of gaffes: Its wacky ''U.B.U.'' series flopped and a bungee-jumping ad was yanked last year for implying aNikewearer fell to his death.''Nikehas known for a long time what they stand for,'' says Dick Sittig, new creative director of ad agency Chiat/Day/Mojo New York, which lost the account after the bungee spot but won it back this year. ''They've had the advantage of getting a head start.''The Pump's success lets Reebok present itself as a serious sports shoe. Earlier ads talked form at the expense of performance, says David Ropes, vice president of marketing. ''It's like we were a teenager, we were feeling our oats. We're still a teenager, but now we know what we want to be when we grow up.''
email_title: Reebok ads 'play hard'

Email_Body: A coach shouldn't worry about losing money if his school takes over negotiating his outside-income contract, according to NCAA executive director Dick Schultz, who handled that chore for his staff when he was athletics director at Virginia."Our coaches made more money because I was a better negotiator than they were," Schultz said at the NCAA's recent annual football forum in Kansas City, Mo.Schultz said Virginia in 1982 became the first school to turn the negotiating of coaches' TV/radio contracts and other deals over to the athletics department. Other schools using the practice include Clemson, Florida State, Florida and Kentucky. Athletics director Vince Dooley is instituting a similar policy at Georgia and strongly hinted that it would be expanded to include shoe contracts.Schultz and Dooley predict the consolidation of outside-income contracts will become a national trend."The college presidents feel more comfortable with it coming under the university and the control of the athletics department," Dooley said.Schultz said Virginia had contracts with three shoe manufacturers, and teams other than football and basketball benefited from those contracts.Georgia basketball coach Hugh Durham is paid $ 40,000 annually for endorsingNikeshoes and $ 40,000 to do speeches and clinics for the shoe company - plus $ 2,000 in merchandise. Football coach Ray Goff last year received $ 21,250 fromNike.However, total school control of shoe contracts for Georgia coaches will have to wait until 1996; Durham recently signed a five-year extension to his contract withNike, which was due to expire in August.Durham will continue to be paid the same amount throughout the five- year extension period ($ 80,000 annually plus merchandise).Durham said he was more interested in a long-term deal withNike than a substantial increase in dollars because he foresees cutbacks in the number of schools and coaches who receive shoe contracts in coming years.
email_title: COLLEGE ATHLETICS; Schultz: Coaches need help; Says schools are better at negotiating TV deals

Email_Body: A range of stainless steel rams designed to withstand the most arduous operating conditions was introduced to the UK at Offshore Europe byNike.The company, Scandinavia's largest manufacturer of high pressure hydraulics, also used the Aberdeen show to launch its Reflex lightweight helicopter rescue kit, which offers separate tools for heavy cutting, pushing, and cutting in confined spaces."Offshore Europe provided our first opportunity to display a selected range of high pressure, heavy duty hydraulic equipment," says Hall Smith, president ofNikeHydraulics Ltd, of Burnley, Britain.  In addition,Nike'sdisplay embraced pumps for manual, air, and electrical operation as well as hydraulic cutting equipment. "Nikehas been in the hydraulic business for more than 60 years, originally as a supplier of products for the automotive industry," says Mr Smith.  "It has gradually moved into products employed in heavy industries like mining, steel, pulp, paper, and the offshore sector."The acquisition in 1988 of Bahco, Sweden's second largest manufacturer of power tools, can be seen as a significant step in this expansion process.  Bahco had long historical links with the oil industry, both offshore and on land, and its range of heavy lift rams had a good reputation amongst fabricators.The new ram range presented in Aberdeen offers the same performance as the established CXA range used in heavy fabrication yards, combined with enhanced corrosion resistance due to its stainless steel construction.The Reflex rescue kit has been developed from Bahco's original range of rescue tools, and can be used either individually or simultaneously by up to three operators.  It supplements existing heavy duty rescue tools currently supplied byNikefor offshore duties.  Cutting and spreading tools, have been modified for subsea operation by remotely operated vehicles.Since the Bahco acquisition, says Mr Smith, a great deal of rationalisation has taken place in theNikeproduct range, supplemented by the introduction of new tools.  "This has given the company one of the most comprehensive lines on the market," he argues.Standard rams can now be offered with capacities up to 250 tonnes, while low height, spring return rams are available with up to 200 tonnes capacity, and a range of specialist hand pumps, developing pressure up to 2,800 bar (40,000 psi).GRAPHIC:Picture, The Reflect lightweight rescue kit fromNikeis designed for helicopter use and provides separate tools for heavy cutting and pushing in confined spaces.
email_title: Hydraulics firm launches rams and rescue kit

Email_Body: NikeInc. sells a lot of shoes at its store in hometown Portland, but it also gives something away: fantasy.ItsNikeTown is a theatrical presentation, a glittering production number starring the customers."People love to shop.  It's kind of entertainment, a social thing," manager Mary Burns said.  "Let's make it even more fun for them . . ." Outside in downtown Portland are the sights, sounds, and smells of rush-hour traffic, intent pedestrians, fastfood restaurants.But insideNikeTown, you can relax in the tranquility of an open town square, with the sounds of birds chirping.  The square, like the atrium of a suburban mall, is surrounded by two levels of separate shopping areas for differentNikeproducts.Light from a huge sparkling billboard highlights the uneven texture of brick walls and pavement and shines off manhole covers."Isn't it something?" says customer Vernette Stowers.  "I drove all the way from Seattle.  My daughter is aNikefan.""I don't think we meant to come up with some incredible turning point in retail or anything," saidNikeTown designer Gordon Thompson.  "We wanted to come up with a store that accurately represented our company and it happened to be this."The funniest thing is, I knew we were doing something unusual in architecture and design and in retail, but it seems to me it sort of has a life of its own now."In a half-hour on a recent afternoon, the store's greeter counted 200 people entering the store.  On weekends, it's even busier."We are averaging on a Saturday up to about 4,000-5,000 people," said Cathy Taylor, vice president of retail forNike, based in suburban Beaverton."The last two Sunday mornings I've had 75 people in line waiting to get into the store at 11:30," Burns said.Thompson, an architect by training, worked in industrial and interior design before coming toNike.  He said he always had "a big admiration for set designers and movies."His fascination took him to Universal Studios in Hollywood, where he visited sound stages and theBack to the Futureset, which features a town square."I started sketching on the way back," he said.The retail areas surrounding the square highlight each collection with separate character.A basketball area has wooden truss ceilings and a wooden basketball court floor.  A recording and speakers beneath the raised floor subtly fill the space with the hollow bounce of basketballs and shoes squeaking on the court.Bright tropical fish swim around shoes from the Aqua Gear collection in vertical, cylindrical tanks.  Nine large TV screens set in the floor form a sort of video pond, in which customers can watch seaweed swaying among the coral on the floor of a warm ocean.To keep inventory from cluttering the sales area, shoes are stored a floor below.  Shoes of the desired style, size, and color can be called up from the stockroom at a moment's notice by computer.  They arrive in a basket on a conveyor that moves up through a transparent plastic tube."It came fromThe Jetsons," Thompson said, referring to the futuristic cartoon series.Neither Burns nor Taylor would provide sales figures, but Burns said the store, since opening in November 1990, "did exactly what we wanted it to."Response has been so strong,Nikeplans a larger store in Chicago, taking over the old Saks Fifth Avenue location.  The Chicago store will contain about 33,000 square feet of retail space, compared with Portland's 7,000 square feet, and its town square will be five stories tall, Taylor said.  It is scheduled to open next May.Taylor saidNikealso is looking at two sites in New York.  She said plans call for twoNikeTowns to open each year in "major areas of the world."GRAPHIC:Photo, TheNikestore in Portland sells more than shoes.  It's a glittering production of theNikemystique, featuring a high-flying Michael Jordan and an iron-pumping Bo Jackson.  AP Laserphoto
email_title: Nike'svision of the ultimate store includes fantasy

Email_Body: The US sports shoe and apparel maker has gone to town with a store concept that combines hi-tech gadgetry with environmental design to produce a sort of Disneyland and Hard Rock Cafe of the athletics world, says Helen ChangON a downtown street corner, in the small city of Portland, Oregon, is a store that opens into another world.Step into the darkened porch, then through the black sliding doors, and you enter a marketing marvel -NikeTown.Inside is a "town square" lined with boutiques on all sides. Above the square, a white plaster statue of US basketball star Michael Jordan leaps through the air, while to the left, a balcony overlooks the scene. NikeTown combines hi-tech gadgetry with environmental design to produce a sort of Disneyland and Hard Rock Cafe of the athletics world. Conceived as a gallery to sell the latest lines ofNikeshoes and clothing under one roof, it demonstrates how a store's atmosphere is as much a marketing tool as the products themselves.The atmosphere inNikeTown is like a theatre stage. Dark and light shadows canvass the various boutiques. Environmental music -the sounds of chirping birds and running streams -- fills the air.Even the store hours are offbeat: Monday to Thursday 10am -7.01pm; Friday 10am -8pm; Saturday 10am -6.52pm; Sunday 11.25am -6.23pm.NikeTown is the flagship store of the US sports shoe and apparel maker, whose worldwide headquarters -directing operations in the US, Europe and Asia -are at Beaverton, about a 20- minute drive from Portland.Nikewill not say how much revenue the store brings in, or how much it cost to build, but it is repeating the concept elsewhere.A secondNikeTown opened recently in Chicago and there plans to create up to eight more in the US in the next decade.Nikealso plans to spread the chain to Europe, but there are no current plans for Asia.Already, the Portland store has developed a cult following. Out-of-state teenagers come to see memorabilia displays to check what a favourite athlete wore during a certain game. Others sit at video displays by the half-hour. And Japanese tourists make their way to Portland just to see the store."We wanted to create product excitement," said store manager Jeff Nichols, about the reasons forNikeTown's design. "We wanted to make an exciting place (for customers) to look at our products."During a recent interview,Nikefounder and chief executive officer Philip Knight said: "One of the key things we try to do is to create an emotional tie with a product."Launched in 1990, Portland'sNikeTown has floor space of 15,000 sq ft, about the size of a supermarket. It draws some 40,000 visitors a year, split equally between locals and tourists.Each of the store's 14 boutiques highlights a different sport or theme -such as running, cycling, tennis or kids' wear -with decor and furniture to match.A boutique forNike'sline of hiking and mountain-climbing shoes and clothes, called All Conditions Gear, features a backdrop that changes from day to night, including a shimmering sunrise which turns to stars against a black sky. Display shelves are made from rock-climbing wires and pegs, and the floor is made from slate rock.Another boutique, containingNike's"Aqua-Gear", includes an aquarium window filled with bright tropical fish. Outside the aquarium, balanced on horizontal wire lines, are mesh shoes -used for walking on reefs -whose bright colours match those of the fish.In the same room, surfboards protruding from the walls double as shelves, while a video "pool" on the floor shows footage of running water and coral reef life.The store also serves as a mini sports museum, with displays of sporting memorabilia spread throughout. One panel features the different shoes worn by basketball star Michael Jordan in various national tournaments."People will just come in and read the memorabilia," said sales associate Hal Melhart.  "They'll come in here for two hours, before they realise they can shop."Sales staff don't spend much time getting the apparel from the shelves -small, hi-tech lifts do that. Instead, sales assistants are encouraged to "educate" visitors aboutNikeproducts.Some say the fervour ofNikeTown's employees -everyone is involved in some kind of sport -can be overwhelming. And retailing experts say the marketing efforts do not necessarily add up to more sales, since many visitors do not buy. At the day's end, they say, it's quality that will sell the products, not gimmicks.ButNikesays its stores provide what today's customers want: fun. And in a way that is fast becoming a slice of Americana.GRAPHIC:InsideNikeTown: The company says its stores provide what today's customers want -fun
email_title: A town likeNike's

Email_Body: The official Olympic motto is:A. Just Do It.B. Citius. Altius. Fortius.C. Life Is Short. Play Hard.The answer depends on whom you ask. The International Olympic Committee stands by B, Latin for faster, higher, stronger. But in the marketing-crazed world of sports that is unavoidably married to the modern Games, mass-media advertising campaigns have sought to condition consumers to pick A (Nike)or C (Reebok).Which brings us to Michael Jordan's wardrobe quandary.He is under contract, for a reported $ 20 million, to endorseNikeand its Air Jordan shoes and related accessories.Jordan had said he was considering not taking part in a medal ceremony if he had to wear a Reebok uniform. Reebok is the official supplier to the U.S. Olympic Committee and paid to have all U.S. Olympians wear Reebok suits on the award stand.Jordan and five other basketball Olympians have contracts withNike.USOC executive director Harvey Schiller said Sunday that the flap - which might have meant no Jordan and others on the medal stand if the team wins the gold - is a ''non-issue. We have a deal.'' He wouldn't elaborate.Said Jordan: ''I don't know anything about it, but if it's true, that's good.''Said NBA Commissioner David Stern: ''The matter of who wears what when is going to be resolved, and I'm sure we'll have all 12 players up there.''WhileNikeand Reebok are maintaining low profiles in the Jordan case, it has magnified the role of sponsors and Olympic commercialism.Sports administrators and corporate marketing officials contend brand- name exposure is a natural and necessary byproduct that rewards huge investments by footwear manufacturers and other sponsors. ''Michael Jordan is not the problem; he earns a substantial living with or without endorsements,'' says Liz Dolan,Nike'svice president for corporate communication.''The people for whom (no money) would be a problem are the ones whose sponsors really support them.''Dolan saysNikedoes not object to Jordan making a brief appearance in Reebok's USA suit to accept an Olympic medal because ''that's ceremonial garb, and that's not the business we're in anyway.''Should Jordan follow through on his pledge to boycott the medal ceremony and snub the Reebok outfit, don't expect a Reebok counterattack. You probably won't hear so much as a peep.''That doesn't have any impact on Reebok,'' says John Boulter, vice president of worldwide marketing for Reebok International Ltd.''But I would feel sorry for any athlete who did that. It would be a shame if it ended like that.''
email_title: USOC says clothing controversy over

Email_Body: Questions surroundingNikeInc.'s future earnings let some air out of its stock Thursday. The maker of Air Jordan and other pricey athletic shoes dropped 4 1/4 to $ 46 5/8 after two analysts scaled back their quarterly and yearly earnings estimates for the company.Shearson Lehman Bros. analyst Josie Esquivel shaved her third-quarter estimate to 92 cents a share from $ 1. For the year ending in May, she cut her estimate to $ 4 a share from $ 4.13. Montgomery Securities analyst Alice Ruth cut her estimate to 95 cents a share from $ 1.10 for the third quarter and to $ 3.85 from $ 4 for the year. Both cited a 33% drop inNike's''refill'' orders for the third quarter. Refill orders are spot orders from retailers to shore up their inventories. Still, Esquivel says the soft market for athletic shoes that cost more than $ 100 a pair will be temporary. She ''strongly reiterated'' her buy recommendation. But Kidder, Peabody & Co. analyst Gary Jacobson saysNikeis facing a period of slow growth. With the slack economy, ''we're beginning to see customers shift away from high-priced footwear to lower priced shoes,'' he says. ''In a tough retail environment, if you have a high-priced item, you'll likely have problems.''He recommends shunningNikestock in favor of arch-competitor Reebok International, which fell 1/4 to $ 17 5/8 Thursday. He thinks more modestly priced shoes such as Reebok's Freestyle and Princess lines are poised for higher sales in a less ostentatious decade.Profit-taking Time: Buoyed all week on rumors of an imminent deal to sell portions of its entertainment businesses, Time Warner Inc. lost 4 3/4 to $ 110 3/4 a share as traders took profits. The stock had soared 17 1/2 points (17.9%) since Monday; 43 5/8 points (65%) since Oct. 11.''Hope springs eternal with Time Warner stock,'' says analyst Peter Appert of Cyrus J. Lawrence. The hope: A deal will surface to help alleviate some of the load of $ 10.6 billion in debt the company is carrying.Time Warner has been saying for more than a year that it is talking with potential international and domestic partners who would buy an equity stake in Warner Bros. studio, Home Box Office cable TV channel or its cable TV unit. Speculation is that Toshiba Corp. of Japan and Canal Plus S.A. of France are interested.- James Kim and Pat Guy
email_title: Nikestock trips on analysts' estimates

Email_Body: Nike,which makes athletic equipment, is negotiating to sponsor the Hogan Tour, a training ground for aspiring PGA Tour golfers. The Hogan Tour was founded in 1990 and named for Ben Hogan, whose golf equipment company underwrote it. The Ben Hogan Co. told the PGA Tour this year it could no longer finance the tour. LION'S PAW: Sophomore Kerry Collins, Penn State's projected starting quarterback, will miss the first two games this season with an injured index finger on his throwing hand, coach Joe Paterno said Monday. ''Kerry got hurt before he reported. He was playing volleyball,'' Paterno said. (College notes, 9C) ROUTS ARE ON: The NFL preseason weekend ended with two routs Monday night. Rich Gannon's 52-yard pass to Anthony Carter ended a 35-point first half and the Minnesota Vikings wiped out the Cleveland Browns 56-3. Also, the Kansas City Chiefs shut out the Buffalo Bills 35-0 as Dave Krieg passed for 160 yards and two touchdowns. MAGIC 32: Rookie center Shaquille O'Neal will wear jersey No. 32 in his first season with the Orlando Magic. O'Neal, the first pick of the NBA draft, wore No. 33 at Louisiana State, but Magic forward Terry Catledge decided to keep No. 33.
email_title: SPONSORSHIP

Email_Body: NIKEis in no mood for a marathon. The athletic footwear company - whose advertisements feature basketball superstar Michael Jordan - is sprinting to the lead in the earnings race in what has become a very lucrative market.  Nikeh$as just reported a 15 per cent jump in second-quarter earnings to a record $US114.4 million.US sales rose 5 per cent and Wall Street is bullish about the company's future.But troubled rival LA Gear is fading fast as mounting financial troubles are complicated by shrinking credit.After becoming the third largest shoemaker in the US in four years, the company has losses of over $US4 million and was recently bought by Stanley Gold, a shrewd Californian known for restoring troubled companies.Nevertheless, there are whispers that the company may soon be known as LA Disappear.END OF STORY
email_title: NIKEJUMPS, LA VANISHES

Email_Body: IT HAS taken four years, but Heidelberg's Willie Herd has finally proved himself a quality player, justifying his reputation and excellent record in Scottish football.Herd was a prize signing by Melbourne Croatia in 1987 after accepting an invitation to play here despite being firmly established in the Scottish first division.The midfielder admitted yesterday the first two seasons turned into disasters after tearing a cartilage in the first game at his new club. "I went to Brunswick Juventus the season after and had a groin problem which again required an operation and ruled me out for the full season," Herd said yesterday."It was frustrating and inexplicable, especially since, in 10 years of senior football in Scotland, I hardly ever missed a game, and by the time I came here I had played over 300 league games." Herd broke into senior soccer as a 17-year-old with East Fife. He was transferred for $40,000 to Falkirk when he was 20, and three years later joined Partick Thistle."(Melbourne Croatia's) Paul Donnelly had accepted an offer to play in Perth at the time and he got in touch. I felt I could do with a change and, on his advice, chose to join an NSL club." Herd felt he had made the wrong move after the two serious injuries.He scored his fifth for the season on Sunday against Melita Eagles to crown off a man-of-the-match performance which earned him the title of the player-of-the-week in the Herald-SunNikeAir Golden Boot award.As the weekly winner, Herd picks up a pair ofNikeAir runners valued at $280. Email_Body: Perhaps it's just an excuse to sell sneakers for $ 100 a pop -- but what an excuse.Walk through the doors ofNikeTown, and the first thing you see is a life-size plaster statue of Mr.Nikehimself -- Michael Jordan -- in mid-jump shot. To either side the walls are papered with Sports Illustrated covers featuring athletes who've endorsedNikeproducts.And that's all before you get to the basketball court, the 22-foot-long, 1,000-gallon tank with live tropical fish, and the video theater where you can watch your favorite athletes work out on film, inNikeapparel. And the amazing dancing bears who do cartwheels before slamming the basketball home!Well, scratch the dancing bears.Nikedidn't go that far when it set up its giant new five-story retail emporium along North Michigan Avenue, Chicago's so-called Magnificent Mile of fancy boutiques and department stores. But the company appears to have spared few other expenses in designing and building what is more a color-coordinated sports museum -- the Disney World of athletics may be more like it -- than a shoe store."It's dope," says Larry Cowans, a 13-year-old from nearby Skokie who is spending the afternoon wandering around the store with his older brother. "That means cool," he quickly informs a befuddled questioner.Cowans, a self-described aficionado of basketball star Charles Barkley, is what you might also call a sports-marketing dream. He's wearing a Georgetown Hoyas T-shirt and gym shorts and a Georgia Tech baseball cap. On his feet are a pair ofNikebasketball sneakers.But it's not just the aficionados who have hadNike'scash registers ringing furiously ever sinceNikeTown opened here a few weeks ago. On any given afternoon, the store is packed with hundreds of shoppers -- suburban housewives, packs of teenagers on summer vacation and scads of tourists who have added it to their Chicago agendas."I'd heard this is the place to come visit," says Clarke Reeves, an Indianapolis schoolteacher who drove up for a Cubs game. "It's kind of like an entertainment center. Instead of having to spend money, you can just browse."Well, he did buy some T-shirts for the kids.Reeves is exactly the kind of customer who has Vince Giacomin wearing a perpetual smile these days. Giacomin is the manager ofNikeTown. He estimates that at least 5,000 people a day have visited the store since its opening, perhaps as many as 10,000 on a good day.To put that into perspective, consider this: The Art Institute, another tourist destination only a half-dozen blocks south on Michigan Avenue, averages only 3,000 to 4,000 visitors a day. The Museum of Science and Industry gets perhaps 5,000 or 6,000."This is the store to go to," boasts Giacomin. "Every time you come in here, you see something you didn't see before -- because there's so much to see."As Giacomin explains it,NikeTown represents in part the company's response to the recession. "Retail is struggling in general," he says. "The retailer only knows to put a four-letter word on the front door: SALE. We've taken a totally different approach. We're talking about creating a different environment for shopping."NikeTown Chicago is actually the secondNikeTown. The first was a similar, albeit much smaller, store in Portland, Ore., near the company's headquarters. NowNikeis planning to take the concept national, establishing a kind of Hard Rock Cafe for the sneaker and leisure fields. It has been scouting sites in Atlanta, New York and Orange County, Calif. There's even talk of going international, in London or Berlin.Given all the hoopla over the Olympic Dream Team, it's not hard to understand the mania here overNikeTown, a veritable shrine to America's most famous athletes -- many of whom, it turns out, endorseNikeproducts. Giant statues of Dream Teamers Scottie Pippen and David Robinson hang from the rafters. Window displays tout the accomplishments of Ukraine's champion pole vaulter Sergei Bubka and long jumper Mike Powell. You can even see the sleek black "bat boot" worn by Michael Keaton in "Batman." (Yup, it was designed byNike.)Innovative design touches turn up in unlikely places. The door handles are sculpted like theNikewings on the side of sneakers. Clerks retrieve shoes from the stock room through plastic tubes that transport the sneakers along a pulley system. As you shop for tennis shoes, the sounds of people smacking tennis balls can be heard over the Brian Eno-esque music on the stereo system, but as you walk into the basketball area, they are replaced by the noisy shouts of a playground hoops match.Of course, the biggest shrine of all here is to Chicago's reigning prince, Bulls guard Michael Jordan. A whole section of the store is devoted to the Air Jordan line of shoes, socks, T-shirts, sweat pants and gym shorts (for $ 38 a pair; there's a half-basketball court too, for trying on your new shoes). In the background: a two-story mural of Jordan on his way to a slam dunk, pasted against blue sky and white clouds.With big whiteNikeAir Jordans on his feet, of course.GRAPHIC:PHOTO, THE INTERIOR OFNIKETOWN IN CHICAGO: THE NEW ATHLETIC-GEAR STORE IS DRAWING BIGGER CROWDS THAN THE CITY'S FAMED ART INSTITUTE.NIKEINC.
email_title: Just Sell It;Five-StoryNikeMart Is an Instant Score

Email_Body: Bob Van Kampen confirmed Friday that his new firm,NikeSecurities, is negotiating with Clayton Brown & Associates Inc. to buy its packaged products division.He said that while the deal has not yet been finalized, he expected the matter to be resolved by Oct. 1."We've been in discussions working with them and trying to come to an agreement," Mr. Van Kampen stated. "I believe we are moving to a resolution, but it's not a deal yet." Mr. Brown, the firm's chairman, could not be reached for comment.Clayton Brown has sold about $6.5 billion of unit investment trusts since 1974, and employs 40 to 45 people in its packaged products division, according to the firm's marketing department.Clayton Brown was once a part of a firm - Van Kampen Wauterlek & Co. - that Mr. Van Kampen started in 1967. Seven years later the firm was divided into two separate companies - Van Kampen Merritt and Clayton Brown & Associates.Mr. Van Kampen said he was "very saddened" that the confidentiality of the negotiations was "breached" when Clayton Brown sent an internal memo to its packaged product employees saying they would continue to be employed either at Clayton Brown or atNike.Mr. Van Kampen startedNikein May, less than a month after Van Kampen Merritt Inc., the firm he formed in 1974 and sold to Xerox Financial Services in 1984, announced it was dropping its investment banking business to concentrate on its asset management business that includes mutual funds and unit investment trusts.One municipal finance source said, "He's coming back in a big way to compete with Van Kampen Merritt."A spokesman for Van Kampen Merritt did not return phone calls.As of April, the firm had sold $19 billion of unit investment trusts and was the largest U.S. sponsor of insured tax-free unit trust investments.Mr. Van Kampen said that all "non-compete" agreements that he made with Xerox at the time he sold the firm had since expired. He explained that the idea to acquire Clayton Brown's unit trust business occurred whenNikeacquired "a key" packaged product employee from Clayton Brown who "felt there would be a possibility Clayton Brown would be interested in selling the whole department."Mr. Van Kampen saidNike, which is operating out of temporary quarters in West Chicago, Ill., employs 20 people - including some former Van Kampen Merritt employees - involved in the trading, underwriting and sale of tax-exempt and taxable bonds to institutional investors.The sale of its packaged products division would not have a great effect on Clayton Brown's business, according to one public finance official."They haven't been among the majors in that area," the source said. "They've been focusing on public finance, doing a lot of work as a co manager."CORRECTION:Bob Van Kampen, chairman ofNikeSecurities, clarified a comment he made in an article that appeared yesterday about negotiations between his firm and Clayton Brown & Associates to purchase Clayton Brown's packaged products division.Mr. Van Kampen said the confidentiality of the negotiations was breached by an unknown person and that, as a result, officials at Clayton Brown issued a memo to its employees saying they would continue to be employed either at Clayton Brown orNike.
email_title: NikeSecurities Attempting to Purchase A Division of Clayton Brown & Associates

Email_Body: Tennis player Andre Agassi may be more famous for his endorsements than for his game. And, in his new ad forNike, he's paired with Julia Child, the grande dame of food who has always refused to endorse any product. In the "Air. By Agassi" spot, the Las Vegas flash bashes tennis balls around a profusion of TV sets. He hits one of the sets with a ball and Child suddenly appears on the screen.Child, who never does commercials endorsing products, says the TV spot resulted from a "snafu with my lawyers when the company asked for a clip from one of my shows" and her share of the royalties is being donated to the American Institute of Wine & Food.Dusty Kidd, director of public relations forNike, says Child was concerned that her spot not appear as an endorsement for the shoes.Nikechose Child, Kidd said, because she is a TV institution."I don't wearNikes," the 79-year-old Child said. "I wear New Balance."
email_title: Agassi ad is Child's play

Email_Body: Muhammad Ali received the Life Time Achievement Award last night during the Jim Thorpe Pro Sports Award Show, a two-hour live special on ABC-TV. The presentation was made by actor James Earl Jones.Other special awards went to Bo Jackson and long jumper Mike Powell. Other winners were Michael Andretti, Cal Ripken, Michael Jordan, Terry Norris, Mark Rypien, Fred Couples, Meg Mallon, Mark Messier, Jim Courier and Monica Seles. No politicsCALGARY (CP) - The two Canadian cities vying to host the 2002 Winter Olympics have sent a clear, angry message to Ottawa - keep politics out of sport.Calgary mayor Al Duerr and his Quebec City counterpart, Jean-Paul L'Allier, signed a joint declaration demanding the Canadian Olympic Association select either of the two cities as its Canadian candidate without politics coloring its decision.NikeappealsMADRID (AP) -NikeInc., which paid millions to put its name on the U.S. track and field team's uniforms at the Barcelona Olympics, is appealing a stunning high court decision that bars the advertising or sale ofNikeapparel in Spain.Spain's Constitutional Court last week refused to lift a lower court order prohibiting the Beaverton, Ore.-based sports apparel company from using theNikename on clothing because a Barcelona firm registered the trademark first in 1932.Jets kicker quitsNEW YORK (AP) - New York Jets placekicker Pat Leahy, the oldest player in the NFL and the third-ranked scorer in league history, retired yesterday after 18 seasons because of a recurring sciatic nerve condition.Leahy, 41, has 1,470 points, and trails only fellow kickers George Blanda (2,002) and Jan Stenerud (1,699).Jockey injuredWILLOW PARK, Texas (AP) - A Trinity Meadows Raceway jockey was in good condition yesterday at a Fort Worth hospital after being thrown and trampled in a race.Doctors said David Muirhead, 26, could be released today.Bulgarian backMILAN, Italy (AP) - Stefka Kostadinova of Bulgaria, back on track after taking two years to recover from foot surgery, will be bidding for gold in the women's high jump at the Barcelona Olympics.Kostadinova, who set the world record of 6 feet, 10 1/4 inches at Rome in 1987, surprised even her husband by clearing 6-8 3/4 in her best effort of the season at a track meet in San Marino on the weekend.Skiing champsBOGOTA, Columbia, (CNW) - Jaret Llewellyn of Innisfail, Alta., and Kim de Macedo of Shawnigan Lake, B.C., won the overall titles at the seven-country Pan American Water Skiing Championships.In the team event, the United States was first with 8,426 points and Canada, the number-one ranked nation, was second at 8,271.In junior competition, Ryan Bush, 15, of Brampton, was second overall.
email_title: Muhammad Ali gets Thorpe Award

Email_Body: CANNON BEACH, Ore. (Reuter) - Beachcombers along the Pacific coast of the United States and Canada are scrambling to collectNikerunning shoes - the result of a lost cargo of footwear washed overboard from a ship a year ago. "I am wearing a pair now, and I love them," said Steve McLeod, an artist in Cannon Beach, Ore., who has collected 70 shoes, including 10 pairs.Local residents of this Pacific coast town 64 kilometres (40 miles) west of Portland said the spring tides deposited hundreds ofNikeshoes along the coast.The footwear apparently washed overboard from a cargo ship more than a year ago, according to the Beaverton, Ore., athletics sportswear company.Niketransportation manager Rick Hastings said the shoes came from five large shipping containers that washed off a ship bound from South Korea to Seattle in May, 1990.The containers held 40,000 pairs ofNikerunning shoes, golf shoes and hiking boots.Hastings said the shoes have been found as far north as Vancouver Island in British Columbia."They have a little bit of seaweed on them and a few barnacles. But scrape that off and you have a standard pair of shoes," Hastings said."The only complaint I have received is that we didn't tie the pairs together, so they have to match them."McLeod said beachcombers have formed the Sneaker Society which meets to swap shoes to come up with pairs. He said anyone who finds shoes on the beach is welcome to join.final-ly; shipping; accident
email_title: Beachcombers are pumped up!

The twoathletes face a four-year ban from competition after random dope testslast month showed they had taken the muscle-building drug Clenbuterol.

Email_Body: IN THE RUNNING battle of the footwear makers,NikeInc. has further advanced its lead over L.A. Gear Inc. The Marina del Rey, Calif.-based company reported its seventh straight quarterly loss Wednesday while rivalNikeof Beaverton, Ore., reported its fifth straight year of record revenues and earnings.Nikeshares jumped more than 10 per cent Wednesday while L.A. Gear dropped more than 15 per cent, closing at $ 10 5/8 , off $ 1 5/8 . L.A. Gear closed at $ 10 7/8 Thursday. L.A. Gear reported a net loss of $ 24.4 million US ($ 1.19 a share) for the second quarter ended May 31 compared with a net loss of $ 4 million (20 cents) in the like period a year ago.Revenue was $ 104.7 million vs. $ 166 million.L.A. Gear attributed its loss in part to settling three shareholder suits, at $ 13.9 million against net earnings, as well as a loss from continuing operations.The lawsuits alleged insider trading and release of false financial statements and prospects for the company. Filed in 1990 and 1991, they name L.A. Gear and current and former officials, including founder Robert Greenberg. The company said the settlements are not admissions of guilt.Court approval for the settlements is expected in late August.L.A. Gear president and chief operating officer Mark Goldston said losses are expected to continue into the latter half of 1992.L.A. Gear installed new management in September after Roy Disney-led Trefoil Capital Investors in Burbank, Calif., bailed out the firm with a $ 100-million investment convertible to a 34-per-cent stake.Since then, new management has been intent on cutting expenses, streamlining company operations and consolidating shoe lines. Still, losses have continued to plague the company since the fourth quarter of fiscal 1990.Meanwhile,Nikeearned $ 70.7 million US (92 cents a share) in the fourth quarter ended May 31 compared with $ 58.6 million (76 cents) in the same period a year ago. Revenue was $ 847.6 million against $ 719 million.For the year, earnings were $ 329.2 million ($ 4.30 a share) against $ 287 million ($ 3.77). Revenue rose 13.7 per cent to $ 3.41 billion in 1992.L.A. Gear's market share dropped from 12 per cent in 1990 to eight per cent last year, whileNikesaw its share grow from 29 per cent in 1990 to 30 per cent last year, according to the Sporting Goods Intelligence in Glen Mills, Pa.GRAPHIC:AP/NIKEAND REEBOK LEAD THE PACK: 1991 Market Share
email_title: Nikestill outrunning L.A. Gear in battle of the footwear makers:Nikescores 5th year of gains while foe tags quarterly loss

Email_Body: Sonny Vaccaro has leftNikeInc. and will join a new sports marketing firm, it was reported in yesterday's editions of the New York Times.Vaccaro, who signed numerous basketball standouts and coaches to endorsement arrangements with the shoe manufacturer, will become co-chairman of DIC Sports Marketing.The sports marketing firm is connected with DIC Animation City, Inc., a cartoon studio that will produces animated features of such sports stars as Michael Jordan, Wayne Gretzky and Bo Jackson.

Email_Body: The National Football League and the Los Angeles Rams will conduct a free clinic for over 400 area youth at Fullerton Junior College,Sunday July 14 at 12:00 p.m. This event is last in a series of 27 throughout the League this spring/summer.  The camps are sponsored by Pro Set, manufacturer of the Official NFL Trading Card, andNike.The "NFL Pro Set Mini Camp for Kids" sponsored byNikewill featur12hgeles Rams players including wide receiver Flipper Anderson and former Los Angeles Rams quarterback Vince Ferragamo. The players will stress the importance of staying in school and deliver impactful motivation messages on striving for individual excellence.  On the field at Fullerton Junior College, the players will demonstrate football skills and techniques of game preparation, fitness and nutrition."Mini Camp" participants have been selected through the United Way and Boys and Girls Clubs of Los Angeles to provide this opportunity for those who would benefit most from the program.Local supporters of the event include radio station KJLH-FM.The public is invited to attend the clinic as spectators at no charge.

Email_Body: By Brian FawcettESQUIRE magazine, which carries the subtitle of Man At His Best butreally ought to be subtitled Upper Middle-class New York Guys Between 35and 50 At Their Most Cynical and Stylish, used to be one of the bestmagazines this side of the Atlantic. It was politically and sociallyastute if not always liberal, the prose was high-octane, and its annualDubious Achievement Awards, begun in the 1960s, were the best summary andsatire of our lunatic civilization available.These days, alas, the magazine is usually more in step with ourparanoid sectarian times than it once was, and the most I'd be willing tosay about it is that it features good prose. The April 1991 issue, whichexhibits a photo of actress Ellen Barkin, has, between pages 64 and 65, aneight-page fold-out that will tell you more about corporate sponsorship ofthe arts than the magazine intended, and probably a whole lot more thanmost of us ever wanted to know. On the front and back of the fold-out are miniaturized reproductions offive commissioned works of art. Charles Anderson (U.S.), Ralph Steadman(British) and Takenobu Igarushi (Japanese) are on the front, and AlphonseHoltgreve (German) and Andre Francois (French) cover the rear. All fiveartists were evidently contracted to interpret a single numerical icon -the number 180 - and to integrate it within what is presumably theirrecognizable style.THE perpetrator isNikeCorp., whose slogan, "Just do it," has becomethe low-density battle cry for a generation of narcissistic physicalactivists engaged in slicking up their bodies while a third of the worldsuffers from malnutrition.The offending fold-out is an ad forNike'snew running shoe, theNike180 Air. The middle four pages are a masterpiece of high-style technicalgibberish about the new runner, done up in neo-Albrecht Durer with water-colour renderings first of the shoe, and then of a skinless foot sittingin it. Also included are a nonsensical architectural plan view of theshoe's sole, and a couple of indecipherable technical drawings aimed atconvincing us of the 180's high-tech perfection.The written text, printed in Spanish, German, Japanese and English,informs us thatNike'svaunted air-cushioning unit (a see-through shellthat contains air and thus makes the shoe lighter), has been made 50 percent larger for the 180 runner.On the two remaining pages of the fold-out are silver-tone cheesecakephotos of the new 180 in hot pink, navy and white. With its see-throughair unit, the runner doesn't quite strike me as the Ellen Barkin ofrunning shoes, who is after all, a woman of complexity and substance. The180 is actually the opposite - a testimony to the degree to whichabsolutely nothing can be aggrandized.So what am I offended at, here, anyway? Well, practically everythingabout theNikefold-out offends me. Nowhere in the eight pages does itadmit that it is an advertisement. Au contraire, the fold-out is marked "confidential" in five places, leading us to believe that it must be aninformation leak that Esquire somehow got hold of. That it is addressed tosomeone named T. Hatfield, a name that does not appear on the Esquiremasthead, seems to confirm this. The apparent authours of the informationleak are three guys in Beaverton, Ore., which is presumably the site ofNike'sdesign headquarters.BUT what is most offensive here is that it tells us how the corporatesector will, in the end, nurture and sponsor the arts. In this case, thework of five-star visual artists serves as the fold-out's coverdecoration, and, by implication, as an illustration of how interested inhelping out the artsNikeis.It also tells us that after a half-century of trying to integrate thearts within the communities whose values and problems they are supposed toreflect and articulate, we're headed back to the dark days when art wasn'tby the masters, but for them.Brian Fawcett is a Vancouver writer and author of Public Eye: AnInvestigation into the Disappearance of the World (Harper Collins).
email_title: PUBLIC EYE   FIFTH COLUMN   When running shoes and art   meet, art ends up getting   trampled, says Brian Fawcett

Email_Body: The Stingers face powerhouse Manitoba in the first round of the 20th ConcordiaNikeClassic women's basketball tournament this weekend."If we're going to bring our program back to the level it once was, we have to play teams like Manitoba," Concordia coach Mike Hickey said. "It doesn't do any good to play against weak teams just for the sake of winning." Concordia lost by 23 points to Manitoba's high-powered offence in non-conference action last month that was part of the Bisons' October feed of Quebec teams as they beat McGill, Bishop's and Concordia on successive days.The Stingers play Manitoba in the last of four opening-round games tomorrow at 8 p.m."We'll probably be at our strongest for the first time this season," said Hickey, whose team has won only once in seven pre- season games. "We have good quickness, so it will be our speed against their size."The three-day Classic, which starts tomorrow at Loyola Gym, has developed into one of the premier tournaments in the country and will be closely watched to help decide the first weekly top-10 national ranking of the season, which the Canadian Interuniversity Athletic Union will release Monday.The Laurentian Vees, CIAU national champion for the last two years, are favored to win the Classic for the third straight year, despite losing national team player Nana Robinson, a guard who has taken the year off from school.Completing the eight-team field are the McGill Martlets and Queen's Golden Gaels, who meet in the opening game at 2 p.m., the Winnipeg Lady Wesmen and Ottawa Gee-Gees, who play at 4 p.m., and Laurentian and Waterloo Athenas at 6 p.m.Concordia is a team - make that a progam - in transition, with a new coach, some new faces and emerging from a controversy and legacy of ineptitude that Hickey hopes is behind the team.Hickey replaced Louisa Zerbe as head coach after last season when Zerbe resigned before the season ended over what she said was a lack of support from the Concordia athletic department.Concordia finished last in the four-team Quebec University Women's Basketball League with a 1-11 record and missed the playoffs for the sixth consecutive year.Zerbe compiled a 5-37 league record during her four years as head coach. On Feb. 3, 1990, Concordia ended a five-year, 0-47 losing streak.It's Hickey's second time as head coach of the Stingers. He coached the women's team from 1976 to 1985, during which Concordia reached the CIAU national tournament four times.Upon his return, Hickey said his first priorities were to make the women's program "enjoyable again" and Concordia the class of the Quebec league.He appears to have succeeded on the first matter, but returning Concordia to its previous glory days might take longer than anticipated.
email_title: Stingers face test; Tip-off with Bisons in tourney

Email_Body: Members of Congress have been running in some tight contests recently, but they will pick up the pace today in the annualNikeCapital Challenge, a 3-mile charity foot race at Washington's East Potomac Park, starting at 8 a.m.Legislators representing 25 states are signed up, including 1991 fastest Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., and fastest from the House: Rep. Susan Molinari, R- N.Y., and Rep. Bart Gordon, D-Tenn.The purpose of the race, say sponsors, is to determine which branch of government is fittest - legislative, executive or judicial, or the media who cover them.Some team names: Just Geren and Bear It, led by Rep. Email_Body: IF the shoe fits, wear it. Especially on the Olympic gold-medal stand. And especially if you're getting paid to wear it. But if your Olympic team warm-up suit doesn't fit your portfolio of contracts, don't wear it. Especially on the gold-medal stand.More and more, the United States Olympic team is populated not so much by athletes from all over America as by athletes from manufacturers of athletic apparel with brand names that sound like newly discovered planets. Michael Jordan and Charles Barkley fromNike.Carl Lewis from Mizuno. Dave Johnson (and his decathlon rival who didn't make the team, Dan O'Brien) from Reebok. In the confusion, Michael Jordan and Charles Barkley think they're here representingNikeinstead of the United States.When the two Dream Team basketball players learned that on the gold-medal stand next Saturday night they would be expected to wear official red, white and blue United States warmup suits with the planet Reebok logo, they threatened not to appear at the ceremony."I don't believe in endorsing my competition," Jordan said. "I feel very strongly abut loyalty to my own company."Upon hearing of Jordan's loyalty to his company, cynics wondered about his loyalty to his country. He's here because he grew up playing basketball in the United States, not because he's an alien from the planetNikeon loan to the Olympic team.As for loyalty to his company, how loyal was Jordan to Coca-Cola when Gatorade offered him more money?Gatorade's slogan is "Be Like Mike." But if he doesn't appear at the gold-medal ceremony in his official Olympic warm-up suit, a new slogan suddenly might be more fashionable: Don't Be Like Mike.Don't be like Charles Barkley either.The Dream Team's other international diplomat explained: "UsNikeguys are loyal toNikebecause they pay us a lot of money. I have two million reasons not to wear Reebok." As if those two million reasons, not to mention his other millions of reasons, were generated on the planetNikerather than in the nation he's representing.It's not that Jordan and Barkley didn't know this all along. According to Rule 14 of the code of conduct signed by every United States Olympic athlete, medal winners will wear apparel supplied by the United States Olympic Committee at award ceremonies."This rule," said Harvey Schiller, the U.S.O.C. executive director, "was approved by the Athletes Advisory Council and all athletes on our teams are expected to abide by it and all other portions of the code. It is mandatory policy that any athlete taking part in an official medal ceremoney in Barcelona will wear this apparel, without exception."Jordan signed that agreement. But as an alien from the planetNike,he crossed out Rule 14.Reebok is one of 40 corporate sponsors that contribute $160 million to the U.S.O.C. treasury."The money we're getting for wearing the official warm-up suit is going to assist thousands of athletes in training," said Mike Moran, the U.S.O.C. director of public information. "No athlete will stand on the medal platform without this suit."To their credit, four other Dream Team members from the planetNikehave not objected to wearing the Reebok warm-up suit at the gold-medal ceremony: Chris Mullin, Scottie Pippen, David Robinson and John Stockton.Through the years, Olympic athletes have prospered from their contracts with manufacturers of athletic shoes. When Mike Powell, anotherNikealien, set the world long-jump record in Tokyo last year, Joe Douglas, the manager of Carl Lewis from the planet Mizuno, turned to Powell's agent, Brad Hunt, and said, "You just cost my guy a million dollars."Until now, no United States Olympian ever objected to wearing the official team warm-up suit with a rival logo.But until now, the planetNikewas never so prominent. More than four dozen aliens are on its international track-and-field roster. It's publishing a daily newletter here. It has taken out a full-page daily advertisement, entitled "TheNikeNews," in L'Equipe, the French sports newspaper.Nikeis the Greek word for winged goddess of victory. But if Michael Jordan and Charles Barkley don't wear their official warm-up suits,Nikewill mean broken-winged goddess of greed.
email_title: Sports of The Times;On Loyalty To Company, Or Country?

Email_Body: AFTER A PERIOD of double-digit growth in the mid-1980s, the athletic footwear market has plateaued.  In 1990 the U.S. market hit $11.9 billion on 393 million pairs of athletic footwear. That represents only a 1 percent increase in units and a 10 percent sales gain, the smallest jump since 1984.  ''The overall athletic footwear market has reached a difficult point for manufacturers, as the recession and price competition from casual shoes are having some impact,'' says Sebastian DiCasoli, SGMA's director of marketing sales.  Still, despite concern over cost, four out of every 10 shoes sold in the United States are athletic-style. In addition, DiCasoli says, the possibility of strong sales for athletic footwear looks bright because of greater participation in fitness walking and the continued promotion of outdoor and cross-training shoes.  In an effort to spur the static market, companies are continuously bringing out new shoes.  ''Without a doubt, the newest meaningful development is the system of air bladders, started by Reebok,'' says Bob Gillespie, a store manager for the Allied Sporting Goods chain. ''Nikenow has an air-pressure system and L.A.  Gear uses it in their R egulator Series.'' The air-pressure system provides the wearer with a custom fit. The shoe conforms to the foot, no matter what the configuration.  On the premise that if air can make a shoe conform to the foot it also can make a glove conform to the hand, Spalding and Mizuno have come out with baseball gloves featuring the air system. Gillespie says his most popular shoe isNike's$130 Charles Barkley model.  ''All the kids want it,'' he says, referring to the black low-cut shoe which makes the air bladder visible through the shoe's mid-sole.  ''There are probably better basketball shoes on the market but this happens to be the one that's hot right now,'' says Gillespie, whose store's price points are from $29.99 for a standard leather tennis shoe to $150 forNike'sAir Force 180 high top with air-system arch and ankle supports.  Popular as the air-system shoes are, one pro shop manager and buyer is not a fan.  ''I've had a lot of bad luck with pump shoes,'' says Barbara Ensner of Evansville, Ind. ''Reebok is making a pump walking shoe in which the pump malfunctions.'' Her shop does well theNike'sChallenge model, worn by top-ranked tennis pro Andre Agassi, Wilson's Pro Staff tennis shoe, and Head's Sonic, a tri-court shoe for racquetball, tennis or basketball.  Another new shoe is the $125 Brooks ''Fusion'' model, with a shock-reducing fusion plate that bends with the wearer and snaps back into place, producing a rebound effect. It's rated tops by Runner's World magazine.  ''The air bag has been around since the late '70s, but the fusion plate is newer,'' says Jim Nolan, a shoe store manager.  Nolan's best selling shoe is stillNike'sAir Jordan, named for Chicago Bulls forward, Michael Jordan. ''It's a basketball shoe,'' Nolan says, ''but 90 percent of my sales are not to basketball players.'' The Air Jordan has been the best selling basketball shoe atNikesince 1985, when the company signed the pro, according toNikespokeswoman Melinda Gable.  She says a new Air Jordan will be introduced in February that will be lighter in weight ''with a more dynamic, glove-like fit.'' In the new shoe, heavier leather has been cut away. So has some material from the outsole.  After Jan. 1,Nikewill introduce its Air Flight Mid, worn by Scottie Pippen of the Chicago Bulls. Weighing only 14.3 ounces, the shoe has a specially constructed tongue.Nike'snew running shoe is the Air Huarache that, according to Gable, ''is so lightweight it's minimalistic.'' Made without a heel counter, the shoe features a back strapping system and sells for $110.  Cross-trainers, athletic shoes that are not sports-specific, have been popular for some time. The Sports Quarters' Nolan says he ''lives in''Nike'scross-trainers, with leather upper and air bags in the heel only.  But Gable issues a warning to those who use them for sports: ''Serious athletes should get a sports shoe.''GRAPHIC:Photo; PHOTO...Nike,Reebok, New Balance and Asics fill a crowded market with more models each year.
email_title: IN STEP: NEW MODELS OF ATHLETIC SHOES KEEP UP SALES
