Email_Body: Forget Deion Sanders the baseball player. Forget Deion Sanders the football player. These days, the really impressive Deion Sanders is Deion Sanders the businessman. He's a hair salon owner. He's a spokesman forNike. He has what his attorney describes as "a six-figure deal" with NFL Properties for trading cards. His own clothing line. His own TV show. He'd like to start his own fishing show."A lot of people may not realize it, but Deion is an extremely intelligent person," said attorney Eugene Parker, who represents Sanders. "And all that he does, he is looking toward his future."With Sanders having his best baseball season this year, Parker is receiving all types of endorsement offers for his client. The craziest?"These people wanted to market this ball shaped like a football but painted like a baseball," Parker said. "We decided against it."Sanders'sNikedeal makes him the heir apparent to that company's other two-sport spokesman, Bo Jackson, especially with Jackson's athletic future uncertain after hip-replacement surgery.Nikerecently released new Jackson and Sanders commercials, both done in the same style. They will debut during baseball's All-Star Game July 14. The shoe company is also making a special batting glove for Sanders."There is a lot around the corner, including a likely soft drink deal," said Parker.As much money as Sanders is bringing in now, the stakes are likely to get higher. The Falcons, who will pay him $ 750,000 this year, just offered him an extra $ 1 million to report to training camp by July 13. The Braves, who pay him $ 600,000 through July 31, want to sign him for the rest of the season.
email_title: The Businessman For all his prowess on field(s), sports star has economic savvy

Email_Body: Toymaker Mattel expects record earnings this year, thanks to the popularity of its time-tested toys like the Barbie doll. Mattel Chairman and CEO John Amerman, meeting with analysts Wednesday, said he is comfortable with analysts' earnings estimates of $ 2.15 to $ 2.30 a share this year. Last year, Mattel earned $ 91.2 million, or $ 1.80 a share, on revenue of $ 1.47 billion. Amerm an added that he expects next year to be a growth year, too. Also, Amerman said Mattel is teaming with Fox Television to produce a line of fashion dolls based on the five lead characters in the popular television series Beverly Hills 90210. Dolls should be on the market as early as next year. CORPORATE PROFITS: The Commerce Department said corporations' after-tax profits rose 3.9% the third quarter, the first improvement after two consecutive quarterly declines.  Profits totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $ 189.9 billion vs. $ 182.7 billion in the second quarter when profits fell 3.7%.  NIKETALE: A new book tells the tale of sneaker giantNikeInc. Swoosh: The Story ofNikeand the Men Who Played There explainsNike'sups and downs and how some of its most successful products came to be. (Story, 4C.)
email_title: BARBIE BOOSTS SALES

Email_Body: The shoe salesman from North Carolina sat with his hands clasped and spoke nicely about his golf game, his two children and what a privilege it was to be there. His fellow salesman from the Ukraine smiled and agreed.In front of them sat more than 1000 representatives of the world's media. Flashes popped and television cameras recorded every nuance and every word. Selling shoes had never been easier.Mind you, these were not your average shoe salesmen. No squeezing small shoes on to smelly, blistering feet for these two. One of them, Michael Jordan, the man from North Carolina who now plies his trade in Chicago, earns more than $25million a year. Sergei Bubka, too, lives comfortably. These are the Olympics and another round of Shoe Wars has begun.Nike, Reebok and a host of other shoe companies are all in Barcelona flogging their merchandise and reminding everyone how many champions they have signed to their labels.It wasNike'sturn on the weekend to do the boasting and it used Jordan and world pole-vault record-holder Bubka to do it. A cinema in downtown Barcelona was booked for the event and 15minutes before the media conference began the place was packed.For 50minutes Jordan and Bubka answered questions, and when you left, you felt as though you had spent half a day at a convention of advertising agents.Nikesigns hung from platforms and, outside in the street, a red bus with an inflated shoe pumped out loud rock music. It was all tacky, contrived and, in the end, completely meaningless."I'm not here because of money," said Jordan, referring to playing in the Olympics. "Nikedid not influence me (to come). I came strictly on my own intitiative." But what did he feel about the way sport has been commercialised, particularly since he was sitting on a stage wearing his sponsor's products and endorsing what a terrific bunch of blokes they were? "Commercialism is a part of all professional sports," he said. "It's a way of life." That was about as interesting as it got. The rest of the time was spent either listening to sycophantic questions about how wonderful it must be to be able to soar like a bird, or listening to dull replies, several of which sounded suspiciously as though they had been rehearsed for a few minutes outside.Of course, the media has no one but itself to blame. With Jordan's fame at such a peak around the world _ it is claimed he is the most recognisable sporting figure on the planet these days, usurping Muhammed Ali _ he has said the same things over and over until he has to click off and turn to autopilot. Yes, it's a privilege to play in the Games.Yes, I love playing golf. Yes, it's tough being me and not having a great deal of privacy.Yes, Michael Jordan has very little privacy. When the grindingly long NBA season is on, he spends most of his time confined to a hotel room, unable to walk the streets for fear of being mobbed. He cannot do the little things. No late evening stroll with an ice-cream. No popping into the pub for a few beers with the boys. He can't even go to a public toilet. At least there he has an advantage over the rest of us.The Dream Team has been criticised in Barcelona for not living in the Athlete's Village, preferring instead the security and comfort of a five-star hotel. They dropped in the other day, explained Jordan, but felt the atmosphere would not have been conducive to a good preparation for the basketball tournament. Being in the village would be the same as living outside in the glare of the public. Athletes would be asking for autographs and pictures, small-time officials would be hanging from their shirt-tails.So instead, Jordan lives on his own and occasionally drops into planned media conferences to flog his sponsor's products. Then he departs just as quickly to go back and hide inside the bubble that is his private life. Shoe salesmen never had it so tough.
email_title: Olympic glory is a shoo-in for Jordan, Bubka

Email_Body: THE latest volley in the sneaker wars will be fired tonight during the Grammy Awards show in commercials for British Knights athletic shoes that use an updated version of a classic insult.The $15 million campaign, created by the Deutsch agency, uses the theme "Your mother wearsNike-- choose change," to warn young buyers that wearing sneakers from the older, more established market leader is "un-cool." Donny Deutsch, the agency's executive vice president and creative director, said the company wanted to use a twist on "Your mother wears combat boots" to make the point that Reebok andNikewere no longer on the cutting edge."We want to be seen as the sneakers for rebellious young people," he added. "Reebok andNikehave become so mainstream they're the sneaker of choice for little old ladies."To make that point, one commercial features a group ofNike-clad, gray-haired women gossiping as they lounge around a tennis court. The spot tells viewers to "choose change," then shows a lineup of flashy British Knights shoes decorated with brightly colored stripes.Another ad tells young viewers that even though they inherited their parents' genes, they need not follow in mom and dad's footsteps, implying that the only "hip" sneakers are British Knights."From a technical standpoint, all of the shoes are basically the same," said Larry Schwartz, an executive vice president at British Knights, which are made by Jack Schwartz Shoes Inc., New York. "We think we can stand out by being more fashion-oriented."Officials ofNikeInc. did not return calls yesterday seeking comment on the British Knights campaign.The potshots from British Knights are part of an increasingly aggressive battle being waged by sneaker makers. Earlier this year, Reebok International began a campaign that taunted the athletes Michael Jordan and Bo Jackson, well-known endorsers ofNikeInc. products.In one spot for the Reebok Pump sneaker, which has an inflatable sole that the wearer can adjust by squeezing a bulb in the shoe's tongue, Dominique Wilkins, the Atlanta Hawks basketball player, says, "So Michael, my man, if you want to fly first class . . . pump up and air out," as he tosses away aNikeAir sneaker, which has an air-filled sole but is not adjustable.In addition, L. A. Gear Inc. has been running a commercial for its Catapult sneaker that uses the slogan "Everything else is just hot air" to take a shot at theNikeAir shoe.Advertising in the $5.5 billion sneaker category has become more aggressive as growth in the market has slowed and the industry's leaders have found it difficult to gain a technological edge.Spending on sneaker advertising has risen substantially. Last year, the top three companies --Nike,Reebok and L. A. Gear -- increased ad expenditures from an estimated $70 million in 1989 to about $115 million. Mr. Schwartz, whose company is ranked No. 7 in the industry, said that on average, sneaker companies spend from 5 percent to 7 percent of total retail sales on advertising.Part of the reason for the jump in spending is the hefty fees paid to well-known athletes like Mr. Jordan and Mr. Jackson, who get $5 million to $10 million for endorsements.The flood of sports celebrities in sneaker ads has drawn criticism from some agency executives who said the glut of personalities tended to cause confusion and made it hard for consumers to remember which sports stars wore what shoes.
email_title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Campaign for British Knights to Escalate Sneaker Wars

Email_Body: Michael Jordan wants to just do it inNikes. So do David Robinson, Charles Barkley, John Stockton, Scottie Pippen and Karl Malone, all of them endorsers ofNike, the clothing/sporting goods manufacturer.But the USOC said Jordan and his Dream Team teammates will have to wear the Reebok-made USA team warmups to be in medal ceremonies.On Wednesday, Jordan said while he did sign a code of conduct agreement, he crossed out the section that requires athletes to wear the official team uniform. "They [USOC] accepted it [when he mailed back]. I didn't get it back. They know my concerns. No one has come to me personally and said, 'You better have the Reebok uniform on when you step on the stand,' " Jordan said.In a statement issued by the USOC, Executive Director Harvey W. Schiller said: "The matter of the offical award warmup suit which is mandatory for all U.S. athletes at medal ceremonies is an official policy of the United States Olympic Committee and included in the code of conduct for all members of our delegation."This rule was approved by the Athletes' Advisory Council and all athletes on our teams are expected to abide by it and all other portions of the code."Steinbrenner Steps InGeorge Steinbrenner will take over medical school expenses for Olympic swimmer Ron Karnaugh, whose father died of a heart attack at the Opening Ceremonies."I'm going to do everything I can to help the young man," Steinbrenner, a vice president of the USOC, said Thursday.Steinbrenner was with U.S. officials and Karnaugh's mother when they woke up the swimmer early Sunday with the news his father had died.The family's trip to Barcelona was financed by neighbors in Maplewood, N.J. The death of Peter Karnaugh, a truck driver, left the family with nothing, Steinbrenner said.Steinbrenner said he talked with one of Karnaugh's sisters about the bills that would arrive after he enters University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Newark next month.Meanwhile, Karnaugh has received a letter of support from speed skater Dan Jansen, who endured a similar tragedy at the 1988 Winter Games.Jansen's sister, Jane Beres, died five hours before he skated in the 500-meter race at Calgary. He fell in that race and again after leading the 1,000-meter race later in the week.Don't Make a Case Out of ItInternational Amateur Athletic Federation President Primo Nebiolo called on other sporting federations to help combat the growing problem of athletes appealing to civil courts.American sprinter Butch Reynolds, suspended for two years after testing positive for drugs, won a U.S. Supreme Court injunction in June allowing him to compete in the U.S. Olympic trials.The IAAF decided to take no further action against Reynolds before the Olympics but the subject seems certain to come up at a council meeting after the Games end Aug. 9. At the moment Reynolds can compete starting Aug. 12."The problem of civil cases is becoming a real problem for sport in the world," Nebiolo told a news conference."In athletics it's not so important because we now have 202 countries affiliated and fortunately in the big majority of these countries we don't have cases of athletes appealing to the civil courts. But, in fact, it can happen. That example can be followed and this can create a certain chaos in our organizations."Straight ArrowAntonio Rebollo, the disabled archer whose blazing arrow lit the Olympic flame, said he had been shabbily treated by Games organizers who cast him aside after the Opening Ceremonies.In an interview with Spanish daily Diario 16, Rebollo said the organizing committee had been "pretty inconsiderate.""I know some people at the top of COOB were against using me. They only decided on me because I could guarantee I wouldn't miss," said Rebollo, a polio victim and medal winner in two Paralympic Games.Rebollo said he was given only two hours' notice he had been chosen as archer.
email_title: NOTEBOOK;Questions of Dream Team's Attire Are Raising Ire

Email_Body: Say this for Deion Sanders: He is lending truth to advertising. In oneNikead, the cynic/comedian/chain smoker Denis Leary said of Sanders: "He's out of control."Nike'scopywriters meant this as a compliment, a synonym for "wacky" or "zany." But on Monday night against Dallas, Sanders wasn't wacky or zany. He was simply . . .Out of control.Watching Sanders that night was akin to watching a child throw a protracted fit. Clearly Sanders wasn't having one of his better games, but that wasn't the disconcerting part. (Goodness knows, we've all seen Falcons mess up before.) What was truly nettling was Sanders's apparent resolve to remain the absolute center of attention at every moment. An actor who overemotes is said to be chewing the scenery. On Monday night Sanders chewed so much scenery as to render the Georgia Dome an open-air facility. His actions suggested that if he wasn't allowed to make a spectacular play, the game just wasn't worth playing. Sorry. This is not how football, or any sport, works.For every lookaway pass Earvin Johnson made on the fast break, he made 20 of the mundane sort in the half-court offense. For every one of Jerry Rice's 100-plus touchdowns, he has caught five 10-yard outs. Breathtaking moments come as a function of fundamentals, not as a counterpoint. Even if the big moment never presents itself, a game can be won in several smaller moments.Every play isn't meant for highlight filmsOn Monday night, Sanders was too busy playing to the ABC cameras to worry about details. Let us recount the ways:In the second quarter, Troy Aikman hit Michael Irvin on a slant. Sanders, assigned to cover, missed the tackle. Irvin continued downfield. Custom calls for a man who misses a tackle to hop up and pursue. Instead Sanders, among the world's fastest humans, stayed on his knees for long seconds, his arms outstretched in disbelief.Later in the second quarter, Dallas kicked off to Sanders deep in the end zone. Sanders made no move to run the ball. Neither did he drop to a knee and down it. Instead he stood in the end zone, railing at the injustice of not being allowed to return this kick. Was he about to rail himself into a safety? No. Though screaming is not considered the universal symbol for a touchback, the nearest official finally granted Sanders one.In the third quarter, Sanders fumbled on a kickoff return. On the next play, Emmitt Smith broke a half-dozen tackles to score. Sanders arrived just in time to shove him through the end zone and under one of the Dome's walls. If it wasn't quite a cheap shot, neither was it a serious attempt to make a tackle. (Serious tacklers don't shove opponents into the end zone.) It was merely a petulant gesture.Speaking of petulance . . . Sanders returned to the Falcon sideline and smashed an aluminum bench. Naturally, ABC caught it all.In the fourth quarter, Dallas kicked off for the last time. Sanders fielded the ball on his 2 and took it into the end zone. This time he kneeled down, forgetting that a touchback cannot be granted if the ball is carried into the end zone. The official, acting properly, made no signal. Had a Cowboy tagged the kneeling Sanders, it would've been a safety. At the last moment, Sanders jumped up and ran out to the Falcons' 26.Hey, I admit it. Time was, Sanders's antics cracked me up. I still laugh when I think of him breaking up a pass against New England, then running in front of the Patriots' bench and thumping his chest. But he's no rookie anymore. He's a 25-year-old All-Pro. He's better than this.To date, Sanders has been lucky. None of his excesses has cost his team a game - yet. (The end zone lateral against Phoenix came close.) But he has to realize that every single play isn't meant for the highlight film, or the sneaker ad. To steal from Denis Leary, I've got two words for Mr. Deion Sanders:Grow up.
email_title: COMMENTARY Like a broken record, Sanders goes for broke

Email_Body: The anonymous source who provided the photos of a sports fixer and Nevada- Las Vegas basketball players that led to the resignation of UNLV basketball coach Jerry Tarkanian has come forward 14 months later to reveal how he got the shots.Lamont Sudbury, 33, an architectural designer, says he obtained the photos by accident from the ex-wife of convicted sports fixer Richard Perry. The pictures, published by the Las Vegas Review-Journal in May 1991, showed Perry in a hot tub with former Rebels players Anderson Hunt, David Butler and Moses Scurry. Tarkanian, who had been involved in a 14-year battle with the NCAA, resigned several days after the photos were published. He now coaches the NBA San Antonio Spurs.Sudbury says he got the photos from Perry's ex-wife, Joanne, with whom he had been romantically involved. She had asked him to take photos of an architectural project he completed at the Perry home, but, said Sudbury, she mistakenly returned the wrong photos, giving him the hot-tub negatives instead.''Like everybody else in Las Vegas,'' said Sudbury in a statement, ''I was aware of an article in Time magazine that had pointed out Mr. Perry's connections to the Boston College point-shaving incident.''However, I did not decide to do anything with the pictures until the spring of 1991, when the Review-Journal reported that Mr. Perry continued to be seen on the fringes of the UNLV program.'' OLYMPICS: U.S. athletes expect to wear theirNikeapparel in Barcelona, even though a Spanish court rejectedNike'sfinal appeal in a multimillion- dollar trademark feud, the U.S. Olympic Committee said Wednesday. The decision by Spain's highest appeals court makes it a virtual certainty thatNikewill have to comply with an order barring it from selling or advertising apparel in Spain. But the entire U.S. track and field team has a contract to wearNikeapparel. And many other athletes wearNikeshoes. BOWLING: Twin brothers Mike and Mark Scroggins of Amarillo, Texas, regained the lead through five rounds Wednesday in the $ 142,500 Beaumont (Texas) Doubles Classic. Mike averaged 238 for his last eight games and won six of those. Mark has a 12-4 match-play record overall. They totaled 15,587 pins.Compiled by Ben Brown
email_title: Photos that embarrassed UNLV obtained by fluke

Email_Body: Sneaker wearers are attracted to the colors of the shoes as much as to their touted technological advances, like air pumps and gel-filled heels.Athletic shoes can be matched to sports outfits and street clothes. And there seems to be a color -- or a combination of colors -- for every taste, now that companies likeNikeand Reebok are mixing colors in their athletic-shoe designs. Their choices are influenced by the fashion, surfing and ski industries. Basketball, running, cross-training and aerobics shoes are emerging in bright colors like "kiwi" and "aruba blue." Tinker Hatfield, creative director ofNike,said "women who take aerobics are generally interested in color because they want their sneakers to match their outfits." Other styles, like tennis and walking shoes, combine ecologically correct earth tones.Nike'scolors for spring range from gray, jade and teal to rust, olive and tan. The women's Air Elite Max at $90 combines turquoise, lime green and white; the men's Air Trainer Max is yellow, black, gray and white and sells for $115.Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls basketball team changed the way basketball shoes are colored, Mr. Hatfield said. In 1987, Mr. Jordan wore game shoes that matched his red and black Chicago Bulls uniform. He now helps design his line of shoes forNike.The distinctive Air Jordan, $130, is fashioned in black, yellow, fuchsia, gray, and green. It has a matching sole bearing Mr. Jordan's silhouette on the heel.Nikeshoes are sold in Manhattan at Footlocker, Lady Footlocker, Paragon Sporting Goods and Herman's.Pamela Bennett-Boucher, trend and color forecasting manager for Reebok, likes to mix color with graphics and abstract patterns. Her shoes for spring feature earth tones. The Boulevard ($69.99), designed for outdoor basketball, comes in charcoal with clay-colored trim.Ms. Bennett-Boucher has colored the soles of women's aerobics shoes, taking advantage of all that kicking and high-stepping. The Aerobic Lite 7000, at $74.99, is done in mandarin or hot pink on white. "There is unexpected excitement when the upper is mostly white and there is a burst of color on the soles," she said, adding that softer colors like seagreen and pink are also popular.She uses what she calls more aggressive colors -- black, copper, orange and metallics like pewter -- for the Pump step trainer, $109.99, to give the shoe an industrial look.For men, the runner's Pump, $129.99, is done in white, sapphire blue, and bright purple. Ms. Bennett-Boucher says men don't usually wear such interesting colors, but they do tend to want colors that stand out on a running track.In Manhattan, Reebok shoes are sold at Athletes' Foot, Paragon Sporting Goods, Herman's, Bloomingdale's, Macy's, and other major department stores.
email_title: Slammin', With In-Your-Face Color

Email_Body: Scouts skipped the surprises in compiling a consensus list of the best players at theNike/ABCD high school basketball camp, which concluded Tuesday in Indianapolis.Nike'sfabulous five are already fixtures on college coaches' most-wanted lists.- 6-9 center Othella Harrington of Jackson (Miss.) Murrah, the camp's second-leading rebounder (5.9 a game) and fourth-best field-goal shooter (55.8%). Averages are lower because campers played only half of each game. - 6-7 small forward Corliss Williamson of Russellville (Ark.) High, the No. 9 scorer (8.9 ppg).- 7-foot center Rashard Griffith of Chicago King, the No. 6 rebounder (4.9).- 6-7 swingman Rodrick Rhodes of Jersey City St. Anthony, who was not among statistical leaders but helped St. Anthony to a No. 2 ranking in USA TODAY's final Super 25 poll last season.- 6-4 guard Jason Kidd of Alameda (Calif.) St. Joseph Academy, who was second in steals (2.5) and third in assists (3.6).Scouts did add one new name to high school basketball's social register: Damon Flint, a previously unheralded guard from Cincinnati Woodward. Flint, a 6-4 junior, ranked seventh in scoring (9.3) and fourth in three-point shooting (43.8%).SIGNED: Shawn Estes, a second team All-USA TODAY baseball player from Minden (Nev.) Douglas High, signed with the Seattle Mariners.Estes, 18, was Seattle's No. 1 draft pick and the 11th player chosen overall in the June draft.Estes, a left-hander, went 8-2 with a 0.80 ERA.  He struck out 141 in 62 innings and allowed only 15 hits.The Seattle Times reported that Estes received a $ 400,000 salary package. Included is his college education paid for by the Mariners. JUNIOR BOWLERS: Youths from the USA, Puerto Rico, six Canadian provinces, the Far East, European and Caribbean military commands, compete in the National Junior Bowling Championships July 17-21 at Woodland Bowl in Indianapolis.A total of $ 45,000 in scholarships will go to the top four finishers in each division: girls handicap, boys handicap, girls scratch and boys scratch, plus the All-America boy and girl as decided by the participants.First-place finishers in each division receives a $ 5,000 scholarship.
email_title: Nikecamp's fabulous 5 turns out as expected

Email_Body: Judi St. Hilaire is trying not to think about the bonus. Lynn Jennings is thinking about it, but isn't making predictions. The two runners could earn a $ 25,000 bonus from Clairol for breaking 25 minutes in Sunday'sNikeWomen's Run 8K in Washington, D.C.Jennings, the 1990 and '91 world cross-country champion, set a U.S. record of 25: 07 in the race two years ago.''I was wicked out of shape, 10 pounds overweight,'' she says. ''It was one of those days when mental desire pulls you through.''Breaking 25 depends on opponents, tactics, weather. You can't say you're going to break a record. It has to evolve.''St. Hilaire beat Jennings in last year's race, finishing in 25: 10. ''The bonus is the last thing I'm thinking about,'' St. Hilaire says. ''I just want to be competitive. We'll run fast because the quality is there.''
email_title: Women get $ 25,000 incentive to 'break 25' inNike8K run

Email_Body: Former North Carolina State basketball coach Jim Valvano will return to coaching for the first time since his ouster when he joins theNikeAll-Star team in Europe this fall.The team will have just one day of practice before leaving Sept. 1 for the tour of Germany and France. Although Valvano was never accused of wrongdoing, he was forced to leave N.C. State 15 months ago, following NCAA violations by team members. But Valvano said his season as a college basketball analyst for ABC and ESPN since then has kept him sharp.''Hey, I coached all of last year - coached my brains out,'' he said. ''I never lost a game, either.''Valvano said he was assured of at least one victory against the German national team.''I'll have (NBA All-Stars) Charles Barkley and David Robinson playing for me for that game,'' he said.
email_title: Valvano set to coachNikestars

Email_Body: MICHAEL JORDAN has told the National Basketball Association it may no longer sell apparel bearing his image, givingNikeInc. those rights exclusively.The Oregonian in Portland, Ore., yesterday reported Jordan's decision, confirmed by the league. The move, unprecedented in the N.B.A., means millions of dollars. The 28-year-old Jordan, who led the Chicago Bulls to their first N.B.A. championship last year, is among the most charismatic -- and profitable -- personalities in the league. (AP)
email_title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Jordan Reserves Rights

Email_Body: Budapest, February 20, 1991 (MTI-ECONEWS) - Niktrokemia(Nike)Industrial Plants, based at Fuzfo, Western Hungary,and the Italian company Fiocchi, have just set up a JV underthe nameNike-Fiocchi Sports Ammunition Manufacturing, Ltd.      The JV's initial capital of 10.4 million USD is equallyshared by two partners.     The Italian partner contributed cash to the venture,with the Hungarian chemical company putting up the site andpremises of its old gunpowder manufacturing plant.     The JV's aim is to manufacture and distribute bulletsfor hunting, sports and industrial purposes, and also todesign and assemble fireworks and pyrotechnical products.     The JV has injected 4 million USD of the initial capitalinto the purchase of Fiocchi technology and manufacturinglines.     The production and sales forecast is for 5 million USdollars' worth of ammunition this year and 11 million USddollars' worth in 1992.     The products will be marketed in both here in Hungaryand in Italy.
email_title: Nike-Fiocchi JV set up
