Email_Body: Former North Carolina State basketball coach Jim Valvano will return to coaching for the first time since his resignation 15 months ago with a 10-day stint with theNikeAll-Star team in Europe this fall.The team will have just one day of practice before leaving Sept. 1 for the tour of Germany and France. "We'll probably struggle," Valvano said. "They have teams that play together year to year, and our team will be more of a hodgepodge. We'll just do the best we can."Although Valvano was never accused of wrongdoing, he was forced to leave N.C. State following NCAA violations by team members. But Valvano said his season as a college basketball analyst for ABC and ESPN since then has kept him sharp.
email_title: BASKETBALL

Email_Body: There's a backlash against dieting and America's narcissistic obsession with thinness.Dieting and stick figures are out.Self-acceptance and shapeliness are in.Honest imperfection is being trumpeted by a new wave of experts who contend that dieting almost always fails and frequently causes eating disorders. EvenNike,the '80s purveyor of sports gear, is getting in on the attitude, with a series of advertisements reminding women they may not be goddesses, but the ground beneath them is still worthy of worship."We know the hype is that if you want a good life, you have to be thin," says Carole Shaw, publisher of Big Beautiful Women magazine. "You're going to have a better life, you're going to have a better guy, you're going to have a better job. If we could only be what we're not."In real life, people of all sizes are having good and bad lives," she says. "Being thin doesn't guarantee you a wonderful life."In 1990, the U.S. government loosened its dietary weight guidelines, except for men and women with health problems and a propensity to carry their bulk in their belly, which has higher health risks."The focus was to look at a healthy weight," says Jackie Haven, a nutritionist at the U.S. Department of Agriculture. "The number may not be flattering in terms of appearance. Some may think that they still are too heavy. . . . But in terms of their health, it may not make a difference."The about-face is being hailed as a breakthrough by weight-control experts emphasizing dieters' self-esteem over weight. The experts are attempting to teach individuals to use food for nutritional reasons rather than as a sedative or a pastime."I'm thrilled that finally people are recognizing what women have known forever: that diets don't work," says Carol M. Munter, a New York psychotherapist and co-author of "Overcoming Overeating" (Addison-Wesley, $ 15.34). "People are finally beginning to take the evidence seriously and give up dieting.""We get put on diets because we live in a culture that refuses to acknowledge that people come in different shapes and sizes," she says.At the University of Toronto, "We spend most of our time helping these women realizing that they deserve to be respected," says Dr. Janet Polivy, a dieting researcher.Diets 'don't work'Experts are also trying to convince dieters, most of whom are women, to take their lives off hold. Many overweight people postpone job and social opportunities with the idea of losing weight."One woman who went through the program was waiting to apply for a job promotion until she lost 50 pounds," says Dr. Polivy, who pointed out to the woman that she had been at the job three years. The woman applied for the promotion and got it.The new approach is advocated for individuals just a few pounds away from their ideal figure as well as to obese people.Diets "don't work any better for people who are 400 pounds than for people who are 20 pounds overweight," says Susan Wooley, an associate professor of psychiatry at the University of Cincinnati who began studying obesity in 1969. "We keep deluding ourselves."As a college student, 5-foot-6 Susan Copeland of Marietta was a trim 128 pounds. But through the years she gradually grew to her current 153 pounds.About 18 months ago, she tried dropping 10 pounds by using liquid diets and skipping an occasional meal. The weight stayed on, and the 34- year-old medical assistant stopped trying about six months ago."Since people tell me that I don't look that weight, that helps me deal with it better," she says. "I'm just content right now. . . . My priority is to eat right and to exercise and to just be healthy."At 300 pounds, Judi Dandy of Stone Mountain used to peer into the mirror and see a fat, ugly, worthless woman. "For so many years I had been down on myself simply because of my size," she says.She tried dieting but always regained the weight. "After I gained the last 100 pounds back, I said, 'The hell with this.' "The 48-year-old says she's become happier and more sociable and has begun eating more healthfully since she stopped dieting. Her weight stabilized at 275 pounds.While the new approach is welcomed by those who once struggled to be svelte, other experts say advising severely overweight individuals not to worry is foolhardy at best - and even dangerous."If you don't want to call it a diet, that's all right," says Dr. Reubin Andres, clinical director of the National Institute on Aging Gerontology Research Center. "But you have to control food intake. . . . To just say, 'Be happy with your body,' I can't do that."The risk of being obeseSeverely overweight individuals run higher risks for developing diabetes, hypertension, coronary artery disease and early death, Dr. Andres says. But he acknowledges, "The big argument has to do with just what is the best range of weights."Nevertheless, anti-diet experts argue that two decades of clinical observation and psychological studies show diets contribute to obesity and eating disorders. They point out that about 95 percent of people who lose weight gain it back within five years, and that "yo-yo dieting" - the cycle of gaining, losing, then gaining weight again - is suspected of causing heart disease."There's nothing wrong with watching what you eat," says Ms. Dandy, founder of Southeast Super Singles, who with a friend recently opened the Refinery consignment shop for large women in Alpharetta. "But when you become a fanatic and when society is so focused on the perfect bod, this is what's causing the problem.""If there was any diet that worked, we would all go on one diet and that would be the end of it," says Ms. Shaw, who founded BBW 13 years ago. "But there's 27,000 diets out there."Dieters are also more likely to binge, says Dr. Polivy, who has documented differences between chronic dieters and non-dieters.Because of this, Ms. Munter and her colleague Jane R. Hirschmann, who both counsel overweight women, eliminate any controls on the type of food clients can eat. Instead, they teach how to recognize hunger and avoid eating out of boredom, depression or anxiety.But Dr. Andres says high diet-failure statistics should not be used to dissuade obese individuals from dieting. "It's a dismal prognosis," he says, "but it would almost be like saying, 'Look, you have cancer, we have a drug, but it's only going to cure 5 percent of the people who take it. Do you want the drug or not?' "But Ms. Dandy welcomes the new advice. "At one time I hated myself, and now I love myself." Counseling and tips from BBW magazine helped convince her she had value."People treat me with respect, and I think it's because I respect myself more," she says. "I dress in much more fashionable clothing. Before, it was like, 'What difference would it make? A fat lob is a fat lob.' "GRAPHIC:photo: Judi Dandy (right) says she's happier since she gave up dieting. She and Jan Nance have opened a consignment clothing shop for large women. / WALTER STRICKLIN / Staff photo:Nikehas jumped on the self-acceptance bandwagon.
email_title: Anti-diet experts seek to redefine 'overweight' Focus is shifting from stick-thin bodies to women's self-acceptance, shapeliness

Email_Body: BYLINE:By Mike Fish Staff writerAbS Being picked No. 2 overall by New Jersey rather than No. 3 by Sacramento not only means a bigger NBA contract for Kenny Anderson, it also means a bigger shoe contract. From a shoe marketing standpoint, a would-be pitchman's earning potential is far greater in the New York-New Jersey area than in Sacramento.  Officials atNikeconfirmed the company is negotiating to add Anderson to its stable of marquee NBA talent, which includes Michael Jordan, and that he is now in position to probably demand a better shoe deal.Being picked No. 2 overall by New Jersey rather than No. 3 by Sacramento not only means a bigger NBA contract for Kenny Anderson, it also means a bigger shoe contract.From a shoe marketing standpoint, a would-be pitchman's earning potential is far greater in the New York-New Jersey area than in Sacramento. Officials atNikeconfirmed the company is negotiating to add Anderson to its stable of marquee NBA talent, which includes Michael Jordan, and that he is now in position to probably demand a better shoe deal.Anderson can expect to receive a yearly shoe contract for about $ 400,000 playing in New Jersey, versus $ 300,000 in the smaller Sacramento market."I think it's much harder to market a guy in Sacramento," said Fred Schreyer,Nike'sdirector of sports marketing. "You'll be on a bad team that no one is ever going to see. While New Jersey isn't a great team and no one will see them much, either, you do have the New Jersey-New York thing and Kenny being a New York schoolboy legend."Sports agent Leigh Steinberg, who represents many of the top NFL quarterbacks, is making his first venture into the basketball arena as the agent for Nevada-Las Vegas guard Greg Anthony. Steinberg's football clients include Warren Moon, Troy Aikman and Jeff George. basketball; personalities; advertising; salaries
email_title: New Jersey will net Anderson big shoe deal

Email_Body: THREE youths threatened to stab two boys unless they handed over their expensive sport shoes yesterday, police said.Police said the three robbers chased two 13-year-old Port Melbourne boys from a light rail station near Ferras St, South Melbourne, about 4pm before swiping the runners. The attack is part of a disturbing trend of robberies on youngsters for their expensive clothing and footwear.Police said the robbers bundled the shoes, a $250 pair of JordanNikebasketball shoes and a $180 pair ofNikeChers, into a black knapsack carried by one of the robbers.The boys told police one youth told them to hand over their runners or they would be stabbed.The robbers are described as aged 15 to 17, and police believe one of them had short red hair and a solid build.Anyone with information about the attack should contact Sen. Det.Gerry Richardson, of South Melbourne CIB, on 696 0122.END OF STORY
email_title: Boys' shoes stolen

Email_Body: It appears that only Michael Jordan is at the center of the latest controversy over the U.S. men's Olympic basketball team's licensing rights. Agents for three other Olympians, two of them yesterday, said that their clients have not been notified of any requirement to comply with an agreement to surrender their likenesses for marketing purposes.NBA Properties, the league's marketing arm and the Olympic licensing agent for USA Basketball, had reportedly asked all Olympians to comply with an agreement under which NBA Properties would have the rights to sell apparel with their caricatures. If the players don't comply, they would be asked to resign from the team. Jordan met with his agent and attorney, ProServ's David Falk, in Annapolis yesterday to decide on a course of action.Meanwhile, Utah's John Stockton, according to USA Today, wrote USA Basketball and said he wanted to play, no matter the guidelines. Stockton is also a ProServ client, as is New York's Patrick Ewing.At issue, once again, is an exclusive agreement between several players -- including Jordan -- andNike, the shoe and apparel company. Under this agreement, the players have givenNikethe right to use their likenesses in the sale of apparel, including T-shirts. And several players have in the last month asked the league to stop using their likenesses in the sale of apparel.Kyle Rote, the agent for Olympian Scottie Pippen, a teammate of Jordan on the Chicago Bulls, said the rumor about an ultimatum from the league "is not factually correct. Everyone is excited about being on the Olympic team and representing the country. . . . Michael is on a different level as far as marketing.""The rest of us appear to be on the sidelines until further notice," another Olympian's agent said.But a league source did make contents of a March 3 letter from USA Basketball President Dave Gavitt toNikePresident Phil Knight available to The Washington Post. In this letter, Gavitt warned Knight that "we reserve the right to replace any of the six [Nikerepresented] players on the Olympic team ifNikecontinues to provide resistance."Gavitt declined to comment on the substance of any allegations, saying, "I view this whole episode, right now, as a non-story. We have 10 players [on the team] who are good players, and more important, good guys. We have acceptances from all of them and they'll honor them [the commitments]. The Olympic team is about playing for America. It's not about agents or agencies."Jordan wondered Tuesday if NBA Properties wouldn't make a profit from the sale of apparel while the players surrendered rights to do the same. NBA Properties is representing USA Basketball because USA is a nonprofit organization.He told reporters, "If it's going to be the way they laid it out to be, then it's going to be tough to swallow -- accept their rules or send in your resignation. I'm saying, 'I'm not here to resign from the Olympics, and I'm not here to accept your guidelines.' "There was no word last night on what course of action Falk and Jordan would take, with the Bulls in town to play the Washington Bullets tonight. Falk did not return telephone calls.
email_title: Players vs. U.S. on Olympic Marketing;At Issue Is Control of Their Likenesses on Games-Related Apparel

Email_Body: BARCELONA, Sunday: The shoe salesman from Carolina sat with his hands clasped and spoke nicely about his golf game, his two children and what a privilege it was to be here. His fellow salesman from the Ukraine smiled and agreed. In front of them sat more than 1,000 representatives of the world's media. Flashes popped and television cameras recorded every look and every word. Selling shoes had never been easier.Mind you, these were not your average shoe salesmen. No squeezing small shoes on to smelly, blistering feet for these two. One of them, Michael Jordan, the man from Carolina who now plies his trade in Chicago, earns more than $25 million a year. Sergey Bubka, too, lives comfortably.These are the Olympics, and another round of Shoe Wars has begun.Nike, Reebok and a host of other shoe companies are all in Barcelona flogging their merchandise and reminding everyone how many champions they have signed to their labels.It wasNike'sturn to do the boasting on the weekend, and it used Jordan and world pole-vault record holder Bubka to do it. A cinema in downtown Barcelona was booked for the event, and 15 minutes before the conference began the place was packed.For 50 minutes Jordan and Bubka answered questions, and when you left you felt as though you had spent half a day at a convention of advertising agents.Nikesigns hung from platforms, and outside in the street a red bus with an inflated shoe pumped out loud rock music. It was all tacky, contrived, and in the end, virtually meaningless."I'm not here because of money," said Jordan, referring to competing in the Olympics."Nikedid not influence me - I came strictly on my own initiative."What did he feel about the way sport has been commercialised, particularly since he was sitting on a stage wearing his sponsor's products and endorsing what a terrific bunch they were?"Commercialism is a part of all professional sports," he said.That was about as interesting as it got. The rest of the time was spent listening to sycophantic questions about how wonderful it must be to be able to soar like a bird, or dull replies, several of which sounded as though they had been rehearsed for a few minutes outside.The media has no-one but itself to blame. With Jordan's fame at a peak around the world - it is claimed he is the most recognisable sporting figure on the planet these days, usurping Muhammed Ali - he has said the same things over and over until he has to click off.The Dream Team has been criticised for not living in the Athletes' Village in Barcelona, preferring the security and comfort of a five-star hotel. They dropped in to the village the other day, explained Jordan, but felt the atmosphere would not have helped them prepare for the basketball tournament. It would be the same as living outside in the glare of the public. Athletes would be asking for autographs and pictures, he said, small-time officials would be hanging from their shirt-tails.So instead Jordan lives on his own and occasionally drops into a planned media conferences to flog his sponsor's products. Then he departs just as quickly to go back and hide inside the bubble which is his private life. Shoe salesmen have never had it so tough.
email_title: JORDAN SHOOTS A FEW FOR THE SHOE COMPANY;OLYMPIC EXTRA

Email_Body: US housing boost Construction starts on new homes and apartments in the United States jumped in August at the strongest rate in 18 months, the Commerce Department said today. The annual rate of starts on new homes climbed by 10.4 per cent to a seasonally adjusted 1.24million units, after back-to-back declines. NikerecordNikeyesterday reported record quarterly earnings and became the first company in the sports and fitness industry to generate more than $US1 billion ($A1.38billion) in revenues during a single quarter.Nike'snet income for the three-month period, which ended 31 August, was $US122.59 million, or $US1.60 a share, an increase of seven per cent.Field may hold more The minerals and energy group Devex believes its Tubridgi gasfield in the Pilbara region of Western Australia could hold much more gas than originally thought. "There could be several more times gas in Tubridgi than the 64 billion cubic feet figure used at the moment," the managing director, Mr George White, said yesterday in Perth.HMA profits creep up The flour miller HMA has shrugged off restructuring costs to post a net profit of just over $1.06 million for 1991-92, up 11 per cent from the previous year. The company said in a statement yesterday that the profit result was achieved despite a drop in sales revenue of 16 per cent to $102 million.YSL in sharp fall Yves Saint Laurent, one of the most famous Paris fashion houses, suffered a sharp fall in net profits from 41 million francs ($A11.2 million) in the first half of 1991 to 2.6 million francs in the same period this year, reflecting the depressed state of the global luxury goods market. The company stressed that the first half was traditionally slack.
email_title: In Brief

Email_Body: Last time Reebok tried to sell its sneakers with fashion ads in 1989, the campaign went over like brown shoes with a tuxedo.Nike- hyping its sneakers for their performance - jumped past stumbling Reebok to become the nation's No. 1 athletic shoemaker. Now Reebok is trying fashion ads again to try to gain ground on archrivalNike- which has 30 percent of the U.S. market compared with Reebok's 26 percent.This time Reebok's campaign is smarter: It's for only one line, the "classic" soft leather aerobics shoe. And the fashion pitch is refashioned to seem more like a performance pitch.The target: the same people who bought the shoes in the mid-1980s.The estimated $ 5 million magazine campaign features thirtysomething men and women engaging in recreational activities - biking, touch football - but clearly taking it easy, and looking good in Reeboks. The slogan: "Reebok Classic. Never Gets Old."David Ropes, vice president of marketing services for Reebok, says the ads capture the "emotional relationship" people have with the old shoes, as opposed to Reebok's newfangled, high-tech sneakers, such as The Pump.The ads are running in People, Esquire and GQ, among other magazines. They were created by Mullen Advertising of Hamilton, Mass., the same agency that created the successful campaign for Smart Food popcorn.
email_title: Reebok takes a fashionable turn

Email_Body: Vince Dooley, man of many hats, made at least $ 374,000 in 1986 for - among other things - wearing many hats.An Alabama company that makes Georgia hats gave Dooley, whose salary as football coach and athletics director at the time was $ 95,000, 12 dozen hats and paid him 2 percent of the gross sales of Bulldogs hats. Dooley's 1986 income was the subject of a three-year court fight between Dooley and The Journal-Constitution. The Georgia Supreme Court recently ordered Dooley, who retired as football coach Jan. 1, 1989, but remains athletics director, plus basketball coaches Hugh Durham and Andy Landers to disclose their incomes.A similar case, seeking the outside incomes of athletics officials at Georgia Tech, including athletics director Homer Rice, football coach Bobby Ross and basketball coach Bobby Cremins, is pending in Superior Court.Dooley's outside income is by no means unusual. Last year, for instance, Notre Dame football coach Lou Holtz's salary was $ 90,000, but his total income $ 750,000.Dooley made more than 2 1/2 times his base salary by being a media personality (nearly $ 200,000 from TV and radio contracts), a shoe salesman ($ 30,000 for endorsingNikefootwear), an orator ($ 12,000 from speaking engagements) and a camp counselor ($ 5,250 from the Bulldog Football Camp).GRAPHIC:Color Photo: Former Georgia coach Vince Dooley more than tripled his base salary with outside income in 1986. / Calvin Cruce / Staff Chart: Dooley's dollars Vince Dooley earned more than $ 374,000 as Georgia's football coach in 1986, according to documents obtained by the Atlanta Journal- Constitution. Source...................Description.........Amount/value University of Georgia....Coaching salary.....$ 95,000.00 .........................Expenses.............$ 4,500.00 .........................Annuity premium.....$ 26,000.00 Nike.....................Endorsement fee.....$ 30,000.00 .........................Merchandise..........$ 2,000.00 Georgia football network Postgame show.......$ 30,000.00 .........................Tailgate show........$ 9,000.00 WGST radio...............Call-in show.........$ 6,000.00 Loran Smith Co...........TV show............$ 152,341.77 Other endorsements.......Caps, clothing, etc..$ 2,406.12 Speaking engagements.....Honorarium..........$ 12,000.00 Bulldog Football Camp....Coaching fee.........$ 5,250.00 Total.......................................$ 374,497.89 Some provisions of shoe contract Nikeprovides 300 pairs of shoes for use by football team; 100 pairs of shoes for the team if it goes to a bowl. Minimum 14 days notice for personal appearances, which shall last no more than six hours at one time, 24 hours including travel time. $ 500 in merchandise for 12 assistants. Contract canceled if Dooley "ceases for any reason to be the head coach of the University of Georgia football team." Value: $ 32,000 Some provisions of cap contract Dooley must wear cap during football games and "encourage each member of the Georgia athletic and coaching staff . . . to wear the Georgia cap." Company provides Dooley with 12 dozen caps per year. Company will not use Dooley's photo in promotions without Dooley's approval. Dooley gets 2 percent of gross sales of Georgia caps; he gets financial statement and has access to company books. Value: $ 2,406.12 Durham, Landers also benefit from endorsements / E9
email_title: Dooley's outside' windfall; Non-coaching revenue 2 1/2 times of base salary

Email_Body: Among the things Bo Jackson knows is how to give the media short rations. But it was a different story this week in Portland, Ore., where NikeInc., one of Jackson's many employers, decided to hold a news conference for high school journalists.With two of his own children watching from a balcony above, Jackson charmed the group with stories about his poor upbringing in rural Alabama and how he became rich and famous.His description of himself: "A nappy-headed kid who threw rocks better than some people could shoot a gun."; Caddyshack updateOccasionally, Sheryl Calcavecchia serves as caddie for her husband Mark at PGA Tour events. Noting that caddies' salaries often involve a percentage of the player's earnings, Mark observed:"She's the only one I know of who gets 100 percent."; The Doctor is out In his new book "Valvano: They Gave Me a Lifetime Contract, and Then They Declared Me Dead," former N.C. State basketball coach Jim Valvano explains why he's working as a TV announcer instead of a scout.In the late 1960s, while coaching the freshman team at Rutgers for Bill Foster, Valvano was sent to Long Island to check out a 6-foot-3 center touted by his brother. Valvano wasn't impressed, and here's the rest of the story:"Oh, the kid visited Rutgers on his own anyway and still seemed very interested, but I convinced Foster he couldn't play at our level and that we should go after another player named Alan Cotler."I lost Cotler to Penn. He's now a lawyer in Philadelphia. I lost track of the other kid. He was in Philly, too, but I think he became a doctor or something. You ever hear of him? Kid's name is Julius Erving."; A fresh startRudy Galindo is back at the U.S. Figure Skating Championships this year, but as a solo performer, rather than as a defending pairs champion, now that his former partner, Kristi Yamaguchi, has decided to concentrate on her solo career.Galindo has made one more adjustment in returning to singles for the first time since 1988: The spelling of his first name."I had changed it from Rudy to Rudi to match with Kristi," he said. "I'm into a new life and wanted everything to be fresh. So I'm back to Rudy."Galindo smiles, jokes and avoids saying anything that could be construed as sour grapes about the end of his pairing with Yamaguchi. But it's apparent he was hurt by the parting."It's kind of hard to be out there by yourself," Galindo said this week as he prepared for the start of the championships. "A few times, I went to grab Kristi's hand, and it was not there."; A K' for historyMark it down for posterity: Reid Ryan, 19-year-old son of Nolan, struck out the first batter he faced as a freshman at the University of Texas. The victim was a friend, Shayne Currin of Texas-Arlington, who spends his summers as bullpen catcher for the Texas Rangers.Reid Ryan's fastball was clocked in the 85 mph range, and his curveball was sharp as he pitched two innings, giving up one run.His dad didn't make the 150-mile trip from Alvin to Austin for the debut. But they'll see each other April 2 as opposing pitchers in an exhibition game.; He's learning fastFrom the Associated Press: When Wayne Gretzky turned 30 last month, Los Angeles Kings owner Bruce McNall gave him a horse they saw being born while they were at the Kentucky Derby.Gretzky and McNall are partners in the racing business, so Gretzky gave half back to McNall."I kept the front half, because I have learned that is the one that crosses the finish line first," joked Gretzky.; For the record . . .- Canada's Helen Kelesi rallied from a 3-0 deficit in the third set to upset third-seeded Jana Novotna 2-6, 7-6, 7-6 in the second round of the Virginia Slims of Chicago tennis tournament. No. 2 seed Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria won her match against Ann Grossman.- Boris Becker beat Alexander Volkov 6-4, 3-6, 6-3 in the opening round of the Donnay Indoor Championship in Brussels, Belgium.- MaliVai Washington beat No. 16 seed Patrick McEnroe 6-0, 6-3 to advance to the quarterfinals of the $ 1 million U.S. Pro Indoor Tennis Championship in Philadelphia. (Complete tennis results, G9).- As many as 50 intramural male and female basketball teams from area colleges will meet in the Schick Super Hoops Regional Festival on Feb. 23 at Georgia State. The top male and female teams from the one-day tournament will play their championship games March 23 at The Omni as part of the Hawks-Miami game.Got a tip for Games & Faces? Give us a call on the message line at 222-2034.GRAPHIC:photo: Jim Valvano Lost a legend photo: Bo Jackson Charming forNike photo: Mark Calcavecchia Creative bookkeeping
email_title: GAMES & FACES; Bo knows just how to rock the media if he's on a roll

Email_Body: As the Summer Olympics draw to a close and nations around the world assess their stature in the medals table, the biggest winners emerging from this global extravaganza are not the athletes, their coaches or their governments, but their corporate sponsors.More than any other Olympic gathering in history, these Games have served as a glittering showcase for big business. Instead of praising parents or other inspirational role models behind their accomplishments, the athletes now regularly express gratitude and devotion to the corporate entities that pay them hefty endorsements.The emblems ofNikeor Reebok are as prominent as the national flag on many uniforms. Companies rather than national Olympic committees dictate the public appearances of athletes. The entire 900-member delegation of the former Soviet Union, attending the Games for the last time as the Unified Team, was underwritten by a $ 3.5 million grant from Smirnoff and adidas. "They made it possible for us to be here," said Alexander Kozlovsky, vice president of the Russian Olympic Committee.Once viewed as a grim contest between rival political systems, the Olympics began turning into a global commercial fair with the 1984 Games in Los Angeles. Instead of resorting to public funding, the Games were entirely financed by the private sector and turned a handsome profit of $ 230 million."The world is changing and we have to adapt to it," said Juan Antonio Samaranch, the monarchical chairman of the International Olympic Committee. "The Games might have come to an end if we did not bring commercial sponsors into the Games because cities and countries no longer can afford to stage them alone. The taxpayers will not stand for it."The collapse of communism in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe over the past three years removed the dichotomy of Cold War conflict from Olympic competition. In these Games, the Soviet athletes say they have been motivated to perform well chiefly by the need to attract corporate support in order to sustain their future athletic careers.For big business, marketing at the Olympics has become fierce competition. With more than 1 billion people watching the Games, the most desirable marketing goal for many companies is to see their brand name associated with the prestige and skills of the world's finest athletes. Country affiliation has dimmed.The ultimate high-stakes battle in these Games has pittedNikeagainst Reebok.Nikecommands the loyalties -- for a generous stipend -- of six members of the U.S. basketball team. For that reason, Michael Jordan and Charles Barkley, two ofNike'smost highly compensated endorsers, adamantly refuse to be seen in the U.S. team's Reebok-designed warmup suits at the medals ceremony. They will be allowed to unzip the jacket to block public view of the Reebok logo."In 1984, we had triple the number of athletes today," Steve Miller,Nike'sdirector of sports marketing, said in an interview. "But now you just can't afford to have them all. So we are trying to get the athletes who are best in their events who also have the best impact for us in the global market."When Mike Powell's hamstring was troubling him before the long jump competition, he missed a morning news conference called byNikeso he could get treatment. No problem. A call to gold-medal-winning triple jumper Mike Conley, who won his event the night before, quickly produced a substitute.Asked how he felt about appearing on such short notice, Conley said, "When they call, I go."Nikehas grown into a $ 3.5 billion-a-year business. More than two-thirds of its annual revenue comes from sales in the United States, but in the future the foreign sector is expected to grow dramatically. Thinking ahead,Nikeis now feverishly competing to recruit the allegiance of top athletes in growing markets. It issued an occasional newsletter (titled Swoosh) on its athletes, something no national Olympic Committee, aside from the USOC, did. It issued a slick magazine -- Barcelona '92 -- featuring its athletes.In Africa,Nikehas signed up the Kenyan runners Richard Chelimo, William Mutwol and Yobes Ondieki. Noureddine Morceli, the Algerian 1,500-meter champion, is considered a key wedge into a youth-oriented North African market.For Eastern Europe and the Commonwealth of Independent States,Nikehas invested a huge sum in Sergei Bubka, the Ukrainian world-record holder in the pole vault whose failure to win a medal in this year's Olympics could diminish his marketing appeal.Nikeis also looking toward China, whose 1.2 billion people may represent the biggest untapped market for high-class sporting goods in the world. Tong Li, the 110 hurdles star, has endorsedNike, and other top Chinese athletes may soon follow.Chelimo finished second in the men's 10,000 Monday night, then was awarded the gold medal on a judge's ruling of interference. On Tuesday the decision was reversed and Chelimo met the media to discuss it -- in a news conference set up byNike, not the IOC or the Kenyan delegation.Reebok has counteredNike'spush by signing up Olympic basketball coach Chuck Daly, U.S. runner Suzy Hamilton and German tennis star Michael Stich. Reebok's biggest promotional tie-in was sidetracked when Dan O'Brien (of the ubiquitous Dan and Dave commercials) failed to qualify for the U.S. decathlon team.Corporate officials acknowledge that the endorsements of gold-medal winners are no guarantee for commercial success. "It's always a gamble because you never know what will click," said Miller.GRAPHIC:PHOTO, BASKETBALL STARS MICHAEL JORDAN (LEFT) AND CHARLES BARKLEY SPEAK FIRST FORNIKE.
email_title: Corporations Bask In Reflected Glory;Business Benefactors Pervade Games

Email_Body: Rob Strasser predicts the future of feet.Strasser and partner Peter Moore helped createNike'sAir Jordan andNikeAir lines. Now Strasser lives in Herzogenaurach, Germany, as a marketing vice president for adidas. Together with Moore, working in the pair's Portland, Ore., marketing firm, Strasser says he's working to change adidas' image as a ''famous-but-boring brand.'' It's about time. Although Adi Dassler made his first gym shoe in 1920, adidas had a puny 4% share of the U.S. market last year - compared withNike's28% and Reebok's 21%.While those giants tweak each other with mild wisecracks in TV ads, Strasser helped create a new adidas Equipment brand that will be rolled out nationally by August with a back-to-basics pitch. One Equipment ad, for instance, says sports isn't about ''greed ... arrogance (or) fashion.''It's a pitch meant to attract baby boomers, many of whom are presumably becoming more sensible at the expense of their fashion sense. The shoemaker will rely on relatively low-key endorsers such as marathoner Grete Waitz. Laughs Strasser: ''The baby boomers are going to set the trends until the last one is dead.''Another underdog, Converse, is relying on a practical pitch: It has launched a new ad campaign with the tagline ''It's What's Inside that Counts''.But last night, adidas and Converse managed to score a conventional marketing coup in their uphill battle against the U.S. sneaker giants. Duke's basketball team wore adidas, Kansas wore Converse.CHEST MATCH: Sam Marion recalls it as ''a hell of an experience.''About 15 years ago, a player on a Little League team Marion managed was hit in the chest - and nearly died being rushed to the hospital.Marion didn't forget. After borrowing heavily, Marion's International Protective Athletic Safety Corp. of Fraser, Mich., developed a $ 70 kids' safety vest suitable for baseball and other sports.Marion's safety vest weighs 1.5 pounds and is made of compressed foam. They're available in about 50 stores so far.They're overdue. The Consumer Products Safety Commission reports 51 baseball-related deaths between 1974 and 1984, and at least 13 in 1989-90. Last Saturday, a 15-year-old New Hampshire hockey player died after being hit with a puck in the chest.Marion says he also has sold the Seattle Mariners on using his $ 80 adult safety jacket in practice. ''It won't be long,'' says ex-major leaguer Lary Sorensen, ''until you see most pro clubs using them.''BLOW OUT: Smokefree Educational Services, a health advocacy group, says it will include Little Leaguers as protesters in an opening day demonstration Monday against the Marlboro billboard in New York's Shea Stadium. The group is offering to pay the New York Mets to replace the cigarette marketer. ... Saying it wants to export U.S. traditions, the World League of American Football is starting a month-long scratch-off promotion sponsored by Kentucky Fried Chicken.
email_title: SPORTS BUSINESS;Marketing duo tries to undo adidas' 'boring' image

Email_Body: All members of the Dream Team will be there on the medal podium after all, apparently, if the Dream Team is fortunate enough to win medals.Another controversy has been resolved with the compromise that anyone (Michael Jordan) who has a personal corporate sponsor (Nike)who objects to the team sponsor's name (Reebok) showing on the standard-issue uniform (United States) has the right to obscure what he does not want to show (logo). "However," Dave Gavitt, president of USA Basketball, said in a statement after meeting with United States Olympic Committee officials, "in no instance will the uniforms be defaced or covered by any other material."So what does that mean?"They can turn down their collars to cover the logo," a U.S.O.C. staffer said. "But we can't say that."  Party Out of BoundsThe athletes' village may appear at first glance to be a peaceful splash of high rises beside the sea but it is turning into party central. Today, a spokesman at the village said he was calling in police to begin patrols, in response to complaints about late-night noise."It's the only way to control the situation," said Armando Calvo, who reported complaints from some residents about athletes being loud and drunken. "Sometimes they get into arguments with volunteers checking their credentials."El Mundo Deportivo, the Spanish sports daily, reports that the problem is largely centered on athletes who have already finished their competition. They play their music loud and return less than quietly from late parties."Maybe it's a mistake to give free housing; because of that, no one is leaving," said Li Gwang Sik, the North Korean bantamweight who defeated Serafim Todorov of Bulgaria on Monday to gain the boxing semifinals.But the boxer said he understood the urge to party. "They can't make us live a monk life," he told the paper. "We're free now."  How About Dan and Robert?Reebok doesn't have Dan and Dave in the decathlon, but it has Dave and Robert. That's Robert Zmelik of Czechoslovakia, who is a long shot to medal in the event but is welcome on Reebok's team anyway.  Tale of the Tape, and Ice PacksThe supplies are going fast for the American athletes here. Ed Ryan, head trainer for United States Olympic Committee operations at the athletes village, says American athletes have already used up 3,500 rolls of tape, 5,000 ice packs and 4,000 bandages, not to mention 1,200 disposable electric stimulation pads for use with ultrasound equipment. Ryan said there was nothing abnormal in the numbers. "We're finding dehydration is one of our biggest problems to date," he said. "The heat and humidity are creating havoc for our athletes." Used Syringes Found in VillageUsed syringes -- possibly for injecting vitamins -- have been found in the rooms of some athletes staying in the Olympic village."It appears the athletes are doing the injections themselves," said Prince Alexandre de Merode, chairman of the International Olympic Committee medical commission. De Merode said that housekeepers have been complaining about finding the syringes in wastebaskets. "I can't prejudge what they were used for," he said. "It could be nothing. It could be an innocent product like vitamins."But I believe this is dangerous," he said. "Athletes should be careful not to take any medication without consulting their medical doctor."Armando Calvo, director of the Olympic Village, said needles have been found "on a general basis" throughout the village, rather than in one area. He said the cleaning company had not specified the number of syringes.Jim Montgomery, head physician for the United States team, said it's not uncommon for athletes to take injections of vitamin B-12."I know for a fact that when countries came into the village, the Polyclinic ran out of B-12 and they had to get an extra supply," he said. "Everyone wanted some. A lot of our track and field guys have wanted shots."Montgomery said he doesn't hand out syringes or let the athletes administer the injections themselves."We have all our used syringes right here at the sports medicine center in the village," Montgomery said. "We give the shots ourselves."(AP)
email_title: BARCELONA: NOTEBOOK;Don't Like the Sponsor? Just Zip It

Email_Body: This began as another pinata job upon the brow of Deion Sanders, who continues to dismay even when he takes his days off. Amazing. He can't make practice with the Falcons because he's having a foot inspected by a team of doctors but can still be profiling that night courtside - said foot not even wrapped - when the Hawks bring Shaquille O'Neal to town. (Fashion tip: Time, my man, to stash the Huntz Hall wardrobe.)Worse, on the day most of the Braves take an opportunity to thank the city for another wild ride, Sanders is indisposed, vogueing in some crosstown gym for anotherNikead. This borders on civic insult. Whatever was done this month to mythicize his athletic abilities, Sanders did residual damage to his local image simultaneously, the McCarver water business a dubious quinella with theNikeair circus. To appear publicly with the Braves would be a hint at contrition, never a Sanders long suit. Perhaps one day, the blessed athlete will realize his life is something more than one long punt return.But the deeper one considers the plight of Deion Sanders, one keeps bumping his head up against a shoe company with its tongs so deep into the back of America's No. 1 cornerback/outfielder.Nikehas grown proficient at this, for its tongs seem to reach everyone everywhere.Ross Perot tells the American electorate to Just Do It. The world comes to Barcelona to find five stories of Michael Jordan - and the boomerang logo - hanging from a building downtown. Morehouse's football team needs new shoes; alum Spike Lee's endorsement comes through, 120 pairs strong. Georgia Tech's basketball team to France?Nikeponies up $ 100,000.In court as well as on courtNaturally, a company so keen on its inflated ownself can't help but periodically make a mess. Who on earth butNikewas able to pit John Thompson against the Rev. Jesse Jackson? Kids kill kids and take their $ 170 sneakers. The company is now in a snit over Jordan's appearance in a Hanes underwear commercial, fretting over His Airness's impugned image, the same image that helped sell $ 200 million of Air Jordan gear last year alone.Alas. But if there is no altruism left in peddling athletic footwear - what happened to the singular promise of "run faster, jump higher?" - there surely is no accounting for howNikehandles its front men. The company was all too happy to provide the private jet for the Miami- Pittsburgh shuttle that puckered Sanders's relationship with Braves brass. And who scheduled Tuesday's ad shoot so who couldn't be where?In Sanders,Nikehas hooked a kid with a sublime weakness for money, and should anyone think Sanders can't keep this up, their $ 3 million deal is slashed 90 percent should Sanders stop splitting time between baseball and football. Though this leans toward indentured servitude, Sanders views the deal as the underpining to his portfolio, barking at reporters during the NLCS, "I don't need no publicity. My contract withNikeis set."The Mourning after for CharlotteTell the Charlotte Hornets. Latest to roll off the Georgetown-Nikeassembly line, Alonzo Mourning was chosen second in the last draft by Charlotte, which is now attempting to sign the rookie who already has a $ 16 millionNikecontract in his pocket. Mourning demands a $ 2.6 million starting salary. The Hornets have but $ 1.96 million available under the salary cap. An Auerbachian nightmare, the rook has all the leverage. So untenable is Charlotte's position, at least five NBA scouts watched the team's last exhibition in readiness for the inevitable fire sale.This is how shoes are sold in America. As ifNikewas actually ever a shoe company. The Oregon firm merely designs and markets the models, all manufacturing doled out to sweatshops in Thailand, China and Taiwan. And for all the marketing, all the Bo and Prime Time and Just Doing It, an Athletic Footwear Association survey found only 12 percent of the 18- to-75 age group affected by celebrity endorsements.Deion's world view is stilted enough. There's something else happening here. It's gotta be the shoes.
email_title: Bad image for Sanders? It's gotta be the shoes

Email_Body: DAVID CLARKSON has countered rumors about his commitment to Sunshine George Cross by grabbing a share of the lead in the Herald-SunNikeAir Golden Boot award.Clarkson, man of the match in the past two rounds, earned the player of the week title for his display against Wollongong Mac.The three votes gives him 17 and equal leadership with St George keeper John Filan. "I had gone for five weeks without picking up votes so it's nice to get some reward for playing well," Clarkson said yesterday.The midfielder returned to Melbourne yesterday after making a hurried dash across the Tasman to see his sick sister in Hobart.Clarkson was a committed supporter of previous Sunshine coach Ernie Merrick, who brought him to the club from Adelaide City.There were suggestions that Clarkson and teammate Craig Foster would walk out of the club after Merrick's dismissal but the player has killed off those rumors with his good form."I certainly didn't like the way Ernie was sacked but it's good to have Tony Vrzina around and it's very important for all the players to stick by the new coach," Clarkson said.Clarkson admitted that desperation had played a part in his recent good form."All of us are playing for our survival as well as the club's," he said."I certainly hope the club won't be relegated but either way we have to try and lift ourselves and play better."If the worst was to happen and the club was relegated, the players will be judged on their performances if they are to get another club." As the weekly winner, Clarkson receives a pair ofNikeAir runners valued at $280. The end of season winner receives $2000 in cash fromNike.Herald-SunNikeAir Golden Boot Award: Round 19 votes:. Adel City v Apia: 2 Maxwell (ac), 1 Csoboth (ac), 1 McFadden (al), 1 Maloney (al), 1 Zabica (ac).Melb Cro v Woll Cty: 3 Pezzano (wc), 2 Biskic (mc), 1 Talajich (mc). Marc v St Geo: 2 Harper (stg), 2 P.Okon (m), 1 O'Shea (stg), 1 Catlin (m). Melita v Preston M: 3 Trajanovski (pm), 2 Bekiaris (pm), 1 Tasevski (pm). Sth Melb v Syd Cro: 3 Kupresak (scr), 2 Franken (scr), 1 Tasios (sm). Syd Oly v Heid: 3 Saad (so), 2 Edwards (so), 1 Phillips (so). Woll Mac v Sunshine: 3 Clarkson (sgc), 2 Hunter (sgc), 1 Naumov (wm). Leaders: 17 Clarkson, Filan. 16 P.Okon. 15 Petersen.13 Bundalo, Petkovic. 12 Stubbins. 11 Biskic, Franken, Jackson, Kindtner, Kuc, Lowe, McCulloch. Phillips, Tsolakis.END OF STORY
email_title: Clarkson answers all the critics

Email_Body: A clash between U.S. Customs Commissioner Carol B. Hallett and Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., contributed to blocking Mrs. Hallett's bid to be the next transportation secretary, industry and administration sources said Thursday.Until Wednesday, when President Bush nominated Andrew H. Card for the post, Mrs. Hallett was considered the front-runner for it. But the Bush administration shifted gears after being notified by Sen. Packwood that he asn't happy with the choice, those sources said. "He had concerns, and he communicated them to the White House," according to an administration source.Sources said Sen. Packwood and Mrs. Hallett crossed swords over the issue of fees assessed toNikeInc., the Oregon-based footwear manufacturer. In particular, sources said, Sen. Packwood asked Mrs. Hallett to reverse a 1991 agency ruling adverse toNike. Her refusal to do so led to an angry exchange between the two, sources said."She didn't bend to Packwood, and he became furious," said an industry executive close to Customs. The executive said the senator has often interceded onNike'sbehalf in disputes with Customs.Sen. Packwood sits on the Senate Commerce Committee, which is responsible for confirming Department of Transportation nominees.Sen. Packwood denied reports that he sent a letter to the president advising him not to nominate Ms. Hallett, but declined to answer other questions about her. "I'm not going to stir up those waters now," he said.Customs officials were unavailable for comment.Grant Hanson, aNikelobbyist, said the company imports millions of pairs of shoes each year and inevitably runs into conflicts with Customs over various issues. "I'm not sure if this was over a particular incident or if it might have been something brewing over a period of time," he said.The choice of Mr. Card, who is currently deputy White House chief of staff, is being seen by some as a victory for Drew Lewis, Union Pacific Corp. chairman. Mr. Lewis lobbied for Mr. Card to win the DOT post, and had supported an effort to make him president of the Association of American Railroads.It is unclear how much influence, if any, Mr. Lewis had in swaying President Bush. But he told securities analysts in New York Wednesday that Mr. Card's close ties to the president and his good working relationship with his predecessor, White House Chief of Staff Samuel K. Skinner, "means that transportation remains on the front burner for the administration."
email_title: CLASH REPORTEDLY HURT HALLETT'S DOT DRIVE

Email_Body: Nikebroke off its sponsorship deal with Katrin Krabbe, the world sprint champion from Germany who's awaiting a four-year ban for failing a drug test. The sportswear company also abandoned a similar deal with Grit Breuer, Krabbe's teammate who also tested positive for a banned substance. "Every contract includes a clause that athletes are forbidden from taking performance-enhancing substances," said aNikerepresentative. Krabbe, the 100- and 200-meter world champion, and Breuer, the world silver medalist at 400 meters, tested positive for Clenbuterol, a muscle-building substance. Krabbe, 22, in an interview published Wednesday by the Super Illu magazine, said the athletes did not know that Clenbuterol was on the list of banned drugs. "I never consciously did anything that was forbidden," she told the magazine. "I am sorry if many fans are now disappointed in me." Thomas Springstein, coach of the two athletes, has admitted giving the drug to the two sprinters and his contract withNikealso has been canceled. The German Athletics Federation has suspended the two pending a hearing that is expected to impose the bans.      NBA: A day after announcing his retirement, Larry Bird was home in Indiana preparing to host a charity golf tournament. "You'll never see me at NBA games unless I'm there to work," said Bird, who will remain with the Boston Celtics as a special assistant. "I have no intentions to go on NBC (TV) and help them do games." Bird also said he doesn't want to get into coaching. On other news, the San Antonio Spurs signed free-agent guard Matt Othick of Arizona. The Chicago Bulls signed second-round draft pick Corey Williams of Oklahoma State to a multiyear contract. Terms were not disclosed; the Clippers signed free agent Charles Smith.     GOLF: Tarpon Spring's Jay Overton led the North Florida PG Section Championship for the second day in a row after shooting a 7-under-par 65 at Bonnet Creek Golf Club in Orlando. Overton, the head pro at the Innisbrook Resort, is 18 under for 36 holes and takes a five-stroke advantage into the final round today. Mike Domalske of Sarasota shot 63 to move into second at 131.     TRACK AND FIELD: Carl Lewis, who failed to make the U.S.  Olympic team in the 100 meters, proved he is still a major force in sprinting by beating a world-class field at a meet in Zurich, Switzerland. Lewis, 31, powered through the final 30 yards and finished in 10.07 seconds, beating a field that included six finalists at Barcelona. Olympic champion Linford Christie of Britain had declined to take on Lewis at the meet.     COLLEGE BASEBALL: Joey Arnold, who had a .360 batting average for Santa Fe Community College in Gainesville last season, is transferring to the University of Florida to play for his father, Gators coach Joe Arnold. Joey, a 6-foot-1, 180-pound shortstop, graduated from Gainesville High in 1990.     BOWLING: Greg Kemp regained the lead after five rounds of the PBA's ABC West Lanes Open in Mechanicsburg, Pa. Kemp averaged 244 his first three games on the way to an 8,175 total. Jim Pencak averaged 241 his last eight games to move into second at 8,057. In other bowling, John Handegard had a pair of 268 games to take a 47-pin lead in the Lansing (Mich.) Senior Open.     BOWLING: Bob Vespi averaged 243 in his last eight games to jump from third to first and will be the top seed for today's finals of the PBA ABC West Lanes Open in Mechanicsburg, Pa. Barry Gurney, a first-year pro, won his first title by defeating Tommy Evans 243-166 for the championship of the Lansing (Mich.) PBA Senior Open. Stacy Rider and Anne Marie Duggan became the first repeat winners of the LPBT's National Doubles Tournament.     MISCELLANY: Mildred "Millie" Schembechler, wife of former Michigan football coach and former Detroit Tigers president Bo Schembechler, died of cancer in Ann Arbor, Mich. She was 63.  Compiled by Pete Couture.
email_title: Nikebreaks off sponsorship deal with German sprinter Krabbe

Email_Body: In a compromise move, Michael Jordan's face will not appear on t-shirts featuring the U.S. Olympic basketball team, and instead,NikeCorp., which owns the rights to Jordan's likeness on apparel, will pay a financial settlement to USA Basketball, which is sponsoring the U.S. Olympic team. The NBA had threatened to ban players from the U.S. team who would not allow their likenesses to appear on USA basketball apparel.  Jordan sold the rights to use his likeness toNike, and Nikerefused to relinquish those rights.  Jordan's likeness was also missing from NBA All-Star Game t-shirts.
email_title: Jordan's Face Absent From Olympic Apparel

Email_Body: Michael Jordan has told the National Basketball Association it may nolonger sell apparel bearing his image, givingNikeInc. those rightsexclusively. The move, unprecedented in the NBA, means millions ofdollars. Jordan, 28, of the Chicago Bulls, is among the most charismatic,and profitable, personalities in the league.Niketakes in about $200-million a year on Jordan's image.
email_title: SPORT IN BRIEFNikeowns Jordan

Email_Body: NIKEsaid its worldwide orders for athletic footwear and apparel scheduled for delivery between December and April totalled $1.6 billion, 18 per cent higher than the same period last year.Second-quarter earnings to November 30 totalling $76 million, or $0.98 per share ($61.5 million or $0.80 per share).Nikesaid its total international sales grew 30 per cent to a record $372.9 million and represented 43 per cent of second quarter revenues, compared to 39 per cent in the same period last year.
email_title: Nikeorders run ahead

Email_Body: The National Football League and the San Diego Chargers will conduct a free clinic for over 400 area youth at the University of California at San Diego, Saturday July 13 at 1:00 p.m. This event is the 26th in a series of 27 throughout the League this spring/summer.  The camps are sponsored by Pro Set, manufacturer of the Official NFL Trading Card, andNike.The "NFL Pro Set Mini Camp for Kids" sponsored byNikewill feature 11 San Diego Chargers players including running back/tight end Rod Bernstine, running back Ronnie Harmon and quarterback John Friesz. The players will stress the importance of staying in school, and deliver impactful motivation messages on striving for individual excellence.  On the Chargers' training camp practice field, the players will demonstrate football skills and techniques of game preparation, fitness and nutrition."Mini Camp" participants have been selected through the United Way and Boys and Girls Clubs of San Diego to provide this opportunity for those who would benefit most from the program.Local sponsors include radio station XTRA and Domino's Pizza who will provide free lunch to all camp participants.The public is invited to attend the clinic as spectators at no charge.
email_title: NFL PRO SET &NIKESPONSOR SAN DIEGO CHARGERS "MINI CAMP" SATURDAY, JULY 13

Email_Body: MADRID, Spain:NikeIncorporated, which paid millions of dollars to put its name on the United States athletic team's uniforms at the Barcelona Olympics, is appealing a high court decision that bars the advertising or sale of its apparel in Spain.Spain's Constitutional Court last week prohibited the sports apparel company from using theNikename on clothing because a Barcelona firm registered the trademark first in 1932.If further legal action fails the firm stands to lose $US20 million ($A26.93 million) in sales in Spain alone and many times that sum worldwide.
email_title: Games ban onNike

Email_Body: WHAT started as a quick cigarette outside a party ended up as a harrowing five-hour rape ordeal on a nearby council estate for a 17-year-old girl, detectives revealed today.Her fashionably-dressed young attacker raped her three times after she braved a group of would-be gatecrashers outside the party in Heath Road, Battersea, for a quiet smoke in the street.The attack lasted until dawn. Detectives today descibed it as particularly savage and said the girl was 'severely traumatised'. The rape took place nearly a month ago, but police have only now been persuaded to publicise the ordeal in the hope that possible witnesses will come forward.The girl was attacked shortly after 1.30am on Sunday 10 May. The rapist wore a pair of £100NikeAirMax trainers and a gold ring with the wordNikeon his left hand.'We were told that this ring was quite unusual, and hoped that inquiries with the supplier might have led us to the attacker,' said acting Detective Segeant Mark Woolner, leading the investigation.'Unfortunately that lead didn't take us as far as we hoped, and we are now appealing for witnesses.'A spokesman added: 'There was a large group of would-be gatecrashers outside, and she walked down the street to avoid them and have a cigarette.'She was approached by a youth aged between 16 and 19 who struck up a conversation about how to get into the party. Then the girl turned and walked away, intending to go to a friend's house.'But the youth followed her towards Dansworth Road and as far as a council block, Sharp House, nearby.'She carried on, thinking he had walked away. Suddenly she felt cold metal against her neck, and behind her was the youth saying he had a knife.'There followed a harrowing ordeal, as the attacker dragged the girl first to the rear of the Hope pub - where he was disturbed by a barking dog - then to bushes outside nearby Shore House and then to a third-floor landing in Sharp House.'In all she was raped three times over five hours,' said the spokesman.'It was getting light by the time she was able to run away - but only after he had robbed her of just over £1. All the time she was terrified to cry out, believing that she might be killed.'She said the rapist was about 5ft 7in tall, of proportionate build, dark skinned with conventionally-cut afro hair, gelled down.He was wearing a red, white and blue cotton scarf, heavy sky-blue tee-shirt, tan bomber jacket and faded baggy blue cord trousers.'This was an entirely opportunistic attack on a defenceless young girl, and there is a serious danger that this person might strike again,' said DS Woolner.'We would appeal to anyone who might have seen something, or who recognises him or his ring to contact us at Battersea on 071 350 1122.'
email_title: Party girl held till dawn by designer gear rapist

Email_Body: A day away from opening a season that could test the talents of coach Bob Weiss's magic act, the Atlanta Hawks held their annual tipoff luncheon Wednesday at the Omni Hotel. The highlights: General manager Pete Babcock made reference to Dominique Wilkins having gotten married during the off-season, glanced at his star player's table and said, "You are still married, aren't you?" . . . Bob Houghton, new general manager for WGST, which broadcasts Hawks games, called Weiss "a boyhood idol of mine." (They looked to be about the same age). . . . Emcee Steve Holman joked with Wilkins, contending that the player has slowed down quite a bit since his recent marriage to Nicole Berry. "She calls their water bed," said Holman, "the Dead Sea." . . . Weiss said he's developed quite a reputation as a luncheon speaker, but admitted, "It's just because I get to follow Steve." . . . Rick Shaw, who produced Braves broadcasts for WGST last year - Braves and Georgia football for WSB before that - has been named executive sports producer by the station. . . . New Hawk Mookie Blaylock, who attended Wednesday after the trade that sent Rumeal Robinson to the New Jersey Nets, must have felt flattered. How many teams rent a hotel ballroom and hold a luncheon for a player the day he arrives in town? . . . Weiss was honorary bartender and did a few of his magic tricks Wednesday night at T.G.I. Friday's at the Prado for the "International Bartender Championships" to benefit the Atlanta Cities in Schools program. . . . The bad news is that New England Patriots coach Dick MacPherson has been hospitalized for acute diverticulitis. The good news is that for 2-4 weeks he won't have to look at his 0-8 team. . . . Baltimore Orioles first baseman Glenn Davis of Columbus, Ga., is holding his Baseballfest golf tournament Friday at Orchard Hills Golf Club in Newnan to benefit the Carpenter's Way Ranch, a Christian home for abused and neglected children. Among those expected to attend are Braves David Justice and John Smoltz, Braves coach Clarence Jones, Wally Joyner of Kansas City and former Oakland A's pitcher Vida Blue.He's making a list and checking it twiceIs itNikeor hokey? Deion Sanders filmed yet another commercial forNikeWednesday at the Riverwood Studios outside of Atlanta, featuring five of his Falcons teammates as Christmas elves. Mike Gann, Tim Green, Darion Conner, Jamie Dukes and Houston Hoover were cast as Deion's little helpers. The star's part was as, uh, "Sander Claus." As you'll see in the commercial, which is to be aired nationwide during the Christmas season, the elves will be tending toNikeboxes going through Sander Claus's factory. Eat your heart out, Bo Jackson. . . . Apparently, nobody was more disappointed than Billy Ray Cyrus over his being unable to sing the national anthem at last Sunday's Falcons-Rams game at the Georgia Dome. Cyrus, who didn't get to bed until 4 a.m. Sunday morning after two concerts Saturday night at Lanierland, wanted to sing despite an overstressed throat but was advised not to by his manager. Cyrus had just stepped out of the shower at about kickoff Sunday and was distressed to hear TV announcers referring to him as a no-show. Cyrus, who would have received no pay for the performance, has told the Falcons he'll sing at a later date as soon as possible and will pay his own expenses.Photo: Mug sh ot of Bob Weiss
email_title: GLENN SHEELEY'S SPORTSCENE Wilkins gets a ribbing at Hawks tipoff lunch

Email_Body: SEATTLE (Reuter) - A Seattle-based oceanographer believes that 80,000Nikeshoes will help explain the mysteries of trans-Pacific migration, the spread of oil spills and where bodies lost at sea will wash ashore.The researcher, Curtis Ebbesmeyer, has been studying the path of the drifting sneakers and sport shoes to learn more about how ocean currents work.The shoes - with a retail value of about $2.5 million - were accidentally dumped at sea in the Pacific Ocean by a freighter nearly 18 months ago and around 2,000 have washed ashore on West Coast beaches from Oregon to British Columbia. "He's had a lot of interest in theseNikes,where they fell in and where they drifted," said Shannon Flotre, a colleague at Evans-Hamilton Inc., a Seattle-area oceanography firm in which Ebbesmeyer is a co-owner and oceanographer.Ebbesmeyer, who was not available for comment on his study, is a specialist on Puget Sound who also has expertise in statistics of drifting objects and keeps records on drifting portions of shipwrecks, icebergs and other matter.The data may help explain migration and anthropology of Pacific Island peoples and is frequently used in oil spill research and even in locating bodies lost overboard.The May, 1990, accident created the largest single drop of man-made drift objects in the North Pacific, surpassing 20,000 drift bottles dumped in the Pacific during the 1950s by a Canadian government research project.Rich Hastings, transport manager at Beaverton, Ore.-basedNikeInc., said the cargo was bound for Seattle from Korea and apparently was lost about 600 miles due south of Anchorage, Alaska."We do have an air cushioning system - some of the shoes had compressed air, which helped them float," Hastings said. "I'm glad it can be at least some benefit. It's not littering the beaches because they're picked up as soon as they land."
email_title: DriftingNikeshelp ocean research

Email_Body: The Kids & Kubs softball team and its living legend, centenarian George Bakewell, will be featured in aNikecommercial, airing for the first time tonight during the All-Star Game.     Bakewell turned 100 in April, having finished his record 24th season with the famous St. Petersburg-based club. Kids & Kubs players must be 75 or older.     In the commercial, there will be a close-up of Bakewell and a mention of the fact that, if Babe Ruth still were alive, Bakewell still would be three years older than the Babe, according toNikespokesman Dusty Kidd.     "It's a look at the team and how they typify the fact that older folks can stay active in sports," said Kidd, who added that the commercial will run for up to three months.KEVIN THOMAS
email_title: Kids & Kubs' Bakewell getsNiketreatment

Email_Body: ''Sometimes we've wondered if we're a solution in search of a problem,'' says Jim Gallagher, marketing manager for Airborne Research Associates of Waltham, Mass. ''But now we're getting lots of calls.''That attention came after a U.S. Open spectator was killed by lightning Thursday. ARA markets $ 395 M-10 Optical Lightning Detectors, a radar and camera system the size of a Walkman that is billed as more effective than lightning detectors on airplanes. Pro golf officials and about 200 golf course pros already use the device, says Gallagher. The company hopes to expand to other outdoor sports - especially boating. Developed by ARA president and ex-MIT physicist Ralph Markson, the device detects ''intracloud lightning'' invisible to the human eye, to sense lightning 20 minutes away. Sometimes, says Gallagher, the device finds that ''threatening-looking clouds aren't really threatening.''TRACK STAR: Publicly held Churchill Downs Inc. will ask stockholders on June 20 to allow its over-the-counter stock shares to increase from 1 million to as many as 10 million. The idea is to prevent any takeover bid and to provide funding for expansion. ... The Winter Baseball League, hoping to launch a six-team Florida league in November, says it will try to sign minor league players in major league baseball organizations. The WBL, whose commissioner is ex-major leaguer Bobby Bonds, has $ 105,000 team salary caps. ... SinceNike's NikeTown company store draws about 5,000 browsers each Saturday, says spokeswoman Liz Dolan, aNikeTown will open in Chicago in May. Another possible site: Berlin. ... Six original National Hockey League teams will wear ''classic'' sweaters in openers next season, partly to hype a new NHL line of old-time league clothing. ... Major League Baseball says undercover Toronto police will search for souvenir counterfeiters before the July 9 All-Star game. Maximum penalty: up to five years in prison. ... Need to phone or fax any sports group? The new Sports Address Bible has 7,500 listings. Call 213-395-6533.HEY, YOGI! National parks generate about $ 500 million annually in concession revenues. Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., thinks Uncle Sam deserves a bigger share. With 41 concession contracts expiring this year, Synar proposed a bill to give the U.S. government 22.5% of gross concession revenues, up from the current 2.5%. ... Among all sports activities, stair-climbing has had the biggest growth in ''frequent'' participants: a 500% jump to 1.8 million in three years. ... Advance Sports Concepts of Columbus, Ohio, says seven NBA teams now use its $ 80 Big Ball, a practice ball two inches wider than regulation.
email_title: U.S. Open puts lightning detectors in demand

Email_Body: Chrysler Corp. may sell a majority stake in its profitable financial services subsidiary, hoping to distance the unit from the automaker's financial troubles.Sale of a controlling interest would represent a change of heart by Chrysler, which late last year said it might sell only a minority interest in Chrysler Financial Corp., in an effort to boost the unit's credit rating and expand its access to cheaper financing. Chrysler yesterday gave no indication of what it is asking for the unit, but the finance arm reportedly carries a book value of about $ 2.5 billion.Nike'sprofit upNikeInc., the largest U.S. marketer of athletic shoes, yesterday reported third-quarter earnings jumped 12 per cent but the performance disappointed Wall Street andNike'sstock price tumbled.The sneaker maker - whose earnings were restrained by advertising and interest costs - earned $ 70.7 million (U.S.) in the quarter ended Feb. 28, or 93 cents a share, up from $ 63.1 million, or 83 cents a share, a year earlier.Separately, the once high-flying sneaker maker L.A. Gear Inc. said it has reached agreement with its banks to restructure loan agreements.WIRE AGENCIES
email_title: Chrysler may sell controlling stake in financial unit
