Email_Body: A CHANGED CHARLES: No sooner did Charles Barkley leave Philadelphia than he develops a new -- well, sort of new -- image, courtesy ofNikeshoes.In his latest commercial forNike,the new Phoenix Sun does an autobiographical rap about his fabled brawls, his spitting, the many times he's been fined, his success as a basketball player, his anti-hero reputation and even plugs his recent book, as well asNike'ssneakers. And all this in 60 seconds.He is really "Charming Charles." As he put it in the ad: "The pocket says it pays to be mean. Excuse me, but don't I have the cutest smile you've ever seen?"HARPER WANTS TRADE: Mavericks guard Derek Harper has asked the team to deal him to one of four or five teams before next season, his agent George Andrews says.Two of the teams reportedly on Harper's list are the Knicks, who acquired former Dallas teammate Rolando Blackman earlier this summer, and the Bulls.
email_title: AROUND THE NBA

Email_Body: PENTLAND, the British sports-goods firm, is set to negotiate a lucrative contractto arrange the to manufacture of Adidas sportswear products in the Far East following its move to buy a 20% stake in the German giant from Bernard Tapie.The deal could revitalise the fortunes of Adidas and enable it to catch up recover some of the ground that has been lost to its two American arch-rivals, Reebok andNike.Further, Paris financiers expect Pentland's Pounds 47m Adidas investment to lead to it taking control of Adidas next summer when Tapie faces his next financial crunch. In the meantime Pentland, famous for its role in which made its mark pushing Reebok to the top of the sports footwear league table, will focus its efforts on securing a lucrative sourcing contract in the Far East with Adidas.It hopes the contract will mirror the long-term deal with Reebok that played a key role in the footwear company's ''miracle turnround'' in the 1980s, when it caught up withNikeearning Pentland Pounds 6m profit last year.Adidas lost out in the cut-throat battle with Reebok andNikeas because it was slow to follow them into the Far East. Today 85% of the West German giant's shoes are made in the Far East but Pentland's expertise in this area should be able to cut costs further.For Pentland, whose brands include Pony and Speedo, the attraction is that net margins at Adidas are only one and a half percent 112% compared with 10% atNikeand Reebok. If they can sort out the Adidas sourcing, profits at Adidas could explode from the current Pounds 19m.Reebok's decision to terminate the sourcing contract with Pentland was a key factor that persuaded the British firm to sell part of its stake for Pounds 200m. Today with Reebok shares riding high at $32, Pentland may soon sell its remaining 13% stake, which is worth another Pounds 222m.The sourcing contract is the icing on the cake but Pentland does not hide its ambition to own Adidas. The chance could come next summer when Tapie will have to must find another Pounds 160m to finance the second part of the Adidas purchase.
email_title: Pentland races for Adidas deal

Email_Body: AMID controversy and angst,Nike, the winged Greek goddess of victory, was hoisted back to the top of the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin yesterday in preparation for the monument's 200th birthday celebrations on August 6.Almost destroyed a year and a half ago by joyful souvenir hunters on the first New Year's Eve after the Berlin Wall came down,Nikeand her four horses have spent the past 15 months having a Pounds 100,000 renovation to protect her from vandals and the environment.More than a thousand people turned out yesterday to watch as a crane lowered the copper statue and her chariot on to the 60ft high gate. Typically for modern Germany, however, the return of the goddess has provoked a profound argument about what she ought to symbolise. When she was locked away behind the wall staring eastwards down Unter den Linden at the decaying communist state, the triumphalism she once represented did not matter. In a united country, however,Nike'sreturn with Iron Cross and Prussian eagle on her staff, has created worries that she will give the wrong message to the world about German ambitions for the future. Helmut Kohl, the chancellor, has also run into criticism over his plan, announced yesterday, to attend the ceremony taking place in Potsdam on August 17, when the remains of Frederick the Great of Prussia are to be moved. Frau Herta Daubler-Gmelin, deputy chairman of the opposition Social Democrats complained that this would rouse mistrust in Germany's neighbours.Similar arguments are being roused by the statue ofNike. Two hundred years ago she was designed by Johann Schadow, court sculptor to King Friedrich Wilhelm II of Prussia, to represent Irene, the goddess of peace. Napoleon changed all that. When he arrived in the city fresh from his triumph at Jena in 1806 he liked the look of the statue and decided to pack it up and send it back to Paris as part of his booty. The goddess lived in exile for eight years until Field Marshall Blucher secured her release in 1814 after Napoleon's first defeat.She returned in triumph, not as Irene but asNike, complete with cross, oak leaves, and eagle. As such she presided over the victory parades of the Prussians, the German Empire and the Third Reich. In 1945, however, the gate and the statue were badly damaged in the battle for the city.Using the scrap and pictures as a model the East German government managed to copy and replace the statue in 1958 without the victory symbols, carefully describing her in the official guidebooks as ''the peace goddess''. Now Friedbert Pfluger, a Christian Democrat Bundestag member from the west German state of Lower Saxony, has started a protest movement about the symbols of victory on her staff.
email_title: Goddess returns in triumph

Email_Body: One of the most influential characters in basketball is a pudgy former high school coach who counts John Thompson and Jerry Tarkanian among his close friends.John Paul "Sonny" Vaccaro has been ranked one of the 100 most powerful people in sports by The Sporting News. He's No. 80, right behind Michael Jordan.Without question, Vaccaro, 52, is the greatest sneaker salesman in America. He isNike'sconduit to the big-name college coaches and marquee programs such as Georgetown and Syracuse, signing coaches to six-figure contracts, some in the neighborhood of $ 200,000, for the favor of outfitting their teams inNikegear. Nikehosts summer camps showcasing the country's finest high school players, with all invitees approved by Vaccaro.Nikesponsors the Dapper Dan Roundball Classic, the granddaddy of national high school all-star games, which Vaccaro started in Pittsburgh in 1965.But critics have trashed Vaccaro for allegedly directing top recruits to college coaches under contract toNike. NCAA investigators, in general, are leery of his cozy relationship with both players and coaches.Now, in the wake of the NBA draft, Vaccaro is under attack from agents who claim he is cutting into their business. Vaccaro, although not involved in contract negotiations, has a hand in the marketing of several first-round picks - including Billy Owens, Dikembe Mutombo and Stacey Augmon, and he is negotiating with Larry Johnson, the No. 1 pick in the draft.All of the draft picks played at college programs under contract to Nike."Everything is an angle," said agent Ron Grinker, who represents Danny Manning, the first pick in the 1988 draft. "I deal with him for players on shoe contracts . But now, I have to worry about him talking to players. He can go on any college campus where he has college coaches under contract and talk to every player. It's a scenario that is not very tasteful to me."Charles Grantham, executive director of the NBA Players Association, said he has been assured by Vaccaro that he will not be involved in negotiating player contracts. The NBA players union has no jurisdiction over endorsements.Vaccaro andNikeofficials deny any potential conflict, saying his latest business venture is independent of the athletic wear company. Vaccaro describes himself as a consultant for DIC Marketing, a Burbank, Calif., firm that has secured agreements to represent the players."I am the conduit, the go-between," Vaccaro said. "They approached me a year ago and said they wanted to get involved with athletes. They knew I've been around athletes all my life."Vaccaro said he screened agents for some of the players, further raising the ire of those who couldn't get interviews. He also negotiated deals for trading cards on behalf of several players - among them Augmon, Owens, Mutombo, Greg Anthony, Anderson Hunt and George Ackles.Several agents accused Vaccaro of directing Augmon, the Atlanta Hawks' top draft choice, and Owens to player representative Arn Tellem. Vaccaro and Tellem, however, deny they have a business relationship."A couple of the agents I've heard from believe Sonny locked them out of a chance to get these guys," said Fred Schreyer,Nike'sdirector of sports marketing. "I don't believe that's the case. The few players he is advising are kids he has been close to for a long time."Magic Johnson's agent, Lon Rosen, said the only way to get to Augmon was through Vaccaro. He never met the player."I've been with Sonny for five years and I trust him," said Augmon. "He's theNikeguy and he's been around our program. I met him in high school at the Dapper Dan, and I've been keeping close to him because he lives in the L.A. area. We go out to dinner. I know his wife."By conservative estimates, Vaccaro has signed more than 60 major college coaches - among them Bobby Cremins of Georgia Tech and Hugh Durham of Georgia - to contracts withNike, along with more than 25 of the country's most influential high school coaches.The money Vaccaro can put in coaches' pockets has elevated him to the position of power broker. In some instances, college coaches find themselves earning more in "shoe money" than is paid them by their respective universities."Sonny, by his reputation, is a controversial guy," said David Falk of ProServ. "He's got lots of contacts and can bring something to the party. I don't think that's all bad, but I think it threatens a lot of people. They feel he may have an advantage through his contacts and may be able to do things for players they're not able to do."Publicly, Falk is reluctant to criticize Vaccaro's dealings. Thompson, the Georgetown coach, is friends of both, and several of his former players are represented by Falk. But even Vaccaro acknowledges that Falk is upset that while his agency is negotiating the contract for Mutombo, Georgetown's latest star, Vaccaro will be responsible for the marketing and endorsements."This is the first time ProServ has lost a player to a marketing situation," said Vaccaro, who previously tried his hand as a gambler and rock 'n' roll concert promoter. "They sort of pride themselves on what they've done with Michael Jordan , so they're upset about Mutombo. It's the first time an outsider, so to speak, has entered their domain."I don't do anything illegal with any of these kids. I know probably all the kids. If they're worried about that, they ought to pray I don't become an agent."
email_title: Nike'sVaccaro a conduit to coaches and players

Email_Body: Barcelona - The crisis over the Dream Team's raiment for the inevitable gold medal ceremony was resolved Tuesday, avoiding a potentially embarrassing situation for the U.S. Olympic Team and further annoyance to the rest of the Olympic community.Some Dream Teamers - many of whom are under contract toNike- had indicated they would not participate in the ceremony if they had to comply with U.S. Olympic Committee (USOC) demands that they wear the official U.S. uniform, which is produced byNike'sarchrival Reebok.But the compromise leaves the players free to hide the word "Reebok," which appears on the right side of the uniform's jacket, simply by leaving it unzipped and thus folded over the name. "In the event the men's basketball team wins a medal, all members will appear on the medal platform in the uniform issued by the U.S. Olympic Committee," David Gavitt, president of USA Basketball said after meeting with USOC officials. "Some players may chose to wear the awards suit in a manner that does not reveal any commercial identification. However, in no instance will the uniform be defaced or covered by any other material."Despite the resolution, Olympic officials are becoming increasingly tired of the disruption the Dream Team has brought to the Games. "There's a limit on being able to behave like a rock star," said Richard Pound, an International Olympic Committee (IOC) vice president."They're not coachable, approachable or governable by the USOC," Pound said. "At the end of all this, there will be some careful assessment of this experience."He said it might be wise to limit the number of NBA players or eliminate them altogether.The controversy also has the sponsors wondering about whether the image of their products has been tarnished."This is starting to take away from the great basketball exhibition of the team and is a distraction for many of the other sports as well," said Reebok vice president John Boulter.He said such disputes "could destroy some of the fabric of the Olympic spirit."The fabric has been strained frequently during the Barcelona Olympics, which has demonstrated the difficulty of mixing superstars with other Olympic athletes.While the other athletes stay in the Olympic Village, which was intended as a place for the world's youth to get to know one another, the stars have stayed in hotel suites.This annoys LeRoy Walker, head of the U.S. delegation and likely next president of the USOC. Walker also is the senior vice president for sport at the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games."It's a way of saying 'I'm better than you. I don't have to deal with you peons,' " Walker said.U.S. Olympic team members are becoming increasingly unhappy that some super-elite athletes don't want to bunk in with them, Walker said. "They are all Olympians and they have all paid the price. They feel they should all be on the same level."Because of that resentment, Walker has begun a campaign to force all American athletes to reside together in future Games, even it it means going without NBA players.Borislav Stankovic, executive director of the international basketball federation, took exception to Walker's comments."I would ask [Walker] what will happen when [the U.S. sends] one other team that will not win a gold medal," Stankovic said. "I think it will do tremendous damage if they [NBA players] will not come again."Nobody in international circles is complaining about the Dream Team," he said. "The teams are losing by 30 or 40 points and they are happy."The Associated Press contributed to this report.
email_title: BARCELONA OLYMPICS BARCELONA SCENE Unzipped, folded collar solves uniform flap

Email_Body: Steve Yormak, one of the few baseball agents based in Canada, hasresigned his certification after facing an investigation by the MajorLeague Players Association. Yormak, whose clients included Toronto BlueJay outfielders Rob Ducey and Glenallen Hill, is a lawyer in the London,Ont., area and a Canadian citizen, although he was born in the UnitedStates. Mike Weiner, the assistant general counsel of the playersassociation, said: "He resigned his certification as an agent in thecontext of an investigation. The end result was that Mr. Yormak chose toresign." Ducey and Hill have not been without controversy as Blue Jays. Ducey, aCanadian from Cambridge, Ont., has requested trades after assignments tothe minor leagues. He also sued the SkyDome over a knee injury suffered in1989. Hill was embroiled in a dispute with the Jays over his 1990 contractoffer. Yormak chose not to comment on his resignation. He says he hasmoved into the baseball marketing and licencing business. Nikerevises adsA last-minute change in advertising strategy byNikehas eliminated from  the North American market a television commercial directed by Canadian  David Cronenberg. An ad campaign for the Air 180 running shoe was to  include commercials made by 12 internationally renowned directors  including Cronenberg, Frederico Fellini of Italy, Eiko of Japan, the  Laurenstein brothers of Germany and Jean-Luc Godard of France. Each  director shot a 15-second segment depicting one concept of the Air 180  shoe. It was to be shown Sunday during the Super Bowl.Cronenberg's spot, filmed in Toronto in October, is set on a distantplanet and features a creature that farms Air 180s growing in insect-likepods. In December, however,Nikepulled the plug on the international TVspots for the North American market, although they will be aired in Europeand Asia. Glenn Wakefield, the national advertising manager ofNikeCanada, said there were two main reasons for the change - differencesbetween North American and European and Asian tastes in advertising andknowledge ofNike. The ads were "very European," he said. "More of anartistic theme."Sources: Marketing, Advertising AgeSuper Bowl ratings, Part 2Pot luck in drug testingA booklet with the title, Drug Free, has been published by the U.S.  Olympic Committee to warn athletes about the dangers of drug use. In  addition to discouraging competitors from using steroids and other  performance-enhancing substances, the booklet appears to be a how-to for  avoiding detection of marijuana use. Marijuana is not considered a  performance-enhancing drug and it is not on the International Olympic  Committee's banned list. However, it is banned by the national governing  bodies of some sports and may be tested for at their request.Under the heading How long does marijuana stay in the system? the USOCreports, "Breakdown products can show up in urine four to 10 days aftersmoking a single joint, and up to 36 days after chronic marijuana smokersquit. THC, the mind-altering ingredient in marijuana, is absorbed into thebody and transformed into metabolites, which can be detected in the urinefor weeks after use."
email_title: TRUTH AND RUMOURS   WILLIAM HOUSTON'S WORLD OF SPORT   Canadian agent resigns

Email_Body: A SEVERE storm two years ago has given scientists unusual tools for studying the currents of the Pacific: shoes.The shoes went from mere footwear to tools of science on May 27, 1990, when the freighter Hansa Carrier ran into heavy weather en route from South Korea to the Pacific Northwest and 21 cargo containers were lost overboard. Five of the containers were filled with 80,000Nikeproducts, many of them buoyant. Since then, in a confirmation of theories about currents in the Northwest Pacific, thousands of sneakers, hiking boots, children's sandals and other shoes have been picked up along beaches from British Columbia to Oregon and as far into the mid-Pacific as Hawaii.That is just where oceanographers would have expected to find them. It has long been known that the Subarctic Current flows from the mid-Pacific northeast to the coasts of Alaska and British Columbia, one fork sweeping south to California, then back toward Hawaii.Two oceanographers, Curtis C. Ebbesmeyer of Evans-Hamilton Inc., a physical oceanographic firm in Seattle, and W. James Ingraham Jr., with the National Marine Fisheries Service of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, began collecting reports on the seagoing shoes a year later, after reading an account in a Seattle newspaper of footwear washing up on beaches. They collected reports from local papers and befriended beachcombers along the coasts of Canada and the United States. Limiting their count to the most reliable finds, they determined that 1,300 shoes had been picked up, including as many as 250 from a single beach.The scientists described this impromptu experiment in the current issue of Eos, published by the American Geophysical Union.Despite months at sea, many of the shoes have been wearable after washing. The problem, though, is that the shoes were not tied together. So beachcombers have been holding "swap meets" to search for mates to their finds.The shoes confirm results of more conventional current-tracing efforts in which large numbers of bottles were dumped in the sea. During 1960-71, for example, 21,615 were released off Oregon by Oregon State University. In a 1956-59project, 33,869 were set adrift. The Scripps Institution of Oceanography released 148,384 off California and Mexico from 1955 to 1971.Assuming that many, but not all, shoes escaped from the containers, the recovery rate of 1.6 percent was not very different from that of 4,518 bottles released in one test near the same current but closer to the West Coast. Of these 2.8 percent were recovered.If other shoes survive -- and if theories about Pacific currents are correct -- "some should arrive in Asia and Japan" in a few years when, the researchers said, "hopefully we will hear from our western Pacific colleagues."
email_title: If the Shoe Floats, Follow It

Email_Body: While his Braves colleagues were being honored at Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium Tuesday and also thanking the fans for their season-long support, Deion Sanders did a Grand Slam Salute to his commercial interests. Sanders spent the day filming aNikecommercial at Georgia Tech - on the baseball field, the football practice field, the track, in Bobby Dodd Stadium and in the weight room. For the commercial, Sanders woreNikeAir shoes trimmed in gold. When last seen at Tech Tuesday night, Sanders was getting spritzed with some fake sweat-in-a-bottle near some weights. His Braves uniform hung on some equipment nearby. . . . Braves outfielder Otis Nixon will receive a nice payback for at the last minute supplying heavyweight champion Evander Holyfield with behind-the- plate tickets for the World Series. Holyfield will get Nixon close-up seats for his Nov. 13 fight against Riddick Bowe in Las Vegas. . . . Nixon, on standing by his bunt attempt in the 11th inning: "Every single time I go up there, that's on my mind. For me, it's not a low-percentage m ove." Golf tournaments have replaced postseason baseball for supplying the Braves with competitive outlets, and everyone but the batboys seems to be holding one. Travel director Bill Acree's tournament for hemophilia is today at the Polo Fields. The Pete Van Wieren celebrity golf tournament for the Atlanta-based Children's Wish Foundation, organized by the Braves' Jeff Treadway and Griffin's Alvin Goldstein, is Thursday at the Griffin Country Club. Pitcher John Smoltz's tournament, to benefit Atlanta's Table, is Nov. 7 at Eagle's Landing. . . . Something you don't see every day: Braves manager Bobby Cox in the dugout wearing a business suit instead of a baseball suit. The last time? "Never," Cox said. . . . Naturally, the Braves wanted one more game, but there was no shortage of them in 1992. From spring training on, the Braves played 203 games - 30 in Florida, 162 in the regular season and 13 in post-season. . . . A woman assembling Braves for introductions asked pitcher Tom Glavine in the dugout, "Who are you?" "I'm Steve Avery," Glavine said. "I'm one of the lesser-known players." . . . Golf pro Paul Azinger, a Braves fanatic, told our Tom McCollister after a practice round for the PGA Tour Championship, "Condolences, man, it was tough. I was really pulling for them. So close two years straight." Azinger wanted to know if Nixon was second-guessed for bunting with two outs but called the move "gutsy on his part." He called Cox's decision to remain with Charlie Leibrandt against Dave Winfield "a close call." Azinger asked, "Is Ron Gant some kind of upset he wasn't used? But how can you argue with how Deion played? He might be MVP if the Braves win."
email_title: GLENN SHEELEY'S SPORTSCENE Sanders has a full dayfilming a commercial

Email_Body: "Old Joe," the smooth cartoon character for Camel cigarettes, showed up as the favorite print ad among boys from 8 to 12 years old, followed by the public service campaign "Just Say No to Drugs." That's according to a survey by Xtreme Inc., a New York-based consulting company. It polled 500 youths who are members of the Xtreme Consumer Panel, a national network of 2,000 males and females from 8 to 24 years.Girls from 8 to 12 preferred print ads for Noxzema, Diet Pepsi andNike.Appealing equally to males and females from 8 to 24 were Pepsi's TV commercial featuring model Cindy Crawford; theNikeHare Jordan commercial; and a Little Caesars commercial featuring a conga line.
email_title: Kids rank ads

Email_Body: NIKE, the American sportswear company, built a huge advertising campaign around four of its sponsored athletes at the Olympic Games. Posters appeared around the world telling the public how successfulNike'scompetitors would be. The trouble is that only one of the four was a winner at the Games. Michael Johnson, the firmest of favourites for the 200 metres, was displayed on advertising hoardings that congratulated the reader for doing something few athletes would be able to do at the Games: passing Johnson.  Unfortunately, the American was suffering from a viral complaint for the semi-final and four people passed him as he failed to make the final.Still, there was always Sergey Bubka, from Ukraine. As Olympic and world champion and world record-holder, he was expected to soar to victory in the pole vault on Friday. The poster proclaimed: ''Spanish air traffic control has been notified''. Bubka failed with his two opening vaults at 5.70 metres, then tried 5.75 and missed that. He was out of the competition without a clearance.Well, at least Nourredine Morceli, the world champion from Algeria, would saveNike'sface by winning the 1,500 metres on Saturday in the commanding fashion with which he secured the world title last year. The advertising slogan read: ''Ever heard the Algerian national anthem? You will.'' Well, we did but not for Morceli. Hassiba Boulmerka ran away with the women's 1,500 metres.She stood on the podium in tears, listening to the Algerian national anthem and wearing her kit emblazoned with the name of Diadora, an Italian sportswear manufacturer. Morceli, meanwhile, finished seventh in the men's 1,500 metres. Nobody fromNikewas available to comment on the embarrassment.Fortunately, Michael Jordan, the fourth competitor selected forNike'scampaign, had the rest of the Dream Team alongside him and the United States squad easily took the basketball.
email_title: Losers in selling stakes

Email_Body: HOLLYWOOD, Calif. (AP) - Muhammad Ali received the Life Time Achievement Award last night during the Jim Thorpe Pro Sports Award Show, a two-hour live special on ABC-TV. The presentation was made by actor James Earl Jones. Other special awards went to Bo Jackson and long jumper Mike Powell. Other winners were Michael Andretti, Cal Ripken, Michael Jordan, Terry Norris, Mark Rypien, Fred Couples, Meg Mallon, Mark Messier, Jim Courier and Monica Seles.No politicsCALGARY (CP) - The two Canadian cities vying to host the 2002 Winter Olympics have sent a clear, angry message to Ottawa - keep politics out of sport.Calgary mayor Al Duerr and his Quebec City counterpart, Jean-Paul L'Allier, signed a joint declaration demanding the Canadian Olympic Association select either of the two cities as its Canadian candidate without politics coloring its decision.NikeappealsMADRID (AP) -NikeInc., which paid millions to put its name on the U.S. track and field team's uniforms at the Barcelona Olympics, is appealing a stunning high court decision that bars the advertising or sale ofNikeapparel in Spain.Spain's Constitutional Court last week refused to lift a lower court order prohibiting the Beaverton, Ore.-based sports apparel company from using theNikename on clothing because a Barcelona firm registered the trademark first in 1932.Jets kicker quitsNEW YORK (AP) - New York Jets placekicker Pat Leahy, the oldest player in the NFL and the third-ranked scorer in league history, retired yesterday after 18 seasons because of a recurring sciatic nerve condition.Leahy, 41, has 1,470 points, and trails only fellow kickers George Blanda (2,002) and Jan Stenerud (1,699).Jockey injuredWILLOW PARK, Texas (AP) - A Trinity Meadows Raceway jockey was in good condition yesterday at a Fort Worth hospital after being thrown and trampled in a race.Doctors said David Muirhead, 26, could be released today.Bulgarian backMILAN, Italy (AP) - Stefka Kostadinova of Bulgaria, back on track after taking two years to recover from foot surgery, will be bidding for gold in the women's high jump at the Barcelona Olympics.Kostadinova, who set the world record of 6 feet, 10 1/4 inches at Rome in 1987, surprised even her husband by clearing 6-8 3/4 in her best effort of the season at a track meet in San Marino on the weekend.Skiing champsBOGOTA, Columbia, (CNW) - Jaret Llewellyn of Innisfail, Alta., and Kim de Macedo of Shawnigan Lake, B.C., won the overall titles at the seven-country Pan American Water Skiing Championships.In the team event, the United States was first with 8,426 points and Canada, the number-one ranked nation, was second at 8,271.In junior competition, Ryan Bush, 15, of Brampton, was second overall.quickly

Email_Body: Reporter Pat Forde covered last week'sNIKEAll-American Academic basketball camp. After talking to scouts and coaches, Forde compiled an early, unofficial list of high school prospects to watch in the coming year. Many have called this coming year's senior class one of the best ever.  Joey Beard, Reston (Va.) South Lakes, F, 6-10, 210. Comment: Smooth, skilled big man who can play either forward position. Considering Duke, North Carolina, Virginia and Notre Dame. Damon Flint, Cincinnati Woodward, G, 6-0, 180. Comment: Explosive guard with shooting range, too. Starred atNikelast year but chose not to attend this year. Schools: Michigan, Ohio State, Arkansas, Cincinnati, Kentucky. Rashard Griffith, Chicago King, C, 7-1, 260. Comment: Has dropped 20 pounds since last year and added muscle but still could add a killer instinct. Says he's ''wide open'' on college choice, but Illinois, Louisiana State and Georgetown appear to be working hardest for his services. Ronnie Henderson, Jackson (Miss.) Murrah, G, 6-0, 180. Comment: Some have enthusiastically compared his athletic ability to Michael Jordan's, but scout Bob Gibbons said he could improve his basketball skills. LSU, UCLA, Kentucky, Ohio State could be the leaders in the clubhouse, but nothing's solid. Randy Livingston, New Orleans Newman, G, 6-0, 188. Comment: Some say he's the best player in the class, but he got off to a slow start atNike.Great athlete who can play either guard position but isn't a great shooter yet. Kentucky, LSU and North Carolina tops his list now, but says he's still open to others. Darnell Robinson, Emeryville (Calif.) Emery, C, 6-11, 230. Comment: A true back-to-the-basket post player. Plays more aggressively than the stereotypical California center. School choices uncertain. Jerry Stackhouse, Kinston (N.C.) Kinston, F, 6-7, 217. Comment: The star of the first few days atNike.Can handle the ball, shoot it, rebound it, and he packs a relentless attitude, to boot. Played hard all the time. Looks like he'll stay in ACC country, with North Carolina State, Duke, Wake Forest, North Carolina and Florida State atop his list. Jacque Vaughn, Pasadena (Calif.) Muir, G, 6-0, 165. Comment: Some question his size, but few question his quickness, penetrating ability and tenacity. Improved stock last year atNike.Has no finalists for college choice yet but initially likes Kansas, Kentucky and Georgetown. Rasheed Wallace, Philadelphia Simon Gratz, C, 6-11, 217. Comment: Another Alonzo Mourning? Rebounds, goes after shots and he has touch to 15 feet. Several big men said he was the toughest guy to play in camp. Has a list of 10 schools, including Temple, Georgetown, Massachusetts, Villanova, Maryland, Syracuse, Ohio State and Kentucky. Dontonio Wingfield, Albany (Ga.) Westover, F, 6-8, 235. Comment: Wowed 'em last year atNike.Did not attend this year. Has good agility and hands. Consistency the only question. Has many school choices.GRAPHIC:PHOTO; b/w CUTLINE: DRIVING FORCE: Jacque Vaughn, right, of Pasadena (Calif.) Muir drives past Kiwane Garris during theNikecamp. His quickness is one of his top attributes.
email_title: Basketball seniors to watch next season

Email_Body: FRANK van Wezel might have expected Olympic year to lift Hi-Tec, the sports shoe group, to the heights; instead it appears to be plumbing the Stygian depths.The stock market put the boot in to the personal fortune of Mr van Wezel, the chairman of Hi-Tec, after he delivered a profits warning at the sports shoe group's annual meeting. Mr van Wezel lost Pounds 16.63 million on paper yesterday as the shares fell from 175p to 106p. He still owns 56 per cent of Hi-Tec shares, worth Pounds 25.5 million on paper at last night's close. Behind the profits warning lies an admission of temporary defeat by Hi-Tec in the race againstNikeand Reebok for the British training shoe market.Khaleeq Taimuri, analyst at Carr Kitcat & Aitken, the broker, said ''the dumping of excess stock'', combined with the lack of upturn in consumer demand, had hurt Hi-Tec. Mr Taimuri saidNike, Reebok and LA Gear had been cutting prices by up to 40 per cent to achieve sales in Britain. Such discounts bringNikeand Reebok into the price range traditionally occupied by Hi-Tec, forcing Hi-Tec in turn to cut prices to maintain sales.Mr Taimuri has cut his forecast for the full year to January 1993 from Pounds 11 million pre-tax profit to Pounds 4 million. He expects a break-even at the half-year stage.Yesterday's events appear to justify Hi-Tecs efforts to diversify out of the British training shoe market into broader markets around the world.  Analysts say the North American hiking market is going well for Hi-Tec and expect European textiles brands to do well.At the annual meeting, Mr van Wezel said: ''Our UK sales so far this year are significantly below those achieved in the corresponding period of last year, and are below our earlier expectations, and we are experiencing a sharper squeeze on margins. Inevitably, these factors will have a pronounced adverse impact on our overall results for the first half of this year.''We have already taken steps to reduce our British cost base, for example, by reductions in our workforce, and we are keeping a tight control on working capital.''
email_title: Hi-Tec stumbles in Olympic year
