Email_Body: For the past 18 months, a Japanese armada has been sailing silently across the Pacific. Now, these secret invaders have begun to infiltrate the shores of the United States. It sounds like a sinister attempt to redress the outcome of World War II. In fact, the explanation for the invasion is pedestrian, quite literally, for the flotilla is made up of 40,000Niketraining shoes that have been slowly bobbing around the Pacific Ocean since the spring of 1990. News that these sartorial requisites have met a watery fate may dismay the youth of the West. However, it has brought joy to Oregon's beachcombers, who have been making a fortune reselling the trainers which, bizarrely, have survived their briny immersion with surprising resilience.Odder still, the data provided by plotting theNikearmada's progress has allowed oceanographers to test several complex theories about the detailed mechanics of Pacific currents. "It has been a real bonus to our work," said James Ingraham of the U.S. National Marine Fisheries Service.This strange story began on May 17, 1990, when a storm struck the freighter Hansa Carrier, which was en route from Korea to the U.S. The ship survived, but its shipment ofNikeswas washed overboard. Not a sole was saved.The incident was forgotten until November that year, whenNiketrainers began appearing along the shores of Oregon. Large hiking boots, high-top trainers and loafers began to bob landwards, at first in ones and twos, eventually in the thousands. To the incredulity of locals, the beaches were swamped with multicolored trainers.Within weeks, this well-heeled landing army had created a thriving new local economy. Beachcombers held swap-meets where they exchanged right and left shoes, which they then resold in pairs."I got my pair for $ 20," said Ingraham. "That's about a quarter of the price I would have paid in a store. Admittedly, they had spent a year sloshing about the Pacific, but after I'd worn them a couple of times they loosened up and are quite comfortable now."The fact that the shoes were still wearable after many months' battering by storms would suggestNikeproducts have a certain weather-resistance, a quality that could well be marketed. However, this has not been seized upon.Maybe not, but the longevity of the trainers has been a real boost for Ingraham who, with colleague Curtis Ebbesmeyer, began studying the shoes' peregrinations. They used the data to produce a lengthy paper for the Transactions of the American Geophysical Union.They report that many of the shoes appeared farther south than would be expected for flotsam borne by the tropical currents that head northward to Alaska.Now, as the currents have swept back out to sea from Oregon, already some of the shoes have appeared on the shores of Hawaii."The next stop is Japan," Ingraham said. "After that, they will start on their second circle of the Pacific Ocean."
email_title: Footwear flotsam carries clues about ocean's flow;Nike'ssole survivors hit the beaches

Email_Body: Shoe rivals halt battle THINGS are tough in the leisurewear business, but at least a truce has been called in the war over hi-tech basketball shoes.Sports rivalsNikeand LA Gear have dropped a legal battle over British patents for the sporty shoes, bringing at least a temporary end to the war of words between the big business competitors.Nikehad claimed LA Gear infringed patent rights while LA Gear launched a counter-claim thatNikewere trying to drive them out of business.
email_title: SHOE RIVALS HALT BATTLE

Email_Body: Veteran Moses Malone and All-Star guard Tim Hardaway are among six National Basketball Association players who will come to Tokyo to play in an exhibition event next month sponsored byNikeJapan Corp.The six NBA players will be divided into two teams along with players from the Japan Basketball League in an exhibition game on Sept. 24 at 6:30 p.m. at Tokyo's Yoyogi No. 2 Gym. A spokesman for the event, called "NikeForce Tour Japan 1992" and which will include slam-dunk and three-point shooting contests, said a sellout is expected. Scheduled to appear with Malone, a three-time MVP currently with the Milwaukee Bucks, and the Golden State Warriors' Hardaway are Golden State forward Billy Owens, Chicago guard B.J. Armstrong and Washington forward-center Pervis Ellison. A sixth player will be named later.Ticket prices are 10,300 yen, 7,210 yen and 5,150 yen and must be reserved by phone in advance. Call 03-3293-2500 between 10 a.m. and 6 p.m. from Aug. 30. Tickets will be mailed in exchange for cash by registered mail.
email_title: NikeTo Bring NBA Stars

Email_Body: THE POST-SEASON awards are starting to pile up for the Vancouver Canucks. On Tuesday, Pat Quinn was named coach-of-the-year by The Sporting News while on Wednesday, forward Ryan Walter was honored as the 1992 NHL Man of the Year.The award is presented annually to the player best recognized in the community as a "positive role model through his conduct on and off the ice." Walter received a $ 20,000 cheque that will be split equally between Canuck Place and Montreal-based Hockey Ministries International, which runs free hockey camps for underprivileged children. "There's one in Vancouver and one in Montreal, the two places where my heart has been," said Walter, who spent nine seasons with the Canadiens before moving to the Canucks last fall.JUST FILM ITThe Whistler area is providing the setting for a new series ofNikeTV ads now being filmed by a Portland, Ore.-based agency. The four ads follow a theme entitled "NikeWild." According to a Whistler Resort news release the commercials feature a "new line ofNikeactive wear modelled in various action adventures such as mountain biking, wind surfing, white water rafting and mountain climbing."The ads are expected to air nationally across the U.S.MOVING WESTThe Canadian Open golf tournament in Vancouver? It's not a sure thing, but Sun golf writer Arv Olson reports on page D11 today that the Royal Canadian Golf Association is considering moving the Open from its permanent site at Glen Abbey near Toronto once every five years.SNOW JOBThere are many claimants to the longest drive of all time in golf. However, an Australian named Nils Lied, working at a weather station in Antarctica, reportedly drove a ball 2,640 yards.How did he do it? Well, a report in "Amazing, but True Golf Facts," says the ball landed on smooth, frozen ice covering a bay and just kept rolling.
email_title: COLUMN ONE

Email_Body: Q: Has all that has happened to you thus far this season - the book criticizing you (Jordan Rules), the licensing controversies and other things, made this year less fun than it might have been?A: It's like a soap opera. Stay tuned for the next development. Playing basketball is fun. It's less fun off the court, though. That's been the big difference of this year and past years. I've been able to escape it all and just go out and play, but once I step off the court, there are a lot of questions I have to deal with - the book, greediness and different accusations. I just have to be truthful and stand up and answer the questions. You can't beat around the bush and say no comment, because that keeps it going. Q: Why did you agree to play in the Olympics in the first place?A: I wasn't really playing for financial reasons and I wasn't looking for any more endorsements. I was only playing because I wanted to hang out with the guys for the summer and be a part of history. Had I known it was going to be a headache like this from the merchandising and licensing stuff, I never would have committed to play.Q: With the agreement betweenNikeand NBA Properties, your likeness can't be used on apparel not sold byNike, and Nikecannot use the Olympics or its symbol on items. The That almost makes you a man without a country, doesn't it?A: I represent a country, but I can't be sold by one.Q: What do you think of Charles Barkley (the outspoken forward of the Philadelphia 76ers)?A: There is always some value in what he says. Who can tell him to shut up? Nobody. He's going to say what he wants. Some people like it, some don't. There's a lot of truth in what he says, but with that truth there is always some doubt of the other stuff that's in there. Either the language or the racism that he adds to his different comments makes it difficult for most people to fully understand, but we as basketball players, and some blacks, understand what he is saying.Q: What is the real story as to why you and Isiah Thomas don't seem to get along?A: The problem has always been he plays for a team I don't like and I play for a team he doesn't like. I've never had a real problem with him. I just don't know him that well and he doesn't know me. There was some competitive jealousy when I first came into the league. Magic Johnson was a part of that, but I was able to spend time with him and and we got past that. There just hasn't been the opportunity for me and Isiah to spend time away from the rivalry.Q: Who is your toughest competition in getting back to the NBA Finals?A: I don't care what anybody says, you can't look past Detroit. They scare you. They have the experience and the same nucleus that won the back-to- backs.Q: With Larry Bird and Magic Johnson at or near the end of their careers, how do you like being designated as the next ambassador for the NBA?A: I think everybody is kind of force-feeding me. I'm a part of the league and I want to uphold the NBA's way, but I think other players have to help out, too. The only guy I know who carried the label of ambassador by himself for a time was Dr. J.Q: How do most teams defense you?A: Everyone knows that driving is my strong point and the weakest part of my game is my jump shot. So most teams try to take away the drive, but when I'm knocking down my jump shot, they usually just try to double-team me.Q: Is Scottie Pippen the best player you ever played with?A: In my eight years in the NBA, yeah. In some ways it's like looking at a mirror. He doesn't want to play at just one end of the floor, either, and you don't find that every day at this level. He's very dedicated.
email_title: Jordan talks about Thomas, Olympics, Barkley and the book

Email_Body: Michael Jordan, a 28-year-old basketball player with the Chicago Bulls, is the City of Broad Shoulders' latest hero. Even in the intense, slightly unbelievable athleticism of professional basketball, he does things that make you gasp.     Many knowledgeable judges reckon he is the most thrilling player ever to grace the court. Columnist George Will has suggested, tongue only half in cheek, that (along with such luminaries as Frank Lloyd Wright and Aaron Copland) Jordan's face should grace high-denomination dollars.      In previous years, Jordan has had to play in a Bulls team that collapsed when the going got tough and in the National Basketball Association's play-offs, thegoing gets very tough indeed.  This year, however, the Bulls are playing the Los Angeles Lakers for the championship.     Professional basketball, more than any other American sport, is dominated by blacks. Since to play professional basketball at all you need great discipline, and to play it at Jordan's level you need extraordinary flair and imagination, it is hardly surprising that the great search for "role models" for black children should have fastened on the Bulls' star. Since Jordan is intelligent and articulate, notable for good sportsmanship and devoted to charitable work (though without ever seeming cloyingly goody-goody about it), he is an obvious choice.     There is, however, a catch two catches, actually. The first is Jordan's association withNike,America's leading maker of sneakers. Jordan has been endorsingNikeproducts since 1984: the Air Jordan shoe isNike'sbest-selling line. He is not alone; other black heroes like filmmaker Spike Lee and John Thompson, the basketball coach at Georgetown University, also endorseNikeproducts.     What is wrong with that? According to Jesse Jackson, black America's most popular politician and a basketball fan, a lot.Nike,he argues, is promoting an "ethos of mindless materialism" by encouraging black children to buy sneakers (the latest Air Jordan costs $ 125) that they cannot afford. That sounds like killjoyism taken to the limit, but Jackson has a point.     It is not as if inner-city children buy just one pair of sneakers; the pressure from the street is to keep up with the latest fashions. Some youngsters own as many as 50 pairs of sneakers; one 14-year-old boy told the Washington Post he spent $ 2,000 a year on shoes.     You do not need to be a genius to work out one of the most likely ways in which some inner-city youngsters come by such sums: It is by selling drugs. Some drug dealers use sneakers as a way of recruiting youngsters to their gangs; some gangs identify themselves by the sneakers they wear, or accept stolen sneakers as payment for drugs. There have even been incidents where people  R have been murdered for their high-fashion basketball shoes.     Nike,to be fair, makes sure that its role-model endorsers like Jordan appear in advertisements warning kids off drugs and encouraging them to stay in school. But Jackson is entitled to wonder whether those messages are as strong as the ones coming from the street.     The bigger catch is in the very idea of role models. Behind the search for role models lies the assumption that only great people such as Martin Luther King, Malcolm X or Jordan himself are worthy of emulation. When those idols are found to have feet of clay andeveryone who draws breath does the pain of disenchantment can be profound. Jordan himself knows the pressure that role-modelling puts on him: "I'm not a perfect person," he has said. He agrees with Charles Barkley, another NBA star, that the most useful role models for childrenare not heroes like himself but their parents.     There is another drawback to role models. The majority of children have no chance of fame on the basketball court, or anywhere else. The veneration of sportsmen and women subtly denigrates more mundane but realistic goals like getting a steady job.     What blacks need is not superstars but economic opportunity; and, as two recent sets of studies by the Brookings Institution and the Urban Institute have shown (as if the point needed laboring), anyone who thinks that they have such opportunity in the same measure as whites is deluding himself.     None of this should be taken as an excuse to denigrate Jordan's talent. But it is a shame that America's obsession with sports means that his kind of talent is celebrated more than that of other men and women.     As his city prepared for the NBA finals, Chicago magazine ran an article on Cyrus Colter, who in his long life has been one of Chicago's leading black lawyers, academics and public servants, and who, when most men would have put on the slippers, took to writing award-winning novels, short stories and poems. His has been an extraordinary tale; it is probably known to fewer than 1 percent of the young blacks who worship Michael Jordan.1991 The Economist Newspaper Limited. All rights reserved.  Distributed by Special Features/Syndication Sales Reprinted from the Economist magazine.
email_title: Jordan's a wonder, but even he questions heroes as role models

Email_Body: Barcelona - It's Day Four of the Olympic Games and Jennifer Capriati is winning her first Olympic tennis match; the U.S. women's volleyball team is losing to blood rival Japan; and Janet Evans is swimming the 800- meter freestyle preliminaries.And you want to entice several hundred top reporters and photographers from the international sports press away from the venues to listen to a pitch for your new track shoes?Right. So here's what you do. Post a notice on the Olympic bulletin board. "Leroy Burrell Press Conference." Burrell is only the former world-record holder and a gold medal threat in the 100-meter dash.Of course, the sports media forgoes the competition and heads en masse to the posh Hotel Avenida Palace. They're hot to quiz Burrell on the controversy surrounding the selection of the 400-meter relay team.And they will, but only after picking up Asics's thick press kit, complete with color brochures and Asics Corp.'s annual report. It's the newfangled Olympic news conference. Trot out superstar athletes, offer up some food and drink and the media will come. The media gets a few good quotes, and you get your prominently displayed company logo in every photo that goes out across the international wire services.Here in Barcelona, the ever-competitive athletic shoe companies have got this marketing ploy down.Mizuno pulled them in Friday with Carl Lewis. While Mizuno's chairman passed his new featherweight jumping shoe through the sweaty press corps imprisoned in an amphitheater at Poble Espanol on Montjuic last week, Lewis fed them bits about his devastating failure to make the 400-meter relay team.Nikeshowed not one, but two feature-length commercials in the Palacio Balana Cinema beforeNikesports marketing director Steve Miller paraded out "The Sultans of Suspension" - Michael Jordan and Sergei Bubka - to the sounds of James Browns's "Gravity." "Air Jordan" meeting "Aeroflot," quipped emcee Ahmad Rashad.In addition to individual contracts with spokestars such as Jordan and Bubka, industry leaderNikecompensates the U.S. track and field team to the tune of $ 1 million a year to wear its gear.Asics's ambassador Burrell - as a member of the U.S. track and field team - also wearsNikeuniforms, but he made it clear he wears Asics shoes.All these sponsorships are a bit confusing for the consumer.Japanese shoemaker Asics is the official shoe of the Barcelona Games - it supplied some 90,000 pairs to the Olympic volunteers, torch runners and organizing committee staff.Nikeis the official shoe of the U.S. track team; but Reebok is an official sponsor of the entire U.S. Olympic team, and is supplying the official award ceremony uniforms.So try to picture this: Burrell wins the 100-meter in his Asics. He pulls on his Reebok suit over hisNikeuniform and listens to the National anthem wearing all three brands.Seems it's getting a bit confusing for the media, too.
email_title: BARCELONA OLYMPICS BARCELONA SCENE Media turnout a shoo-in with Olympians as bait

Email_Body: It's Reebok!When prize basketball player Shaquille O'Neal left Louisiana State this spring and put himself on the professional market, the athletic shoe makers gave him the full-court press. Reebok beat out the others, includingNike, its main rival, and gets to crow. Celebrating like a prospector who found pure gold, Reebok executives put a pair of size 21s on the young 7-footer and gave him a coming-out party last week.Some party.He hasn't played a minute yet for a pro team, but the Massachusetts- based maker of athletic shoes signed him to a $ 3 million-a-year contract, just to wear those shoes and speak kindly about them.PoorNikewill have to make do with Michael Jordan.These shoes are big business. Reebok last year had revenue of $ 2.7 billion, mostly selling shoes and other sports apparel.Ernest Holsendolph's column appears every Sunday, Wednesday and Friday.
email_title: Shaquille O'Neal finds good fit with Reebok

Email_Body: PHILADELPHIA - Sales ofNikeInc.'s new cross-training athletic shoe went from zero in 1987 to an estimated $ 400 million this year, and Bo and everybody else know one big reason why.In addition to selling a lot of shoes, the advertising campaign featuring athlete Bo Jackson firmly established the small ad shop of Wieden & Kennedy as undoubtedly the hottest agency in Portland, Ore.Now Wieden & Kennedy has taken on another challenge, that of trying to get Subaru of America out of reverse. As a result of its landing the high-profile, high-billing account, Wieden & Kennedy is opening a Philadelphia branch, which, by itself, will rank as one of the city's largest agencies. The first Subaru ads by Wieden & Kennedy are to appear around Labor Day. Both the car company and the agency are mum on the content, but Subaru's director of advertising, Mark Dunn, promises that "they're definitely something completely different" from other auto ads.The campaign already is something different in one respect. Virtually all automotive advertising has been done by big Madison Avenue- based agencies. Nine-year-old Wieden & Kennedy, by contrast, had never had a nationwide client until it won the account ofNike, based in Beaverton, Ore.; Bo knows' brought attentionThe overwhelming success of the "Bo knows" ads brought prosperity and rapid growth to Wieden & Kennedy. For several years, the agency had all it could handle just keeping up with its star account.But when Subaru went looking for a new agency about three months ago, Wieden & Kennedy felt it was ready for another big account. And Subaru, suffering from losses and shrinking market share, was ready to try something fresh.Subaru of America, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., took off in the 1970s with what was then a unique product, an inexpensive four-wheel-drive passenger car. With Subaru all the way was its New York ad agency, Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver.But Subaru went into a skid in the mid-'80s. Other carmakers brought out and elaborated on four-wheel-drive models, and they had other models and better-established corporate identities to lure customers.Subaru of America began suffering losses and shrinking sales, and, last fall, the parent carmaker back in Japan, Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd., took matters into its own hands. It bought the Subaru of America stock that had been publicly held and began direct operation of the subsidiary.; Wanted to be major accountOn April 11, Subaru put its advertising account "into review," meaning it was up for grabs. Subaru was looking for some specific traits in its agency, said spokesman Richard Marshall."We wanted to be a major account but not their sole account," he said. Nor did Subaru want to be one of many sizable accounts held by an agency.The strategy was to find an agency big enough to have the resources to service a national account but small enough that Subaru would command management's undivided attention.A consultant helped narrow the list to a half-dozen candidates. One by one, they trooped to a meeting room in the Hyatt Cherry Hill to make a presentation for about nine top-ranking Subaru executives.David Luhr led Wieden & Kennedy's four-hour presentation. Although he can't discuss the creative concepts he pitched, he says that the presentation was built around the idea that "Subaru always has had a distinct personality. It was not a Honda, not a Toyota; it was always styled a little differently."; Basic, reliable, but dullSubaru has always been thought of as a car that was "basic, Spartan, durable and reliable, but not very pretty to look at," says Mr. Marshall of Subaru.Indeed, that is the theme of Levine, Huntley's last work for Subaru, the "Never Die" commercials that depict latter-day, upscale Subaru drivers discomfited to run across battered but hard-working old Subarus that look as if they are being driven by Okies escaping the Dust Bowl.The ads clearly say that Subaru wants a new image. It now falls to Wieden & Kennedy to determine what that image will be.The market for compact and subcompact cars is extremely competitive, with literally dozens of similarly priced and equipped contenders.In that kind of market, "advertising can really make a difference," Mr. Luhr says, so Wieden & Kennedy can rightly claim credit if Subaru's fortunes begin to turn around. By the same token, Subaru has placed a great chunk of its fate in the agency's hands.Wieden & Kennedy promised Subaru that it would open a branch near Cherry Hill to service the account.; Philadelphia office plannedBid the middle of July, Mr. Luhr also plans to staff an office of about 40. Enough people will be brought in from Portland to assure that the new office really is a Wieden & Kennedy site, but the majority are expected to be new hires.The Philadelphia office will be a branch, but one that could grow as large as its home office. The Portland office has about 120 employees and handles $ 250 million in annual billings.The Subaru account alone will have 40 employees and up to $ 70 million in billings. In Philadelphia, where relatively few agencies handle national accounts, few shops have billings of more than $ 100 million from all sources.Mr. Luhr says the Philadelphia office eventually will look for other accounts, but for about a year or so, it will handle only Subaru."This is a huge account for us, and we're going to get comfortable with it first," he says.Larry Fish writes for Knight-Ridder Newspapers.
email_title: Little agency creating ads for Subaru; Firm gained fame for Bo knows' campaign

Email_Body: After market conditions and financing problems forced Hickok's Sporting Goods to close seven of its eight stores last month, three major creditors have dealt another blow to the 32-year-old business: an involuntary bankruptcy petition.Russell Corp.,NikeInc. and Reebok International filed the Chapter 7 petition against the Atlanta-based chain last Friday in the federal bankruptcy court for the northern district of Georgia. An involuntary Chapter 7 petition is a way creditors can force a business into bankruptcy, sell off its assets and get their money back. The petition states Hickok's and its parent firm, the Young Group Inc., owe the Russell Corp. $ 456,405,Nike$ 377,914 and Reebok International $ 891,491 for goods sold and delivered.Hickok's can either agree to the filing or try to fight it. Officials of the company said they were not prepared to comment.
email_title: Bankruptcy petition filed against Hickok's

Email_Body: PITTSBURGH - Deion Sanders, who might well be the Atlanta Braves' 25th man now, will play football Sunday in Miami for the Atlanta Falcons.  Sanders was to leave after Saturday's fourth game of the National League Championship Series on a private plane apparently sponsored byNike,for whom he does commercials. Sanders is paid $1 million byNikeif he plays both sports and $100,000 if he plays just one.  Additionally, he would forfeit $118,000 in football salary if he did not show up Sunday in Miami. That represents 1/17 of his $2 million salary.Nikeis said to be planning a commercial around Sanders' two-sports-in-one-day adventure. Sanders is expected back here Sunday night for the fifth game of the playoffs.  Braves general manager John Schuerholz said he would not have placed Sanders, who's called ''Prime Time,'' on his 25-man playoff roster if he had known he was going to try to play both sports.  ''If he gets banged up and can't play, it puts us at a disadvantage,'' Schuerholz said.  Manager Bobby Cox of the Braves said, ''I thought we had him exclusively through the playoffs and the World Series, and that's not fact.'' Braves President Stan Kasten said: ''We have been informed he will play football. There's nothing else to say. Everything else will wait for another time.'' Sanders, on why he no longer is talking to the Atlanta media, or most everybody else, said: ''They had a privilege. They abused the privilege.  They lost the privilege.'' Bob Walk, Sunday's starter for the Pittsburgh Pirates in Game 5, made 19 starts, completing one durin g the season. He was 6-6 with a 3.38 earned-run average when starting. Walk may be remembered as the pitcher who started the first game of the 1980 World Series for the Philadelphia Phillies against the Kansas City Royals.  ''I don't think back then I realized what was happening,'' Walk said. ''I think I realize now what's at stake. It means a little bit more to me now than it did then.  ''My goal is to go out and hopefully throw six or seven innings, and when I leave the game hope my team has a chance to win.'' Walk is the only National League pitcher with at least 10 decisions a year to have a winning record in each of the last six seasons. He is also the only remaining player from manager Jim Leyland's first team, which lost 98 games in 1986.  ''The past few years I've pretty much gone wherever (Leyland) wants me to go,'' Walk said. ''When I went into his office yesterday and he told me, of course, I was surprised. I think he said, 'You're starting Game 5.' And I said, 'Starting?' '' Walk, 35, has had almost constant groin injuries the last few years. ''I don't feel I'll ever go out there again and not have an ache or pain somewhere,'' he said.  Against Atlanta, Walk is 5-9 in his career. ''They are probably one of the teams that have given me more trouble than anyone else,'' Walk said. ''I had success against a couple of guys who I won't mention - I don't want to jinx myself.'' One of them probably is Dave Justice, who is one for eight against Walk.  Otis Nixon is three for 15. However, the Braves are batting .303 overall against Walk.  While Braves catcher Greg Olson, a 1991 World Series notable who has ankle and leg injuries, entertains media as he supports himself on crutches, backup Damon Berryhill wonders why he was shortchanged.  ''I thought it was a joke,'' said Berryhill, a former Cub. ''It was like Greg had played all the games and I hadn't at all. I think he was seven games ahead of me.'' Unlike Olson, Berryhill prefers the shadows. 'Greg is a politician and I'm not one for the spotlight,'' Berryhill said.  Atlanta second baseman Mark Lemke, who has a .226 major-league career average, had 16 hits in his last 32 postseason at-bats before Saturday's game.  Braves lefthander Steve Avery, who will start the fifth game for Atlanta, has beaten the Pirates three times in succession in the last two playoff series. He has given up just four earned runs, all in the second game this year, in 22 2/3 innings.  ''Any time you have confidence against a team, it makes it easier to go out against them,'' Avery said. ''I don't know how much they think about it when I'm out there - if they're pressing a little bit to get to me early. I don't know what the reason is they haven't had much success against me, but it's an advantage for me.''
email_title: 'PRIME TIME' WILL WORK OVERTIME SUNDAY

Email_Body: Memo to MICHAEL JORDAN: Decathlete DAVE JOHNSON, who is Mr. Reebok, says he will proudly wear theNike-sponsored U.S. track and field uniform with not a moment's thought to company loyalty and all the other Jordan-inspired malarkey. He will wear his Reebok warm-up, will strip to hisNikeuniform, and stand on the medal stand (he hopes) with his official Reebok suit.  ''The reason we're here is to represent our country, not our company,'' he told BOB KRAVITZ of the Rocky Mountain News. ''When you get here, company things need to be left at home.'' Let's review, for all the brand-name shoppers.Nikemakes the track uniforms for the U.S. team. Champion makes the basketball uniforms. The boxing uniforms are made by adidas. Forty sponsors are paying a collective $160 million to the U.S. Olympic Committee and each athlete gets about $3,000 worth of luggage, cosmetics, jewelry, chewing gum, diet soda, etc.  But apparently that's not enough for Jordan, who probably makes more per breath than that.  ''I feel very strongly about loyalty to my own company,'' he has said.  Says MIKE LITTWIN of the Baltimore Sun: ''I'm waiting for him to say he regrets he has but one life to give to his shoe company.'' And furthermore . . . Johnson summarily dismisses the idea that Jordan or SERGEI BUBKA could become great decathletes.  ''Take my word for it,'' Johnson said. ''I can come closer to dunking a basketball like Jordan than Jordan could to pole vaulting or throwing the javelin.'' Wait'll promoters get wind of this. Coming soon! To an arena near you! The Battle of the World's Greatest Athletes (and shoe companies)!  Now you know: Gold, silver and bronze medals were not always the reward for finishing in the first three places at the Olympic Games. In the 1900 Paris Games, valuable pieces of art were presented instead.  For the U.S. Olympic team, one size obviously does not fit all.  Reebok says it produced 38,000 pieces of clothing in 12 sizes ranging from double extra-small for female gymnasts to size-6 extra large for MARK HENRY, the 367-pound weightlifter.  Henry may need a tuck in his tights. ''I've dropped about 4 pounds, you know, walkin' and scopin' out the local (Barcelona) scene,'' he said.  ''Ain't much food here I can call by name, but I'm hoping to get back up to 367 before my competition.'' QUOTE/UNQUOTE ''We're here for free, we've given up our summer. There's a lot of money up here, a lot of people putting their livelihoods at stake just to be here.'' MAGIC JOHNSON, Dream Teamer POST PUZZLER Who set a world long jump record during the 1924 Olympics but got only a bronze medal? (Answer Tuesday) SUNDAY'S POST PUZZLER: When was the last time an American won the 1,500 meters at the Summer Olympics?  ANSWER: Mel Sheppard in 1908.
email_title: EYE OPENERS

Email_Body: After more than 70 years in the sneaker business, Converse Inc. is pinning its future on five words.Caught flatfooted in the great sneaker war of the 80's, the company has been eating the dust raised byNike,Reebok and L.A. Gear for five years. Using glitzy, celebrity-studded commercials to push one new line of high-performance sneakers after another, the Big Three have grabbed two-thirds of the athletic shoe business while helping to triple its size, to $5.6 billion annually in the United States. Meanwhile, Converse, hobbled by a scattershot approach to marketing, has been stuck with a 2 percent share. Now the company is gambling $22 million on a new ad campaign built around the slogan, "It's What's Inside That Counts." The campaign, which begins Thursday, is designed to highlight the company's long tradition of making solid, if unexciting, sneakers -- at a price lower than the Big Three.The campaign, which features basketball stars Larry Bird and Bernard King, is particularly important to Converse, which has recently been operating in the troubled shadow of its parent, Interco Inc. The St. Louis-based furniture and footwear company, weighed down with debt in fighting off a hostile takeover 1988 attempt, filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this year.The Boston-based advertising agency that is producing the commercials, Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson, has a lot riding on the campaign as well. The second-largest agency in New England after Hill, Holiday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc., IQ&J has represented Converse for eight years and counts it as one of its most important national clients. Although IQ&J largely escaped blame for past marketing failings -- Converse says a lack of direction on its own part was the chief villain -- the agency is under intense pressure to deliver the goods with the new campaign. Just last Friday, the point was underscored when Hill, Holiday lost its Reebok account.How Converse and IQ&J worked together is a tale of creative chaos, tight deadlines and taut nerves. The three-month the effort tested the resources -- and the patience -- of client and agency both.The effort began in earnest last September. Gordon Tucker, Converse's fourth marketing director in as many years, had concluded a summer of research with a list of adjectives that encapsulated consumer and trade perceptions of the company's major products, which include Magic Johnson basketball shoes and Chuck Taylor All Stars.The company had been marketing its brands separately, diluting the impact of the Converse name. The adjectives -- confident, passionate, hard-working, tough, selfish and genuine -- were to be used as guidelines for pushing the Converse name itself, particularly with the key buying group, teen-agers.IQ&J assigned two creative teams to the project to compete in coming up with the campaign, a traditional industry practice. The teams were a study in contrasts.One paired Don Pogany, a copywriter who recently left the agency, with Peter Favat, an art director. Both men wear faded blue jeans to work; Mr. Favat accents his with cowboy boots and a small gold earring. They had made ads before for Converse, marked by fast-paced editing and clever punch lines.The second team, new to the Converse account, consisted of Mike Sheehan, in the copywriter slot, and Robert Rich as the art director, both of whom are more conservative in dress and taste. They favor a simple, direct approach in their ads.While some agencies devise campaigns on their own and present finished ideas to clients, IQ&J executives prefer to hold a series of sessions in which they show their work in progress. At these, the "tissue meetings," concepts are explored through drawings on tissue paper."Involving the client in the creative process means there are no surprises," said Bruce Kelley, IQ&J's president.The first meeting was scheduled for Nov. 13. Mr. Tucker wanted a finished campaign idea by the end of that month, in time for Converse's annual sales meeting on Dec. 2.The two creative teams plowed through newspapers, magazines and books looking for sports images. They devised three potential campaigns, tried to eliminate one but finally decided to present all three.The morning of the first tissue meeting was cold even by Massachusetts standards. About a dozen executives met in a cramped conference room at Converse headquarters in North Reading, Mass., about 20 miles north of Boston. The atmosphere was casual. IQ&J's executive creative director, Christine Chamberlin, explained the ground rules: a first tissue meeting was meant to be a broad review, a place to discard concepts the client didn't like.The agency opened with "Worn in the USA," which everyone agreed was the wildest but weakest idea. Mr. Favat turned on a boom box and danced around the room in flawless imitation of a team mascot at a half-time show. The campaign, he said, would depict fans of a high school football team readying themselves for the game. Mr. Tucker laughed, but it was clear he didn't take the approach seriously.Then came a campaign built around a school locker room. One ad closed with a voice reminiscing, "The moments are temporary but some things are permanent. Converse -- some things never wear out."To present the third concept, "The Original," Mr. Sheehan also took his audience inside a school locker room. A coach tossed boxes of Converse sneakers at his players. "We play as a team, we dress as a team," he tells them. The tagline: "Converse -- The Original."Mr. Tucker asked the agency people which approach they preferred and Mr. Kelley pushed hard for "The Original.""It shows there is us and there is them," Mr. Kelley said, explaining that it set Converse apart from other brands with its "pre-emptive statement" that it was the original sneaker. Mr. Tucker was unconvinced, arguing that such a distinction had little meaning outside the industry. But he liked the idea of associating Converse with the timeless moments and youthful exuberance of sports. "Sports teach kids about values," he concluded. "That image fits us."The four members of the creative teams smiled politely like small children chastised by their mothers.The second tissue meeting was scheduled at IQ&J's offices for 5:30 P.M. on Nov. 20, two days before Thanksgiving. The meeting started about an hour late because the agency people simply couldn't agree on what to present. Some thought Mr. Tucker's suggestion of associating sports with values was hokey. Some felt Converse needed to outdo the stylized approach of other sneaker companies. Some refused to give up on "The Original."Mr. Kelley tried to start the meeting off on a positive note by introducing an idea for a new Magic Johnson billboard. Mr. Tucker hated it. The agency then tried to salvage "The Original" theme. Mr. Sheehan and Mr. Rich had discovered that several Larry Birds were listed in local phone books. They envisioned ads asking "What is an original?" in which these noncelebrities would discuss their feelings about sports. But the consensus was that the idea closely resembled Reebok's unsuccessful "UBU" (you-be-you) campaign from a couple of years earlier.Ms. Chamberlin addressed Mr. Tucker's values issue head-on with an idea entitled "Stand for Something." She offered examples of coaches lecturing athletes on the sins of being late to practice and letting the team down. Mr. Tucker politely suggested it was too preachy.After four hours, Mr. Tucker was frustrated. The agency had presented a jumble of ideas. He liked the regular guy approach and was still attached to looking inside the minds of young athletes and examining their feelings about sports. Ms. Chamberlin told her staff to enjoy Thanksgiving and come in over the weekend.But early on Monday, the 26th, Ms. Chamberlin told IQ&J's chairman, Richard C. Garrison, that her staff was still at odds.Mr. Garrison drove to Converse's offices in an attempt to buy more time. Mr. Tucker refused. Mr. Garrison then vowed that by the time Mr. Tucker left Friday for his sales meeting in Miami, IQ&J would have sold him a finished campaign.Mr. Garrison returned to IQ&J and tersely told the Converse team they needed to stop bickering and find an answer.The next day, the group went back to its list of 300 taglines and finally saw what it had been looking for. "It's What's Inside That Counts" had been analyzed, re-analyzed and finally dumped shortly before the previous meeting. Now, it fit the bill. It addressed the values issue that Mr. Tucker insisted upon. And the word "inside" gave Converse an opportunity to sell specific product benefits of its shoes.Armed with the tagline, the creative teams dusted off the second version of "The Original" campaign, devising a number of ads featuring noncelebrities talking about sports. (The focus ultimately changed to celebrities discussing their lives.) The campaign's tone belonged to the Sheehan-Rich team. The proposed look -- including a reliance on fast-paced editing -- came from Mr. Pogany and Mr. Favat.Mr. Garrison called Mr. Tucker to say the agency had found the answer. Privately, he and Mr. Kelley kept their fingers crossed.Mr. Tucker arrived at IQ&J at precisely 8 A.M. on Friday, and two hours later he bought the campaign. When he left, he found a limousine with champagne waiting at the curb, courtesy of Mr. Garrison, to take him to the airport.It was Mr. Tucker's turn to sell the campaign, to Converse's president, Gilbert Ford. On Saturday, Mr. Ford signed on. On Sunday, so did the sales force. Now, after nearly four months of production, the question is whether the public will sign on, too. MAKING IT -- OFF MAD. AVE.Richard C. Garrison, the chairman and chief executive of Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson, is determined to hold onto the Converse account, which, after Ocean Spray Cranberries Inc. and T. J. Maxx, a national chain of discount apparel stores, is the biggest client at the Boston-based agency.Moreover, Mr. Garrison wants to use the new Converse campaign as a national showcase for IQ&J."The creative element of the advertising is particularly powerful in the sneaker wars," he said. "We want to deal with accounts that have high-quality brand names and high visibility as national players."Mr. Garrison's notion of national prominence does not include moving out of Boston, however. Although many regional agencies expand by opening offices in other cities, Mr. Garrison believes national accounts will come to him.He wants his firm to remain a single office focusing on large accounts in the Northeast corridor and linking up with international agency networks at his clients' request. He dubs IQ&J a mini-network because it provides a range of communications services -- public relations, design and direct response -- in addition to advertising.IQ&J's turbulent recent history makes Mr. Garrison leery of rapid expansion. In 1986, Quinn & Johnson/BBDO, a small Boston subsidiary of the large New York agency, BBDO Inc., bought 80-year-old Ingalls Associates to create Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson. But then BBDO merged with two other mega-agencies, Doyle Dane Bernbach of New York and Needham Harper Worldwide of Chicago, to form the Omnicom Group, which had $8.4 billion in billings last year.The 42-year-old Mr. Garrison, who had become president of the combined IQ&J, quickly discovered he was a very small fish in a huge pond. So in February 1989, he and four partners borrowed $4.5 million to purchase IQ&J. The five felt that conflicts of interest with Omnicom accounts restricted the agency's growth. Since the firm became independent, its total billings have grown 14 percent, to $134 million last year.Freedom also allowed Mr. Garrison to infuse the agency with an entrepreneurial spirit. "There's a lot of screaming and yelling and passion flowing in the halls," Mr. Garrison says with a mischievous grin. "But we don't have that many jerks."GRAPHIC:Photos: Christine Chamberlin and Richard Garrison of Boston-based IQ&J (Jim Bourg for The New York Times); Bernard King and Larry Bird star in the new IQ&J campaign. (Converse Inc.) Graph: "Sneakers: The Foot War," tracks sales of athletic footwear for Converse, Reebok, L.A. Gear andNike,1987-1990 (Source: Goods Intelligence); tracks spending on adult atheltic footwear advertising, 1987-3rd quarter 1990 (Source: Leading National Advertisers)
email_title: Converse in Adland, Playing Catch-Up Ball

Email_Body: SOUTH Melbourne is finding out that every one of its NSL games is a virtual Cup final.If it's not a local derby, it has been the pressure of bouncing back from a defeat or hitting back at criticism of its playing style. Even against the lower sides the expectations have been not only to win comfortably, but also to do it with flair. South's annual clashes against sister club Sydney Olympic have also been regarded as special and a means of proving which of the Greek backed clubs is more dominant in the competition.Sunday's clash between the two in Sydney has an added ingredient, according to South striker Kimon Taliadoros."Every game South Melbourne plays is a big game, but personally, I have been looking forward to this one for some time," Taliadoros said yesterday."They knocked us out of the finals last season and this is more of a revenge game for me. It was that way when we met them at home earlier this season, but I believe we still owe them." Taliadoros celebrated his return to the senior side after a seven-week absence by scoring two goals in the 7-3 win over Wollongong Mac last Sunday.His effort earned him the player of the week title in the Herald-SunNikeAir Golden Boot award for round 17."It is certainly the highest scoring game I've been involved in my senior career," he said.Taliadoros paid special credit to his striking partner Paul Trimboli for the goals."If you look into them, you'll find that Trimmers was involved in almost all the goals at some stage.He was an integral part of my two," he said."As is the case with most South Melbourne goals, they were the result of excellent teamwork. I was lucky to be the last man at the end of the line to apply the finishing touch." As the player of the week, Taliadoros receives a pair ofNikeAir runners valued at $280, as well as collecting votes towards the Golden Boot.The end of season winner of the award receives $2000 fromNike.Herald-SunNikeAir Golden Boot Award.Round 17. email_title: Finals time for South

Email_Body: ALAN DAVIDSON'S return to international soccer may well be in jeopardy with his decision to postpone indefinitely the operation he needs to repair knee ligaments.Davidson was told by Socceroo doctor Siri Kanangara to book in for the operation, but the utility has delayed it for several weeks to help out Melbourne Croatia. He has now decided to postpone surgery until the end of the season. "I've put it on hold and will get it done when I can (after the season)," he said yesterday. "We have had a lot of injuries and suspensions and I agreed to delay it."The club knows I could break down any time or, providing I'm lucky, I could go right through."Davidson's operation will rule him out for up to five weeks and, if he was to have it immediately after the league campaign, it would virtually rule him out of international commitments.He may delay it further but at this stage he doesn't want to think that far ahead. The media hailed Davidson's performance on the weekend as his best club game for several seasons.His display in Melbourne Croatia's match at Olympic earns him the player-of-the-week title in the Herald-SunNikeAir Golden Boot award.The weekly winner receives a pair ofNikeAir runners valued at $280.The end of season winner, based on the weekly votes, collects $2000 cash.St George keeper John Filan remains the leader on 18 votes. Davidson has moved up to 12 votes.Herald-SunNikeAir Golden Boot Award. Round 23. Votes: Adelaide v Heidelberg: 3 Veart (ac), 2 Brattan (h), 1 Herd (h). Email_Body: ON THE OTHER FOOT: Deion Sanders's endorsement contract withNikeathletic shoes would drop sharply in value if the two-sport star decided to play only baseball or football, the Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported.The three-year deal signed this year gives Sanders about $ 1 million a year, provided he remains in both sports, according to an attorney who reviewed the deal for the newspaper.Nikespokeswoman Lisa DeNeffe declined to comment on terms of the contract. Sanders's agent, Eugene Parker, could not be reached, the newspaper reported yesterday. If Sanders, who is an outfielder for the Braves and a cornerback for the Falcons, decided to play just one sport, the contract's value would drop to about $ 100,000, the Journal-Constitution said.Nikealso has an option to drop the contract completely if Sanders chooses one sport.Sanders appeared headed toward making a decision to play either baseball or football exclusively. However, he reached an agreement this summer to remain a part-timer with each team.MOVES: The Broncos waived RB Jeff Alexander and signed LB John Sullins from the practice squad. ... The 49ers activated WR Ron Lewis and placed LB Mitch Donahue on IR.NO DEFENSE: The only knock on the newest member of the Dolphins is that he's too small to play in the defensive line.That's where Miami really needs help. But the Dolphins instead spiced up their offense this week by signing free agent TE Keith Jackson.With Dan Marino, Richmond Webb and the three Marks -- Clayton, Duper and Higgs -- Miami already had one of the most potent offenses in the NFL."It seems like every year we load up on offense," Higgs said. "Hopefully we'll load up on defense like that one of these days."Going into today's AFC East showdown at Buffalo, doubts persist as to whether the Dolphins can stop a good team. They ranked second-worst in the NFL last year in run defense. So why spend $ 6 million on Jackson?"He's just a great football player," Marino said. "Any quarterback would want that addition to their offense."
email_title: AROUND THE NFL

Email_Body: Unfazed by her semifinal loss to Steffi Graf a day earlier, Arantxa Sanchez Vicario stormed back Friday to win three matches in one day at the French Open, one in women's doubles and two in mixed doubles.     Today's schedule is almost as tough. She and Conchita Martinez are to play a women's semifinal in the early afternoon against Jana Novotna and Larisa Savchenko-Neiland.      Shortly afterward, Sanchez Vicario and Todd Woodbridge are to face Lori McNeil and Bryan Shelton in the mixed doubles final on center court.     It's the second year in a row Sanchez Vicario has reached the  semifinals in three events.Courier may have $ 24-millionNikedeal    Jim Courier reportedly has signed a six-year, $ 24-million clothing contract withNike.     Asked to confirm the deal, Courier's coach Jose Higueras said, "Well, if I were getting that much money, I'd wear anything."     Higueras told reporters he didn't know about the contract, but he was wearing aNikewarmup suit.     Courier has been under contract with the Italian clothing manufacturer Diadora.Agassi's hatshide balding head    Andre Agassi wears caps, bandanas and other assorted headgear because he wants to hide his increasingly thinning hair, says the French sports daily L'Equipe.     The paper reported Friday that Agassi doesn't take off his cap in the locker room and that his fellow pros tease him mercilessly.Therapist helps French players    Before losing to Petr Korda in Friday's semifinals, Henri Leconte seemed to be playing on a cloud. That's because he feels loved by the fans, said psychoanalyst Georges Ejzenberg, who has worked with many top French sports figures.     Athletes call Ejzenberg a "motivational manager," who eases them  through winning and losing.Making finalssatisfies hunger    Jakob Hlasek was asked how it felt after he and fellow Swiss Marc Rosset reached the men's doubles final.     Rosset: "This makes me very happy, even if you can't compare it to a Grand Slam singles final."  What does it compare to?     "Well, let's say it's like a cheeseburger and fries."WIRE SERVICES
email_title: Sanchez Vicario wins 3 doubles matches

Email_Body: An impaired driver left paralysed by a highway crash after drinking beer supplied with dinner at his workplace has been barred from suing his employer for damages.Michael Jacobsen, 19, claimedNikeCanada Ltd. breached its duty of care to him, an inexperienced drinker, when it provided him with alcohol as an incentive or reward to work overtime.He saidNike, having allowed him to continue to consume alcohol after he became intoxicated, knew or ought to have known he was unable to drive his vehicle due to fatigue and alcohol consumption. Lawyers forNike, citing a legal precedent that says no one can benefit from his or her own wrongdoing, argued in a pre-trial motion that Jacobsen's action should not be allowed to proceed.B.C. Supreme Court Justice Richard Blair agreed, saying: "The conduct of the plaintiff (Jacobsen) is the type which society is trying to eradicate."The dangers of driving while impaired are great and devastating, particularly to the innocent users of the highway who have the misfortune to become involved in traffic accidents caused by persons who are driving while impaired."For this court to allow the plaintiff's claim to proceed would be to condone the actions of the plaintiff, who was clearly defying the law in driving while his ability to do so was impaired by alcohol."The court was told Jacobsen worked a 16-hour day on Sept. 6, 1991, part of it at B.C. Place Stadium, where he and other employees erected a trade show display forNike.When he finished work, Jacobsen was supplied with a dinner consisting of fried chicken and salad. A choice of beverages, including beer and soft drinks, was available.Jacobsen consumed two bottles and four cans of beer supplied byNike.He then went with a co-worker to two nearby drinking establishments, where he drank another bottle of beer, part of a half pint of draft beer and a full pint of draft.Driving home alone to Port Moody on the Trans Canada Highway at about 2:15 a.m., Jacobsen lost control of his vehicle, swerved across the nearside lane and crashed into a ditch. He was rendered a quadriplegic.Expert evidence at the hearing indicated Jacobsen's blood-alcohol content at the time of the accident would have been between .17 and .20, substantially above the legal limit.Blair, upholding the legal precedent cited byNike, quoted an earlier judgment in which Justice Martin Taylor said: "It would be manifestly unacceptable to fair-minded, or right-thinking, people that a court should lend assistance to a plaintiff who has defied the law."
email_title: Paralysed driver barred from suing

Email_Body: The Greenville (S.C.) Spinners haven't played a game - or even finalized their roster.But the Global Basketball Association team has a novel idea for sports teams looking for new revenues: Instead of just giving career counseling and motivational speeches to your players, make a business out of providing them to your fans.By the time the GBA - a new pro league with 11 U.S. franchises - tips off in November, the Spinners hope to have signed up a number of local companies for motivational seminars. They won't be your typical corporate outings. Figuring there's a growing demand for corporate seminars that help develop teamwork and concern for quality, the club will work with a local technical college to provide motivational speakers and career and family counselors. After daytime seminars, workers will attend a Spinners game.Spinners coach Joe Williams, who coached at Jacksonville, Furman and Florida State, says seminars will come with a range of options. Companies can opt to have their signs spread along the length of the court at the game that ends their motivational outing. Or let their key employee throw out the first ball at tipoff time.But companies shouldn't get their hopes up too much. Seminar prices vary and are negotiable. But the Spinners top price, for their ''Grand Slam Outing,'' is close to what New York Knicks coach Pat Riley gets for a motivational speech: $ 15,000.IT'S THE SHOES:Nikespent $ 178.8 million on advertising in 1990, says Advertising Age, which makes the shoemaker the USA's 58th-biggest advertiser. Last year, the trade magazine ranked it 99th.But the Alliance for the Mentally Ill of New York State, an advocacy group, thinksNikestill has something to learn about marketing - at least about showing sensitivity to the mentally ill.The group has criticized aNikemagazine ad, featuring San Francisco 49er Jerry Rice.Nikesays the ad refers to Rice following the inspirations of his inner voice, with copy reading ''crazy people talk to themselves. And finally, you realize, only a madman doesn't listen.''Nikesays it won't drop the ad but will cancel billboards for cross- training shoes using athe tagline ''Multiple Personalities.''CARD BEARER: Jack Nicklaus' Golden Bear International, along with Marine Midland Bank, is introducing a VISA affinity credit card. Along with various golf discounts, users get a Nicklaus golf tip on every monthly statement. ... Coming this Christmas: Cardboard cutouts of CNN sports anchors to help promote a sports video, part of a merchandising push that might result in watches and luggage with the cable network's logo. ... In its biggest promotion, Chrysler will team with K mart and CBS for promotions tied to the 1992 Winter Olympics. Chrysler, reportedly, will spend about $ 50 million for ads on CBS broadcasts. ... Changing times: A new $ 30 Cardillo Cross-Trainer spandex weightlifting belt hopes to compete with traditional leather belts made for heavy lifting. Also, Weslo Inc. of Logan, Utah, is introducing a home treadmill with a VCR hookup to show users Utah's red rock desert as they exercise.
email_title: New league out to motivate fans

Email_Body: Reebok's heroes: Reebok's dueling-decathletes ad campaign hit its stride only when the athletes themselves faltered. When Dan O'Brienwashed out at the Olympic Trials, Reebok turned footage of his defeat - and rival Dave Johnson's sympathetic hug - into an ad that packed in as much drama as 16 days of the Games. Failure has never seemed so honorable. Agency: Chiat/Day/Mojo  Nike'sclowns: How could you go wrong with Michael Jordan and Bugs Bunny in one ad? They teamed up in this 60-second Super Bowl spot that ought to be running on the Cartoon Network - as programming. Bugs gets to run through his typical carrot-schtick, - including putting on a dress, - and Jordan does a good Porky Pig.Agency: Wieden & Kennedy Boomer humor: For those whose love beads have given way to love handles, Lee's funny ads for its Easy Riders made their point with a gentle poke rather than a pinch. In one, a jeans button pops and ricochets around the living room like a bullet in a Western. In another, a slightly smug shower singer goes from tenor to soprano when he zips his pants. The company's ads for women put female voices in men's mouths, without demeaning either sex. Not easy - and not very common.Agency: Fallon McElligott AT&T's split screen: Truly interesting long-distance company ads are rarer than a 10-cent pay phone. This one was visually glorious, -and bypassed the now-hackneyed special effect of transforming images on the screen, called morphing. Cliff Robertson was still droning away in the background about worldwide long-distance, but it was easy to get lost in admiring the smoothly flowing images and the ethereal soundtrack instead.Agency: Young & Rubicam Bud's fridge break: Amid all the sweaty hoopla of the summer Olympics, Budweiser rolled out an ad that relied on a clever idea instead of a celebrity endorsement. Babe-free, regular-Joe-free, the ad simply pictured a refrigerator and a caption telling viewers that, unlike other advertisers, Budweiser wouldn't mind if they skipped watching the commercial to grab a cold beer. Now that's a dry beer ad.Agency: DMB&BPlanes, fashion and birds in best of rest - United Airlines: ''Parrot'' - A Brazilian parrot pecks out the airline's theme song to push United's service to Rio. Not only can that bird play Gershwin, he can act.- Saturn: ''Schoolteacher'' - The true story of a teacher who writes to the factory workers building her car. They tape her photo to the rearview mirror as the car goes down the assembly line. Sweet, not schmaltzy.- US West: ''Voice messaging'' - Remember the geeky guy from Bud Dry's ''Why can't they love us for our minds'' ad? He redeemed himself here as a deadpan office assistant denying he broke the answering machine.- Kmart: ''Fashion'' - Upscale women and sharp dialogue acknowledging Kmart and fashion aren't usually associated. If the clothes are as slick as the ads, they're the next Gap.- Doritos: ''George Foreman I-V'' - Who taught those kids to act so cute? You did, Dad.- Coca-Cola: New Times Square sign - a $ 3 million Broadway production. It was better than Cats.GRAPHIC:EAR PHOTO, color; PHOTOS, b/w (5) CUTLINE: BUGS BUNNY: Takes it to the hoop with Michael Jordan in acclaimedNikead. CUTLINE: PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION: AT&T's ad shows a London double-decker bus transform almost seamlessly into an Asian elephant. CUTLINE: REEBOK AD: Dave Johnson reacts as teammate Dan O'Brien fails to make U.S. Olympic Team. CUTLINE: THE FRIDGE: The ad Bud gave viewers permission to miss. CUTLINE: HOOPS AND HOCKS: Jordan and Porky Pig inNikead. CUTLINE: HIGH-SPEED PROJECTILE: In Lee ad, family escapes flying jeans button.
email_title: Remarkable ads sparkled

Email_Body: SPORTS shoe giantNikehas drawn up plans to shift up to US$ 150 million worth of production out of China if the US acts on its Section 301 mainland hit list.The multi-billion dollar group says it will be forced to raise the price of running and sports shoes by up to 15 per cent if the US refuses to back down on threats to double tariffs. Nikeinvestor relations director Mr Ron Parham said: "We have put together very extensive contingency plans in the case of the sanctions being levied against China."We will shift products back to other bases. Every product built in China is also built in other countries, and it would take us only three to five months to fully transfer all our China volume into a variety of other countries." The US has imposed an October 10 deadline for the resolution of the acrimonious dispute over US access to the Chinese market. Nikehas already mounted an intensive lobbying campaign in Congress to avoid the punitive measures, which it claims will damage the industry as a whole.If no agreement is reached by midnight on October 10, the US will impose punitive tariffs of up to 100 per cent on up to $ 3.9 billion in annual Chinese exports to the US. China has said it has drawn up a list of its own covering a similar amount of US exports.The National Retail Federation has told the Office of the US Trade Representative in the current public hearings in Washington that punitive tariffs against Chinese imports would strike a "severe blow to American consumers" and could cripple some retailers as they head into the Christmas season. Nikecurrently produces some 20 per cent of its shoes in China, representing about $ 300 million in turnover for fiscal 1993, shared among seven factories on the mainland.Production vice-president Dave Taylor said: "In the first six months of this year over 40 per cent of all shoes imported into the US came from China, so if the Section 301 hit list is enacted there is serious, serious damage to the US retail industry. It's a huge deal."The idea behind 301 is to make it impossible to do business, so it punishes the importing country."In Hongkong, a spokesman for Yue Yuen Holdings, one ofNike'smain suppliers of Chinese-made shoes, said the threats applied mainly to domestic US consumption and were of no great concern to the company.Yue Yuen executive director Steve Li I-nan said: "They are trying to convince the authorities not to act. We will take note of it for reference but they are being forced to say things to influence people in the US not to take action."The US market accounted for about 69 per cent of Yue Yuen's turnover in the five months to February this year, but European sales had expanded strongly and were expected to increase as a proportion of total sales over the next few years, Mr Li said.He added thatNike, one of Yue Yuen's four biggest customers, realised "China is the best place to make shoes" on a cost basis. Nike'sMr Taylor agreed, saying China offered "the lowest cost source; one of the best quality sources, and a huge labour pool".According to Mr Parham, shifting production out of China to other Southeast Asian Markets would add around 10 to 15 per cent to manufacturing costs."To some extent shoes will become more expensive if the levies are enacted by Congress. Unfortunately that hits the consumer," he said. Nikeand its competitors also face a squeeze from the other side of the Atlantic, with new EC quotas.Mr Taylor said the EC-imposed quotas - originally scheduled to take place this year but postponed as member countries failed to agree on a package - had already prompted the company to adopt contingency plans."We have lobbyists in Europe monitoring the whole thing for us," he said. "We are using contingency plans right now, because some countries are not taking products in. France have got quotas, but we are working round them."It's a problem. We just need to know what the rules are to figure how we can work on them."Europe isNike'sbiggest market after the US. The group plans to do 50 per cent of total sales abroad by fiscal 1996.It reckons the non-US market is worth between $ 8 billion and $ 10 billion, with around one-third coming from the Asia-Pacific region and half from Europe.
email_title: Nikeplan to shift China operations; Niketakes steps to shift part of production from mainland

Email_Body: MARKET HITS NEW HIGH. The stock market kept its recent rally rolling to new highs Wednesday, powered by mounting hopes for a sustained economic recovery. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 60.60 points on Tuesday, rose another 12.30 to 3,258.50. Volume on the Big Board came to an estimated 312.40 illion shares as of 4 p.m. EST, up from 264.55 illion on Tuesday. NationDomestic production of oil falls sharply    With oil companies focusing on foreign fields, U.S. crude oil production declined dramatically in the latter part of 1991, painting "a bleak picture" for domestic producers, industry officials said Wednesday.     The American Petroleum Institute reported that domestic production dropped 2 percent in the fourth quarter of 1991 to the lowest fourth-quarter level in 30 years and continues to decline at an annual rate of 300,000 barrels a day.     A year ago U.S. production had stabilized, said Edward Murphy, the institute's director of finance and statistics. But the decline resumed during 1991 when producers failed to get needed tax breaks and it became clear congressional efforts to enact a new energy plan would be unsuccessful, he said.  BOOK CRITICAL OFNIKE. Steroid use byNike-sponsored athletes and widespread under-the-table payments to amateur competitors are among the allegations in a book released this week that details the inner workings of the athletic shoe and apparel giant. Swoosh, The Story ofNikeand the Men Who Played There was written by sisters Julie Strasser and Laurie Becklund. The authors write that competitors for Athletics West, theNike-sponsored track club that operated from 1977-1985, used steroids and officials of the club were aware of the practice.Tampa Bay/State  WOLF BROTHERS CLOSING STORE. Wolf Brothers, an upscale clothing retailer founded in downtown Tampa 94 years ago, will close its location in the city's central business district on Friday, said Fred Wolf, the store's manager and a grandson of the founder.  Wolf Brothers, owned by Chicago-based Hartmarx, was unable to renew its lease with the Lykes Co. that owns the old First National Bank building at Franklin and Madison streets. The retailer could not find another downtown location, Wolf said. He said the store's 15 employees either will retire or move to other Wolf Brothers locations.Earnings  WACHOVIA REPORTS LOSS. Wachovia Corp. reported a loss of $ 40.6-million, or 46 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1991, blaming the results on special charges arising from its merger with South Carolina National Corp. That compares with earnings of $ 84.4-million, or 98 cents a share, during the three months ended Dec. 31, 1990. For the full year, net income totaled $ 229.5-million, down 34 percent from $ 345.7-million in 1990. Wachovia, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., acquired South Carolina National on Dec. 6 in an $ 848-million stock swap, giving Wachovia combined assets of $ 33.1-billion.         DOW          DOLLAR             YIELD     30 Industrials   VS Japanese Yen   30-Year U.S. Bonds     3258.50          128.66            7.57              +12.30           +1.81             +0.05
