Email_Body: John Thompson, the renowned Georgetown University basketball coach, is good at what he does -- and that's not limited to coaching. He likes his players to be fine students as well as fine athletes, and in this and other ways he proves that he is a man of some values. One of them, unfortunately, is to sound like Adam Smith's parrot.Capitalism, capitalism, Thompson squawks when asked about the $ 200,000 or so he gets annually fromNikeshoes. In exchange, Thompson shoes his team inNikes. He makes public appearances for the firm. He acts as one of their spokesmen, and he tried, without success, to broker a deal betweenNikeand Jesse Jackson over minority hiring and other such matters. Even Big John Thompson doesn't win them all. If patriotism is the last refuge of the scoundrel, then capitalism must run it a close second. It's often invoked as a lame excuse, an attempt to duck a moral argument by saying all ways of earning money are equal. But across town from Georgetown is the University of the District of Columbia. It's the city's public institution of higher learning, and many of its students are poor. On its basketball team is one Keith Goodie. He owns 56 pairs of sneakers.Goodie is to sneakers what Imelda Marcos was to pumps. In his addiction, he is in no way typical, but he is representative. He told The Post he doesn't know anyone who doesn't own at least 25 pairs. To this, people in the sneaker business would only shrug their shoulders in cynical acknowledgment: What else is new? They know that athletic shoes make a major fashion and status statement in the inner city. Lots of poor kids have dozen of pairs, and they are the shoes of preference for drug dealers.Jesse Jackson had his own differences withNike. But when it comes to sneakers in general, what he says makes sense. These shoes, selling for as much as $ 135 a pair, are symbolic of an urge to showboat. They are worn by kids whose pride, whose entire self-esteem, is on their feet or on their backs. They spend recklessly because they think they have no future, and they have no future because, among other reasons, they have little self-discipline. Jackson to his credit says so.It goes without saying that poor people have little money. But they often lack something else as well: a refusal to postpone gratification. Whether it's having a child when too young or squandering money on athletic shoes, this behavior is characteristic of the culture of poverty. So, too, in a way is basketball. It's a game of youth that promises an almost instant payoff for the extremely talented. But as a way out of poverty, it has the long odds of a lottery: just a handful win.Thompson and the other coaches who have contracts with shoe firms surely understand the lure of basketball and the impact famous coaches have. But instead of acknowledging that their endorsements only reinforce a destructive mentality, they proclaim a mindless allegiance to the free-market system. "So all of a sudden it's a sin in this society for a person to be capitalistic?" Thompson said. "But as long as I live in America, that's exactly what I am going tobe."Trouble is, Thompson's role as a capitalist is in direct conflict with his role as a mentor to young black athletes and, since basketball is king, to young black males in general. When his team takes the court with everyone wearingNikes, not only do the people in the arena notice but so does everyone watching television. After all,Nikeis paying him big bucks expecting a big payoff. Here is the ultimate in false values: a team wearing a certain shoe so that the coach can make a buck.But what if Thompson allowed his players to wear any shoe they wanted? What if kids all over America could see that one sneaker is very little different from another and their obsession with name brands (at incredible profit margins) marks them as suckers? What if they gleaned the message that the shoes and their look didn't matter at all, but that performance was everything? Isn't that a lesson that transcends shoes?Of all that ails the black underclass, a weakness for expensive sneakers is hardly the most serious. But as Jesse Jackson knows, it is representative of a larger problem, one personified by a college student who squanders his money on shoes -- making rich people even richer and himself a bit poorer. In this regard, John Thompson and other basketball coaches offer nothing in the way of rebuke. In perhaps the most important respect, the coach is not coaching.
email_title: John Thompson'sNikeConnection

Email_Body: C-SPAN will provide live coverage of Queen Elizabeth II's address to a joint meeting of Congress today, starting at 11:40 a.m... ."Donahue" (Channel 9 at 9 a.m.) this morning asks, "Did Reagan and Bush Delay the Hostage Release to Win the (1980) Election?" Among the guests: Gary Sick, former National Security Council aide in the Carter administration ...The Children's Television Workshop yesterday announced its "most exciting and innovative project since 'Sesame Street,' " an ambitious $ 20 million-a-year multimedia effort designed to help 7- to-10-year-olds understand what they read and to help them write clearly ...Nike, the athletic footwear giant, will contribute $ 5 million, the largest single corporate grant ever made for a children's educational television project. CTW has also committed some $ 6 million of its own funds ...Centerpiece of the project will be a weekly, half-hour action-adventure drama called "Ghostwriters," which is expected to premiere on PBS in the fall of 1992 ...According to CTW president David Britt, "Ghostwriters" will feature "a gang of six youngsters -- including black, Latino, Asian as well as white -- plus an invisible seventh, a ghost" ...The ghost, who is silent but whose words appear on the TV screen, will be the "motivator," explained Britt, "making the kids understand how important it is to express yourself well, to communicate, how reading and writing are relevant" ...Britt expects that each program will also include a celebrity guest who will "read something" and "suggest a writing project -- maybe asking the kids to keep a diary for a week, things like that" ...He predicted that " 'Ghostwriter' will capture the contemporary beat of MTV, the graphic look of print on screen, elements of the popular culture and a dramatic format to create the program and the excitement surrounding it" ...Britt said current plans "hopefully" call for 48 new programs a year for three years, to be produced over perhaps a five-year period, and representing a potential outlay of some $ 60 million eventually ...He said the bulk of the $ 20 million annual budget would be expended on a national campaign to reach children at home, in school and in community environments. Highlights of the campaign: 20 million copies of a mini-magazine to be distributed free in conjunction with the program; more than 200,000 copies of teachers' materials to be distributed through a variety of channels; a nationally syndicated weekly newspaper column; and two nationwide contests to be conducted during the show's first season ...In addition to the funds provided byNikeand CTW, PBS is contributing $ 2.8 million; the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, $ 1 million; and the Mary Reynolds Babcock Foundation, $ 100,000 ...Richard K. Donahue, president ofNike, said yesterday that his company's contribution is "a continuation of a lot of other things -- our participation in the Stay in School program last year, our work with the National Education Association. We saw it as an extremely high-quality opportunity that was difficult to pass up ..."It is worthwhile making this kind of an investment because it lasts well beyond the period in which it's actually operating. The size of this project gives us a chance to focus on something that's needed -- and usually you can't identify the impact. We're very proud we can participate" ...Now ThisAt the last minute, somebody up in New York forgot to tell him about the mandatory drug tests at ABC so it wasn't until yesterday -- a day late -- that ABC News could officially announce that Tom Bettag has been named executive producer of "Nightline" ...By the afternoon, he was in Washington to introduce himself to the staff of 15 at the News bureau and discuss the night's program with anchor Ted Koppel ...The former executive producer of "CBS Evening News With Dan Rather" is no stranger to Washington. He began his broadcasting career as an assignment editor at the CBS News Washington bureau 22 years ago ...Bettag, 46, is only the fourth executive producer in the 11-year history of the very successful late-night show. Bill Lord, Rick Kaplan and Dorrance Smith preceded him ...Bettag said an increased emphasis on investigative reporting can be expected. He said the program does so superbly during crises -- such as the Persian Gulf War -- that the trick will be to maintain that kind of momentum. "I think I've just got to remind them once in a while of just how good they are" ...His predecessor, Smith, departed for the White House in March. Bettag said the fact that "Nightline" continued to operate without a glitch and without an executive producer for the next two months was another sign of "just how strong this program really is" ...He will operate out of New York, where another 15-plus "Nightline" staffers work, at least for the time being. Manhattan-based ABC News president Roone Arledge likes to keep an eye on his executive producers ...Bettag had been executive producer at "Evening News" for five years when he was replaced earlier this year by Erik Sorenson ...Two more ABC notes: Arledge received an honorary doctorate in humane letters from Boston University this past weekend. According to BU President John Silber, Arledge's "programming innovations have transformed broadcast news reporting. You have increased the range of news coverage, developed new kinds of news programming such as 'Nightline' and dramatically increased the size of the television news audience. You are perhaps better known to the general public for your achievements in sports broadcasting, but we take particular note of your accomplishment in raising the industry standard for television news coverage; it is in this context that we propose to honor you" ...And a video salute prepared by producer Rhonda Roberts and videotape editor Rick Watkins at the ABC News bureau here will be shown to guests tonight at the annual White House News Photographers Association dinner, which will be held at the Washington Hilton ...The video uses footage shot at home and in the Middle East as a tribute to the men and women who served in the Persian Gulf War and the members of the media who covered it ...The video is about eight minutes long and is set to the music of M.C. Hammer's "Can't Touch This" and Whitney Houston's version of "The Star-Spangled Banner" ...The network premiere of " 'Crocodile' Dundee II" Tuesday night earned a 13.6 national Nielsen rating and a 23 percent audience share between 9 and 11 and enabled CBS to win the evening ...Each national ratingzzzz point represents 931,000 TV homes ...Over on ABC, the season finale of "Roseanne" averaged a 14.6/24, the penultimate episode of "STAT" did an 11.8/19 and an original "thirtysomething" -- during which Michael finally quit the agency!!! -- averaged a 9.4/16. If you're keeping track, the season finale (or worse!) of "thirtysomething" will be May 28 ...On NBC, "Perry Mason: The Case of the Glass Coffin" averaged a 12.8/22. A very good "Shannon's Deal," which followed at 10, drew exactly the same number "thirtysomething" did for ABC. That is not good. Symmetrical, perhaps. But not good ..."China Beach will fill that yawning "thirtysomething" slot next month, returning to temporary active duty after a fans' write-in protest campaign to ABC network officials ...The Emmy-winning "China Beach" was suspended in December with seven episodes remaining to be aired. Those episodes will be shown on Tuesdays at 10 p.m. beginning June 4 ...No word yet on the future of "CB." ABC is to announce its fall schedule next week ...More HonorsChannel 9 was among the 24 winners of awards presented by Action for Children's Television (ACT) earlier this week at the National Press Club ...Nine was the only network affiliate honored in the Commercial Television category. WUSA's "In Our Lives" series was tapped, said ACT, because of its "dramatic vignettes helping teens learn to cope" ...The 10-year-old "In Our Lives" is the only regularly scheduled, locally produced TV show in this market that "provides a forum for teens to express their needs, problems and concerns," according to WUSA. Pauley Gwynn is host; Triona Mance-Lee, senior producer; Khalim Piankhi, executive producer; and Mike Mannarino, producer ...Among the other honors distributed by ACT were two "stop, look & listen awards," which went to Turner Broadcasting System's "CNN Newsroom" for "delivering ad-free news daily to nearly 20,000 U.S. schools"; and ABC News for the special "War in the Gulf: Answering Children's Questions," cited as "a timely response to children's needs in a national crisis" ...And a Washington production was among the winners of the 23rd annual Robert F. Kennedy Journalism Awards presented yesterday at a ceremony at the McLean home of Ethel Kennedy ...The first prize in television went to a "Frontline" segment called "Throwaway People" that "examined how the once proud and successful black community of Shaw in Washington, D.C., has declined and become part of the black underclass" ...Producer-director was Sherry Jones, whose Washington Media Associates has previously won two Du Pont/Columbia journalism awards. Roger Wilkins was correspondent and Foster Wiley was co-director ...

The sporting goods industry resembles Dominique Wilkins's missed slam-dunk in this year's NBA All-Star game: There's still plenty of spring in its legs, but maybe not what there used to be.That was the message, in effect, that John D. Riddle, president of the Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association, deliverd to analysts Wednesday. They were gathered at the Georgia World Congress Center on the eve of the industry's annual Super Show mega-convention. Mr. Riddle said the $ 30 billion industry grew 6 percent last year - good, compared with the 2 percent overall growth of U.S. manufacturing, but sharply down from the double-digit growth in the 1980s."Manufacturers are prepared for a good, but by no means great, year," said Mr. Riddle, who attributed the slowdown to the recession and tight credit.Sales growth this year will be driven by sports apparel and equipment for tennis, bowling and billiards, Mr. Riddle said, estimating 8 percent increases.In previous years, athletic shoes put the bounce in the industry's step. But shoe sales may rise only 6 percent this year, he predicted.Apparel sales, worth $ 13.6 billion, will eclipse total sales for all sporting equipment at $ 10.9 billion, he predicted.; Pumping it upAthletic shoe manufacturers, meanwhile, have stepped up rivalries to increase their sales.No. 2 Reebok three weeks ago launched its most agressive advertising effort yet, attacking No. 1Nikewith a $ 20 million campaign using the slogan "Pump up, and air out."Nikecried foul, claiming Reebok was abusingNikeendorsers by mentioning them in Reebok's ads.Reebok Chairman Paul Fireman told analysts Wednesday the company plans to step up the attack, pumping an additional $ 15 million into its ad budget this year, for a total of $ 70 million.Meanwhile, Reebok said it plans to buy up 21.3 percent of its outstanding common stock for $ 396 million. As part of the deal, Pentland Group PLC will reduce its stake in Reebok to 13 percent from 31.6 percent.
email_title: Sporting goods firms expect OK year

Email_Body: JUST when we thought the "Chicken Ryckman" saga had mercifully come to an end, we get a letter from B.C. Lions owner Murray Pezim."As you know," the letter begins, "I have recently been engaged in a war of words with (Calgary Stamps owner) Larry Ryckman about the Danny Barrett trade. In the heat of the moment, I referred to not only Larry Ryckman as a chicken but his father Claude as well."When I called Claude Ryckman a chicken, I meant it figuratively and I certainly didn't mean for anyone to take this literally. Mr. Ryckman is not a chicken, he is a hog farmer. I sincerely apologize to Claude Ryckman for any embarrassment I may have caused him by the fowl language."We also received a copy of a letter sent to Pezim by Claude Ryckman, who asked that Pezim issue a retraction through the media. Contacted Thursday at his farm in Fort Assiniboine, Alta., Claude Ryckman said he hadn't yet received a copy of Pezim's letter and refused further comment.We also promise to refuse further comment on this story.JUST WEAR ITWhat to wear? What to wear?The U.S. Olympic Committee says it's got to be Reebok if the U.S. basketball team wins the gold and wants to attend the gold medal ceremony.Charles Barkley, Michael Jordan and several other members of the U.S. basketball team under contract toNikesay that's a problem."UsNikeguys are loyal toNikebecause they pay us a lot of money," Barkley said. "Nikepays us a ton of money. I have two-million reasons not to wear Reebok."
email_title: COLUMN ONE

Email_Body: ON WIMBLEDON'S elegant grass courts a grim multi-billion pound battle is being fought - but its takes a sharp eye to catch the action.Slogging it out are the mega-stars of the sporting world -Nike, Reebok, Adidas, Asics, Puma and LA Gear.Nikeis currently several sets ahead in the match for global market share. Wimbledon's cachet makes it the premier marketing event. The world sports shoe market is worth at least $ 18 billion (£10 million) in sales at wholesale level and tennis is probably 10% of that. Apparel sells for getting on for $ 30 billion and anything specifically tennis is hard to split out.But the sports goods companies go for clothing because the brand names are easier to detect on TV screens.Shoes are where the big money is made, however. Top-of-the-technology shoes cost at least $ 180 (£100) retail for those not lucky enough to be sponsored. Odds are those shoes left the factory gate in China, Taiwan or Indonesia for $ 18 - but there are lot of men in the middle including 10% for customs.The US buys most, at around $ 6 billion wholesale, followed by Europe's $ 3 billion. Of that Britain takes $ 0.6 billion.Rankings followed anxiously by the industry are those compiled by Pennsylvania-based John Horan's Sporting Goods Intelligence. He placesNikeas number one seed with $ 2.3 billion sales of footwear, followed by Reebok with $ 1.8 billion. In the USNikejumped from 28.6% to 29.8% in market share last year, while Reebok moved from 21.3% to 22.8%.Tough marketing programmes run by these two are, according to John Horan, 'knocking the daylights out of Adidas'. Its clout has been shrinking.Last year, says Horan, Adidas did well, gaining US market share, from 3.3% to 3.5% - although this was a slower rate of growth than the top two.  Sales are now $ 1.1 billion.This year Adidas, in the uncertain hands of French socialist millionaire Bernard Tapie, has been losing match points. With Tapie laden with debt, money for marketing seems to be missing.'That is why everyone is waiting for Pentland to take all of Adidas,' says Horan, referring to market speculation that Pentland is just waiting in wings to add dramatically to its 20% stake with a bid for Tapie's 55% shareholding.'That will really toughen the competition. At the moment it is all the smaller names that are benefiting from Adidas's struggles,' Horan adds.Coming up are Puma, Keds, Ellesse, Fila and K-Swiss. Slipping down the league of smaller companies are LA Gear, New Balance, Etonic, Converse and British Knights and Pony.But the scene has been changing rapidly this season.Armed with £400 million from selling out of Reebok, Pentland boss Stephen Rubin has been able to pick and choose with whom he wants to do business.The new alliances to watch are those with LA Gear (with whom Pentland does the sourcing and a 6% stake), and Ellesse (for whom Pentland sources all footwear). At the cheaper end of the market Pentland owns the Pony brand.For the puntersNikehas fallen from $ 77 this year to $ 56 on a profit warning. Reebok, too, has just issued a warning.Pentland sold out at $ 26-5/8 - the price is now $ 22-5/8. It bought into LA Gear at $ 11, currently it is $ 13.Pentland itself is still moving ahead - on hopes of a bargain bid for Adidas.

Email_Body: MAJOR DENIES DECISIONBY UK TO BACK DELORSThe United Kingdom government has still not decided whether to back Jacques Delors for a second term as European Commission president, U.K. Prime Minister John Major said Tuesday.Mr. Major denied newspaper reports the government had made a tacit agreement that Mr. Delors should be reappointed despite fierce opposition from many Conservative members of Parliament.He confirmed that when the U.K. takes over the European Community's rotating presidency between July and December, it will promote an examination of the principle of "subsidiarity" - the idea that decisions in the EC should be made nationally or locally rather than at the EC center if this is more apt.  CITIBANK BOMB THREATSFUEL CONCERN IN TAIWANTAIPEI, Taiwan - Police searched Citibank's four Taiwan branches Tuesday in the latest in a series of bombings or threats involving U.S. companies and possibly related to trade tension with Washington.Citibank's local headquarters received threatening telephone calls Saturday and again Monday, but a police search turned up nothing, a bank spokesman told The Journal of Commerce.A series of explosions in several McDonald's restaurants in Taipei killed one person and injured four in late April. The bombings and subsequent threats to Kentucky Fried Chicken outlets forced both restaurants to close for several days.The most recent threats may be related to anger over U.S. trade policy with Taiwan. Anti-American sentiment rose when the U.S. Trade Representative placed Taiwan on its priority watch list for inadequate protection of intellectual property rights.Washington removed Taiwan from the list last month after Taipei agreed to U.S. demands to increase protection. Critics here assailed the government's move as a climb down, and several industries say they face ruin. JAPANESE BEER, MADEIN US, TO HIT MICH.Ginjikomi, the new Japanese draft beer, will be available in Michigan by the end of the month. The beer, brewed by New York-based Sapporo USA, was introduced in the United States six months ago. NIKETO TAKE CONTROLOF SWISS DISTRIBUTIONBEAVERTON, Ore. -NIKEInc., the sports and fitness company, announced plans to add Switzerland to the list of countries where the company directly controls distribution rights to theNIKEbrand.NIKE, based here, will assume rights from the current independent distributor effective Jan. 1, 1993.NIKEproducts have been sold in Switzerland since 1978 through Sevysa SA, an independent distributor based near Lausanne. LIGHT-INDUSTRIAL PARKSET FOR LHASA, TIBET LHASA, Tibet - A small, light-industrial park, which will be open to overseas investors, is being constructed in Lhasa by the regional government and the Ministry of Light Industry, officials said.Some 10 million yuan (US$ 1.8 million) will be spent this year on roads and water and electricity supply. Five factories to produce woolen carpets, packaging products, paper, plastics and beverages will be the first to be launched.
email_title: TRADE BRIEFS

Email_Body: ALAN Davidson is the first player to argue about being selected as the Herald-SunNikeAir player-of-the-week.His performance when Melbourne Croatia fought back from a goal down to beat Wollongong Macedonia 2-1 at the weekend earned rave reviews from the media and he was the automatic choice for the weekly award.But the veteran Socceroo was reluctant to accept. "I felt I worked hard, but the game was marred by a strong wind and didn't lend itself to outstanding performances," he said."It was my first outing in midfield, but it turned into a game for defences having to cope with long balls. All we did in the middle of the park was battle."Although the team won praise for its battling performance, new Melbourne Croatia coach Ken Worden was less than satisfied.He says most of the players have to lift their game by 15 per cent.Davidson was among those targeted. He was told he did an adequate job but more was expected of him because of his achievements and experience."He told me I've played at just about every level and expected more of me," Davidson said."If I accept the award, there'll be no end of ribbing in the dressing room this week." Worden might have been critical in the dressing room, but he agreed Davidson deserved the award."He was the orchestrator in a good team effort," Worden."He is not just a hard worker or marker, his experience and confidence and knowledge of the game allowed for a good steady job." As Davidson continues to produce on the field, he is already preparing for a post-playing career in the game.He is doing coaching courses and enjoys being involved in the media with a column in the Sunday Sun."It has given me the chance to air my views, but it has also been a real education to find out how the press works," he said.As the weekly winner, Davidson collects a pair ofNikeAir runners valued at $280. He also collects votes towards the end of season award.The season's winner collects $2000 fromNike.Herald-SunNikeAir Golden Boot award.Round 13 Votes: South Melb v Marconi: 3 Okon (m), 2 Petersen (sm), 1 Nastevski (m). Apia v Woll City: 2 Okon (al), 1 M.Brown (al), 1 Kuc (wc), 1 Bate (wc), 1 Hughes (al). Woll Mac v Melb Cro: 3 Davidson (mc), 2 Donnelly (mc), 1 Cavanah (wm). Adelaide C v Melita: 3 Cerro (me), 2 T.Vidmar (ac), 1 Callanan (me). Syd Oly v Preston: 3 Phillips (so), 2 Edwards (so), 1 Jackson (pm). Syd Cro v Heidelberg: 2 Herd (h), 2 Petkovic (scr), 1 Gibson (scr), 1 Rizopoulos (h). Sunshine v St Geo: 3 Clarkson (sgc), 2 Hasler (sgc), 1 O'Shea (stg).Leaders: 17 Filan. 14 Petersen. 12 Petkovic. 11 Bundalo, Clarkson, Kindtner, P Okon, Stubbins.10 McCulloch. 9 Durakovic, Jackson, Krslovic, Lowe, Spink. 8 Blagojevic, Gimenez, Kuc, Tapai. 7 Davidson, C Foster, Ivanovic, McPherson, Yankos.END OF STORY
email_title: Reluctant hero gets points

Email_Body: If it were up to him, Boston's Reggie Lewis would wear Celtic-green suede basketball sneakers on the court instead of black.Then again, color is of little concern to the 6-7 swingman. ''It's not the color of the shoe,'' says Lewis, who looks for comfort and fit, ''it's the individual that makes the shoe.''If that individual is Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls, then wearing black on the court has ramifications beyond basketball. It becomes a fashion statement.Since Jordan and the Bulls started the trend three years ago in the playoffs, sales of black shoes have skyrocketed. Numerous college and high school teams wear them.All the major companies -Nike,Reebok, Converse and adidas - report major increases in sales of black sneakers. AtNike,black shoes account for 75% of sales; at Converse, 60%.''It's an all-time high,'' saysNike'sDusty Kidd.Thirty of Converse's 54 models are offered in black, says spokesman Mickey Bell.Black sneakers aren't limited to basketball. Even tennis, long stifled by ultraconservative dress codes, tolerates dark footwear on pros such as Andre Agassi.Manufacturers have gone to great lengths to make black sneakers, long considered clunky-looking in basketball, sleeker.''The thing that makes (today's black sneakers) look faster is the silhouette,'' says Kidd, adding that color accents and space-age designs make shoes appear ''more aggressive.''Says Kidd: ''With some guys, they're so quick that no color is going to make them look slow.''
email_title: Black shoe sales lace up top spot

Email_Body: IN the heart of Chicago's Michigan Avenue shopping district, theNikeTown building looks as tranquil as the Saks Fifth Avenue store it once housed.Then you pass through the revolving doors. New Age music is playing, mixed with the tape-recorded clamor of playoff crowds. Banners hanging from the ceiling read: Performance, Technology, Innovation. And then, through a set of automated black doors (like any astronaut or aquanaut, one must enter this world gradually), you arrive in 68,000 square feet of museum exhibits, aquariums, video theaters and athletic photography. And half a basketball court.This, you have to remind yourself, is a shoe store.NikeInc., the Beaverton, Ore., sport-shoe concern, can well afford its audacity. With annual revenues of $3.4 billion last year, the company has made its name with celebrity endorsements and irreverent ad campaigns. Three years ago,Nikeexecutives decided to break from the company's history of modest retail outlets to gather all their wares under a single roof -- in effect, to jam every method of image enhancement into a box and see what happened.The first experiment was a small-scale store in Portland, Ore., which opened in November 1990. The Chicago store, more than three times its size, is the concept's real test. It opened on July 2.Walking along the manhole-dotted "streets" ofNikeTown Chicago, you soon get lost between big design concepts and impressive details. Everything you see bears the mark ofNike'scorporate mythology.There are the Greek-style friezes of athletes in action on the facade, and life-size plaster statues of mountain bikers are suspended from wires in the three-story atrium. There are door handles in the shape ofNike's"swoosh" logo and museumlike placards that tell the legend of Bill Bowerman, aNikefounder. One day in 1971, so the story goes, Mr. Bowerman, a University of Oregon track coach, got it into his head during breakfast to pour latex into a waffle iron and thus discovered the waffle-soled shoe.There's also the maple basketball court, where you can test sneakers (but not play ball) beneath a 35-foot picture of Michael Jordan and a quotation from William Blake.Scattered around the entire store, in fact, are "inspiration boards" bearing abstract messages: "You get up in the morning, early. You think about your run. Anticipation is your first stretch. Then you go."On the store's 12th day of operation, though, no one seemed to be doing much reading. There were shinier objects to examine, notably the nine-screen video floor in the aquatic apparel section, where crowds gathered to gaze down at a film of sharks, drifting seaweed and sand washing over conch shells."I am not sure I understand," said a Norwegian tourist. "Is this to be walked upon?"A young salesman, Patrick Roach, stepped up to prove the floor's strength by holding an elderly woman's hand as she gingerly stepped onto the video sea. "You get the best effect if you're on top of it," Mr. Roach said, picking his way around customers who were trying on sandals. "It's really very safe."While tourists stopped to pose with the octopuses in the video underfoot, Mr. Roach typed a stock number into a sober black computer terminal. Next to it stood a wide clear-plastic tube flooded with emerald-green light. Two minutes later, he opened the door of the tube and found a pair of sandals.InNikeTown, you are never more than a few steps from these big tubes, which are actually miniature state-of-the-art elevator systems.. They run from every selling area to the stock area on the fourth floor, the functional heart ofNikeTown. There, burly men sprint between shelves of orange and black boxes, pluck out the required shoes and feed them into the system."If those tubes remind you of 'The Jetsons,' it's no coincidence," said Gordon Thompson 3d,Nike'sdesign director. "The transport system is actually a modified Spacely Sprockets idea."Mr. Thompson's role in the project, he said, involved everything from devising floor layouts to color-coordinating the tropical fish in a 22-foot-long aquarium with the shoes that sit on the rack in front of it."My job is to be a sort of film director, and this store tells a story," he said. "It's a mythology, but one for a range of consumers, people who are 7, 27 and 67. What we've done is taken one theme, athletics, and pulled it in every conceivable direction. I like to think it's part 1939 World's Fair and part theater. But I guess the bottom line is, it's a store."It's easy to lose sight of that fact. Still, to match the surfeit of design, there's a staggering amount of merchandise. There are all-condition jackets, Lycra shorts, beach shoes called aqua socks, running socks, trekking socks, cycling socks, aerobic socks, cross-training socks and every kind of sport shoe imaginable. Items are organized by sport so you can, for example, do all your tennis shopping in one feverish wave.And how much did this store costNike?Executives declined to discuss the subject, commonly joking that it cost "more than Michael Jordan's championship ring," but one employee said the price tag was around $34 million.InNikeTown's plush video theater, a few dozen people clustered to watch an endless loop of footwear commercials. Two young executives danced in the back of the room to John Lennon's "Instant Karma," but a Tulsa couple's eyes never left the screen.Four towheaded children sat in a row on the floor. While two of them peeled off to buy posters of Andre Agassi, the two who remained cheered when a Spike Lee commercial forNikecame on. Then with the precision of a Gilbert and Sullivan patter song, they recited the words of the ad with Mr. Lee: "The mo' colors, the mo' better," they chanted. "Peace!"GRAPHIC:Photo: AtNikeTown Chicago, shoppers can test sneakers on a basketball court featuring a 35-foot photograph of Michael Jordan and a quotation from William Blake. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)
email_title: OUT THERE: CHICAGO;Jock Citadel

Email_Body: Sporting goods wholesalers and retailers have defended theprices of recreation footwear despite some brands being tippedto hit the $400 mark next year.Liberal MP Dorothy Kotz claims the prices are an "exploitationof the youth market".But the Office of Fair Trading has said it has no control overthe multi-million-dollar industry.The claims of exploitation come as the sports footwear warintensifies between the two US-based giantsNikeand Reebok,Tipped to hit $400 markThree leading brands of sports shoes - Reebok (above), LA Gear(below) and Puma (bottom) ... prices can vary as much as $40from shop to shop, according to the Australian Consumers Associationwhich collectively account for $160 million in sporting gearsales in Australia. The Office of Fair Trading said there was no price controlover sports footwear in a "free market where consumers canshop around"."Only if a situation arose where there was price-fixing byagreement could any action be taken," an Office of Fair Tradingspokesman said.Mrs Kotz said a Prices Surveillance Authority inquiry in tothe "exorbitant" price of sporting footwear should be launchedbefore prices went any higher."They have done it in the music industry in regard to tapesand CDs and they should it with sports shoes," Mrs Kotz said.Her complaints come as the recreation footwear pushes up throughthe $300 mark with speculation a $400 pair ofNikeshoes willbe released next year.SA's leading sporting goods retailer, Rowe and Jarman, saidyesterday footwear now accounted for 50 per cent of its sales.Store manager and ex-football star Paul Weston said the marginon sporting footwear was "very small indeed."He blamed government duty and quota charges on the high costof Reebok andNikewear.Top of the lineNikeand Reebok sports shoes are between $179and $280 a pair.Both brands are made in Taiwan and Korea. NikeAustralian distri- butor is John D Trading in Melbourne. Managingdirector MrTony Peddie said yesterday about 80 per cent was placed on thecost of the shoes through government charges before they weredistributed to the retailer."There is a 100 per cent cost on the shoes by the time theyget to the stores," Mr Peddie said."That is due to $7 a pair in quota costs and 45 per cent induty. After that there is a freighting and administration costs."'Monopolisingthe market'It was established yesterday a pair ofNikesin Britain costsless than the wholesale price of a pair of the same shoes soldin Australia. A pair of (original) Reebok sports shoes can bebought in Seoul for $59 but will cost more than a $100 in Adelaide."This is the same situation we had in regard to taped andCD music," Mrs Kotz said. "And the PSA looked in to that toget the price down."Mrs Kotz was highly critical of footwear companies targetingyouth "who already are under peer pressure to buy and wearthe best in sports shoes.""They are being manipulated into buying high price productswith slick marketing and certain brands are monopolising themarket and pushing the prices higher." In a sampling taken yesterday atthree city storesNikeAirTrainers were selling at $227, Reebok Court Victory Pump wereselling at $259, with Air Jordans -Nike'sbiggest seller -on special at $199.It was claimed by retailers profit margins were almost negligible.However the Australian Consumers' Association in its runningshoes survey checked prices in all Australian capitals and foundvariations, mark-downs and specials on bothNikeand Reebokto vary as much as $40 a pair."It is unilkely the retailers will sell these shoes at a lossso there is a considerable mark-up," said ACA media spokesmanMr Geoff Sirmai.
email_title: Tipped to hit $400 mark MP calls for inquiry into shoe;prices

Email_Body: Hanson PLC, Britain's largest industrial conglomerate, is buying British construction group Beazer PLC in a $ 609 million (U.S.) deal.Hanson said yesterday it will offer $ 1.56 in cash and one new Hanson warrant for each Beazer ordinary share in Britain and $ 6.26 in cash and four Hanson warrants for each Beazer American Depositary Receipt. The ADRs represent four Beazer shares."Our long-term faith in the construction industry is bolstered by our belief that we have reached the bottom of its current cycle of recession, and we look forward to developing Beazer's well-established businesses alongside our own," Lord Hanson, chairman of Hanson, said in a statement. Hanson, one of Britain's 10 biggest companies, is a trans-Atlantic conglomerate with interests ranging from Smith-Corona typewriters to Jacuzzi whirlpool baths.Beazer is one of Britain's largest house builders, with interests in real estate development. The company also has interests in major building projects and open cast mining.In the United States, Beazer is the largest producer of sand and gravel, with operations in hot mix asphalt, concrete products and ready-mixed concrete.Nikesets recordNikeInc., the worldwide athletic footwear and apparel maker, says its first-quarter profit of $ 114.4 million (U.S.) has set a world record in the sports and fitness industry.It is the first time any company in the industry made more than $ 100 million in a single quarter,Nikeexecutives said.Chairman Phil Knight said in a news release, "We have built a global brand franchise and we believe that this quarter's results prove it is possible to be both the best and the biggest."Earnings for the three months ended Aug. 31, which translated to $ 1.50 per share, were up 15 per cent from $ 99.6 million, or $ 1.31 per share, a year earlier, the Beaverton, Ore.-based company reported.Nike'sexpansion in Europe led a 14 per cent growth in company revenues to a record $ 947.2 million from $ 833.6 million a year earlier.Remarks hurt RatnersRatners Group PLC, owners in the United States of Kay and Sterling jewelry stores, has posted its first half-year loss in five years, blaming the poor results partly on disparaging comments made by the retailer's chairman about his company.The company posted a pre-tax loss of $ 30.66 million (U.S.) in the six months ended Aug. 3, on sales of $ 780.7 million. That compares with profit of $ 16.1 million on sales of $ 642.4 million for the same period last year.Chairman Gerald Ratner's widely publicized comment that some of his company's products were "crap" hurt his company's sales and its image in the marketplace, analysts said.Delta deal clearedThe European Community's executive body has cleared Delta Air Lines' proposed takeover of Pan American World Airways' trans-Atlantic routes.Under the deal, Atlanta-based Delta has proposed acquiring Pan Am assets that include routes between the United States and Europe and its hub in Frankfurt, Germany.Pan Am, which is in bankruptcy court, hopes to sell the routes to get cash for creditors as part of a plan that would keep Pan Am alive as a smaller carrier based in Miami and focusing on Latin American routes.The European Commission said it found that the asset sale would not create "a dominant position as a result of which effective competition would be significantly impeded in the common market or a substantial part of it."Mercedes eyes PorscheMercedes-Benz AG chairman Werner Niefer says his company is "for now thinking about" taking a stake in German sportscar maker Porsche AG, but has not yet done so, an Austrian radio station official confirmed.Niefer made the remark in response to a question by a reporter for the Austrian state radio, based in Vienna.Porsche, a closely held German company based in Stuttgart, has said its group sales fell in the fiscal year ended July 31.German media have circulated reports that potential partners, including Volkswagen AG and Mercedes-Benz, are prepared to buy stock in the company to help it overcome financial hurdles.
