Email_Body: Voters in the Meramec Valley School District will be asked on June 4 to increase the district's tax rate by 48 cents for each $100 of assessed valuation.  The money would be used for operating expenses and to pay for salary increases for teachers, said Superintendent Edward Hillhouse. The proposal needs a simple majority to pass. The district is mainly in eastern Franklin County, with small parts in St. Louis and Jefferson counties.  The district's tax rate last year was $2.23. If passed, the increase would add $45.60 to the school tax bill of the owner of a house worth $50,000.  Hillhouse said the increase is needed to hire two teachers at Coleman school and a part-time kindergarten teacher atNikeSchool.  The district also wants to install a computer lab at Robertsville School and to buy new reading series for pupils in kindergarten through third grade.  Hillhouse said the district is considering a bid of $69,000 for the series from Houghten and Mifflin Inc.  Some of the money would be used for teacher salary increases. Teachers will not be getting a raise in the next school year, Hillhouse said.  The district also wants to consider expanding counseling services, he said.  Hillhouse said the district's last operating tax increase occurred 17 years ago. In that time, voters have approved two bond issues, one seven years ago for $3 million and the other three years ago for $3.1 million. Hillhouse said that money went to build Truman School andNikeSchool and for renovations at existing schools.  Hillhouse said each school has been promoting the tax proposal.  ''Everybody I've talked to has said they're with us,'' Hillhouse said.  ''We've received no organized opposition.''
email_title: DISTRICT WILL SEEK 48 TAX INCREASE

Email_Body: Just like people, more companies are using physical fitness to stay in good shape.The growing trend toward the sponsorship of fitness-related events points to a healthy desire by Canadian companies to raise their profiles among conscious consumers.''The growth in sponsorship reflects a trend through the 1980s, when the public was becoming more aware of fitness,'' says Graham Fraser, owner of TriSport Promotions Inc. of Grimsby, Ont., a promoter of triathlon events across the country. ''Ten years ago, most of our sponsors wouldn't have talked to us. Now they like to sell the fact they're associated with a fitness-related event.'' In some cases, boosting exposure through spectator or participant sports is a natural.Athletic-wear companies, such asNikeInc., have developed multimillion-dollar advertising campaigns featuring professional athletes like football and baseball star Bo Jackson and basketball player Michael Jordan to win over aspiring athletes across the continent.Regionally, smaller promotional events, such as community coaching clinics and local sporting events, bring the corporate message closer to consumers.''The big, international sponsorships are well known, but we try to bring to make the brand more personal by sponsoring local events, too,'' says Roy Agostino, promotions co-ordinator forNikeCanada Ltd.'s Eastern region.''This is the bread-and-butter of our business,'' says Murray Souter, vice-president of marketing at Toronto-based Reebok Canada, a division of Avrecan International Inc. ''It's much like automakers sponsoring pro car racing - we need to be involved.''For such companies, athletic sponsorships take on a practical quality. By providing top-flight athletes with their product, the shoe companies get wear-testing data and free expert design input in return.But for others, the connection isn't so apparent.In 1990, for example, Royal LePage Real Estate Services Ltd. spent more than $500,000 on sponsorship of a nationwide triathlon series in conjunction with Reebok, Toshiba and other sponsors, and plans to continue its association with the sport for another three years.COMMON THEMEMoncton-based Cavendish Farms sponsors a junior ski-racing program at selected resorts across the country; McKenzie Financial Corp. in Toronto does the same at Ontario resorts.And Crown Life Insurance Co. sponsors the Participaction Challenge, in which more than four million Canadians register 15 minutes of physical activity on a specified date each year.Emphasizing their commitment to local communities is a common theme among corporate sponsors.''As an insurance company, we like people to be well,'' says Barry Francis, assistant vice-president of corporate communications at Crown Life, which spends about $500,000 on the event annually. ''But it's also a great way to enhance the image of the company. Our representatives get a higher profile in the communities where they live and work.''While the public-relations aspect of promoting a healthy clientele can'tbe underestimated, few sponsors would deny that they're cashing in on the high-profile nature of sports. In most cases, decision-makers look for well-advertised events with high attendance figures to get the most bang for their buck.NOTHING IN STONEAnd when considering a fitness-related sponsorship, few firms will take the initiative and organize an event on their own. In most cases, the sport's national association, or a promotional company like TriSport, takes care of the organization, advertising, and promotion, while the company provides the funding.Though companies will often maintain an association with a particular event for several years, the value of their commitment is rarely written in stone, Fraser says. Given the current recession, therefore, some athletic events may see the level of sponsorship drop considerably over the next year.''One of the first things to go when times get tough is usually discretionary spending, and sponsorship often fits into that category,'' Fraser points out. ''Some companies may find it hard to justify spending a lot of money on sponsorship, but they'll still want the exposure. It'll be a tough time for anyone just getting into the game.''
email_title: FITNESS IMPROVES FIRMS' FIGURES: Sponsorship ties products to health

Email_Body: Robert Van Kampen returned to the securities business two weeks ago with the purchase of the unit investment trust operation of Clayton Brown & Associates.  Van Kampen, who built one of the top unit trust businesses at Van Kampen Merritt, is expected to quickly add other product lines to his new firm,NikeSecurities. Van Kampen confirmed last month that he was holding advanced talks on the acquisition of the First Trust funds with his former partner, Clayton Brown (IDD 9/2).In a written statement,NikeSecurities said almost all Clayton Brown employees in that division would be moving over toNike.  James Bowen, head of Clayton Brown's unit investment trust business, will continue to run the group forNike.Clayton Brown has sponsored over $ 6 billion in First Trust funds, but that market share has slipped in recent years.  Industry officials said Robert Van Kampen's extensive distribution contacts with regional broker-dealers will be the key to growing the business.The purchase puts Mr. Van Kampen into direct competition with the firm that still bears hits name, Van Kampen Merritt.  If the competition does heat up, both firms will be able to keep an eye on each other.
email_title: Robert Van Kampen closes deal for unit trust firm

Email_Body: Barbie heaven's come to Madison Avenue.An all-Barbie shop, opening here today at FAO Schwarz, is the largest collection of Barbie-o-rama under one roof. The boutique packs 1,500 square feet of everything Barbie: dolls, doll outfits, children's clothes, books, pencils, backpacks, cosmetics, etc. Barbie on Madison is the latest in a string of one-brand retail stores, known in the trade as designer stores. Some are company-owned. Some have a retailing partner. Barbie on Madison is owned and operated by FAO Schwarz.''Barbie has reached classic status,'' says Donna Gibbs of Mattel, maker of Barbie. ''One of the keys to Barbie's success has been the expansion beyond just dolls. We want to show just how much there is to Barbie.'' Other designer stores:-NikeTown.Nike'ssecond store opened this summer in Chicago. Inside: gear for 20 sports. ''The Chicago store, which is 60,000 square feet, lets us show our entire collection. No retail store has the space to do that,'' says Melinda Gable ofNike.Store No. 3 opens next year in Costa Mesa, Calif.- Sony Gallery of Consumer Electronics. Sony's three-story museum like store in Chicago once housed a Saks Fifth Avenue department store. Now it's nothing but Sony. ''This store is almost educational. We want consumers to come in, see all that there is and walk away picturing it in their homes, their cars, their offices,'' says spokesman Rick Clancy.- Levi's. Dropped by Gap stores last year, Levi's has been testing three of its own stores. Two more open this winter in New York and in the Mall of America in Minneapolis.What's next? Any hot brand is a candidate, says Michael Gade, consultant at Coopers & Lybrand: ''Lego might be a good choice. Or Batman. Or maybe Dracula will turn into something big. If you have a strong brand, you can use a retail store to create more excitement. Seeing all the products displayed in one store can get a customer to say 'Wow.' ''
email_title: Now Barbie has her own store

Email_Body: Up in Goat Park, the legend picks glass off the concrete, chides a grown man for urinating against the fence, listens solemnly to an invitation to come to the Columbia University gym tonight and pick up an award."What for?" "You're a legend," says an older man. "We call it the Golden Hoops First Playground Legend Award.""Who's the second?""That's next year, be somebody else."The legend, Earl (the Goat) Manigault, sighs. He's 47 years old, broke and dying. He needs money for his tournament and a heart transplant for himself. He watches a covey of teen-age Michael Jordan clones, shaven heads, baggy shorts,Nikeshoes, pad onto his court."You should ask Michael for money," I say."Ask him to look at my tape, read my proposal and help me," says Manigault. His eyes poke into distant corners of his park. "We're helping him, all these bald heads andNikes.Look at me." He points down at his whiteNikes."Was looking for Converse, but all's I could find around here size 13.""So, you gonna be there?" asks the Golden Hoops man.Manigault shrugs. A second team of Michael clones arrives to play the first. The courts, officially in the Happy Warrior Park, are off Amsterdam Avenue in Manhattan, between 98th and 99th streets, nestled among apartment buildings packed with players. This has been Goat Park since the early 1970's, when Manigault began his youth tournaments, first hustling drug dealers for shirts, trophies and referees, later soliciting foundation grants.This year's tournament, 13 teams, something more than 100 youngsters, is one of the smallest because it began late, and tentatively; it seemed unlikely that Manigault, his heart irrevocably damaged by drugs, alcohol, street living, jail, would see summer. Last winter, after the Columbia-Presbyterian Transplant Unit rejected him as a poor medical and social risk, Manigault was weak and barely coherent. It seemed as though only the legend was left.Uptown, it is still a powerful legend of a teen-age prodigy who could pick dimes off a backboard, who dunked over Kareem when Kareem was still Lew Alcindor; a 6-foot-1-inch guard who could control anything on the court and nothing off it. He didn't stay in college and he didn't make the pros. He became famous for failure, an easy metaphor for the dark side of the city game, where the best are often the most self-destructive."I'm not into the Dream Team," says Manigault. "It's not right. Should be amateur. I could pull one or two players off every block around here, go to the Olympics and win a gold medal.""That's the urban myth," I say."That's the word," says Manigault.He moves off to get the first game started and disappears into the late afternoon swirl of Goat Park, 12-year-old fans, old men, babies, winos, players, hustlers, a pulse that helped bring him back to life.He has also had remarkable friends. A Princeton professor, Stephen F. Cohen, has been a fierce lobbyist for more than 20 years, and the foundation head, Walter Naegle, has fed and housed him. They found the city apartment he now shares with his two grown sons.A young cardiology fellow at Bellevue, Dr. Mimi Guarneri, "tuned up" Manigault this year. He is now being seriously considered for a heart by the transplant unit at Mount Sinai, he says."This is his challenge now," says Ray Diaz, a 29-year-old record company executive who learned the game as a youngster in this tournament. "It's his second life. The future is not about keeping up the legend but about helping the kids."The Golden Hoops man is getting impatient: "You gonna be there?""This is what he has to deal with all the time," says Diaz, who starred in high school, college, and the Puerto Rican pro leagues. He has his own tournament now. "How does one be a legend? He's worth a million dollars and he doesn't have a dime."Manigault nods to the Golden Hoops man. He'll be there, he says. He turns back to the game to watch its star, Patrice Casimer of the nearby Franciscan Community Youth Center, a compact point guard with presence. Patrice is going into his senior year at Cardinal Hayes High School. He is being recruited by colleges and drug dealers."We're working on Patrice's game and head," says Alex Achille, the center's director and a former Goat tournament player. "A lot of drug dealers want him to play on their teams.""Why is that bad?" I ask."What's the point of all this," says Achille, "if a 10-year-old kid is looking up to a dealer?"Manigault drifts by. "The dealers I came up with are all dead or doing big time," he says. "I don't know these new kids.""You wouldn't take their money?" I ask."I said I didn't know them; I didn't say I woudn't take their money." He smiles slyly. "I just wouldn't go ask 'em.""Money from Michael is our next big move," says Diaz. "Spike Lee will get us to Michael, who's got to be thinking movies next, right? He needs that first credible role. We got the script. Who else should play Earl, but Michael, right?"The legend nods.
email_title: BASKETBALL;The Word From the Goat Park Legend: 'I'm Not into the Dream Team'

Email_Body: IT IS understandable that Michael Jordan, the most identifiable man in American sport, would find it a little disconcerting to see his face slapped on the chest of almost every man, mother and child in the US.So the emperor of US professional basketball has issued a new edict about clothing.From March 31, no one, absolutely no one, will be able to put Jordan's face or name on any form of souvenir unless it isNike, the world's largest manufacturer of sporting apparel. Not even the NBA, which will be restricted to selling Jordan's No.23 Chicago Bulls shirt because team uniforms are the property of the NBA and not the individual player.It is not surprising that Jordan has finally called an end to the liberal use of his image and name which left Chicago in a sea of Jordan T-shirts after their title victory last year.And if the personal reasons are not enough, the financial ones are certainly worth considering.Jordan makes a mere $4.22 million from playing basketball. He collects more than $30 milllion selling a variety of products ranging from Wheaties, Hanes underwear to McDonald's food, Gatorade and the Illinois state lottery. Nikelast year sold more than $300 million in goods featuring Jordan and will make a great deal more after March 31.Now at the NBA, there are mutters of discontent. They say he has now "effectively separated" himself from the league, making himself bigger than the game.Unlike the other US professional sports - ice hockey, football and baseball - the NBA does not give a player a percentage of the profits made from souvenirs.The NBA made $90 million in profits from souvenirs last season and returned the favor by handing just $A680,000 to the player pension fund.ButNikemakes a financial promise to Jordan."Every piece we sell," saysNikepresident Dick Donahue, "Jordan gets a piece of."This is not a Jordan issue; it's a persona issue."NBA lawyer Gary Bettman says: "I suppose we'll feel an economic impact from this." "Our primary business is the sale of uniforms," he said. "And our best seller has been and will continue to be the Bulls jersey with (Jordan's) No. 23 on it." - MICHELANGELO RUCCIEND OF STORYGRAPHIC:Deadline . . . Micheal Jordan andNikeare tightening their grip onthe star's line of clothing.
email_title: NEW RULES FOR JORDAN

Email_Body: Bob Devaney, one of the most recognized figures at the University of Nebraska since his arrival as football coach in 1962, says he is bitter with the manner in which he was led to retirement after 31 years of service to the state. Devaney, who will step down Jan. 5 as athletic director, said he also feels bitter about the manner in which his replacement, Bill Byrne, was selected. ''I was hoping I could work a little longer,'' Devaney said.  GOOD NEWS: Jockey Kent Desormeaux was released from Centinela Hospital Medical Center in Inglewood, Calif., Wednesday - five days after sustaining several small skull fractures in a fall at Hollywood Park. After his release, Desormeaux headed to Arcadia Methodist Hospital, where his wife, Sonya, gave birth to the couple's first child, 4-pound, 1-ounce Joshua Jason. Desormeaux could be back riding in 4-6 weeks. SHOE WARS: A patent infringement lawsuit has been settled byNikeInc. and Avia Group International, the shoe makers announced Thursday. Avia filed the lawsuit in 1991, charging thatNike's''Air 180'' and ''Air Force 180'' running and basketball shoes infringed on Avia patents.Nikeresponded that one of its patents was infringed by several Avia athletic shoes. Neither company would discuss terms of the settlement. GREEN FEES: Charitable contributions from the PGA Tour, Senior PGA Tour and Ben Hogan Tour reached a record $ 29 million this year, it was announced Thursday by the PGA Tour. DOWN UNDER: Three Australians led the way Thursday in the first round of the $ 2.7 million World Championship of golf at Montego Bay, Jamaica. Craig Parry shot 2-under-par 68 for the lead. Greg Norman and Peter O'Malley shared second at 71. DURAN WINS: Four-time world champion Roberto Duran (87-9) stopped journeyman Ken Hulsey (16-8) with a hard left to the ribs Thursday in the second round of a scheduled 10-round middleweight fight in Cleveland. BOUNCED: From Vermont to Nevada, college basketball underwent changes in 1992.
email_title: TIME TO GO

Email_Body: ANiketennis shoe found in a garbage can days after the slayings of two University of Florida students could have made the imprints found on one victim's neck, an expert witness testified Tuesday.     The marks left on the neck of Eleanor Anne Grace, 20, indicate the shoe was repositioned at least once, said Florida Department of Law Enforcement crime lab analyst supervisor Ernest Hamm.     Carpet cleaner Alan Robert Davis, charged with killing Grace and her roommate Carla Marie McKishnie, 22, last June in their Casablanca West apartment, told investigators less than 48 hours after the killings that he knocked Grace unconscious after she sprayed him with Mace.      He said he strangled McKishnie before returning to Grace, who was found on the floor of an upstairs bathroom. McKishnie's body was found under a bed.     Dollar General cashier Debbie Hutchins said theNikeshoes seemed to be the ones she put in a bag for Davis, 30, after he bought a new pair of shoes June 6, 1991, the day the women were killed.     "He had the new shoes on. He had the old shoes in his hand," Hutchins said. "He asked me if I would put the shoes in a bag."     Alachua County sheriff's detective Robert Gaff said he and another detective retrieved those shoes from a garbage can outside the Dollar General on June 9, 1991.     Hamm, the crime lab analyst, said that although theNikeshoes could have made the marks, he couldn't guarantee the imprints came from that shoe.     Hamm told Circuit Judge Robert P. Cates that three fingerprints found in the bathroom sink match Davis' fingerprints and a palm print from the counter around the sink matched Davis' right palm print.     Assistant State Attorney Ralph Grabel said Davis' confession, along with testimony from the medical examiner who performed the autopsies, will be introduced as evidence today. He expects to complete his case today.
email_title: Imprint on victim's throat linked to shoe

Email_Body: Random observations from the wide, wide world of television sports: - Bo Jackson came through a television the other night. Walked right through the sucker in an effort to express his utter disgust with the medium, one supposes.  Of course, it wasn't real. It was merely another in a seemingly endless series of clever (and somewhat disturbing)Niketelevision commercials.  Do we know Bo in any other way?  Anyway, in this one Jackson spoofs his image (created in previous commercials, naturally) that he can do anything. In the middle of the spot, Bo walks off a lavish stage set, complete with musicians and beautiful back-up singers.  He walks right through a TV set into a living room, where he chides a little boy who is sitting there for watching too much television. He then heads to a gym where he is shown going about the difficult business of rehabilitating his career.  The career that exists outside of commercials, that is.  The message, presumably, is that what Bo is really all about is hard work and sweat, which is not exactly whatNikewas saying in its earlier ''Bo knows'' commercials. No, those implied that everything from hockey to rocket science came naturally to this wondrous athlete.  This time, there's work involved and since the product being advertised is something worn in weight rooms and gymnasiums, it makes sense to finally put Jackson in such a setting. The message about hard work was equally welcome and Tuesday's All-Star game was a great place for the spot to make its debut. But let's pause here for a healthy dose of cynicism. Bo Jackson chastising a kid for watching too much television? Bo Jackson telling us that image is not everything? Who's kidding who? Not that it is Jackson's fault, but no athlete has been dominated by his TV image more than Jackson. Jackson's pro sports career, as spectacular as it was in brief spurts, could not compete with Jackson's TV image.  Most athletes need to be at or near the top of their games to sustain a career in commercial endorsements. All Jackson had to do w as be Bo.  This advertisement is proof of that. Jackson has yet to play an inning - and may never play an inning - in a Chicago White Sox uniform, and yet his Sox uniform (stylishly black, of course) is featured prominently in this advertisement.  Bo does not have any White Sox RBIs, but he does have a White Sox image.  Thanks toNike.Of course, image is whatNikeis selling, every bit as much as sneakers.  Images perpetrated by TV commercials. Images consumed willingly by little kids (and big ones, too) who watch too much TV.  Should we listen to Bo and not watch so much TV and go out and ''just do it''? Or, should we just sit back and be overwhelmed by the amazing and attractive image of Bo?Nikeis telling us to do the former while cleverly enticing us to do the latter.
email_title: BO'S LATESTNIKECOMMERCIAL DELIVERS A MIXED MESSAGE

Email_Body: THERE are two works on tennis at the Royal Academy's Summer Exhibition. Turbo Tennis is a bronze girl with pigtails, racket and roller-skates. The other is a naive painting called Centre Court which bears no relation to Wimbledon.The same hand is responsible for the only rugby offering, World Cup Final, which has no sense of occasion or Twickenham - making two impostors, treated just the same. Perhaps the Kipling quote, reproduced at the entrance to the Centre Court, went to the artist's head. The exhibition also includes three works on football, two on cricket, one each on boxing and the London Marathon and, in the architectural section, the National Hockey Stadium at Milton Keynes. And that is all.It is uncertain which is more naive, the work or the hanging committee. But, when it comes to hanging, the committee is more deserving. There should be no surprise that sport is ill-represented. So is art. This is evidently the age of infant daub and abstract artifice.Yet Britain has a noble heritage in sporting art and now a minister of both and more. If the Summer Exhibition has sunk beyond the pale, where junk enough is hung in Piccadilly on Sundays, David Mellor has a clear opportunity to relax the tug-of-war between grant-seeking factions by setting up an exhibition of sporting art. He has only himself to persuade.SPAIN's peculiar trademark law is threatening to put a sock inNike'ssponsorship of the United States Olympic track and field team. An attorney owns theNikename in Spain, registered 60 years ago by a Barcelona sock maker.  Without his permission - and he shows no hurry to grant it for nothing - athletes cannot use the name.Nike(US) talk of "trademark piracy".Spanish laws used to permit anyone to register and renew a name simply by paying a fee, even without ever producing anything. Though the statutes were changed in 1988, registrants still do not have to prove they have an on-going business or product when filing an application. If the brand is not used in five years, a challenger must sue the trademark's owner, who then has three months to begin using the mark.In July 1990Nike(US) were issued a registration for their name but two Spanish courts have since upheld the earlier trademark. Though this applies only to sports apparel, not shoes,Nike(US) put potential sales losses at pounds 11 1/2 million in Spain and many times that worldwide. It does not help that their adversary is called Amigo.THERE may be something in rainbow sunglasses after all. Judging by appearances they fail wretchedly. But Richard Blakey, the first wicketkeeper to follow the fashion, is guarding against further migraine attacks. Several times previously he had been forced from the field. With the glasses he has had no trouble.On the other hand Martin McCague of Kent, trying them at Canterbury, failed to see the benefits or, apparently, the ball. After two misfields and the fumble of a simple catch, he sheepishly handed the things to the umpire John Holder.GOAL celebrations know no bounds in Brazil. After scoring the winner for Botafogo against Cruzeiro at the Maracana stadium Carlos Alberto Dias jumped on to a telephone booth behind goal, where he was mobbed by team-mates. The referee was not amused. He took Diaz's name, not to mention address and 'phone number.PRISONERS at Spain's Ocana jail near Toledo have been getting into the Olympic spirit by staging their own games. Nine nationalities are represented although Spain, with the largest team, are favourites to top the medals table.A prison official said that "sports incompatible with an enclosed area" were not in the programme. There is no pole vault.
email_title: EXTRA TIME: SIXTH COLUMN

Email_Body: SWOOSHThe Unauthorized Story ofNikeand the Men Who Played There.By J. B. Strasser and Laurie Becklund.Illustrated. 682 pp. New York:Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $24.95. ONCE upon a time, people did not jog. The very notion of lacing up hideously expensive sneakers to trot along the roadside at a sweat-breaking pace would simply never have occurred to the ordinary person.There were sports shoes, of course, manufactured by a handful of low-profile companies catering to professional and amateur athletes who ran track or played team sports. But for typical middle-class Americans, a complete sports-shoe wardrobe comprised a pair of tennis shoes, some golf shoes with parquet-marring cleats, and a pair of high-top sneakers for shooting baskets with the guys.Then, in the mid-1960's, something happened. Almost overnight, the loneliness of the long-distance runner was invaded by hordes of health-conscious converts to the runner's religion. Fad became frenzy: if you weren't jogging, you should have been jogging. And for the shoe business, the world turned upside down.Suddenly the sports footwear market became an arena worth fighting for. And fight the shoemakers did -- across national borders, with shifting alliances, by fair means and foul. Despite its inane title -- the "Swoosh" is the fat, lopsided chevron that isNike'strademark -- this is a lively and engrossing account of that battle, as told from the perspective of the men who fought to pushNikefrom nowhere to the front ranks of its industry.A raucous crew they were, too. A more accurate subtitle for the book would have been " 'Chariots of Fire' Meets 'Animal House.' "Nikeexecutives routinely punished themselves with grueling international travel, impossible production deadlines, constant financial anxiety -- and used alcohol as an ever-present anodyne. Marriages fell apart. People fell apart. Sometimes even the shoes fell apart. But the bombardment of the competition -- chiefly Adidas, the German running-shoe giant -- continued without so much as an occasional cease-fire. Ultimately, it was a war with few heroes and many, many casualties.The silent, implacable general in the fight was Philip H. (Buck) Knight, the enigmatic Oregonian who willedNikeinto existence and who is still chairman of the $3 billion public company that his brainchild has become. At the University of Oregon in the late 50's, Buck Knight -- a shy, monkish accounting student -- was a competent but unspectacular runner for Bill Bowerman, the school's legendary track coach. In late 1963, when Mr. Knight decided to go into the shoe business, Mr. Bowerman agreed to help him -- for a half-interest in Blue Ribbon Sports, the company that would becomeNike.For Mr. Bowerman, the perfect running shoe was the Holy Grail. Years before he teamed up with Mr. Knight, he had been cobbling together his own experimental versions for his top runners. But those were amateur endeavors; when he sealed theNikepartnership with a handshake, Mr. Bowerman went pro. He put Mr. Knight's shoes on the feet of his own hero athletes -- an endorsement from Olympus in the runner's world -- and he contributed to the research process. He quietly sold his cachet, his influence with young athletes, toNike.In return, he eventually became very rich.It was on just such alliances that theNikeempire was built. The Bowerman connection was perhaps more noble than some of the later cash-for-cachet dealsNikeentered into with amateur and professional athletes and coaches. And it was certainly less crass than the liaisons already forged by a few ofNike'srivals. But it was the first step in a process that ultimately came to define the company and, indeed, the entire industry.That process reached its fullest development inNike'sdealing with Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls, the electrifying athlete whose association withNikeput the term "Air Jordans" into the sports lexicon -- and burned a desire for fancy footwear into the minds of countless impoverished city youths. At the peak of the Air Jordan frenzy in 1985, the $65 shoes were being resold on the street for $100 a pair. "I can't wear them around here," one National Basketball Association executive said at the time. "I'm afraid they'd be taken away from me on the way to work by some kid with a gun."For some of the men who builtNike,this commercialization of the sports they cherished and the athletes they idealized felt like heartbreak, or like betrayal. But for most of them, it felt like a war -- against richer, more powerful European adversaries like Adidas and Puma, against Asian factories and finance companies who wanted more of the action, against the pushy agents who handled the star athletes, and even -- sadly, too often -- against one another.The book's major flaw is its failure to illuminate the man who started it all -- a shortcoming that perhaps cannot be entirely attributed to its authors, J. B. Strasser, a formerNikeemployee (whose husband, Rob Strasser, is one of the company's founding executives and now part owner of a consulting firm that works for aNikerival), and her sister, Laurie Becklund, a reporter for The Los Angeles Times. Phil Knight remains, after hundreds of pages, the same indistinct and enigmatic figure he was when the story opened. A "black hole," one of his subordinates once called him. The "masked man," pronounced another. Mr. Knight offered little cooperation with this book, its authors concede in their preface, and he emerges mostly as a mosaic of images: Buck Knight as seen by the other actors on the stage. There is little sense of what drove him, what inspired him, why he did what he did -- except for a poignant suggestion, as the story is ending, that he might, just possibly, have done it for the money.CertainlyNikemade enormous amounts of money for the people who built it. When the company went public in 1980, Mr. Knight joined the ranks of the very rich. The ruinous effect of success on an entrepreneurial company is a threadbare cliche in business, of course, but in "Swoosh" it is transformed into an exciting, intimate adventure that gives the old tale a fresh gloss.The fundamental wonder of theNikestory is that so much emotion and effort and imagination have been expended on behalf of a slab of rubber and a few scraps of nylon mesh. However, the authors of "Swoosh" are occasionally able to lift the running shoe to the level of cultural icon. At those moments,Nike'sstory begins to echo that of an entire generation -- those newborns of the baby boom who rebelled in the 60's, jogged through the 70's, memorized aerobic pulse levels in the 80's and have arrived at the 90's with tender joints and at least three pairs of athletic shoes on the floor of the closet.Odds are, at least some of those shoes areNikes.GRAPHIC:Photo: Philip (Buck) Knight in 1962, before he foundedNikeInc., breaking the tape in a pair of Adidas shoes. (Jeff Johnson/From "Swoosh")
email_title: They Just Did It

Email_Body: If Bo Jackson's sporting career is over, that would make him the last of the great baseball stars, and even he didn't exactly qualify. He was a hybrid, a baseball-football freak whose like we hadn't seen since Jim Thorpe. And it took a shoe commercial to make him really famous anyway.  Where are the great baseball stars? I mean real stars, Ruthian stars, where-have-you-gone-Joe-DiMaggio stars? Mickey Mantle, Willie Mays, Hammerin' Hank stars?  As far as I can tell, there aren't any, even though baseball, as a game, is bigger, grander, more popular than ever, or haven't you tried pricing baseball cards lately? And even though we live in an era where anyone - picture your name here - can be a celebrity.  It isn't as if the games we play aren't yielding heroes. Michael Jordan is the only man in America whose popularity rivals Stormin' Norman (take note: he drinks Diet Pepsi) Schwarzkopf. He is On-The-Air Jordan. Talk about hang time, Jordan has true staying power, from your shoes to your breakfast table to your soft drink to who knows where it will end. It doesn't stop with Jordan, either. Old people get Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer. Young people get Boris Becker and John McEnroe. Magic Johnson, Mr. Robinson. And Joe Montana, he's everywhere now. Even Mike Tyson. Greg Lemond - who rides a bicycle - gets Taco Bell. Basketball, football, boxing, cycling, golf, tennis.  Baseball, anyone?  Maybe it's the criteria we set for stardom these days. In the modern era, stardom has come to mean endorsements, commercials, TV time.Nikemade Bo; Bo didn't makeNike. Nikedid as much for Bo as Miller Lite did for Marv Throneberry. It's all an advertising game.  Let's take the case of David Robinson, who is a fine basketball player but no better than Patrick Ewing or Hakeem Olajuwon. Somebody in advertising picked out Robinson, who is bright and articulate, but the ad boys didn't trade on that, either. They made Robinson into the stereotypical 7-foot mean guy whose path you had better cross only with caution, in comic juxtaposition with the numbing calmness of Mr. Rogers. It's a media creation, and Mr.  Robinson, although he performs in a small market, is now a media star.  Why didn't somebody pick Rickey Henderson instead?  There is one easy explanation, and that's shoes. Basketball players wear shoes that people buy by the millions, pumping up the volume. People don't kick back in cleats, if only for safety reasons. The shoe industry and the National Basketball Association have fed nicely on each other in classic economic symbiosis, and they've both grown apace. And there's the crossover effect. Minute Maid is coming out with a commercial starring Isiah Thomas, Dominique Wilkins and Ewing, who are hot because basketball is hot becauseNikecommercials are hot.  But Boomer Esiason just got a Reebok commercial. Why not Don Mattingly? Why not Eric Davis? Why not Ryne Sandberg? Why not Dwight Gooden?  Nolan Ryan is getting work these days, but, gosh, is there a better story anywhere in sports? This guy is a biological phenomenon who, by any logic, ought to be a megastar - but who isn't, at least on Madison Avenue.  Even the experts are stumped. If the time is ripe for anti-heroes - McEnroe, Jim McMahon, Brian Bosworth, Charles Barkley - why not Jose Canseco, who has fame, personality and all the bad, bad boy you could ask for? Go figure.  There are actually more stars, in the old sense, in baseball than in any other sport. There are names that people who follow baseball know. But as it was explained to me, baseball, in advertising jargon, is an ''old reliable brand'' and therefore possesses limited sex appeal. And it's a regional brand.  Cal Ripken is big in Baltimore, Andre Dawson in Chicago and Michael Jordan everywhere.  But could there be more to it? Has baseball somehow become a faceless sport? Or is it that the real heroes, say Pete Rose, have shown themselves to be flawed?
email_title: ADVERTISING WORLD SNUBS THE STARS OF OLD RELIABLE - BASEBALL

Email_Body: The Atlanta Braves are a victory away from reaching the World Series tonight at Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium, but everybody is engrossed with the guy who isn't here. We're talking about Deion Sanders, whose mind is elsewhere.Maybe it's in Buckhead.Maybe it's in Miami. Maybe it's in Beavertown, Ore., whereNikemakes enough money to make Sanders do goofy things.There was Sanders's latest silliness that began Saturday night after Game 4 of the National League Championship Series in Pittsburgh. First, he took a limo to the airport. Then he caught a charter to Miami for Sunday's Falcons game against the Dolphins. Then he swam the English Channel. Then he shot deer in Alaska. Then he sauntered into the Braves' clubhouse for Sunday's Game 5 against the Pirates.Braves president Stan Kasten isn't pleased these days. After all, Kasten is o ne of the few sports executives who was forced to phone one of his players to ask that player what his plans were for the next day."The details were a little sketchy," said Kasten, hours after he dialed Sanders in his hotel room Saturday. Witnesses said the conversation between Kasten and Sanders was rather loud. Anyway, somebody asked Kasten if Sanders would do what he was rumored to do after flying to the Falcons' game and hustle back to town to continue his role as the most overpublicized bench player in baseball history."He didn't say," said Kasten, grinning, with eyebrows raised. "I'm just assuming that he's coming back."Braves general manager John Schuerholz isn't pleased with Sanders, either. Schuerholz says he wouldn't have placed Sanders on the Braves' playoff roster if he knew Sanders would renege on his agreement to stay exclusively with the Braves throughout the postseason."I'll discuss the situation after the playoffs," said Schuerholz, his words toasting Pittsburgh's chilly air. As for Braves manager Bobby Cox, when asked if Sanders's latest silliness would have been worse if Sanders weren't just another guy on the roster, "If he were a starter doing this, it would be a huge issue. Now it's just an issue."No, this is just Deion Sanders, the ego that both the Braves and the Falcons can do without. Sanders's ego is the size of Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium and the Georgia Dome. Sanders's ego is out of control. Fortunately, for Atlanta sports fans, Sanders's ego can become somebody else's problem in 1993, since neither the Braves nor the Falcons are contractually obligated to the guy after their respective seasons.The sad thing is that it has taken the ultimate of silliness from Sanders to make the Braves see what they should have seen all along, and that is Deion Sanders cares only about Deion Sanders. Well, that and his three-year, $ 3 million contract withNike. In fact,Nikeis making a commercial of Sanders's latest silliness.Nikeruns Sanders. If he plays only one sport someday,Nikesays it will cut his payroll by $ 900,000 per year.That "someday" for Sanders might come soon within these city limits, hopefully in regard to the Braves and the Falcons.Sanders stopped talking to the local media, by the way, because of your afternoon columnist. I wrote last month that Sanders was embarrassing himself by saying the Falcons were using a "plantation" mentality during negotiations that gave him a $ 2 million salary with the team this season.I wrote that Sanders should "shut up," and he did. He said he was doing so because of me.Well, I blew it. If I'd known that Sanders follows my advice, I'd have asked for a piece of hisNikecontract. I can't ask now, because Sanders told author John Feinstein in regards to why he doesn't talk to the local media, "They had the privilege, they abused the privilege, and now they've lost the privilege."Darn.
email_title: Sanders loyal only to himself,Nike

Email_Body: PENTLAND GROUP, which recently acquired Adidas, the sports goods company, is launching a $30m (Pounds 15.4m) advertising campaign, in an effort to fight off its American rivals,Nikeand Reebok. It also wants to introduce a series of top-of-the-range products. Adidas has sacked its advertising agency, Young & Rubicam, and appointed Leagas Delaney, whose clients include Porsche cars and Timberland shoes, to help protect the market-leading position of Adidas in Europe. The Nuremberg company, which used to have 50% of Germany's sports-shoe market, has seen its share slip to 40%. Adidas also plans to take on Reebok andNikein America, where it has 3% of the market.Frank Farrant, Pentland's finance director, said: ''The brand is so powerful it doesn't have a problem once we've put some momentum behind it.''Pentland, which entered a conditional agreement to buy control of Adidas two months ago, is expected to report interim profits of about Pounds 19m tomorrow, and a dividend increase.Results from the deal, which is scheduled to be completed in November, will not be included in this week's figures. In 1991, however, under the control of Bernard Tapie, Adidas made only Pounds 7.6m profit on turnover of Pounds 1.1billion.Stephen Rubin, chairman of Pentland, who netted Pounds 390m last year by selling his stake in Reebok, believes he can now resurrect Adidas with improved marketing, sourcing, distribution and product innovation. A key task is to improve margins at the company.Beefeater Gin is attacking its arch-rival Gordon's for reducing its alcohol strength from 40% to 37.5% by volume in an advertising campaign by Abbott Mead starting today.
email_title: Adidas plans $30m boost

Email_Body: Budapest, August 26, 1991 (MTI-ECONEWS) -Nike-Fiocchi,a Hungarian-Italian JV which manufactures ammunition,recently embarked on a 250-million-forint (3.33-million-USD)capacity expansion project.      The JV, which operates on the premises of NitrokemiaIndustrial Works at Balatonfuzfo, Western Hungary, was setup on January 1, 1991, with an initial capital of 662million forints (8.82 million USD).     The partners -- Nitrokemia, and Fiocchi of Lecco, Italy,share the capital 50:50.     Nike-Fiocchi manufactures ammunition mainly for huntingand sports guns, as well as for special weapons.     The company expects to put out products worth 450million forints (5.92 million USD) this year, 80 per cent ofwhich will go for export.     Main markets are Denmark, Germany, The Netherlands andCanada.     About 15 per cent of the JV's output is made up ofpyrotechnical products.     As well as manufacturing cartridges for fireworks, Nike-Fiocchi has just started a trial production run of itsown patent, a rocket used for braking hang-gliders.     A variety of cartridges for power nail-punches isanother of the company's own developments: these are usedprimarily in the building industry. The majority of theseproducts will similarly be exported, mainly to WesternEurope.     The Hungarian-Italian JV reckons that the250-million-forint development project it recentlyimplemented will be complete by 1993.     New production lines with capacities larger than thepresent equipment will be put into service via this project.     As a result of the investment, overall capacities willbe increased by 50 per cent.
email_title: Hungarian-Italian ammunition manufacturing JV - development plans

Email_Body: Barcelona - We have seen early in these Games clues to future Olympics, when athletes no longer will align themselves by nation and heritage, but rather by how they are shod. No more flags. No more anthems. Only the drumbeats of commerce.In the opening ceremonies of tomorrow, competitors will march into the stadium behind the corporate logo of their choosing. Teammates may not speak a common language, but they will be on a common payroll. Stirring medal ceremonies will consist of some 30-second spot flashed on a big screen - no doubt directed by Spike Lee - while the theme of the gold medal winner's sponsor blares over the sound system.It's honestly not that far away.Some U.S. track and field performers already have shown us how difficult it is to keep a team together on the flimsy basis of pride-in- country.Tuesday, Danny Everett of the 1,600-meter relay went to the media with complaints that his choice, Andrew Valmon, was excluded from the four-man team in favor of Michael Johnson because of shoe politics. He charged that coach Mel Rosen and Johnson were solemates - bothNikeguys - and they conspired to keep Valmon off the team because he does not have the proper insignia on his shoe. Never mind that Johnson is probably the more capable 400-meter man.You can see bad things coming for this relay team. Maybe a baton gets dropped because somebody's contract prohibits contact with another athlete from a different company.This team doesn't need training, it requires a corporate merger.Europe has broken up or recombined because of politics and age-old ethnic divisions. The United States is breaking up over footwear.The lines already have blurred concerning who is competing for whom. Track's biggest stars have been independent agents for a long time, collecting beneath the U.S. flag once every four years. The arrangement has never seemed more transparent than here.If you wanted to interview Carl Lewis at the start of the Games, that would not be arranged by the United States Olympic Committee, but rather by the athletics-wear company, Mizuno. You would be directed by helpful Mizuno employees to a cramped, steamy atrium where Lewis would meet the world's media and discuss the current state of business. Another giant in the world of overpriced sneakers, Asics, was proud to announce its news conference Wednesday with 100-meter contender Leroy Burrell. Also on hand would be company chairman Kihachico Onitsuka. Used to be, athletes appeared with their coaches. Now they tow foreign CEOs.Undisputed champion of redesigning the Olympics isNike, which is running almost daily orchestrated media events at a theater it rented in downtown Barcelona. It has claimed outright many of the most popular athletes here as its own, ignoring whatever other insignia they may bear. The only differentiation it makes between people is in size and width.Michael Jordan and Commonwealth of Independent States pole-vaulter Sergei Bubka appeared almost as teammates together on theNikestage, the conference moderated by NBC's Ahmad Rashad. Call it a seminar on hang time.Charles Barkley stopped by. Scheduled to follow were members of the Croatian basketball team. Most ambitious yet is the "NikeInternational Track and Field Team" -Nike'stitle, not mine. Consisting of such diverse members as the previously maligned Michael Johnson, Chinese hurdler Tong Li, Nigerian sprinter Mary Onyali and middle-distance runner Letitia Vriesde of Suriname, they are supposed to appear today as one big, happy, nylon-upper coalition.I like the chances of theNikeInternational Track and Field Team to do well in the medal count in these Games. TheNikemachine should be a force for Olympics to come.For all this time, idealists have dreamed about weaning the Olympics from its nationalism, the unseemly flag-waving and jingoism. That is being steadily attended to by the makers of fine leisure wear. In the near future, the worst chant you'll hear at the Olympic Stadium will go something like:"Your shoe stinks! Your shoe stinks!"
email_title: BARCELONA OLYMPICS Mercenary athletes use hard-sell on soft shoes

Email_Body: JOE BISKIC, captain of Melbourne Croatia, has been named player-of-the-year in the Herald-Sun-NikeAir Golden Boot award.The midfielder overtook the three joint leaders - John Filan, Anthony Franken and Mike Petersen - with three votes in the postponed match against Marconi in Sydney.Biskic was the only one of seven players with award-winning chances to poll votes. He said last night it had been easy to play well in a Melbourne Croatia team full of good players.He conceded the win may force him to change his retirement plans.As the Golden Boot winner, Biskic will receive $2000 cash fromNikeAir.Biskic is hopeful it will turn into a double celebration with Melbourne Croatia winning the league title.Fixture details for the first round of the NSL championhip finals series: Sunday April 14. Elimination semi (4th vs 5th): Marconi v Melita Eagles at Parramatta Stadium, 3pm. Preliminary semi (2nd v 3rd): South Melbourne v Adelaide City at Olympic Park, 3pm.Herald-SunNikeAir Golden Boot Award.Round 26. Votes. email_title: Biskic's win may result in a career extension

Email_Body: TheNike/ABCD Basketball Camp, the swoosh-stripe fashion show that doubles as a showcase for the USA's most dazzling high school boys basketball talent, concluded last week.Participants hailed it as one of the best ever. Although the camp stresses academics, featuring five hours of classwork daily, its dribbles might be numbered.A controversial piece of legislation from the National Association of Basketball Coaches is aimed at reining in summer camps. The NABC says the current system fails in several areas:- It allows third parties to exert influence over prospects in recruiting or act as middlemen between players and college coaches.- It forces coaches to crisscross the country for all of July to put in appearances watching prospects; such appearances are believed to be essential in wooing recruits.That runs at odds with cost-cutting measures the NCAA is trying to enforce.''It's an area that's totally unregulated,'' said University of Southern California coach George Raveling, chairman of the NABC Recruiting Committee.The committee recommends that the NCAA start regulating. Its suggestion: nine NCAA-sponsored regional camps.The recommendation goes before the NCAA Council July 31. If it passes, it will be forwarded to the NCAA convention in January, where university presidents will vote on it as a two-year pilot program to be implemented in summer 1993.''I think it has a real good chance of passing,'' said Rick Evrard, NCAA director of legislative services.According to the NABC plan, only high school seniors-to-be (not other underclassmen) would be invited to its camps, at a cost of $ 75, and only high school coaches would work at the camps.Most important, these would be the only camps college coaches are permitted to attend, which presumably would put talent shows likeNikein the shoebox.''I think it's ludicrous,'' saidNikecoordinator Sonny Vaccaro, the man who outfits his 120 campers in shoes, shirts and shorts - and the man whom some call the most powerful in college basketball because of his shoe deals with dozens of the game's top coaches.''I think it's blind. And the reasons aren't good enough for me to believe that what they're trying to do is for the best interests of the kids.''Raveling stressed he is merely the chairman of the NABC's Recruiting Committee, not a lone firebrand.''I'm interested in who these people are who think it's a slim chance,'' he said. ''They're certainly not the people who vote on it. ... A lot of coaches want to demonstrate to adminstrators they're on the same page.''Raveling said he has been banned from three camps for his advocacy of a new summer system.The only camp Raveling would name that he said has banned him is Dave Krider's All-American camp in Cincinnati. Krider also is sports editor for the La Porte (Ind.) Herald-Argus and picks all-USA teams for USA TODAY.Raveling said players are saying they feel pressured to attend Krider's camp in order to boost chances of being all-USA.''We don't promise kids anything,'' Krider said. ''I have never, ever told kids anything as far as my position at USA TODAY helping them in any way.''Krider's camp made its debut last year. He and partner Bobby Kortsen charged coaches $ 200 for Kortsen's scouting service - which they had to buy in order to gain access to floor seating at the University of Cincinnati's Shoemaker Center.Krider, who will charge only $ 15 this year, claims some schools spend more than $ 20,000 on recruiting, ''so how much is $ 200 really?'' Krider also alleges that at their camps, Bill Cronauer (BC Camp) and Howard Garfinkel (Five Star) have sold private information on prospects. Garfinkel could not be reached, but Cronauer denies the charge.The divisiveness among camps, Raveling said, keeps them from presenting a united front to discuss the issue with the NABC.''Everyone is pointing his finger at the other guy,'' he said. ''There's a need for regulation. You can't even get five of them in the same room to arbitrate.''Several college coaches scouting Vaccaro's camp had reservations about the new proposal.''It's mixed, I think,'' Georgetown's John Thompson said of the coaches' reaction. ''I think a lot of guys are for it because of what they perceive it to be: They perceive it to be something where the NCAA will take total supervision and there will be no influences at all.''. ... But is the NCAA capable of administering a camp? Let's stop and think about that. They can't even administer enforcement services; they don't have enough people. Where's the (camp) staff going to come from? Where's the funding going to come from?''
email_title: College basketball coaches mostly unhappy campers

Email_Body: With so many types of sports shoes in the market, how do you pick the right one? MARY ROSE GASMIER asks a man who should know.WHETHER you are a big-foot, small-foot, thin-foot or fat-foot, the point of buying sports shoes is to get a pair that fits your particular needs. And one man who should know how to go about doing this is James Spiro Davis, 49, chairman of New Balance.New Balance's American sales of US$ 95 million (S$ 153 million) last year limp far behindNike'sUS$ 1.7 billion and Reebok's US$ 1.3 billion in the same period.Nikeholds 29.8 per cent of the United States market, Reebok 22.8 per cent. New Balance trails with just 1.8 per cent. Given these figures, and as Mr Davis was on a selling mission here last week, some sales talk is perhaps understandable."We don't have the promotional budget thatNikehas but I just believe that ours is a far superior product," he says, sunk in an armchair in the lobby of the Shangri-la Hotel.To his credit, though, when asked for advice on what the Singapore consumer should look for in a pair of athletic shoes, he immediately sits up to give clear, detailed instructions, then stands up to demonstrate how to test your shoe.He suggests several factors one should bear in mind when selecting athletic shoes:<> The most important factor is correct fit: Most shoes are produced in lengths but European feet are longer and narrower, whereas Asian feet are shorter and broader. So the best-fitting shoes are those that offer the width and length appropriate to your foot. A shoe that looks good but does not fit may cause blisters.<> When shopping for a shoe, first decide what you will use it for: This is where product performance comes in.<> Shoes are designed differently for men and women because women have narrower heels, so when selecting a model, make sure that it is also the correct "gender".A shoe usually has two soles. The outer outsole is made of durable high-carbon rubbers mixed with chemicals and pigments. It is glued with a urethane-based cement onto the inner midsole.The midsole consists of ethylene-vinylacetate or high-density polyurethane which is usually thicker from the heel to mid-foot to give stability and shock-absorption for the "heel strike", the hard landing on the heel when one runs or jumps.The midsole is usually made of softer, lower-density polyurethane for the upper part of the foot, which lands more gently during exercise.If the materials are of poor quality, a shoe that appears to have a lot of spring and offers a good cushioning effect when you walk up and down in the store may, over time, lose resiliency.<> So, in buying running shoes, a "hard-heel lander" whose heel normally hits the ground very hard, should look for a running shoe with a reinforced heel -this may be an extra rubber pad that runs in a horseshoe shape round the outer edge of the shoe heel.Those who tend to run more on the balls of their feet should look for extra reinforcement in this area.Pick a shoe that offers more forward-backward stability and less torque (sideways wobble).  These are usually found in shoes which have a fairly high midsole.Shoes like this are also good for heavy people who need stable shoes that can take their weight and will not wobble with each stride. They also offer better grip for cross-country runs or rock-climbing.<> Running shoes for track and field use and for competitive sports should be lighter, with thinner midsoles and outsoles made of lower-density ethylene-vinylacetate.The lightness is important for running speed, and the heels are better designed to take the lighter weight of athletes who are generally slim-built. Such shoes should have little torque and more forward-backward stability.<> For court games like tennis or squash, choose shoes that allow easy sideways movement.  Running shoes like those described above do not fit this purpose as they are not designed for sideways jumps and leaps: The midsole is too high and there is not enough build-up of the sole around the edges.When testing the shoes in the shop, move as you would on a court to test flexibility.Knowledgeable salesmen can tell you which model offers a better grip on a wood surface, such as a squash court, and which on hard ground or artificial surfaces.<> If you engage in very strenuous activity, you should check for uppers with nylon-mesh which allow air circulation and easy evaporation of sweat. All-leather uppers will retain heat and cause discomfort.
email_title: The right fit

Email_Body: Leave it to Andre Agassi.Or perhaps, to be more accurate,Nike.First, the swashbuckling Las Vegan turns the stuffy tennis world on its ear with his tousled tie-dyed hair and stone-washed denim shorts. Not satisfied with this tradition-flaunting attire, he then - with the blessing ofNike,his clothier of record - adds Day-Glo cycling shorts and crop-topped shirts. Then, just when purists have reluctantly started to resign themselves to this godawful apparition, the born-again Agassi embraces . . . tradition.In keeping with his image as a creature of extremes, for his maiden appearance yesterday at centre court at the All England Club the clean-shaven Agassi wore (gasp) white.White warmup suit. White crop-topped shirt. White shorts with white lycra cycling shorts. White socks. White tennis shoes. White headband.A contrast was Grant Connell, Agassi's Canadian-born opponent who was also dressed byNike.He looked like a peacock - even though he conformed to Wimbledon's "predominantly white" clothing rules. That is to say, the Vancouver southpaw's shoes had jade green markings and his first shirt was splashed with blue and hot pink.At 3:45 p.m., Agassi, swathed in a white nylon warmup suit, arrived on centre court to a swell of applause from a gallery that included the Duchess of Kent.Milking the occasion for all it was worth, Agassi went over to his chair and slowly, like a stripper, began to disrobe. As he took off his pants, revealing his white look, there were wolf whistles, cheers, applause.When rain began again at 5:08 p.m., washing out play for the rest of the day with but a meager six matches completed, Agassi and Connell were level at one set each and 1-1 in games in the third. The No. 73-ranked Connell took the first 6-4 and the fifth-seeded Agassi the second 6-1.In what had to be most distracting and intimidating circumstances, Connell did himself proud. He kept his poise, served and volleyed well and moved confidently on the slippery grass. He broke Agassi in the seventh game, then conceded just three more points on his own serve en route to claiming the first set.Agassi, who had not played a grass court match since losing in the first round here in 1987, started out looking uncomfortable on the unfamiliar turf but grew increasingly comfortable and aggressive as the match progressed. By the second set, he'd harnessed his errant first serve and begun whaling his returns of serve, racking up 16 winners, and broke Connell twice to build a 5-0 lead. When Agassi is firing at that level, no one can blunt his attack.But while Agassi had the momentum when play stopped, he is vulnerable on grass. There is no evidence that his volleying has improved. He still tends to wind up and take a big swing in midcourt, rarely comes in to crowd the net, rarely opts to come in to volley off his serve. In other words, he has made few adjustments to his normal hard-hitting style to accommodate the vagaries of grass.He might beat Connell. But he's won't be a serious contender for the men's title.Connell is not throwing in the towel. Having put to rest his prematch jitters and having had some time to assess the match, he's not pessimistic that he can come back and win - weather permitting."It was a great feeling. I loved it. But he's damn good, so I have to get in my first serves and then it's down to two out of three."In other matches, top-seeded defending champion Stefan Edberg finally finished the match he started Tuesday, defeating Swiss Marc Rosset 6-4, 6-4, 6-4. Eightseeded U.S. Open champion Pete Sampras won his first Wimbledon match - 6-1, 6-2, 6-3 over Brazilian Danilo Marcelino - and sixth-seeded German Michael Stich removed American Dan Goldie 6-4, 6-1, 6-2.None of the other Canadians finished. Montreal's Martin Laurendeau is leading 6-3, 7-6 (7-4), 3-6, 2-2 in his match with Briton Danny Sapsford. Patricia Hy of Richmond Hill won the first set 6-2 against veteran South African Ros Fairbank-Nideffer.
email_title: Agasssi still quite a sight in white at Wimbledon

Email_Body: Among the great moments in athletic apparel history, 1985 will be recorded as the year that changed us forever.It was the year Cybill Shepherd showed up at the Emmy Awards wearing a black strapless gown and high-top orange Reeboks.And it was the yearNikesigned an NBA rookie named Michael Jordan to a $ 5 million, five-year endorsement contract to launch a shoe called Air Jordan. Since then, America has had a hard time deciding whether $ 80 sneakers are for show or for function. Along the way, sports apparel has become an estimated $ 21 billion-a-year industry in this country - and shoes are just the jumping-off point.As about 88,000 representatives of the nation's sporting goods industry converge on Atlanta this weekend for the Super Show, they will be looking at an industry that, if not recession-proof, is certainly in better shape than most of the economy.According to the Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association, the industry's retail sales, including equipment, hit $ 31.56 billion in 1991 - up 4.4 percent from 1990. And they're expected to accelerate again this year, climbing 5 percent to $ 33.14 billion.The industry's fiscal health, however, has little to do with the nation's physical health. According to a study by Kurt Salmon Associates, 80 percent of the sports apparel sold in this country is purchased by "non-participants": those who buy for fashion, not function.Remember the Billy Crystal/Fernando gag, "Better to look good than feel good"? America takes it to heart.Reebok understood that appeal in 1985 when it sold its aerobic shoes in 27 colors and shifted the emphasis of its advertising from performance to high fashion. But whenNike'sAir Jordan sales hit $ 107 million nine months after it was launched, sneaker chic suddenly turned hard core: Americans wanted "serious" athletic apparel first - even if they were just wearing it for fashion.Reebok's sales slumped, andNike'ssoared.Reebok has since rebounded, introducing its "Pump" line of performance sneakers, selling $ 750 million worth, for up to $ 160 a pair, in two years. Still, 70 percent of Pump sales are for "street use," according to the company. AndNikeestimates 50 percent of its Air Jordans, at up to $ 130 a pair, aren't worn for basketball.The companies have come under fire for allegedly marketing the shoes to youths who can't afford them. Some youths reportedly have been killed for the shoes.Reebok now is introducing a line of Pumps for under $ 100. And aNikespokesman says the company recognizes the problem, but denies it has aimed its ads at inner-city youth."Our target market is people who actually want to use the shoe for athletic purposes," says company spokeswoman Melinda Gable. "We don't segment our advertising. It's national in scope."The performance appeal has since, like top athletes themselves, made the transition from amateur to pro. The big boom in apparel these days is in licensed merchandise with professional team logos and colors.
email_title: SPORTING STYLE Show highlights a $ 21 billion industry

Email_Body: AUSTRALIAN runner Lisa Ondieki is close to signing a controversial sponsorship contract which will allow her to chase marathon gold at the Olympic Games in Barcelona.Ondieki is one of several athletes, including Rob de Castella and Kerry Junna-Saxby, yet to agree to a contract.She said yesterday she was likely to sign next week after changes agreed to by the Australian Olympic Committee. When Australian team members were first handed the contract, it stipulated they must support the AOC's sponsors from the time of selection until arrival back in Australia after the Games.They were also expected to endorse AOC sponsors, even if they were personally sponsored by opposition companies.The AOC this week altered the contract, making the support start when teams arrive in the Olympic village, rather than during the preparation.And no athletes will have to endorse sponsors in competition against their own.Ondieki said it was a victory for the athletes and the concessions were "worth fighting for".The 1988 Olympic silver medallist has been sponsored byNikefor 10 years while the Australian team is sponsored by adidas.Ondieki leaves for the US on Tuesday to continue her Barcelona build-up and will meetNikeofficials to discuss the contra discuss it again withNike, who have sponsored me for 10 years now," she said.Ondieki said athletes she had spoken to from other nations had not received the pressure imposed on Australians and officials here were more "bureacratic" than elsewhere.Ondieki said the contract dispute had unsettled her."It's been unpleasantness and stress that you can do without," she said."It's sad to say but it's another reason I'm glad I'm leaving Australia - so I can leave this all behind." Ondieki will be based in Phoenix, Arizona until it becomes too hot, and in May will head to Europe.She will run in the San Fransisco Bay to Breakers race, then a 10km event in Central Park, New York.Barcelona will be Ondieki's 15th marathon and she admitted the pressure would be on her."It's a strange situation going back to the Olympics again when I've won silver because it means I can only do one thing to do better, and that's win the gold," she said.The Olympic marathon course is different from anything Ondieki has tackled before, with a wicked hill at the end."It's a unique course because it's the only marathon course that increases in elevation - most race directors want a fast race so they have a decrease," she explained."I don't think it'll give anyone an advantage but it's so bad that you have to change your training to take it into account." AAPEND OF STORY
email_title: Lisa close to signing up for AOC

Email_Body: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration is missing work safety violations because it rarely reinspects targeted work sites and relies on information voluntarily supplied by employers, according to a report by the GAO.Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.47 percent this week, down from 9.50 percent last week, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. One-year adjustable rate mortgages were at an average initial rate of 7.22 percent, down from 7.23 percent last week.Nine soybean traders convicted of fraud and racketeering at the Chicago Board of Trade were sentenced to jail terms of up to three years and ordered to pay hundreds of thousands of dollars in fines and restitution. NEC, one of the world's biggest computer chipmakers, said earnings fell 36.2 percent in 1990.Greyhound Lines said its chairman and chief executive, Fred Currey, has agreed to resign. Currey would not confirm or deny whether the resignation is tied to the company's plans to emerge from bankruptcy protection this summer.Britain cut interest rates by a half percentage point in an effort to speed an economic recovery promised by the ruling Conservative Party before the next general election. It was the fifth half-point cut since February.Nikecounter sued Avia Group International, contending that the rival shoemaker is making shoes that useNike'ssole cushioning technology. In a suit last week, Avia accusedNikeof infringing on patents for its Cantilever sole -- a system that directs the shock of impact away from ankles and knees.Germany is expected to name Bundesbank Deputy President Helmut Schlesinger as successor to outgoing central bank president Karl Otto Poehl, Reuter quoted government sources as saying.Canada reports that the number of its bankruptcies has soared 77 percent in April from a year ago as a slump in consumer spending hit the retail sector.TRW named Timothy W. Hannemann general manager of the company's Space & Defense Sector. The company's Systems Integration Group, which has headquarters in Fairfax, will report to Hannemann.Polly Peck International's creditors agreed to a rescue plan that hinges on the continued operation of the company rather than the sale of its Del Monte fresh fruit and Sansui electronics operations to repay outstanding debt.Carter-Wallace withdrew its letter of intent to buy Procter & Gamble's Dramamine motion sickness brand of medication.

L.A. Gear Inc. is gearing up to introduce a line of shoes intended to catapult the company into the ranks of performance-sneaker leadership.The high-tech line, called Catapult, features an ''anti-fatigue rebound system'' designed to give the wearer added lift for jumping higher. Teaser TV ads now airing - by the BBDO Los Angeles agency - call Catapult The Machine. They urge viewers to watch the shoe's launch in an ad to run during Super Bowl XXV on Sunday.Starring in the launch ad: Karl Malone, power forward for the Utah Jazz basketball team. It ends with a slogan referring to rival shoes as hot air - a dig at sneaker giantNikeInc.'s best-selling Air line.''It's directed at certain people, obviously,'' says Sandy Saemann, exec VP of L.A. Gear. Coincidentally,Nikealso will run a Super Bowl ad to launch a shoe, -the Air 180.L.A. Gear became the USA's No. 3 sneakers firm, behindNikeand Reebok International Ltd., by marketing fashion-oriented shoes that women loved. But the market turned more performance-oriented, -leaving L.A. Gear at a disadvantage. L.A. Gear surprised Wall Street on Monday with a fourth-quarter loss from selling leftover shoes at reduced prices. The stock fell 2 7/8 Monday, then dropped 1 Tuesday to $ 9 1/2.With Catapult, L.A. Gear will have feet in both markets. ''Why can't shoe companies be both?'' Saemann says. ''Ford makes the Explorer, a slick little muscle truck for young men, and makes the Thunderbird for young women.''Catapult will make its debut in a basketball version. Scheduled to follow this year: versions for sports such as tennis, running and cross-training.
email_title: L.A. Gear aims Catapult at competitors

Email_Body: DIAMOND JUBILATION How strong have the Toronto Blue Jays been in recent years, even though the club has never gone all the way? Consider this statistic: If the period from 1983 to 1991 had been one endless nine-year season, the Blue Jays would have had an outrageous 37-game lead over the next-best team in the American League.GOOD NEWS AND BAD NEWSWhen he won the Masters, Fred Couples' earnings for the golf season reached $ 1,008,162. This made him the sixth player in PGA Tour history to get to the seven-figure mark for a year, but he did it in the shortest amount of time. On the other hand, it has to be a bit deflating for Couples to know his record surge put him just a little ahead of the average major league baseball salary.THAT'S SHOE BUSINESS Consumer Reports is out with ratings of 32 brands of running shoes and theNikeAir 180 model was ranked No. 2 for men. "Toe box was like a slipper," said one runner.There's one catch to that lofty rating, though. The report notes thatNike'sNo. 2 shoe costs nearly twice as much as the No. 1 rated shoe, Saucony Jazz 3000, and the No. 3 regarded shoe for men, Avia ARC 2040MZ.You don't supposeNikehaving all those high-priced athletes on the advertising payroll has something to do with that? A ROYAL PAIN Wiseguy of the week award goes to ESPN's Dan Patrick, who broadcast this report about the 1-16 Kansas City Royals: "The Royals have optioned second baseman Terry Shumpert to (triple-A) Omaha," he said, "and that's a promotion."Ouch.
email_title: Fun & Games

Email_Body: While Michael, 11, tried on the Air Jordans his parents had promised him for basketball camp, his 8-year-old sister, Kate, fondled the little-girl-sized Reebok Pump from the display. It's her dream shoe, but at $ 80, her parents won't go for it.   What makes it so cool?     "When you push the pump button," she explained, "it makes you, like, run faster, or it makes you, like, jump better. It helps you do aerobics. It feels like air is floating inside of your shoe."      Then, "when you don't want to run real fast or jump, you press the button" and the sneaker deflates.     How does she know all this if she has never worn a pair?     "Everybody knows about them," she said, clearly appalled that I'd had to ask. "Like, it's a popular shoe."     One more child hornswoggled by advertising, you might think: but no. Reebok's ads don't claim the Pump which pumps air into bladders in the shoe's lining to create a closer fit makes you run faster or jump higher.     Reebok's John Morgan admits right up front that it doesn't.     And he's right. Zillions, the kidversion of Consumer Reports, proved it. They heard the same run-faster, jump-higher playground myth and decided to test it out. When they outfitted their kid testers in three kinds of shoes the Reebok Pump, theNikeAir Jordan and theNikeQuantum Force they found that the kids jumped to exactly the same heights in all three models, and actually ran a little bit slower in the Pumps, which were noticeably heavier than the other two. When the testers were told they could keep the shoes they liked best, nobody chose Pumps.     According to Morgan, those results may need updating soon. Since Reebok introduced the first Pump, he says, they've streamlined its air-pump technology. The Pump they'll introduce in August, he says, weighs only 15 ounces per shoe, more than five ounces lighter than the model Zillions tested.     It still won't make you run faster or jump higher. What it does do, Morgan says, is reduce ankle injuries. He says tests at the University of California at Berkeley matched 200 kids in low-tops against 200 kids in regular high-tops and 200 kids in Pumps and found that the Pump cut ankle injuries by 60 percent.     So where did the run-faster, jump-higher rap come from? Morgan doesn't know, but it doesn't surprise him. Kids, he says, "have a tendency to build stories around shoes." For instance, a black high-top basketball shoe Reebok happened to introduce shortly after the death of University of Maryland basketball star Len Bias came to be known in the Washington, D.C., area as the Len Bias Memorial Shoe. And, on New England playgrounds, the black high-top Pump that the Boston Celtics' Dee Brown wears and that he so effectively called attention to during the NBA All Stars Slam-Dunk Contest last February by pumping and repumping before every try is known as the Deebok.- Patricia McLaughlin has written for the Philadelphia Inquirer, Washington Post and Rolling Stone magazine.
